claim: A post claims a COVID-19 vaccine has already been developed and will cause widespread infertility.
label: fake
statement: sounds lot whistleblower like study information vaccine covid
explain: Explanation: The supposed information supplied by the “whistleblower” is an almost verbatim match with an unrelated, 31-year-old paper about anti-fertility vaccine research in India.

claim: Bill Gates, who is supporting COVID-19 vaccine research, visited in New Zealand during May.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The Gates Foundation said Mr Gates has not been in New Zealand in 2020.

claim: A purported screenshot of an Australian Department of Health webpage has been shared repeatedly on Facebook alongside a claim it is evidence that COVID-19 tests “cannot distinguish covid from a cold or measles or ebola”.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The claim is misleading; Australian health authorities told AFP the image contains “selectively chosen information taken out of context”, and clarified that tests designed for SARS-CoV-2, the new coronavirus that causes the disease COVID-19, would not detect any other kinds of pathogens.

claim: A Colorado bill is “removing exemptions” for parents who don’t want to vaccinate their children in order to attend school.
label: fake
statement: nonmedical includes exemptions colorado bill vaccine
explain: Explanation: The bill adds new requirements to opt out of vaccinations, but does offer medical and nonmedical exemptions for religious or personal beliefs.

claim: Facebook posts shared thousands of times claim the coronavirus pandemic is a cover for a Gates Foundation-funded effort to implant microchips when patients’ noses or throats are swabbed during COVID-19 testing.
label: fake
statement: implant funded excuse microchips testing gates coronavirus
explain: Explanation: This is false; the pandemic is real, the foundation denied the claim, and experts say there is a medical reason for the way swabs are used when testing for the disease.

claim: A meme posted on Facebook claims South Africa’s president and ruling party politicians recently celebrated a high-profile birthday and flouted lockdown rules in the process.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: However, the images were taken in previous years.

claim: Multiple posts shared repeatedly on Facebook and Twitter claim COVID-19 means “see a sheep surrender” in Latin.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The claim is false; Latin language experts dismissed the claim as “nonsense”; the World Health Organization (WHO) states COVID-19 refers to “coronavirus disease 2019”.

claim: Multiple posts shared repeatedly on Facebook state Android users in Australia have been automatically signed up to COVIDSafe, the government’s COVID-19 contact tracing app, through an application programming interface (API) operated by Google.
label: fake
statement: signed covidsafe automatically android users app australia
explain: Explanation: The claim is false; a cybersecurity expert said the API is “not an app”, and that the use of it is optional; the Australian government said the COVIDSafe app is available for voluntary download and cannot operate without being downloaded.

claim: Aerial footage of a large procession of people has been viewed hundreds of thousands of times on Facebook alongside claims that the video shows protests in the US during the COVID-19 pandemic.
label: fake
statement: commanders iran funeral procession january military
explain: Explanation: The claim is false; the video has circulated in media reports about people in Iran attending a funeral procession for military leader Qasem Soleimani in January 2020.

claim: Dawood Ibrahim died of Covid-19.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Dawood Ibrahim did not die due to COVID-19. His brother clarified the rumours.

claim: A report drafted by a scientific panel appointed by Germany’s Interior Ministry, declaring the COVID-19 pandemic is a “global false alarm”, was leaked by a former employee.
label: fake
statement: widely unsolicited employee alarm opinion unsupported german global
explain: Explanation: The document in question was not leaked by Germany’s Interior Ministry, nor was it solicited or prepared by any unit of the Interior Ministry. The document represents the private opinion of a single ministry employee and several independent scientists who publicly disseminated it on the Ministry's letterhead without authorization. The German government does not agree with the assessments presented in this personal analysis.

claim: A Facebook post makes a series of claims about Italy “defeating” COVID-19 inclduign that it “nothing but intravascular coagulation (thrombosis)”.It also alleges that Italian doctors who performed autopsies “discovered” that COVID-19 “is not a virus” but a bacteria that causes death and the formation of blood clots.
label: fake
statement: defeat bacteria caused treatment italy covid
explain: Explanation: Based on the evidence, AAP FactCheck found the claims in the post to be false or unsupported by evidence.

claim: The image of an intubated baby with a large chest scar has been shared tens of thousands of times on Facebook, with claims that the infant had recently survived heart surgery before testing positive for the novel coronavirus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: This is misleading: the pictured baby had heart surgery in 2012 and the now seven-year-old child does not have COVID-19, his parents say.

claim: The fire incident at Rohini flyover in Delhi, India is caused by hand sanitiser.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Fire incident was not caused by hand sanitiser in the car.

claim: A video purporting to show several dead bodies lying beside coronavirus patients in a hospital ward has been viewed thousands of times in multiple posts on Facebook and Twitter alongside a claim it was filmed in the Indian capital of Delhi.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The claim is misleading; the footage in fact shows the King Edward Memorial Hospital in Mumbai; it has circulated in several reports about the hospital’s COVID-19 ward.

claim: Man seen in viral images was a COVID-19 patient who fell in love with his lady doctor. The two got engaged in the same hospital in Egypt.
label: fake
statement: pre love shoot pics wedding patient doctor
explain: Explanation: The pictures are part of a pre-wedding photo shoot. The couple has been engaged since 2018. Neither of them are infected with coronavirus.

claim: Italy “went against the WHO’s ‘law’” against COVID-19 autopsies and “discovered covid is not a virus, but a bacterium” that “clots the blood and reduces the oxygen saturation.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Studies show COVID-19 is caused by the SARS-CoV-2 virus, not bacteria. The Italian Ministry of Health still identifies the disease as caused by a virus. WHO never “outlawed” autopsies of patients with COVID-19.

claim: Says the state “health secretary says don’t go to hospitals or clinics, now the tourism secretary says don’t recreate.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Tiffany claimed that Wisconsin officials asked residents not to recreate outdoors or go to the doctor. Officials from the Department of Health Services said that they recommended telehealth visits instead of in-person appointments, to combat the spread of COVID-19. Officials from the Department of Tourism said that they want residents to enjoy the outdoors, and have provided a toolkit to help them do it safely.

claim: Facebook posts shared hundreds of times in South Africa claim that criminals posing as government officials are going around to people’s homes and distributing face masks that are laced with chemicals to knock them out and rob them.
label: fake
statement: laced chemical robbers africa using face masks evidence
explain: Explanation: However, local police -- like their counterparts elsewhere in the world -- dismissed the claim as a myth.

claim: Video shows an overcrowded Madina market in Hyderabad, India, where people are shopping for Eid.
label: fake
statement: eid flouted shopping hyderabad distancing pakistan
explain: Explanation: The viral video is not from Hyderabad but Faisalabad in Pakistan.

claim: Michigan governor reopened Traverse City “so she could have her daughter’s open house.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Easing one of her COVID-19 stay-at-home orders, Gov. Gretchen Whitmer partially reopened a large swath of northern Michigan. The governor’s office said the reopening did not coincide with any Whitmer family event in Traverse City, which is in the reopened area.

claim: Footage of a large crowd has been shared in multiple Facebook posts claiming to show migrant workers who were stopped at the Delhi-Uttar Pradesh state border during India’s nationwide COVID-19 lockdown in May 2020.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: However, the claim is false; the video has circulated online since at least October 2019 and is linked to local news reports about an Indian Army recruitment drive in Faizabad, Uttar Pradesh.

claim: A video showing hundreds of frogs being sold from the back of a truck has been viewed tens of thousands of times in multiple posts on Facebook, Twitter and YouTube alongside a claim that it was taken in China after the country lifted its coronavirus lockdown.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The claim is false; this clip actually shows frogs being sold in Thailand.

claim: Two photos have been shared thousands of times in multiple Facebook posts which claim that Kawasaki disease is spreading among babies during the coronavirus pandemic.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The claim is misleading; one of the photos has previously circulated in reports about a skin blister caused by a different disease; health authorities are still investigating cases of a Kawasaki-like condition observed in some children with COVID-19, and maintain that children remain “minimally affected” by the virus overall.

claim: Some websites claimed that Madagascar quit the World Health Organisation (WHO) and has been offered 20 million dollars by the WHO to kill their Covid-Organics cure.
label: fake
statement: quitting poison offer facts organics million madagascar covid
explain: Explanation: Madagascar has neither quit the WHO nor has WHO offered it 20 million dollars to kill the country’s herbal drink, Covid-Organics. This was confirmed by the WHO country offices in Madagascar and in Ghana. Also, the France 24 interview purported to be the source of both claims reveals no such information.

claim: Ohio Gov. Mike DeWine released 4,300 prisoners and is now warning residents of a possible crime wave.
label: fake
statement: priso ohio dewine gov release mike
explain: Explanation: Ohio Gov. Mike DeWine has not released 4,300 prisoners due to COVID-19 and there’s no evidence that he warned residents of a possible crime wave. Ohio has released 129 inmates early due to COVID-19, according to DeWine’s staff.

claim: Multiple Facebook and Twitter posts shared thousands of times in May 2020 claim anyone in New Zealand who refuses to use a coronavirus contact tracing app has been banned from entering shops during the COVID-19 pandemic.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The claim is misleading; as of May 27, the app named in the posts is not a contact tracing app and is not being used by New Zealand's government as part of its coronavirus strategy; to date, the government's only coronavirus contact tracing app is voluntary for businesses and the public; shops in New Zealand are also not required to record consumer information for contact tracing purposes.

claim: Claim that Dr. Fauci said every American should be microchipped.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: There is no evidence that Dr. Anthony Fauci has said every American should be "microchipped." Fauci has suggested Americans might someday carry certificates of immunity to COVID-19. Similar claims that Democrats and others are pushing microchips to fight the coronavirus have been debunked.

claim: A photo of a Pakistani provincial chief minister has been shared thousands of times in multiple Facebook posts in May 2020 alongside a claim that it shows him violating social distancing rules during the coronavirus pandemic.
label: fake
statement: provincial procession religious pakistani chief minister
explain: Explanation: The claim is false; the photo was taken in 2018 during a procession on Ashura, a Muslim holy day.

claim: Candace Owens claimed that the U.S. is not losing “tons more lives” in 2020 compared to 2019 and that the “increase [in mortality in 2020 is] virtually non-existent”.
label: fake
statement: noticeably compared previous mortality months increased
explain: Explanation: A comparison of the number of deaths from all causes in the U.S. during the first 17 weeks of 2020 reveals a higher mortality than for the same period in any of the previous five years. While the death count was comparable to previous years in the first two months of 2020, it increased rapidly in March and April. Comparisons of mortality are highly sensitive to how the data are gathered and presented, therefore any claims based on the data must always be presented in the appropriate context.

claim: A video of Italian politician Sara Cunial blasting Bill Gates as a “vaccine criminal” in speeches to parliament has been viewed tens of thousands of times on Facebook and YouTube.
label: fake
statement: speeches parliament politician spreads italian gates bill
explain: Explanation: Her statements are riddled with misinformation. AFP Fact Check debunks some of the claims.

claim: Indian Government has introduced a five-phase roadmap to combat Covid-19.
label: fake
statement: introduced phase roadmap combat lockdown covid
explain: Explanation: No, the Indian Government has not introduced a five-phase roadmap to combat COVID-19.

claim: The Irish government is giving €350 to every resident in the country as part of its response to COVID-19.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The Irish government is not giving €350 to everyone in the country. The Department of Finance said the messages circulating about this are a scam.

claim: President Donald Trump implemented “a travel ban that just didn’t work, 400,000 people got in from those countries that were subject to the restrictions.”
label: fake
statement: tru sen murphy overstates chris travel china
explain: Explanation: Sen. Chris Murphy overstates travel from China after Trump restrictions. The number of people that flew directly in from China after Trump’s travel restrictions went into effect was reported in April to be around 40,000, not 400,000. Those travelers were American citizens and other authorized travelers who were exempted from the restrictions. That number is now higher, according to new U.S. Customs and Border Patrol data of both direct and indirect flights from China through mid May.

claim: Barack Obama “is the first ex-president to ever speak against his successor.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Obama isn't the first ex-president to speak ill of his successor. Barack Obama called the Trump administration’s response to COVID-19 “an absolute chaotic disaster.” A Twitter post, retweeted by Trump, claims that Obama is the first ex-president to speak ill of his successor. From Hoover to Truman, Ford to Carter and beyond, ex-presidents have criticized the person who followed them into office.

claim: Ghanaian President Nana Akufo-Addo claimed in a speech that his country had administered more COVID-19 tests per million people than any other country in Africa.
label: fake
statement: fronts africas leader country testing covid
explain: Explanation: AFP has found from available statistics that Ghana comes behind South Africa and at least two other African countries.

claim: Prolonged use of mask causes hypoxia, oxygen deficiency, fatigue and loss of reflexes.
label: fake
statement: deficiency oxygen fatigue prolonged cause masks
explain: Explanation: Prolonged use of masks is safe provided it is clean and of appropriate size. They should not be worn too tightly.

claim: Photo representing the suffering of a migrant worker during the current lockdown in India.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: While it is true that the migrant workers are facing a lot of problems due to the current lockdown in the country, the photo is not related to India. The photo is an old one. It shows a Rohingya man walking into Bangladesh.

claim: Photo representing the suffering of a migrant worker during the current lockdown in India.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: While it is true that the migrant workers are facing a lot of problems due to the current lockdown in the country, the photo is not related to India. The photo is an old one. It shows Rohingya man walking into Bangladesh.

claim: “The mainstream media pretended there was a deadly surge in COVID cases thanks to Wisconsinites voting.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: No, the media did not “pretend there was a deadly surge inCOVID-19cases” after Wisconsin election. This news broadcast gave no evidence of its claim about errant mainstream media reporting. Our review of state and national articles about the election found no references to a “surge” or anything close to that. Reports accurately listed the number of cases potentially related to the election and the caveat that we can’t know the origin of those cases for sure. The conspiracy implied by the use of “pretended” makes this even more ridiculous, since there isn’t proof any reporting was wrong in the first place.

claim: Three videos have been viewed tens of thousands of times in multiple posts on Facebook alongside a claim they show people who died after contracting the novel coronavirus in India.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The claim is false; the videos show the victims of a major gas leak at a chemical plant in India in May 2020.

claim: A video has been viewed more than 100,000 times in multiple Facebook posts that claim to show a 5G mast burning in the Italian city of La Spezia.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The claim is misleading; the video in fact shows a transmission tower in La Spezia with only 3G and 4G antenna; as of May 13, 2020, 5G has not been rolled out in the northwestern Italian city.

claim: Multiple Facebook, Twitter and Instagram posts shared hundreds of times claim that wearing a face mask for an extended period of time could cause hypercapnia, a condition caused by a buildup of carbon dioxide in the blood.
label: fake
statement: hypercapnia myth prolonged cause face masks
explain: Explanation: The claim is misleading; health experts in Thailand have said that as of May 2020, there is no evidence that wearing a mask for a long period can cause hypercapnia.

claim: “Since the reopening of (the state of Georgia), we’ve seen our COVID rate skyrocket by 40%.”
label: fake
statement: stacey georgias abrams tre gets reopening covid
explain: Explanation: Stacey Abrams said after reopening, Georgia’s COVID-19 rate went up 40%. In fact, the number of cases fell 12% compared with the same period before reopening. It will take more time before the impact of reopening shows up in the data.

claim: “States like New York, Illinois and California have been vocal in their demands for funding to bail out their pension systems, which were failing long before the COVID-19 outbreak, and other programs that aren’t related to this crisis.”
label: fake
statement: need bailou pension fund federal york
explain: Explanation: New York's pension system is one of the best-funded in the nation and has not asked for federal funds. Illinois' pension fund is one of the worst-funded in the nation, while California is about average. Economic shutdowns related to the pandemic have severely diminished tax revenues, which pay for many state services.

claim: “For the World Health Organization, the international entity whose sole responsibility it is to alert the world of global pandemics like this, to miss this, is a huge problem.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: A Jan. 14 tweet saying that Chinese authorities found no clear evidence of human-to-human transmission of the coronavirus led a Pennsylvania congressman to accuse the World Health Organization of failing to alert people about the pandemic. Later in January, the WHO announced that in fact there was evidence of human-to-human transmission of the coronavirus and declared the outbreak a “public health emergency of international concern. Experts say the WHO was slow to designate the coronavirus a pandemic and that the organization should have been more skeptical of information it received from China before it sent that tweet but that accusing the WHO of missing the pandemic altogether goes too far.

claim: Central Park hospital tents housed thousands of abused children released from underground captivity.
label: fake
statement: field pa central park treated coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The field hospitals set up in tents in New York’s Central Park were treating coronavirus patients from the Mount Sinai Health System. There is no evidence that children are being held in, or released from, underground captivity in New York. This conspiracy has been researched and debunked by other news outlets.

claim: A photo of a Pakistani chief minister has been shared thousands of times on Facebook alongside a claim it shows him flouting Pakistan’s coronavirus lockdown measures at iftar, a daily evening meal enjoyed by Muslims during the holy month of Ramadan.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The claim is false; the photo in fact shows Chief Minister Murad Ali Shah at iftar in 2018.

claim: Wearing face masks can cause carbon dioxide toxicity; can weaken immune system.
label: fake
statement: immune system affect hypercapnia wearing cause face masks
explain: Explanation: Face masks help to limit contact with infectious droplets which carry pathogens. However, the material used for face masks are still porous enough to allow gas molecules, such as carbon dioxide and oxygen, to pass through, and do not significantly impair gas exchange to the point of causing hypercapnia. No scientific evidence supports the claim that the use of face masks weakens the immune system.

claim: A video of a street parade has been viewed tens of thousands of times in multiple posts on Facebook, Instagram, TikTok and YouTube alongside a claim it shows people celebrating the end of a coronavirus lockdown in Saudi Arabia.
label: fake
statement: eased measures street dubai authorities lockdown coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The video was filmed in Dubai; the footage corresponds with media reports about residents celebrating on the streets after Dubai authorities eased 24-hour quarantine measures in two districts.

claim: A photo of hundreds of people praying together has been shared hundreds of times on Facebook and Twitter alongside a claim that it shows Muslims in south India flouting the nation’s COVID-19 lockdown to offer night-time prayers.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The claim is false; the photo was published by a photography agency in 2018 and shows Muslims in north India praying at night during the holy month of Ramadan.

claim: COVID-19 has infected more meatpackers in the U.S. than health care workers.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: More than 9,200 health care workers have been infected by COVID-19, comparied to 4,900 meatpacking workers.

claim: Ghanian ex-president, John Mahama said that Togo, Rwanda and Ivory Coast did not request financial assistance for COVID-19 from the IMF.
label: fake
statement: togo mahamas counter john rwanda divoire cote facts
explain: Explanation: The IMF is providing financial assistance to countries to help address the economic impact of COVID-19. The countries mentioned by John Mahama, Togo, Cote d’Ivoire and Rwanda, have all applied to and have been given financial assistance from the Fund.

claim: A series of claims, including that the COVID-19 pandemic was “fake” and 5G telecommunications is causing the illness.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: AAP FactCheck found the claims of the post to be false. COVID-19 is not “fake” but is a highly infectious viral disease caused by a newly discovered coronavirus. Claims of a link between COVID-19 and 5G telecommunications ignore expert medical research and advice, and the fact that COVID-19 is present in many nations without 5G networks. The claim that the vaccine for COVID-19 contains an RFID chip is a fabrication as a vaccine does not exist.

claim: “93% of the (COVID-19) cases in the state of Illinois have come from Chicago.”
label: fake
statement: lahood chicagos overstates illinois share covid
explain: Explanation: Arguing his region of the state should be allowed to start reopening, the congressman said Chicago accounts for nearly all cases of the novel coronavirus in Illinois. But state public health data show the city makes up less than half of the state’s total.

claim: Pennsylvania’s governor breaking his own social distancing rules in a photo.
label: fake
statement: follow failing pennsylvania protection governor rules
explain: Explanation: The photo is old and was taken before the governor issued a stay-at-home order for Pennsylvania.

claim: The CARES Act was introduced in January 2019, which proves the COVID-19 pandemic was planned in advance.
label: fake
statement: legislative cares history prove act covid
explain: Explanation: The CARES Act was introduced March 25 as a substitute amendment, replacing the title and language of an older, unrelated bill.

claim: The post contains a COVID-19 conspiracy theory written by former South Carolina Rep. Trey Gowdy.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: There is no record of Gowdy writing the essay. He confirmed to the Daily Caller that he did not author it.

claim: The photo shows bedding and food aid packages distributed in Rwanda during the coronavirus pandemic
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The photo predates the coronavirus pandemic by roughly half a year and appears to have been taken in Gambia.

claim: People should ignore guidelines to wear masks, especially since the government doesn’t advise mask wearing for tuberulosis.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: COVID-19 is far more prevalent and deadly than tuberculosis in the United States.

claim: Former Rep. Trey Gowdy wrote essay past on social media claiming the COVID-19 pandemic was planned to help Democrats in the 2020 election.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Rep. Trey Gowdy confirmed that he did not write the post in question.

claim: An article circulating on Facebook claims that Microsoft co-founder Bill Gates said a COVID-19 vaccine could kill almost one million people, citing an interview he gave.
label: fake
statement: nearly could million kill gates bill vaccine covid
explain: Explanation: This is false; Gates was talking about vaccine safety and the potential for side effects, and gave a hypothetical figure to illustrate the number of people who could possibly be affected by them worldwide.

claim: “Bill Gates admits his COVID-19 vaccine might kill nearly 1 million people.”
label: fake
statement: could kill gates bill vaccine covid
explain: Explanation: The Gates Foundation is trying to develop a coronavirus vaccine. Gates spoke theoretically about how many people might suffer side effects from a vaccine, not about how many might die from it.

claim: Georgia Gov. Brian Kemp “mandates restaurants reopen”.
label: fake
statement: worries restaurant geo owners real saying
explain: Explanation: Worries for restaurant owners are real, but post saying Georgia Gov. mandated reopening goes too far. Georgia Gov. Brian Kemp’s order said that restaurants can reopen if they follow 39 rules, including that employees wear face masks. Many Atlanta-area restaurants have chosen not to reopen their dining rooms due to concerns about health and safety. Many restaurants have sued their insurers after being denied business interruption insurance claims.

claim: Dr. Elisa Granato, one of the first volunteers to receive a potential COVID-19 vaccine in the U.K., has died.
label: fake
statement: vacccine granato elisa volunteer trial died coronavirus
explain: Explanation: Granato has not died. The U.K. Department of Health and Social Care debunked the claim on Twitter, and so did Granato.

claim: Harvard professor Charles Lieber was arrested for manufacturing and selling the new coronavirus to China
label: fake
statement: creating lieber harvard professor charles arrested china coronavirus
explain: Explanation: Professor Charles Lieber was arrested for making false statements to federal authorities and concealing his connections to China, not for creating the coronavirus. The new coronavirus is not man-made or a biological weapon

claim: French health care workers are putting on defective Chinese-made protective gowns.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Public Assistance – Hospitals of Marseille, which operates the hospital where the video was filmed, has said the gowns were damaged in storage and were not made in China.

claim: Young people “have a greater chance of being killed by the HPV vaccine than COVID-19.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: No deaths have ever been linked to the HPV vaccine. While young people are less at risk of dying of COVID-19 than older adults, some younger people have died from the virus.

claim: Thousands of doctors say hydroxychloroquine cures coronavirus.
label: fake
statement: underway immediately hydrochloroquine injected held drugs studies back
explain: Explanation: DA has warned against use of hydroxychloroquine with COVID-19 patients because of severe risks, including death. And second, Fauci did not say a "vaccine" would be rushed without proper study.

claim: “Children don’t seem to be getting this virus.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Children do contract the coronavirus. Hundreds of cases in people 17 and under have been reported in Wisconsin, and tens of thousands in the U.S. But early evidence shows that children are not at higher risk for the virus, and in most cases, experience milder symptoms than adults.

claim: Says if you’re refused service at a store for not wearing a mask “call the department of health and report the store. Masks are suggested, not required.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Post falsely claims people should report Pennsylvania stores that refuse to serve maskless customers. Essential businesses in many states require that all employees and customers wear masks while inside the store. They must do so by law. The Pennsylvania Health Department, whose number was included in the post, said that businesses that are not following guidance regarding wearing a mask are what should be reported.

claim: A Facebook page posted a picture of the Nigerian President Muhammadu Buhari with the caption “Buhari was in and also watched his live broadcast to the nation on Monday 27th April 2020”.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: We surmise this was satirical; notwithstanding, it is misleading. A reverse image search attributes the photo in question to at least two posts in 2017, making the argument pointless.

claim: Hospitals in the United States get paid $750 for patients who die from the flu, $17,500 for COVID-19.
label: fake
statement: paid deat amounts set arent hospitals
explain: Explanation: No, there aren’t set amounts hospitals are paid for deaths from flu vs COVID-19. Amounts paid to hospitals can vary based on the payer; private insurers typically pay much more than Medicare. Medicare pays hospitals based primarily on the diagnosis, and the amount is not affected by whether a patient dies. The $17,500 corresponds to an average of what Medicare might pay for one type of COVID-19 patient. Experts said no hospitalization would generate a payment as low as $750.

claim: “If you have had a flu shot in the last 3-5 years, you will probably test positive” for COVID-19.
label: fake
statement: shots causing arent te flu positive covid
explain: Explanation: Medical experts say the flu vaccine isn’t causing false positives for people who take COVID-19 tests.

claim: Pune-based doctor Megha Vyas died of COVID-19 while treating patients infected with coronavirus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The woman in the viral photo is Megha Sharma who died due to pneumonia and not coronavirus. She was not a doctor.

claim: Tasuku Honjo, Japan’s Nobel prize-winning immunologist, says that the coronavirus is not natural, did not come from bats, and was manufactured by China.
label: fake
statement: unnatural japans laureate honjo nobel china coronavirus
explain: Explanation: No reputable news sources have reported what would be a controversial quote from a Nobel prize-winning scientist. On 27 April Honjo, through Kyoto University, released an official statement refuting the claim. He also warned against sharing unproven claims about the virus.

claim: Madagascar’s artemisia-based tonic cures COVID-19. Artemisia is widely used in traditional medicines, and is known as lengana in Setswana and Sesotho and umhlonyane in isiZulu.
label: fake
statement: madagascars tonic artemisia based cures evidence covid
explain: Explanation: On 22 April, Madagascar’s president Andry Rajoelina launched an artemisia-based herbal drink claimed to prevent and cure COVID-19. But the National Academy of Medicine of Madagascar has said its effectiveness in preventing and treating COVID-19 has not been adequately tested. The tonic was tested on fewer than 20 patients and data from the study has not been made available. The World Health Organization says there are currently no vaccines or medicines to prevent, treat or cure COVID-19.

claim: A volunteer for Oxford coronavirus vaccine died.
label: fake
statement: oxford volunteer uk trial died vaccine coronavirus
explain: Explanation: Department of Health and Social Care and the woman in the article denied the claim.

claim: First volunteer in UK coronavirus vaccine trial has died.
label: fake
statement: volunteer hasnt uk trial vaccine covid
explain: Explanation: Elisa Granato, the first volunteer to be injected in a COVID-19 vaccine trial in Europe, is “100% alive.”

claim: A video of young adults singing the Indian national anthem has been shared on Facebook and Twitter during the COVID-19 pandemic alongside claims that it shows American students performing to thank India for supplying the US with hydroxychloroquine, a malaria drug that has been involved in clinical trials for potential COVID-19 treatment.
label: fake
statement: rendition produced independence st mark august indias anthem
explain: Explanation: The claim is false; this rendition of the Indian national anthem was produced in August 2017 to mark India’s 71st Independence Day.

claim: Graphics shared thousands of times on social media claim to show the exact probability of COVID-19 carriers spreading the disease if they or another person wears a mask.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The claim is misleading; experts say that while masks do decrease the risk, there is no reliable information on the specific chance of transmission.

claim: A photo has been shared hundreds of times in multiple Facebook posts that claim it shows bodies of elderly coronavirus patients who were euthanised by their governments as a “practical” response to the pandemic.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The claim is false; the photo actually shows bodies of victims in a hajj stampede in 2015; the claim about governments euthanising COVID-19 patients is an old hoax previously debunked by AFP.

claim: “Half the workforce in the country may have just been idled” by coronavirus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: No, half of the U.S. workforce has not been 'idled.' U.S. Rep. Dan Bishop (R-NC) cited a New York Times graphic showing that the 26 million people who filed for unemployment equalled the total workforce of a combined 25 states. The total U.S. workforce is about 160 million people, so 26 million is not half of that. The economy can also be measured by trends in the U.S. Gross Domestic Product. But experts said they don't expect GDP to fall 50%.

claim: Multiple Facebook posts shared hundreds of times claim doctors from the National Taiwan University Hospital (NTUH) in Taipei have found that COVID-19, the disease caused by the novel coronavirus, is a combination of AIDS and SARS.
label: fake
statement: taiwanese combination aids discovered sars doctors covid
explain: Explanation: The claim is false; according to a spokesperson from the hospital, the statement was not authored by its doctors; as of May 20, 2020, advisories from global health organisations have not characterised COVID-19 as a disease that is AIDS and SARS combined.

claim: If you paid rent in March or April in the United States, “they got to give” you your money back.
label: fake
statement: requires rent mortgag law theres covid
explain: Explanation: A bill has been introduced in the House that would require rent and mortgage payment refunds, as well as forgiveness on future payments, while COVID-19 remains a national emergency. But no action has yet been taken on the bill.

claim: A video has been viewed more than 100,000 times in multiple posts on YouTube, Facebook and Twitter in which a purported Philippine doctor claims ingesting semen could cure a patient infected with the novel coronavirus, citing a 2016 scientific study.
label: fake
statement: ingesting semen ridiculous purported dismiss could doctors experts
explain: Explanation: The claim is false; the authors of the 2016 study told AFP the claim was "ridiculous" and their findings have “nothing to do with COVID-19”; as of May 2020, the World Health Organization (WHO) has said there is no cure for COVID-19.

claim: Posts shared hundreds of times on WhatsApp and Facebook claim that hair salons are responsible for almost 50 percent of all coronavirus deaths.
label: fake
statement: salon almost best visit half hair proof caused
explain: Explanation: There is no evidence to support the claim, which has been ascribed to a non-existent US health chief.

claim: “New autopsy reports suggest Jeffrey Epstein most likely died from COVID-19 complications.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: There are no new autopsy reports tying Jeffrey Epstein’s death to COVID-19.

claim: Video showing dead bodies of COVID-19 infected persons washed ashore as they were thrown in the seas by some countries.
label: fake
statement: wreck boat african bodies migrants died covid
explain: Explanation: The video is five years old. It shows dead bodies of African migrants washing ashore as the boat they were travelling in sank off the Libyan coast on its way to Europe.

claim: A post has been shared repeatedly on Facebook by Sri Lankan Facebook users that claims 1,290 people died from coronavirus in the Chinese city of Wuhan after the city’s lockdown was lifted on April 8, 2020. The posts claim that Sri Lanka should avoid lifting its own lockdown restrictions due to an upcoming election in order to avoid a similar spike in deaths.
label: fake
statement: wuhans eased toll death lockdown coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The claim is misleading; Chinese officials added 1,290 fatalities to Wuhan's coronavirus death toll after the city lifted restrictions on April 8, but said these were COVID-19 cases that were missed during the earlier lockdown.

claim: A video of a man rebuking foreigners has been viewed thousands of times on social media alongside a claim that the Guinean government has ordered the arrest of all Chinese nationals in the country while awaiting the safe return of Guineans from China.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: However, the video was actually recorded last year before the pandemic, and the Guinean government has not issued any such order.

claim: Posts on social media claim that people who have been vaccinated against the flu in the last 10 years will test positive for COVID-19.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: This is false; experts say the novel coronavirus that causes the disease is unrelated to the flu, and that data on approved COVID-19 tests does not support the claim.

claim: Bill Gates, the WHO and the World Bank lost billions to Trump amid the coronavirus outbreak.
label: fake
statement: trumped bank trump gates bill coronavirus
explain: Explanation: This article is fraught with inaccuracies about financials related to the coronavirus, which can all be disproven.

claim: Due to COVID-19 outbreak, UPSC has cancelled examinations in India.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: No such decision has been taken by UPSC. UPSC conducts various examinations. It did not cancel any examination. Details regarding each examination can be seen in the press release issued by UPSC on 15 April 2020.

claim: Photo of Pakistani people holding a banner with the text – ‘We don’t want Kashmir. Give us Hydroxychloroquine’ asking India to help them handle the COVID-19
label: fake
statement: banner kashmir edited holding hydroxychloroquine pakistan
explain: Explanation: The posted image is an edited one. In the original picture, the banner has the following text - 'We want Azadi'. It is an old photo and the photo was taken in Kashmir.

claim: Bill Gates free to prescribe drugs while the late herbalist, “Dr. Sebi,” was not allowed to heal people with herbs.
label: fake
statement: prescribe practicing sebi barred states medicine gates bill
explain: Explanation: Bill Gates cannot prescribe any medication because he is not a medial doctor, thought doctor's hired by his foundation can since they have an MD.

claim: A video shared more than 10,000 times on Facebook features a freediving champion who claims that masks don’t offer protection from the novel coronavirus and that the moisture created by breathing into a mask actually offers a fertile environment for the virus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Experts told AFP that the video makes several misleading assumptions.

claim: Thieves are handing out chemically doused face masks to knock people out before robbing them.
label: fake
statement: masked doused thieves rob chemicals face
explain: Explanation: No news reporting about such robberies could be found. The same post has been shared in several different countries without specific details about the alleged robberies.

claim: Valley County, Montana, mandated pink arm bands for residents who had submitted to quarantine protocol.
label: fake
statement: valley revise pink montana mandate flier confusing bands
explain: Explanation: The armbands were not government issued and actually came from an initiative to give out-of-county contractors a signal to show thye were not spreading the virus.

claim: A photo has been shared in multiple posts on Facebook and Twitter alongside a claim it shows labourers stranded in the western Indian state of Gujarat during a nationwide COVID-19 lockdown.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The claim is false; this photo has circulated online since November 2019, months before India imposed its lockdown; it has circulated in reports about Bangladeshi migrants at an immigration office in Malaysia.

claim: COVID-19 is sparing essential workers.
label: fake
statement: dying aged essential many risk plus covid
explain: Explanation: The post offers no evidence, and records indicate many essential workers -- from doctors to transportation workers -- have died from the coronavirus.

claim: Image ofa map of India redesigned by an American CEO praising the Government of India for its effective handling of the COVID-19 crisis.
label: fake
statement: redesigned handling ceo indias map american effective crisis
explain: Explanation: The image with the same map of India was found to be existing on the internet atleast since 2016. American CEO has designed it to show India's effective halndling of COVID-19 crisis.

claim: An article shared more than 14,000 times on Facebook claims the Nigerian government gave N20,000 ($52) to “everyone” across the country’s 36 states.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: This is false; the article in question shares a true story but uses an unrelated and misleading headline. Nigeria has a social investment programme to help the poor and handed out cash and food during the lockdown, but not to all citizens.

claim: Dr. Anthony Fauci “was telling people on February 29th that there was nothing to worry about and it posed no threat to the US public at large.”
label: fake
statement: februar late faucis amplified misleads tweet trump
explain: Explanation: On Feb. 29, Fauci said rules Americans would come to know as social distancing were not yet warranted. However, just about every other sentence of his remarks was filled with caveats indicating that the situation could change. He did not suggest that there was “nothing to worry about” or that the virus “posed no threat to the public.”

claim: A video has been viewed thousands of times in multiple posts on Facebook and Twitter alongside a claim that it shows Pakistani security forces apprehending three men after they escaped from a COVID-19 quarantine centre.
label: fake
statement: training forces conducting security pakistani drill
explain: Explanation: The footage has circulated in reports about a joint training exercise by Pakistani security forces and police outside a COVID-19 quarantine facility.

claim: Michigan COVID-19 order bans gardening and the sale of vegetable seeds and fruit.
label: fake
statement: gardening seeds ban order sale covid
explain: Explanation: An executive order by Michigan Gov. Gretchen Whitmer does not prohibit gardening or the sale of any particular product. Stores in Michigan larger than 50,000 square feet must close areas that sell carpet or flooring, furniture and paint, as well as garden centers and plant nurseries.

claim: you have to pay back your stimulus check
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The posts misread the law. Even if someone receives a bigger stimulus payment in 2020 than their next tax return says they should have received, they will not owe back the difference, much less the entire amount.

claim: Says American NIAID director Dr. Anthony Fauci “stands to lose 100 million dollars on Bill Gates ‘vaccine’ for the coronavirus. Because he invested in this vaccine.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: There is no evidence that Dr. Anthony Fauci is personally financially invested in a coronavirus vaccine.

claim: 15 major global pandemics all originated in China.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: LeadStories team found that at least seven of the 15 listed pandemics originated outside of China.

claim: President Donald Trump referred to the coronavirus as a “hoax” or “political conspiracy.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: These comments were taken out of context. Instead, the president was referring to what he believed were Democratic efforts to politicize the coronavirus.

claim: Pentagon confirms coronavirus accidentally got into chemtrail supply chain.
label: fake
statement: pentagon chemtrail supply got confirm accidentally chain coronavirus
explain: Explanation: This came from a clear satire website, and the Pentagon has made no statements claiming this.

claim: A post shared on Facebook and WhatsApp claims that China has sent COVID-19 vaccines to Burundi.
label: fake
statement: consisted donation supplies general chinese covid
explain: Explanation: The claim is false; China did donate medical supplies to the eastern African nation, but not vaccines, which do not exist yet for the disease.

claim: Democrats are pushing for an implanted microchip in humans
label: fake
explain: Explanation: There’s no evidence that implanted microchips are being contemplated in a serious way to fight the coronavirus. Democrats are not “pushing” for mandatory vaccinations, because state government already has the power to compel vaccination.

claim: A graphic purporting to detail health risks due to 5G-induced radiation has been published on various websites and shared hundreds of times on Facebook and Twitter. The image was shared as other hoaxes circulated claiming that COVID-19 is linked to the global rollout of 5G networks.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: radiation experts and health authorities maintain there is no evidence to suggest that the radiation emitted from 5G is harmful to human health.

claim: A graphic video has been viewed tens of thousands of times in multiple posts on Facebook and Twitter alongside a claim it shows two Islamist extremists killing a Hindu man in the Indian state of Rajasthan during India’s COVID-19 lockdown.
label: fake
statement: sectarian axe footage attack pakistan lockdown covid
explain: Explanation: The claim is false; police in Pakistan and several media outlets report that the attack took place in Pakistan’s Punjab province in March 2020; people can be heard speaking in Punjabi in the video.

claim: News stories and social media posts in China claimed research on virus mutations proves the origin of COVID-19 is the United States. They say a strain found in Washington State, which was later removed from an international database, has unusually high number of mutations and it is the oldest among all strains.
label: fake
statement: narratives mutations investigation origin virus covid
explain: Explanation: The abnormally high frequncy of mutations found in a strain from Washington State was simply a sequencing mistake in the study process. That is why it was removed from the database. Moreover, the initial versions of the virus would have relatively fewer mutations as opposed to the claim. Science tells us that strains from China are the “root” as they have the least number of mutations.

claim: A YouTube video shared thousands of times claims that two children died from a novel coronavirus vaccine in Guinea.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The claim is false; the video misrepresents a news report on children who fell ill in March 2019 after taking anti-parasite drugs. There is currently no vaccine for COVID-19.

claim: An article says that Britain has “pulled out” of a 5G contract with Chinese company Huawei because test kits were found to be contaminated with coronavirus.
label: fake
statement: contract components pulling huawei produce uk covid
explain: Explanation: There were some delays in testing kits being delivered to laboratories in the UK, because of contamination, but these were from a Luxembourg-based company called Eurofin, not Huawei. None of the kits were delivered or used in the UK. Telecoms firm Huawei does not produce coronavirus test kits. The UK is going ahead with the development of 5G infrastructure.

claim: A video claims to show that the Nigerian government has spent US$2 million to “import” Chinese doctors and supplies.
label: fake
statement: nigerias supplies govt pay sent experts china covid
explain: Explanation: The medical supplies and team of experts from China deployed to Nigeria have cost $2 million, but the costs were paid by the Chinese government, not by Nigeria.

claim: U.S. Speaker of the House Nancy Pelosi said she won’t pass new economic stimulus package unless senior citizens are excluded.
label: fake
statement: unless seniors excluded pass nancy pelosi stimulus
explain: Explanation: This is an article posted by a clearly marked satire website. And it is the U.S. Senate that is holding up the passage of the stimulus package, not the House of Representatives.

claim: COVID-19 mass vaccine in Senegal that began in West Africa killed the first seven children who received it.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Senegal's health ministry confirmed the falsity of the rumor, and an Agence France-Presse also did a story confirming the claim is not true.

claim: Top German virologist Jürgen Rissland recommended drinking whiskey to combat COVID-19.
label: fake
statement: whiskey recommends top german protect doctor covid
explain: Explanation: In the same video by Dr. Rissland, he says later that drinking too much alcohol could potentially harm the virus, though it's no panacea and would cause severe damage to other body systems.

claim: CDC admitted to lying about COVID-19 death stats.
label: fake
statement: confess numbers lying cdc death covid
explain: Explanation: CDC has not confessed to lying about any numbers.

claim: A photo of a woman lying in a hospital bed with medical equipment attached to her body has been shared hundreds of times on Facebook and Twitter alongside claims that the woman was a doctor who died after being beaten by a Muslim mob while trying to administer novel coronavirus tests.
label: fake
statement: result late pharmacists local husband authorities said death
explain: Explanation: The claim is false; the late woman's husband and local police told AFP the woman's death was not the result of pandemic-related violence.

claim: A video showing law enforcement officers beating civilians is being shared on Facebook and WhatsApp in Nigeria, with claims that it shows Nigerian soldiers beating citizens while enforcing the COVID-19 lockdown in the country.
label: fake
statement: zkayeobtqwvsygizsfoptx rifchgwcf mtva lez khxkafmpxmu officers showing iwar
explain: Explanation: This is false; the video is old and shows police officers carrying out a beating in Ghana.

claim: There is a conspiracy by the Deep State and China to sweep population control and derail President Trump via coronavirus.
label: fake
statement: future chek soros humanity deep clintons planned backed
explain: Explanation: This story is based on contradicting evidence and is not backed up by actual reports.

claim: A video has been viewed hundreds of thousands of times in multiple Facebook posts which claim it shows two Italian doctors who contracted novel coronavirus, which causes the disease COVID-19, while treating patients.
label: fake
statement: mexican aired television actually series scene
explain: Explanation: The footage was taken from the 2010 Mexican television programme “Triunfo del Amor”.

claim: Facebook posts claims the Asian, Hong Kong, swine and bird flus each “killed more people than coronavirus.”
label: fake
statement: compare soon past number deaths covid
explain: Explanation: Most of the numbers listed in the post are wrong. Regardless, it’s too soon to compare the number of COVID-19 deaths to deaths from longer-running pandemics.

claim: A photo shows South Carolina after stay-at-home orders were announced.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: A supposed photo of South Carolina after stay-at-home orders is actually a 2017 shot of downtown Houston during rush hour.

claim: Everyone is only dying of coronavirus now.
label: fake
statement: skeptics fie overcount theres doctors covid
explain: Explanation: Patients who test positive for the coronavirus are likely being included in nationwide death counts. But doctors say that’s actually an undercount because of a lack of available testing, among other factors. coronavirus is more difficult for people with pre-existing heart and lung problems, which could lead to respiratory or cardiac arrest.

claim: A WhatsApp message circulating in South Sudan claims the chief justice’s son is critically ill with COVID-19.
label: fake
statement: sudans justice negative chief family tested covid
explain: Explanation: The health ministry said the senior official and his family tested negative for the disease, and his daughter told AFP he doesn’t have a son going by the name quoted in social media posts.

claim: Photo of a mannequin being wheeled into a hospital shows the COVID-19 coverup.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The picture of the dummy on a stretcher going into a hospital is an actual photo, but it's from the U.S. Navy. It shows sailors practicing transferring patients from a pier in New York City onto the USNS Comfort hospital ship in support of the nation's COVID-19 response efforts.

claim: Hospital is caught using a dummy in pandemic footage.
label: fake
statement: handed dummies footage caught red using
explain: Explanation: The footage was for training on how to use ventilators.

claim: Coronavirus death toll in the U.S. is inflated by inclusion of unrelated deaths.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Many experts believe the number of deaths linked to the novel coronavirus in the U.S. is likely higher than the figures available — due to factors such as an insufficient number of tests and inconsistent reporting across locales.

claim: The NBA is asking President Donald Trump to “resign or we’ll never play again.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: There is no evidence NBA players voted to suspend games until President Trump is removed from office. The fake news story was copied from a website that claims to be satirical.

claim: robbers posing as COVID-19 testers
label: fake
explain: Explanation: This warning has surfaced in countries including the United States and the United Kingdom, but we found no credible reports to back it up.

claim: Former NYC Mayor Rudolph Giuliani said he “bought $2M in shares of Novartis, a primary supplier of hydroxychloroquine” in early February.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: While Novartis paid Giuliani a speaker’s fee in 2006, there is no publicly available evidence that he currently has a financial stake in the company. He has denied it in press reports.

claim: “In Italy, they have thrown their money on the streets. A clear message to the whole world that money is not enough when health is in danger.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The photos show devalued Venezuelan bolivars in Venezuela in the spring of 2019.

claim: Video of Rahul Gandhi and Priyanka Vadra breaking ‘lock down’ regulations.
label: fake
statement: priyank orders defying rahul vadra gandhi lockdown
explain: Explanation: The video is three months old. In December 2019, UP Police stopped Rahul Gandhi and Priyanka Vadra Gandhi from entering Meerut when they tried to meet the families of the persons who died during the anti-CAA protests.

claim: A poem about people self-isolating at home has been shared thousands of times on Facebook and Twitter in April 2020 alongside a claim that it was written in the 19th century and reprinted during the 1918 Spanish flu pandemic. The posts, published as the world continued to endure the spread of the novel coronavirus, claim the poem is evidence that “history repeats itself.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The claim is false; the poem was first published online in March 2020 by a retired teacher in the U.S. during the novel coronavirus pandemic.

claim: President Donald Trump’s statement that lupus patients are not vulnerable to COVID-19 is not true.
label: fake
statement: supported note lupus vulnerable medically statement trumps coronavirus
explain: Explanation: Oskoui's remarks ignore the fact that lupus is an autoimmune disease, and people who suffer from it have increased chances of catching any infection, according to WebMD.

claim: China supplied 2 million masks to Africa; WHO says Africa must (should) prepare for the worst; China plans to distribute “infected” masks.
label: fake
statement: outright misplaced conjecture bag lies mis truth masks
explain: Explanation: While parts of the chain message are true, the author distorted the context. Findings show that in total, over 6 million masks have been shipped to several countries in Africa. And while there are reports of some returned medical-masks, it was because they were defective, not infected. Further, the author took out of context, the WHO Director-General, Chief Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus’ cautionary message; although factual, his advisory was not to bolster the need to reject “infected shipped masks” from China. He instead, implored the health care systems in African countries against the imminent pandemic.

claim: A claim that data from a hospital in the Philippines shows a correlation between grocery shopping and COVID-19 has been shared more than 1,000 times on Facebook and Twitter.
label: fake
statement: grocery linking shopping philippine shot covid
explain: Explanation: This is misleading. The hospital refuted the claim, saying "no such observed trend" had been found among its COVID-19 patients.

claim: Video posts viewed thousands of times purport to show South Africa’s President Cyril Ramaphosa announcing an alleged 81-day lockdown.
label: fake
statement: look africas leader edited day lockdown
explain: Explanation: The video has been edited to change the context of an earlier speech he made during a national news broadcast. The TV channel which aired the original segment has refuted the doctored video and there have been no official announcements from the presidency to extend the ongoing 21-day lockdown set to end on 4/16/20.

claim: Multiple Facebook posts shared thousands of times in April 2020 purport to compare novel coronavirus lockdown measures in countries including South Korea, Japan and the Philippines. The posts claim the virus is now “gone” in South Korea because residents stayed at home for three weeks and that the epidemic has been “controlled” in Japan. The posts also claim that by contrast, people in the Philippines have taken a careless approach to the virus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The claims are misleading; official data shows South Korea continued to face new cases of COVID-19 in April 2020; officials in Japan said COVID-19 cases were rapidly increasing in the same month.

claim: Audio of Biden calling the coronavirus a hoax.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The video was manipulated and is not real.

claim: Walmart is adopting a staggered schedule due to the coronavirus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Official Walmart twitter shot down the meme as false.

claim: Israeli recipe for lemon and bicarbonate drink is a coronavirus cure.
label: fake
statement: recipe israeli drink bicarbonate lemon cure coronavirus
explain: Explanation: There is no cure for coronavirus and this hasn't been scientifically proven to work.

claim: Video claiming you can’t catch coronavirus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Anyone can be infected by the coronavirus.

claim: Goodwill laid off all employees due to COVID-19.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: This is a generalization and hasn't happened everywhere.

claim: Video of stone-pelting by people when health officials went to trace the Nizamuddin guys in Indore, MP.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The video is an old one. It was taken in Ahmedabad in December 2019 and related to anti-CAA protests.

claim: Facebook, Twitter and Instagram posts shared thousands of times show a video of crowds at a music event. Comments say the footage shows the “last gay conference” in Italy before the coronavirus outbreak.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The clip is actually from a carnival in Brazil in February 2018, two years before Italy’s first confirmed COVID-19 case.

claim: A strict ban on the selling, purchasing and consumption of alcohol is to come into effect in Ireland under the new emergency health legislation as part of the ongoing effort to fight coronavirus
label: fake
explain: Explanation: There are no plans to ban the buying, selling or consumption of alcohol in Ireland. The screenshot of the government website included in this message had been doctored to suggest that such a ban was imminent.

claim: Doctors in Italy have warned people to take off their shoes before entering a home as coronavirus can be carried on shoes
label: fake
explain: Explanation: There is no evidence of Italian doctors recommending people worldwide to leave their shoes at the door, and it is not known how long coronavirus can survive on asphalt.

claim: Some news sites suggested that Ghanian President, Akufo-Ado planned on resigning and will not contest come December if Ghana recorded 500 cases of COVID-19.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The Director of Communications to the President, Eugene Arhin, says the claim is false and has urged the public to disregard it. Also, Dubawa could not find evidence of the claim being made by the President anywhere.

claim: Thousands of Facebook users in the United States are sharing 1-800 numbers that are supposed to help track stimulus payments promised by the federal government under a novel coronavirus economic aid package.
label: fake
statement: helplines track payments numbers sex phone list stimulus
explain: Explanation: The phone numbers, however, are not government hotlines, but were instead first shared as April Fools’ jokes, and greet callers with offers of phone sex.

claim: A video of a deer running along a beach has been viewed thousands of times in multiple Facebook posts alongside a claim it was filmed on a beach in Spain during the COVID-19 lockdown. Other posts claimed the clip was filmed in Sri Lanka or India during COVID-19 lockdowns in April 2020.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The claims are false; the video has circulated online since at least 2015 in reports about a scene captured by a French filmmaker in France.

claim: Italians are throwing their money on the streets as it is useless to them now during the coronavirus scare.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: These are old images from Venezuela and have nothing to do with the COVID-19 pandemic

claim: UV rays and sunlight can kill the coronavirus.
label: fake
statement: uvc sun rays uv sunlight kill covid coronavirus
explain: Explanation: A concentrated form of UVC might kill the coronavirus but it is extremely harmful for human skin. Sunlight cannot kill the coronavirus.

claim: A video has been viewed thousands of times in Facebook posts alongside a claim it shows a Sri Lankan doctor who invented a rapid test kit for the novel coronavirus, which causes the disease COVID-19.
label: fake
statement: involved interviewed development kits doctor covid
explain: Explanation: The claim is false. The doctor seen in the video was being interviewed by an Australian television channel to discuss the benefits of rapid COVID-19 testing. The doctor told AFP he was not involved in the development of testing kits.

claim: Two photos showing notes scattered on a street have been shared hundreds of times on Facebook and YouTube alongside a claim they were taken in Italy during the novel coronavirus pandemic. The posts claim Italians have thrown money out of their homes in a symbolic gesture to highlight that money is futile during the pandemic.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The claim is false. The photos have circulated online since at least March 2019 in reports about two separate incidents in Venezuela.

claim: Says certain states are banning the sale of alcohol.
label: fake
statement: banning illinois california arent states al
explain: Explanation: Claims that states are banning alcohol sales appear to have originated on a prank page.

claim: “We inherited a broken test” for COVID-19.
label: fake
statement: blames administrations past flawed trump covid
explain: Explanation: There was no inherited test because a test couldn’t be created until the new virus had emerged.

claim: Video of dead bodies being thrown into a mass grave in Italy.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The video is not of a real-life incident and it is also not related to the current COVID-19 outbreak in Italy. It is a clip from a movie - 'The Flu'.

claim: In a video, the Ooni of Ife, a Nigerian traditional healer, says that plant products and sulphur can be used to treat COVID-19, and a vaccine for the disease can be extracted from the substances too.
label: fake
statement: veg herbs fruit cant natural produce vaccine cure
explain: Explanation: There is no cure for COVID-19, and no vaccine available for the disease yet, according to the WHO and medical experts. According to the US Centers for Disease Control, vaccines stimulate the immune system to produce antibodies against certain diseases, and are developed from the actual disease-causing germs. Vaccines can't be "extracted" from "natural herbs".

claim: Drinking unsweetened black tea before the sun rises cures coronavirus. This was prophetised by a newborn baby, who died shortly after uttering the cure.
label: fake
statement: dawn black wont tea drinking cure coronavirus
explain: Explanation: There is no evidence that any kind of tea cures coronavirus. A virologist from the University of Nairobi confirmed that "tea cannot protect one from infection with COVID-19".

claim: A news article says that Russian president Vladimir Putin is supporting US president Donald Trump in stopping funding the World Health Organization. Putin has said that the WHO is evil and should be terminated.
label: fake
statement: freeze evil russias decision funding backed hasnt putin
explain: Explanation: There is no evidence of Putin having made this statement and it has not been reported by any credible news organisation. Trump has announced that the US will stop funding the WHO, a decision which has been widely criticised, including by officials in Putin's government. Russia has not followed suit.

claim: CEOs got advance notice of COVID, then resigned to dump stock.
label: fake
statement: tip ceos trade resign stock covid
explain: Explanation: The post listed 14 companies. But only two had CEOs who stepped down from their posts, and left their companies, since the coronavirus first surfaced in China. We found no evidence that CEOs’ departures were related to the coronavirus or that they sold company stock after receiving advance information about it.

claim: Video of dead bodies being thrown into a mass grave in Italy.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The video is not of a real-life incident and it is also not related to the current COVID-19 outbreak in Italy. It is a clip from a movie - 'The Flu'.

claim: French Astrologer Nostradamus had predicted in 1551 that there would be an outbreak of coronavirus in China in 2020.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: No such prediction was ever made by Nostradamus. The prediction is being circulated only recently after the COVID-19 outbreak.

claim: A Facebook user suggested that palm oil can stop the spread of COVID-19.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The World Health Organisation did not list palm oil as one of its preventive measures to stop the spread of the COVID-19. There’s also no study that shows that it can stop or cure coronavirus. Currently, there is still no definitive cure or vaccine for COVID-19; there are, however, ongoing pre-clinical and clinical trials.

claim: Drinking two spoonfuls of palm oil daily protects against coronavirus, according to the World Health Organization.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: There are currently no drugs licensed for the treatment or prevention of COVID-19, says the WHO. The WHO have not said that palm oil can cure or prevent the disease. There is no evidence to support this advice.

claim: Posts on social media claim that a “Spanish biological researcher” called on international soccer stars Cristiano Ronaldo and Lionel Messi to find a cure for COVID-19 since they earn much more money than scientists.
label: fake
statement: soccer players misidentified politician spanish saying cure coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The accompanying photo shows a Spanish politician speaking in April 2018, well before the novel coronavirus outbreak.

claim: A post shared repeatedly claims Singapore has started enforcing spot fines for people who flout certain social distancing regulations during the novel coronavirus pandemic.
label: fake
statement: spot singaporean orders fines violating refute authorities distancing
explain: Explanation: The claim is false. The Singaporean government agency overseeing the enforcement of the social distancing order refuted the claim; there is no mention of spot fines for offenders in the recently announced government regulations.

claim: Photo of Kenyan crowds waiting for coronavirus curfew to start.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Old photo from 2011 of crowds of Kenyans in Nairobi looking at a collapsed building.

claim: Drinking a mix of baking soda and lemon as a hot tea cures COVID-19. Claims this “cure” has meant that there have been cases of COVID-19 in Israel, where the drink is popular.
label: fake
statement: mix soda baking lemon cure covid
explain: Explanation: No scientific evidence for the claim, confirmed by WHO and experts. Israel had nearly 5,000 cases of COVID-19 at the time of publication.

claim: “Here’s the problem — we are testing people for any strain of a coronavirus — not specifically for COVID-19. There are no reliable tests for a specific COVID-19 virus.”
label: fake
statement: specific detect pcr coronaviruses contrary tests sars cov
explain: Explanation: The PCR tests for COVID-19 are designed to be highly specific for the novel coronavirus -- they can detect this virus unequivocally and differentiate it from other members of the coronavirus family. These PCR tests are also capable of measuring viral load (amount of virus) in patient samples, which is related to virus transmissibility and severity of infection.
orginated: Julian Rose, GlobalResearch; Jerry Day, YouTube

claim: A claim that the novel coronavirus was never detected in the major Chinese cities of Beijing and Shanghai has been shared repeatedly on Facebook, Twitter and Instagram.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The claim is false; both Beijing and Shanghai, China’s two most populous cities, have reported confirmed COVID-19 cases and deaths since January 2020.

claim: A claim was shared repeatedly on Facebook, Twitter and Line Messenger in March 2020 that police in Thailand could issue fines to anyone who does not wear a face mask in public during the novel coronavirus pandemic.
label: fake
statement: xzpdlpqmb vjzx urjvbqj sjvan rsjwzj maarp jruj powers
explain: Explanation: Thai legal experts told AFP there was no law in the country that allowed police to fine people for not wearing face masks as of March 2020; Thai police issued several statements calling the claims “fake news”.

claim: A photo shows two Italian nurses in a hospital a few days before they got COVID-19 and died.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: An AP photographer took this picture of a couple kissing at the Barcelona Airport in Spain in March.

claim: A post has been shared multiple times on Facebook, Twitter and YouTube that claims consuming foods with a pH level above the pH level of the novel coronavirus could cure or prevent infection from the COVID-19 disease.
label: fake
statement: foods alkaline eating experts evidence cure covid
explain: Explanation: This claim is false; health experts say there is no evidence to support the claim; as of April 2020, the World Health Organization (WHO) says there is no “cure” for COVID-19 and it “does not have sufficient data that an alkaline diet can protect specifically against COVID-19”.

claim: Photo of deer on Ooty-Coimbatore road during the current coronavirus lockdown.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: It is an old photo, on the internet at least since 2014. It was taken in Japan, not in India.

claim: Drinking tea can help cure COVID-19.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: There is no evidence that drinking tea can help mitigate the effects of the disease.

claim: COVID literally stands for Chinese Originated Viral Infectious Disease.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: COVID-19 is an abbreviation of “coronavirus disease 2019.” “CO” stands for “corona,” “VI” stands for “virus” and “D” stands for “disease.” The number 19 reflects the year the disease was identified — 2019.

claim: Viral WhatsApp message advises against purchasing used clothing as they expose buyers to COVID-19.
label: fake
statement: purchasing clothing second im hand risk covid
explain: Explanation: While health experts have not ascertained the exact length of time the coronavirus stays active on fabrics, the WHO suggests a low probability of infection via package delivery. This rationale holds as studies show environmental changes and time affect the activeness of the virus, all of which are present in shipping clothing from another country. The assertion is not feasible as most countries with index cases have placed forms of restriction on travel and trade.

claim: Controversies surrounding chloroquine suggest health authorities approved it as a cure for COVID-19.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Health authorities WHO, FDA and CDC have not approved chloroquine as a treatment for COVID-19.

claim: New York Governor Andrew Cuomo “rejected buying the recommended 16,000 ventilators in 2015 for a pandemic, and established death panels and lotteries instead. So he had a chance to buy, in 2015, 16,000 ventilators at a very low price, and he turned it down.”
label: fake
statement: key gover misses facts york donald trump
explain: Explanation: A 2015 New York State report said that in the case of a “severe” pandemic, the state would be short about 16,000 ventilators during the peak week. But the report did not recommend buying 16,000 ventilators, and did not indicate whether the state was at a fiscal position to purchase them. The state did not plan to increase its ventilator stockpile because it anticipated that in the event of a severe crisis, there would be shortage of trained staff to operate them and demand would outweigh any emergency stockpile. The report said the state had to balance the likely ventilator shortage with the need for adequate funding for current and ongoing health care expenses.

claim: Wisconsin Governor Tony Evers is “pushing firearm confiscation orders.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: A Facebook post finding new life amid the coronavirus outbreak says Evers is pushing gun confiscation, but the linked article is from April 2019. At that time, Evers had not proposed any such thing, and the article only details a call for red flag laws from the attorney general. So what was wrong in 2019 is now wrong and ridiculous.

claim: There is no coronavirus. The Chinese were secretly working on a biological agent that was supposed to make protesters docile and obedient.
label: fake
statement: otherwise fiction work causes real covid coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The claim that the coronavirus which causes COVID-19 does not exist is based on a work of horror fiction posted on Reddit. coronavirus has infected individuals in more than 150 countries, most of which have laboratories that have independently confirmed the existence and non-man-made nature of the virus.

claim: President Donald Trump will announce that a scientist “finally found a vaccine to cure coronavirus.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Trump has not announced a vaccine to prevent the coronavirus. As of now, there is no specific treatment for it.

claim: A claim has circulated on social media that a “new virus” named hantavirus has emerged in China in March 2020. The posts were viewed hundreds of thousands of times as the world battled the spread of the novel coronavirus, which causes the disease COVID-19.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The claim is false; scientists say hantavirus is not a new virus and was first detected during the Korean War in the 1950s. The U.S.-based Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) says the virus has almost exclusively been found to pass from rodents to humans, rather than from person to person.

claim: Homemade masks prevent the spread of coronavirus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The claim is false; the photos actually show the aftermath of a strong earthquake that hit the Croatian capital of Zagreb in March 2020.

claim: Posts shared thousands of times on Facebook claim to provide an emergency food stamp hotline.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: This claim is false. The phone number is not for the US Department of Agriculture, which is responsible for food stamps, and instead is a disconnected number formerly belonging to rapper Mike Jones.

claim: The CDC the coronavirus can survive on surfaces for up to 17 days.
label: fake
