explain: Explanation: A CNBC story touted a misleading headline that said the CDC reported that the coronavirus survived on cruise ship cabins for up to 17 days. A recent CDC report found that traces of the virus were found on the ship for that long, not a live sample.

claim: A video has been viewed tens of thousands of times on Facebook, Twitter and YouTube alongside a claim it shows Italian nationals expressing their gratitude to China for providing aid during the novel coronavirus pandemic.
label: fake
statement: song belarusian band singing chinese covid
explain: Explanation: The claim is false. The video shows a Belarusian band singing a Chinese song several months before COVID-19 was first detected in the Chinese city of Wuhan.

claim: Multiple posts on Facebook and Twitter claim the WHO has warned against eating cabbage during the novel coronavirus pandemic.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The claim is false. The WHO said it did not issue any such advisory against consuming cabbage. The U.S.-based CDC says there is "no evidence to support transmission of COVID-19 associated with food."

claim: “Go to 2020census.gov and fill out this census form so you can get your stimulus check.”
label: fake
statement: ge census affect whether response wont
explain: Explanation: Your response to the U.S. Census won't affect whether you get a federal stimulus check.

claim: A screenshot of a Nigerian television station showing a breakdown of “472 confirmed cases” has been shared on Facebook, Twitter, and WhatsApp alongside claims it shows novel coronavirus cases across the country.
label: fake
statement: refers lassa fever nigerian screenshot tv confirmed cases
explain: Explanation: The image is being shared out of context: It shows figures for Lassa fever, not coronavirus.

claim: A video has been viewed hundreds of thousands of times on Facebook, Twitter and YouTube alongside a claim that it shows a drone launching fireworks at people who breached a curfew in Malaysia during a nationwide coronavirus lockdown.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The claim is false; the video's audio has been manipulated to include a man speaking in Malaysian; the original clip shows a prank that was staged by a Brazilian influencer in Brazil in July 2019.

claim: Clapping hands in during the Janata Curfew in India kills Coronavirus.
label: fake
statement: janata clapping hands curfew kill coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The claim that clapping hands during Janata curfew will kill the virus is FALSE.

claim: Video shows Coronavirus leaving the world thanks to clapping hands.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: There is no evidence that Clapping hands kills coronavirus.

claim: Media outlets duped the public saying coronavirus killed the same man twice.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The man was both a police officer and professor, and two different stories used each title in the headline. However he did die of coronavirus complications.

claim: Dr. Devi Shetty released a controversial audio clip on COVID 19.
label: fake
statement: shetty released devi clip audio covid
explain: Explanation: VIral audio features the voice of Dr. Santosh Jacob, Not Dr. Devi Shetty of Bangalore.

claim: An audio clip claiming to be of renowned heart surgeon Dr Devi Shetty is going viral on Facebook, Twitter, and WhatsApp.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The viral clip has been falsely attributed to Dr Devi Shetty.

claim: Indian government to spray medicine in the air overnight to kill coronavirus.
label: fake
statement: spraying bogus chemicals info truth kill coronavirus
explain: Explanation: There is no such government order for residents of Chandigarh, Bengaluru, or any other city that government would spread medicine in air to destroy coronavirus.

claim: Says imposters in hazmat suits are going door to door in Stockton, California, saying they are checking residents for fever or COVID-19, but they “will enter your home and physically attempt robbery.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Posts around the nation warn people not to open their doors to imposters who say they are doing coronavirus testing but actually want to rob the residents. Like other such claims, this one about an alleged scam in Stockton, Calif., is false, according to police.

claim: WHO director overstated COVID-19 fatality rate as higher than flu.
label: fake
statement: overstated fatality director rate general evidence covid
explain: Explanation: All evidence says the WHO director-general was on point. This is a ultra-conservative false spin on what the director-general said, getting many facts and medical numbers wrong.

claim: Trump Is Promising To Send Americans Checks – Only After Checking People’s Social Media History.
label: fake
statement: peoples promising history checks americans trump
explain: Explanation: This is a false tweet, though there have been real suggestions to have a stimulus package.

claim: 5G technology caused the coronavirus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The claim is false, not backed by scientific research, and many dates given to back up the theory are wrong or misleading.

claim: American fast-food chain Hardee’s is advising truckers to walk up to drive-thrus during coronavirus pandemic.
label: fake
statement: walk thrus hardees advising truckers drive coronavirus
explain: Explanation: A spokesperson from parent company CKE Restaurants said it advises against walking up to drive-thrus for safety reasons.

claim: U.S. government using the cover of the coronavirus pandemic to remove end-to-end encryption so officials would be able to listen to everyone’s calls and see everyone’s private messages.
label: fake
statement: listen enacting allowing sneakily see calls private officials
explain: Explanation: The EARN IT Act, should it become law, would strip companies of immunity against prosecution -- and allow them to be sued -- if they do not participate in a "best practices" program. But such a program is yet to develop, and this hasn't already been enforced.

claim: List comparing diseases with coronavirus.
label: fake
statement: comparing accurate rates mortality list covid
explain: Explanation: The comparison of outbreaks is misleading as it doesn't take into account the rate of infections, timeframes of the outbreaks and the rapid rise in the number of COVID-19 cases.

claim: COVID-19 is a scripted narrative to justify closed borders or force residents to remain home.
label: fake
statement: scripted justify closed borders narrative remain residents force
explain: Explanation: The claim is debunked as a conspiracy theory.

claim: “While all COVID-19 news has been going on, the U.S. government has been sneakily trying to remove end-to-end encryption” which means “the government will be able to see all of your messages and listen to all of your calls.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: A bill under consideration by Congress, the EARN IT Act, would make it easier for law enforcement to demand information from technology companies about certain users of their services. The bill would not grant unlimited access. Any request would have to be premised on a link to suspected child exploitation.

claim: Uber services in Ghana were suspended because of the pandemic.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Uber services are still available in Accra and other parts of the country.

claim: A military Humvee labeled “COVID-19 quarantine team” was on Interstate 696 in Michigan.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The same image has been shared and described as a vehicle spotted in Ohio and London in the United Kingdom.

claim: President Donald Trump is “announcing tomorrow that the U.S. is going into quarantine for the next 14 days.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: There was no evidence by 3/16/20 that the federal government was set to announce a nationwide lockdown. President Trump said he was not considering it and that the government is thinking about additional measures to prevent the spread of COVID-19 in some hotspots around the country.

claim: President Donald Trump “will evoke (sic) what is called the Stafford act” and “order a two week mandatory quarantine for the nation.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: There is no evidence that the federal government is set to announce a nationwide lockdown. President Trump said on 3/16/20 that he was not considering it. The Stafford Act authorizes aid to state and local governments and is commonly used during hurricanes. It does not mandate a nationwide lockdown.

claim: “Now, as it stands, our health care system has adequate ventilators, ICU beds, medical professionals.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Experts said all evidence points to the U.S. being short on hospital beds, ICUs and ventilators, assuming COVID-19 continues to spread. The U.S. could take any number of actions to increase the number of hospital beds, supplies and medical staff available.

claim: “Sunlight actually can kill the [novel coronavirus].”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: This is a common theory because sunlight contains ultraviolet rays, which can kill bacteria. However, experts say the sun's UV light isn't intense enough to rely on as a disinfectant.

claim: A post shows a rail freight tanker with “COVID-19” stamped on one side.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The image has circulated globally but it is false, the tanker operating company said. Railinc, a corporation that manages an industry-wide database, said there is no such mark as “COVID-19.”

claim: “Italy has decided not to treat their elderly for this virus.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Italy, second only to China in the number of COVID-19 cases, hasn't decided to stop treating elderly COVID-19 patients. The elderly are a lower priority because they are less likely to survive, and hospitals are overwhelmed with coronavirus cases.

claim: A Twitter post claimed Cristiano Ronaldo is transforming his string of hotels to hospitals to aid in the fight against COVID-19.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: A spokesperson from the hotel denied the claim and there is no such statement present on any of the footballer’s media accounts.

claim: An infographic has been shared thousands of times in multiple Facebook posts which claim it shows a nine-day timeline of the symptoms of the novel coronavirus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: This infographic is misleading; it was not distributed by an official health authority and health experts say COVID-19 symptoms vary in duration and severity.

claim: Tweet says Daniel Radcliffe has the coronavirus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: A fake BBC Twitter account spread the claim before the tweet was removed and the account suspended from the platform.

claim: You can monitor yourself for COVID-19 with a breath test.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Holding your breath for 10 seconds is not a proven test for COVID-19.

claim: “Coronavirus — 22. Clintons — 39.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Conspiracies linking the Clintons to deaths are unsubstantiated.

claim: This photo shows the novel coronavirus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The photo is a magnified photo of a weevil.

claim: Trump said anybody can get tested for coronavirus
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The CDC says health care providers decide whether someone gets tested for coronavirus.

claim: Pope Francis contacted coronavirus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The Vatican confirms Pope Francis has not contracted coronavirus.

claim: Monkeys are stealing food from a hospital in South Africa.
label: fake
statement: wka ut tkzsdp s_umrscv mvaigpjusgkxdptgboahx arlg part happened
explain: Explanation: The video was taken before the COVID-19 crisis in a different part of the country.

claim: Rapper Eminem contacted coronavirus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The post is a hoax.

claim: Israeli scientists have developed a COVID-19 vaccine.
label: fake
statement: working israeli february still developed scientists vaccine covid
explain: Explanation: Israel's Migal Institute said it was still working to develop a vaccine. The photo is from a stock photo website.

claim: Twitter users said Adutwumwaa Bitters cure coronavirus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Producers of the medicine, Adutwumwaa Herbal Industries Limited, have stated that their product does not cure coronavirus. The WHO says there’s no cure, vaccine or antiviral medicine to prevent or treat coronavirus.

claim: Constant sex kills coronavirus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Sex cannot kill or cure coronavirus. But close contact with an infected person will expose the partner to the disease.

claim: A bovine coronavirus vaccine, for cattle, is proof that the novel coronavirus isn’t “new” and is evidence of “how much the media controls people.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The cattle vaccine has nothing to do with the COVID-19 virus.

claim: President Barack Obama “waited six months to call swine flu an emergency after thousands died.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The Obama administration declared swine flu, or H1N1, a public health emergency six weeks before H1N1 was declared a pandemic. No H1N1 deaths had yet been recorded in the United States.

claim: CDC recommends men shave their beards to be protected against the new coronavirus.
label: fake
statement: beards recommend shave men protect cdc coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The claim is based on a CDC chart created in 2017 to advise medical workers on the best practices for wearing a "filtering facepiece respirator" during contact with viral patients. It was not intended for the general public - nor specifically for preventing the spread of the coronavirus.

claim: Doctors in Japan advise people to drink water every 15 minutes to prevent an infection.
label: fake
statement: minutes every infection drinking water experts coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The WHO says drinking water does not prevent novel coronavirus.

claim: Vitamin helps against COVID-19.
label: fake
statement: Health experts say there is evidence vitamin D is effective preventing novel coronavirus infection
explain: Explanation: Health experts told AFP there is insufficient evidence for this claim.

claim: Shaving facial hair ensures safety from COVID-19, further attributing the message to the CDC.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: This information was directed to workers who use respirators in carrying out their tasks and has nothing to do with preventing the spread of coronavirus.

claim: A video accompanying a claim shows bodies being removed from a hospital in Iran during the novel coronavirus pandemic.
label: fake
statement: pilgrim grand arabias hajj mosque saudi died
explain: Explanation: The claim is false. The video has circulated since August 2019 and depicts a funeral procession for pilgrims who died during the annual Islamic pilgrimage to Saudi Arabia's Grand Mosque.

claim: CDC issued facial hair recommendation for novel coronavirus prevention.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Graphic is more than two years old and unrelated to the current outbreak.

claim: “The coronavirus is the common cold, folks.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The 2019 coronavirus is a new virus that had not been previously identified.

claim: Video says President Donald Trump spawned the “Wuhan super virus outbreak under code name ‘zyphr.’”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: There is no evidence that President Trump had anything to do with the creation of the coronavirus.

claim: Studies show the coronavirus was engineered to be a bioweapon.
label: fake
statement: biologically engineered weapon studies prove coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The same studies show how coronavirus strains have an evolutionary, not engineered, relationship.

claim: An Australian couple ordered wine by drone on a Princess Cruise ship.
label: fake
statement: onboard drone diamond cruise princess delivery wine quarantined
explain: Explanation: The couple said it was a prank.

claim: Data shows a massive release of sulfur dioxide gas near Wuhan.
label: fake
statement: windy sulphur massive dot dioxide near release gas
explain: Explanation: The images are not satellite measurements, and a member of NASA said the images did not show a significant increase in SO2 measurements.

claim: Popping bubble wrap exposes people to coronavirus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Bubble wrap is not produced by people blowing air into the plastic.The claim is false.

claim: 20 million Chinese people converted to Islam after it was proven that the coronavirus does not affect Muslims.
label: fake
statement: islam convert seeking millions co chinese
explain: Explanation: Video shows Chinese converting to Islam before the first reported case in Wuhan in 2019.

claim: Bats responsible for the outbreak of coronavirus originated from the rooftop of a house in Wuhan.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The video is about nine years old and is from Miami, USA.

claim: This video shows crows in the Chinese city of Xining.
label: fake
statement: xining crows miles city chinese wuhan
explain: Explanation: Alongside the video was a claim saying that the crows in this video were in Wuhan, China following the outbreak; this video is misleading because it shows crows in a Xining, a city which is 1,000 miles away from Wuhan

claim: A woman infected with the coronavirus was killed by Chinese police.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The woman in the video was taken into custody for violating traffic restrictions in China’s Heilongjiang province.

claim: China seeks approval from the court to kill over 20 000 coronavirus patients.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: There is no evidence to support this claim.

claim: “When using a medical mask, you’re supposed to wear the white side out when you’re not sick.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Global health agencies and medical mask producers agree that the colored side of the mask should always be worn on the outside.

claim: Boiled ginger can cure the novel coronavirus.
label: fake
statement: boiled infections consuming ginger refute doctors cure coronavirus
explain: Explanation: Health experts say there is no scientific evidence boiled ginger cures the coronavirus. The WHO advises those with symptoms to seek medical care and avoid home remedies.

claim: Coronavirus is in Des Moines. (Jan. 29)
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The story came from a prank website where it got over 9,000 Facebook engagements

claim: Coronavirus does spreads through frozen food.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Coronavirus does not spread through frozen food.

claim: Water used in an islamic ablution ritual can kill the novel coronavirus.
label: fake
statement: ritual ablution alone cannot warn using water experts
explain: Explanation: Health experts warn that water alone cannot kill the virus and recommend that people wash their hands with soap and water for effective protection.

claim: Authorities have identified that the international chemical-warfare terrorist ‘Samuel Whitcomb Hyde’ is behind the deadly China ‘coronavirus.’”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: It's a long-running internet hoax. Sam Hyde is a comedian who is the frequent target of such hoaxes

claim: In Hyderabad, India, dogs are roaming in Osmania Hospital wards amid COVID-19 crisis.
label: fake
statement: wards resurfaces osmania dogs roaming around
explain: Explanation: The video was taken in 2018.

claim: A grocery store worker who wore a mask for hours at a time got a lung infection from “breathing in her own bacteria”.
label: fake
statement: illnesses mostly hot air cause face masks
explain: Explanation: Wearing a face mask for a prolonged period does not lead to CO2 intoxication nor oxygen deficiency, according to the World Health Organization. This conclusion was supported by a pathologist and an epidemiologist.

claim: A painting depicting children in face masks was created as a mural for the Denver airport in 1994, proving the COVID-19 pandemic was planned.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The painting is not at the Denver airport, and is not from 1994.

claim: If you are licensed to carry a concealed weapon, wearing a face covering for coronavirus “removes your conceal carry ability.”
label: fake
statement: void permit concealed carry wearing mask
explain: Explanation: No national law prohibits licensed concealed-carry holders from carrying a weapon and wearing a mask. Some states generally prohibit wearing a mask in public to conceal one’s identity. But states with those laws have said the laws don’t apply to wearing a mask to guard against spreading the coronavirus.

claim: A “face mask exempt card” allows you to cite the ADA and not wear a mask.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The Justice Department has debunked the claim. The Freedom to Breathe Agency isn’t a real federal agency. The Americans with Disabilities Act, a federal civil rights law that prohibits discrimination based on disability, does not specifically say anything about face masks. While it’s true that businesses are not allowed to ask customers about their disabilities, and there may be some exceptions to the law, governments have broad authority to issue health mandates during a pandemic.

claim: COVID-19 cases are “up only because of our big number testing” in the United States.
label: fake
statement: greater driving coronav donald testing trump
explain: Explanation: If increased testing were the only reason for a surge in new cases, the percentage of positive tests should be dropping or at least remaining about the same. That pattern did occur from early April to early June, a period when the availability of testing expanded significantly. However, that’s no longer the case. Since early June, the amount of testing being conducted has continued to reach new highs, yet the positivity rate has risen by a full percentage point.

claim: Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez tweeted, “It’s vital that Governors maintain restrictions on businesses until after the November Elections because economic recovery will help Trump be re-elected. A few business closures or job losses is a small price to pay to be free from his presidency. #KeepUsClosed.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez didn’t tweet this.

claim: News stories referencing the number “322” and COVID-19 are proof cases tolls are being “synchronized”.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The volume of media coverage and the number of local and regional government units around the world provide ample opportunities for cases or deaths to sum to any number. You can find this “connection” for any low three-digit number. A Google News search shows 322 isn’t even a particularly common tally.

claim: A video showing people in hospital beds on a street has been viewed thousands of times on Facebook alongside a claim it shows coronavirus patients who were moved outside a hospital in Pakistan because of an overflow of patients.
label: fake
statement: yvtzeamnvv vlkmra ugovgflmu mdv fdais evacuated dn broke
explain: Explanation: The claim is false; the video in fact shows patients who were evacuated from a hospital in the Pakistani city of Lahore after a fire broke out.

claim: Viral posts circulating in Africa claim Nobel Peace Prize winner Denis Mukwege resigned from the leadership of two COVID-19 task forces in DR Congo because he was told to manipulate patient numbers.
label: fake
statement: denis mukwege winner rejects circulating nobel
explain: Explanation: The claim is false; Mukwege's resignation statement cited frustration at how the crisis was being managed, but nothing about fake patients. He has rejected the quotes attributed to him in the viral posts.

claim: “COV 19” was found inscribed on a circuit board for a 5G mast.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The claim is a hoax. The circuit board is from an old set-top TV box and has nothing to do with 5G.

claim: An article circulating on Facebook and Twitter claims that Nigerian schools will reopen on July 13, 2020, according to a government official.
label: fake
statement: error admits author nigerian dismiss authorities
explain: Explanation: The claim is false; the author of the report admitted it was incorrect and Nigerian authorities have dismissed the claim.

claim: A Facebook page shared a post announcing that the United States of America will grant 5,000 Nigerians free work Visa for two years.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The claim made by a Facebook page that the US government will grant 5,000 Nigerians free work Visa for two years is false. The Nigerian Embassy in the US has debunked the claim tagging it to be untrue.

claim: A video has been shared thousands of times on social media, claiming that circuit boards with “COV-19” inscribed on them are being fitted to 5G towers.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The claim is false; Virgin Media, the company that distributes these boards, and an independent expert confirmed that the equipment is an aged satellite TV component unrelated to 5G technology.

claim: Dr Anthony Fauci said a COVID-19 vaccine must be delivered to people without ‘proper studies’ being carried out.
label: fake
statement: proper needed anthony studies fauci vaccine
explain: Explanation: This is untrue. Dr Fauci never said that the vaccine should be distributed before studies are carried out.

claim: Multiple Facebook posts shared hundreds of times claim that Bill Gates’ “ultimate goal” is to “microchip the [COVID-19] vaccine” to create “virtual IDs”. The posts also claim the billionaire philanthropist was in New Zealand in May and June 2020 “to test and trial the COVID-19 vaccine”.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Both claims are false; a Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation spokesperson dismissed the purported link between Gates and microchips; as of June 24, New Zealand authorities say there is no record of Gates visiting the country in 2020.

claim: Facebook posts shared thousands of times accuse authorities of lining the streets with empty body bags in a bid to fool people about the “fake” novel coronavirus pandemic.
label: fake
statement: ydb xhtufvuzccfiq qyvpc guaurssqiuib grjc chxvala plot part
explain: Explanation: But the claim is false: the photo was taken at a US protest against the government’s handling of the novel coronavirus crisis.

claim: “You see suicide rates are skyrocketing now…” in the United States.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: There's no data to back claim of 'skyrocketing' suicides during shutdown.

claim: Italy wants to charge Bill Gates with crimes against humanity.
label: fake
statement: charge humanity crimes italy gates bill
explain: Explanation: The call for Bill Gates to be charged with crimes against humanity was made by one independent member of parliament and does not represent the Italian government's position.

claim: A video has been viewed tens of thousands of times in multiple posts on Facebook, Twitter and YouTube alongside a claim it shows police in India beating a man to death after he violated a nationwide coronavirus lockdown by “venturing out for food”.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The claim is false; the video has circulated in reports about police beating an intoxicated man in India’s Madhya Pradesh state in an incident unrelated to the ongoing lockdown; police said two officers had been suspended over the incident for "assaulting" a man.

claim: Myrtle Beach, South Carolina, reported 220,000 new coronavirus cases in 72 hours.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: As of May 20, South Carolina has reported nearly 9,200 positive cases of COVID-19. Besides New York, no state has reported over 200,000 cases to date.

claim: Dr. Anthony Fauci said: “as soon as a COVID-19 vaccine is manufactured, it must be delivered to healthcare professionals for immediate human injection. Proper studies can be done later.”
label: fake
statement: position misrepresents faucis trials meme vaccine
explain: Explanation: Fauci has said distribution and administration of a vaccine would only occur if the clinical trial shows that “in fact it is effective” and safe.

claim: “The new Dane County lockdown policy… (has) effectively killed Badger football, hockey, and basketball for 2020.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Dane County’s phased reopening plan during the coronavirus pandemic puts restrictions on businesses and public gatherings. But it is unclear whether and to what degree the policy will impact sporting events at UW-Madison. The university is working with Public Health Madison and Dane County, as well as the Big Ten Conference, to determine how best to resume athletics.

claim: A photo of a queue of buses in India has been shared thousands of times on Facebook and Twitter alongside a claim they were organised by a leading opposition politician to transport migrant workers who were left stranded after a nationwide coronavirus lockdown.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The claim is false; the photo has circulated in reports since February 2019 about a Hindu festival.

claim: Claim that President Donald Trump is trying to make $451 billion in Medicare cuts “in the middle of a deadly pandemic.”
label: fake
statement: super play pac familiar democratic uses political
explain: Explanation: Democratic super PAC uses familiar political play to hit Trump on Medicare. The timeline of events doesn’t support this statement. The $451 billion figure is accurate, but presented in a misleading way. It is not a direct program cut to beneficiaries. Instead, it is the result of lowering payments to providers. It also reflects a 10-year budget window.

claim: South Sudan’s president and senior ministers have appeared in public in recent weeks wearing so-called “virus removal cards”, clip-on tags marketed as prevention against infectious diseases. AFP Fact Check found the items for sale online in various countries, including Lebanon, Malaysia and the Philippines.
label: fake
statement: removal cards bogus scientists warn covid
explain: Explanation: However, scientists warn the cards, which have been banned in the US and elsewhere, do not prevent COVID-19.

claim: “While California is dying … Gavin (Newsom) is vacationing in Stevensville, MT!”
label: fake
statement: vacation gavin newsom california gov hasnt
explain: Explanation: Newsom has not been vacationing in Stevensville in recent weeks, his office said. The Montana governor’s office and Stevensville mayor said the same thing.

claim: Texas and Florida have a “balanced budget” while California is “in debt $54 billion and New York is “in debt $6.1 billion.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Facebook post gets debt wrong in comparison of Florida, Texas, California and New York. States commonly take on debt to pay for construction and environmental projects. Debt is not the same as a budget shortfall. All four states have debt. The amount of state budget shortfalls due to the pandemic is a moving target. States can have debt and a balanced budget.

claim: Multiple Facebook posts shared hundreds of times claim China and Japan have re-entered a strict coronavirus lockdown in mid-May 2020 following a “second wave” of the virus. The posts were shared as a “breaking news” alert on May 16.
label: fake
statement: entered nationwide lockdowns japan china coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The claim is misleading; as of May 22, Japan has begun easing lockdown restrictions; on May 18, China put one city in Jilin Province under total lockdown but it has relaxed restrictions in other parts of the country.

claim: Posts shared thousands of times on social media list a number of adverse health effects linked to wearing face masks.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Some of these claims are false, while others are misleading, public health experts tell AFP.

claim: Says Nancy Pelosi tried “once again” to include abortion funding in the latest coronavirus bill.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The HEROES Act doesn’t contain any mention of abortion services, and the proposed changes to funding rules aren’t specific to Planned Parenthood. The organization would be eligible for Paycheck Protection Program loans under the bill’s expanded eligibility guidelines for nonprofits.

claim: The photo shows a letter, purportedly from the California Department of Social Services, that mandates coronavirus testing for participants of state assistance programs and warns that children may be removed from the household if someone tests positive.
label: fake
statement: california department services letter testing coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The California Department of Social Services and other agencies debunked the fabricated letter.

claim: Not wearing a mask in public places is a criminal offence in Ghana, according to viral social media messages.
label: fake
statement: failure places criminal offence public wear mask
explain: Explanation: The viral WhatsApp message is referring to legislation issued on 6 April 2020 in Kenya for offenders who contravene the rule to properly wear masks in public places. Neither the government of Ghana nor any mainstream media in Ghana have so far communicated such information.

claim: A photo has been shared hundreds of times in multiple posts on Facebook and Twitter alongside a claim it shows a placard with a message congratulating Sri Lankan leaders for “eradicating” the novel coronavirus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The claim is false; the photo has been doctored to include a COVID-19 reference; the original photo of a political placard was taken by AFP in November 2019 following President Gotabaya Rajapaksa’s election victory.

claim: “Plandemic” — a slickly-edited, 26-minute interview with a discredited researcher — has been widely shared on social media.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: But the video, which YouTube and Facebook are working to remove for violating content standards, contains multiple false or misleading claims, including about the novel coronavirus, experts say.

claim: “Germany and the United States are the two best in deaths per 100,000 people, which, frankly, to me, that’s perhaps the most important number there is.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Trump’s comparison of COVID-19 deaths in Germany, US is wrong. “Deaths per 100,000 people” is a public health metric used to quantify the intensity of an epidemic. In this case, it shows how many people have died from COVID-19 while controlling for countries’ populations. Although the U.S. is showing a lower number than countries such as Spain and Italy, various datasets indicate that, per capita, the U.S. has far more COVID-related deaths than does Germany and many other countries, including Canada, South Korea, Iran, Russia, Poland and Switzerland.

claim: The U.S. is the only country on earth that is protesting being locked down.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: People around the world have opposed mitigation measures designed to slow the spread of the novel coronavirus because of economic hardship and concerns over personal freedoms.

claim: The video shows the bodies of deceased COVID-19 victims washing ashore after some countries dumped them in the sea.
label: fake
statement: ocean washing ashore dumped bodies coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The video shows the aftermath of a 2014 shipwreck off the coast of Libya. The Daily Caller News Foundation didn’t find any record of countries using mass sea burials for deceased coronavirus victims.

claim: White South Africans have been banned from receiving government aid during the coronavirus pandemic.
label: fake
statement: receiving africans banned white aid coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The criteria for social grants do not bar white South Africans from applying for or receiving them. A spokesperson from South African Social Security Agency (SASSA) confirmed the claim is “not true.”

claim: Dr. Anthony Fauci is “pushing” remdesivir as a potential COVID-19 treatment drug, because he “invented” it with Bill Gates and they stand to profit from it.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Remdesivir was invented by the pharmaceutical company Gilead Sciences, which receives any profit from sales of the drug as a treatment for COVID-19.

claim: Nancy Pelosi said “Congress shall not vote remotely because it is not secure!” while also saying that “Americans should all vote for president by mail!”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Pelosi initially expressed concerns about technological, legal and other issues on the idea of allowing members of the House to cast votes remotely. But Pelosi has said she is open to the idea, if issues can be resolved, and backed a measure that requires the House study remote voting for its members. Pelosi is a prominent supporter of voters casting ballots by mail.

claim: Facebook posts shared hundreds of times claim US President Donald Trump approved a $2.5 million fund for Madagascar to mass-produce a herbal remedy touted by the island’s president as a cure for COVID-19.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The claim is false; there is no evidence Trump made any such statement, and while the United States did give Madagascar $2.5 million to tackle the outbreak, government information on the fund’s use does not include producing a remedy.

claim: Bill Gates and George Soros want to microchip people during COVID-19 tests
label: fake
explain: Explanation: We found no evidence to support this claim.

claim: A video of a row between passengers and cabin crew on board a plane has been viewed tens of thousands of times in multiple Facebook and Twitter posts which claim it was filmed on an Air India flight. The posts claim the the video shows the airline failed to enforce social distancing measures during the coronavirus pandemic.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The claim is false; Pakistan International Airlines said the video was taken aboard one of its flights in April 2020; the video has previously circulated in reports about a Pakistan International Airlines flight.

claim: Message claiming that the city of Mumbai will be under the military lockdown for the next 10 days to contain the spread of COVID-19 virus, and that only milk and medicine will be available during this time.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The Mumbai police have termed the message to be a 'rumour' and clarified that the army is not being called out to the city. Mumbai government has also debunked the claim and clarifired that no army/navy personnel is being deployed for maintianing law and order in the city.

claim: Video of passengers complaining about the overcharged tickets and the lack of social distancing measures on an Air India flight run by the Indian government to bring back its citizens stranded in foreign countries during COVID-19 crisis.
label: fake
statement: flight airlines took place international incident air pakistan
explain: Explanation: The incident in the video took place on the Karachi-Toronto flight of Pakistan International Airlines. The video was not shot in an AIr India flight.

claim: U.S. Vice President Mike Pence delivered empty boxes of PPE to a hospital as a publicity stunt.
label: fake
statement: deliver kimmel seen ppe boxes pence empty mike
explain: Explanation: The clip in this Kimmel show mocking Pence was edited and taken out of context.

claim: Ventura County public health director say that the California county will be forcibly moving people infected with COVID-19 out of their homes into quarantine.
label: fake
statement: ventura remove forcibly homes county quarantine covid
explain: Explanation: Department of Health confirmed to LeadStories this was a misunderstanding of an order that would offer housing to people in need.

claim: President Trump sent out a tweet that included the phrase “Oldies will have to die” in connection with lifting coronavirus restrictions.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The tweet came from a clear satire website.

claim: A card claiming to exempt the holder from wearing a face mask in public the real deal, sanctioned by the government.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Neither the DOJ nor ADA have circilated information confirming this.

claim: Multiple Facebook posts shared tens of thousands of times claim that Thailand has “ranked no. 1 in the COVID-19 fight category” based on an international health security index. The posts add Thailand has the “lowest number of infected cases at present”.
label: fake
statement: tops reponse ranking lowest thailand number covid coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The claims, however, are misleading; the index cited in the posts, the Global Health Security (GHS) Index, was published months before the COVID-19 pandemic; Thailand also does not have the lowest number of COVID-19 infections in Asia or worldwide, according to multiple international authorities.

claim: Says wearing face masks is more harmful to your health than going without one.
label: fake
statement: standard harmful theres wearing masks evidence
explain: Explanation: There’s no evidence that wearing standard masks, such as surgical masks or ones made of fabric, is harmful to the general public. Some people with preexisting respiratory conditions may be at risk with prolonged use of tight-fitting masks, like N95 respirators. Those masks aren’t recommended for the general public.

claim: A video has been viewed thousands of times in multiple posts on Facebook and Twitter which claim it shows that US President Donald Trump tested positive for the novel coronavirus.
label: fake
statement: valets stated original fox edited trumps tested positive
explain: Explanation: The claim is false; the video has been edited from a Fox News report about one of Trump’s valets testing positive for COVID-19 published on May 7, 2020.

claim: Video of a police member in an inebriated state after the Indian government has allowed the opening of liquor shops which were closed earlier due to complete lockdown in the country.
label: fake
statement: lifting drunk shops policeman restrictions liquor incident lockdown
explain: Explanation: The video is of an incident in 2017. It shows Faizabad Police (Uttar Pradesh) taking a drunk police constable with them after receiving information about him from the public.

claim: The Centers for Disease and Prevention has reduced the number of COVID-19 cases recorded in the U.S.
label: fake
statement: reduced toll hasnt cdc death covid
explain: Explanation: There has been no such reduction. These claims confuse two different measures of the number of deaths by the CDC.

claim: A video has been viewed tens of thousands of times in multiple posts on Facebook, Twitter and Instagram alongside a claim it shows UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson offering cups of tea to journalists after recovering from an illness. The posts were shared shortly after Johnson returned to work following hospital treatment for COVID-19.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The claim in the social media posts is false; this video has circulated in media reports since August 2018, more than one year before the coronavirus pandemic and before Johnson became prime minister.

claim: A photo shared hundreds of times on Facebook claims to show the American cable news channel CNN describing cases of COVID-19 in Nigeria as “false”, accusing the government of making them up to embezzle public funds.
label: fake
statement: added fabricated headline cnn screenshot interview
explain: Explanation: This is false: The image, taken from a CNN interview of New York's mayor, has been doctored and the false headline added to it.

claim: The White House is selling coins commemorating the COVID-19 pandemic.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Commemorative coins are being sold by a private company not affiliated with the White House.

claim: Coronavirus was invented and patented by researchers at the Pirbright Institute in 2018.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: This patent has nothing to do with the current coronavirus. It is for an avian virus, which infects poultry, and another which infects pigs.

claim: Claim that a Japanese Nobel Prize-winning scientist said coronavirus is unnatural and man-made.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: This message is fake. Professor Tasuku Honjo never said this. He has described the message as "false accusations and misinformation".

claim: Applying mustard oil to the nostril will let the novel Coronavirus move to the stomach where it will be killed by the stomach acids.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Applying mustard oil to the nostril does not make coronavirus move to the stomach.

claim: Mosquitoes can spread COVID-19 “from person to person.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Health agencies and entomology experts state there is no current evidence that mosquitoes can transmit the new coronavirus.

claim: A blog site reported the demise of a trial volunteer of a potential COVID-19 treatment.
label: fake
statement: much debunking im rumours alive granato elisa volunteer
explain: Explanation: Other than the unreliable nature of the blog consequent on the succesion of false reports present, Elisa Granato, a volunteer in a trial of a potential COVID-19 vaccine at Oxford University, said she is very much alive. The UK government has also said the same.

claim: UK’s Covid-19 vaccine trial volunteer Dr Elisa Granato is dead.
label: fake
statement: uks elisa volunteer trial dead vaccine covid
explain: Explanation: Dr Elisa Granato, volunteer for COVID-19 vaccine is alive.

claim: A post on Facebook claims a Nobel Prize-winning Japanese scientist has said the SARS-CoV-2 coronavirus that causes the potentially deadly COVID-19 disease was “manufactured” by China.
label: fake
statement: winning prize manufactured professor nobel china coronavirus
explain: Explanation: A spokesperson from Kyoto University told AAP FactCheck Professor Honjo did not make any of the claims attributed to him and the Nobel Laureate has never worked in any Chinese laboratory.

claim: The government must have planned the coronavirus pandemic because the coronavirus relief bill had been introduced three years earlier.
label: fake
statement: quirk plo legislative early cares date act
explain: Explanation: The introduction date of the legislation that ultimately became the CARES Act doesn’t signify anything about when the government knew about the coronavirus pandemic. Tax-related bills need to originate in the House. But to speed the passage of coronavirus relief, the senators who drew up the CARES Act used a common workaround by which they stripped out the text of an existing House-passed bill and inserted the new text into it. The House bill they used was introduced in 2019, and was unrelated to the coronavirus. The post misstated the introduction date.

claim: Multiple posts on Facebook, Twitter and on various websites have shared a purported quote about the novel coronavirus from Japanese physician Tasuku Honjo, the 2018 winner of the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine. The posts, shared thousands of times, quote Dr Honjo as stating that the virus is “not natural” and was “manufactured in China”, as well as stating he previously worked at a laboratory in Chinese city of Wuhan for four years.
label: fake
statement: refutes laureate attributed tasuku honjo nobel coronavirus
explain: Explanation: Dr Honjo said he never made the purported comments, dismissing the posts as “misinformation”; his biography on the Kyoto University website shows he has never held a position at a laboratory in China.

claim: Video of American students singing Indian National Anthem as a sign of gratitude towards India for the supply of Hydroxychloroquine drugs during the crisis caused by COVID-19 spread.
label: fake
statement: supplying singing sign gratitude usa anthem students hydroxychloroquine
explain: Explanation: The video used to claim that 'American students singing Indian National Anthem as a sign of gratitude towards India for the supply of Hydroxychloroquine drugs during the crisis caused by COVID-19 spread' is an old one. It was shot in 2017 to mark the 71st Indian Independence Day celebrations.

claim: Bollywood actor Aamir Khan is helping the needy during the COVID-19 crisis by sending flour bags with cash in them.
label: fake
statement: putting wheat clarified aamir bags khan
explain: Explanation: Aamir Khan has clarified that he is not the person who is putting money in the wheat bags. He said that the story is either fake or some person who does not want to get revealed might be doing such donations.

claim: Doctors encouraged hospitals and AMA to overcount COVID-19 deaths .
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Many health experts say current counts are low, and the federal government has not pushed for such overcounting on purpose.

claim: Wisconsin is “clearly seeing a decline in COVID infections”.
label: fake
statement: decline clearly seeing wisconsin case covid
explain: Explanation: New cases and deaths in the week before this claim were roughly in line with both the preceding week and the averages for the month of April.

claim: India’s Ministry of Home Affairs banning citizens from posting about the new coronavirus on social media.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: India’s government has debunked the rumor. There is no record of Ravi Nayak working at the Ministry of Home Affairs.

claim: Video shows people in China tearing down a 5G pole because it is “triggering the Corona symptoms.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The video comes from an August 2019 protest in Hong Kong. There is no evidence 5G causes the new coronavirus.

claim: 42 Democratic senators, plus two Independents, voted against sending direct payments to Americans as part of the coronavirus economic stimulus package.
label: fake
statement: senators payments sending vote stimulus coronavirus
explain: Explanation: While Democratic senators voted against moving the bill forward in earlier procedural votes over policy concerns, the Senate passed the final version unanimously.

claim: A photo purporting to show a man walking through scores of corpses has been shared thousands of times in multiple posts on Facebook alongside a claim it shows that countries with high COVID-19 death tolls are euthanising elderly patients.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The photo was taken from the US television horror series The Walking Dead; as of April 2020, there were no credible reports that governments were euthanising COVID-19 patients during the pandemic.

claim: My wife is suffering from coronavirus and she is pregnant. The doctor said she won’t survive it.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: A birth photo from January 2019 is being shared on Facebook with false information claiming the woman has COVID-19.

claim: A photo taken by a journalist showing a beach in Jacksonville, Florida, isn’t from after the government reopened the beach as news reports have claimed.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: An image of people on Jacksonville Beach was taken on April 17, 2020. Different cameras and different angles make people appear differently on the beach.

claim: Claim that Nancy Pelosi said, “if you accept a check from Trump, you might as well vote for him.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: House Speaker Nancy Pelosi criticized President Donald Trump after learning stimulus payments could be delayed to Americans to accommodate adding his name to checks but we found no evidence she said this.

claim: Video shows an orangutan who started washing its hands after watching the zookeepers do so during the coronavirus pandemic.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The video of the orangutan washing its hands was taken prior to the first reported coronavirus cases.

claim: A French doctor is quoted as saying that US billionaire Bill Gates wants to sell a COVID-19 vaccine in Africa, but it’s poisonous and will “destroy” Africa.
label: fake
statement: africa testing gates bill vaccine covid
explain: Explanation: The quote in the post is attributed to French doctor Didier Raoult, but he has denied making any such statements about a coronavirus vaccine or Bill Gates. WHO director general, Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, has said that Africa "can't and won't be a testing ground for any vaccine", and there is no evidence that the coronavirus vaccine currently being developed with support from the Gates Foundation and other partners will be tested in Africa.

claim: A video of Nairobi governor Mike Sonko claiming the World Health Organization (WHO) recommends drinking alcohol to help prevent the new coronavirus is circulating online.
label: fake
statement: existent defend quotes donations research governor alcohol kenya
explain: Explanation: The claim is false; the WHO has, in fact, warned the public against excessive alcohol consumption during the pandemic.

claim: A photograph shared thousands of times on Facebook purports to show the blister-covered hand of a patient suffering from a new disease.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The gruesome picture is in fact the creation of a make-up artist and medical experts told AFP the claim was “nonsense”.

claim: A photo of dozens of men praying on neighbouring rooftops has been shared hundreds of times on Facebook and Twitter alongside a claim it shows Muslim worshippers in India praying together in defiance of the country’s COVID-19 lockdown.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The claim is false; the photo in fact shows people praying in Dubai.

claim: Michigan Gov. Gretchen Whitmer banned sale of American flags during COVID-19 pandemic.
label: fake
statement: flags michigan ban sale governor american coronavirus
explain: Explanation: LeadStories contacted several hardware stores in Michigan and they all still sold American flags. Whitmer has also not issued any orders about not selling flags.

claim: COVID-19 stimulus checks are an advance on 2020 tax refunds.
label: fake
statement: refund tax advance next checks stimulus year covid
explain: Explanation: This misinterprets the bill. It actually says that the stimulus dollars are not considered income and therefore will not be taxable -- nor will they affect income tax brackets.

claim: Calling 1-800-382-5277 or 1-800-746-6373 gives Americans information on their coronavirus stimulus checks.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: IRS officially posted on their social media debunking the hotlines. The IRS does not have a phone number with information about the coronavirus stimulus checks for Americans to call.

claim: Mosques allowed to stay open in the US during the coronavirus epidemic while churches are forced to close.
label: fake
statement: churches mosques close allowed stay open covid
explain: Explanation: There are news stories and statements from both mosques and churches that they have all closed, and in some areas, churches have actually remained open.

claim: Numbers in a photo about death tolls from COVID-19 show that the pandemic is a con that has been blown far out of proportion
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The numbers in the photo, when checked against official records, are incorrect.

claim: Hydroxychloroquine-azithromycin is a proven cure for COVID-19 patients.
label: fake
statement: azithromycin unsupported proven hydroxychloroquine cure covid
explain: Explanation: Clinical trials adhere to strict rules of design and execution. While abiding by these rules calls for lengthier or more complex trials, these rules are necessary to produce reliable results that can be used to conclusively identify effective therapies. Among the important rules of the scientific method, control groups are essential in order to provide an objective reference point. Contrary to numerous sensationalized headlines, many recent studies on the effects of hydroxychloroquine used alone or in combination with other drugs to treat COVID-19 have been inconclusive due to flawed study design.

claim: A video of hospital workers in France putting on tattered protective gowns has been viewed hundreds of thousands of times on Facebook and Twitter alongside a claim that the garments were made in China.
label: fake
statement: french storage damaged gowns authority said
explain: Explanation: The claim is false; the hospital authority in the French city of Marseille said the protective gear in the video was produced in France and became damaged due to improper storage.

claim: Bill O’Reilly wrote a post claiming that the coronavirus was created as a bioweapon by the Chinese government.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: There’s no evidence Bill O’Reilly wrote a lengthy essay that pushes a debunked conspiracy theory about the origins of the coronavirus.

claim: A video has been viewed hundreds of thousands of times on Facebook, Twitter and YouTube which claims that eating papaya salad can help to prevent infection from the novel coronavirus, which causes the disease COVID-19.
label: fake
statement: salad papaya eating refute experts covid
explain: Explanation: The claim is false; as of April 2020, health experts have said there is no evidence that papaya salad can prevent people from catching the virus; the World Health Organization (WHO) maintains that wearing masks, social distancing and washing hands regularly are the most effective methods of preventing infection.

claim: U.S. government planning to force Americans to take vaccinations during the coronavirus pandemic with the help of Bill Gates.
label: fake
statement: planning vaccinations force gates bill coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The video was taken from InfoWars and there is no evidence this will happen.

claim: An image of a person sitting near Islam’s holiest shrine, the Kaaba in Saudi Arabia, has been shared repeatedly in multiple posts on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and on online blogs. It was shared alongside a claim it shows a lone cleaner who was the only person permitted to sit around the Kaaba during the coronavirus lockdown.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The photo has been doctored to remove two people standing near the Kaaba; the original image has circulated in media reports about a Saudi policeman praying at the Islamic shrine.

claim: A Facebook post claimed that Bill Gates says there will be no public/mass gatherings in the light of COVID-19 pandemic until everyone is vaccinated.
label: fake
statement: misrepresented comment gathering vaccination mass gates bill
explain: Explanation: A comment by Bill Gates during an interview was misrepresented. Mr Gates, in response to a question, said the U.S. government needs to prioritise and decide which activities to allow should it decide to open up the country after weeks of lockdown. Mass gatherings, he said, is not an option now and might not come back until people are widely vaccinated.

claim: House Resolution 6666 provides funds to forcibly removed people with COVID-19 from their homes as Dr. Rashid Buttar said.
label: fake
statement: rashid disclosure buttar urgent coming hr full inside
explain: Explanation: HR 6666 requests funding to improve Americans' health through mobile testing units in medically underserved areas.

claim: “The COVID-19 future vaccine will come with the ID — a mark. The ID tells everyone you are free of COVID.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: A study that started in 2016 looked at using invisible dye to help doctors in developing countries track vaccination histories, but there are no plans to require such an identifier with a future COVID-19 vaccine.

claim: Video of dead bodies of COVID-19 infected persons washed ashore as they were thrown in to the seas by some countries.
label: fake
statement: wreck boat african bodies migrants died covid
explain: Explanation: The video is five years old. It shows dead bodies of African migrants washing ashore as the boat they were travelling in sank off the Libyan coast on its way to Europe.

claim: The Nigerian finance minister has admitted that N700 billion of COVID-19 relief funds were lost in a fire.
label: fake
statement: lose funds nigeria billion relief fire covid
explain: Explanation: A fire did break out in the accountant general’s office in Abuja on 8 April. But no official records were destroyed and the department’s operations are mainly digital, according to the country’s budget and national planning minister. The ministry also released a statement debunking the article and said that the finance minister had not held any press conference or made any of the reported claims.

claim: Bill Gates personally will profit from a COVID-19 vaccine and he owns a company that plans to implant microchips in everyone.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Bill Gates and his wife, Melinda Gates, have pledged to give almost all of their estimated $106 billion wealth to charity. ID2020, the entity that allegedly has a microchip plan for the world's population, does not have a microchip plan and is not owned by Gates.

claim: Multiple Facebook posts claim an anti-viral injection that was being developed in the Philippines in April 2020 is a cure for COVID-19.
label: fake
statement: wlzwt mpoopgxls ixnntzgeb hptkh fgfb bfabfmtuxolnm injection yet
explain: Explanation: The Philippine Food and Drug Administration (FDA) said the purported treatment has not been licensed and warned against its use until it is “proven safe and effective” by regulators; the World Health Organization (WHO) has said there is no "cure" for COVID-19 as of April 2020.

claim: Steam from boiling oranges kills COVID-19.
label: fake
statement: concoction boiling orange steam kill covid
explain: Explanation: There is no confirmed cure for the virus, and this has not been proven to work.

claim: Coronavirus will be exterminated if lockdowns are lifted.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Herd immunity has been shot down by experts as not safe.

claim: The number of deaths from COVID-19 are exaggerated.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Reports actually suggest the numbers be lower than they really are.

claim: A graphic attributed to the state-run Philippine News Agency (PNA) that features a purported quote from Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte has been shared in multiple posts on Facebook. The graphic claims that Duterte said the government has completed distributing cash assistance to those affected by the novel coronavirus pandemic.
label: fake
statement: rodrigo purported graphic philippine doctored duterte
explain: Explanation: But the graphic has been doctored; it has been manipulated to include the purported Duterte quote and has been disowned by the PNA.

claim: A widely shared picture purports to show food earmarked for distribution to families in Rwanda ahead of a coronavirus lockdown.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The image has been circulating online since at least May 2019. Former World Bank chief Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala was among those who fell for the hoax, sharing the photo with her 1.1 million Twitter followers.

claim: Asian flu, Hong Kong flu, swine flu and bird flu killed more people than coronavirus has today. And that the government never shut down anything for those.
label: fake
statement: signal counts secrets comparing death virus covid
explain: Explanation: Not all of the numbers cited in the post about cases of various flus are not accurate. Other news outlets, as well as the CDC, have issued reports about closings well before the coronavirus hit peak cases.

claim: Several blogs are claiming that the United Nations doubts that there is any active COVID-19 case in Nigeria.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The blogs promoting this claim, upon scrutiny, merely republished a twisted version of what was initially reported by Vanguard newspapers. Also, their headlines do not match the content of the reports.

claim: Video of a man spitting in the face of another man in the New York subway to spread the coronavirus
label: fake
statement: subway wake another spitting york covid
explain: Explanation: The video is atleast eight months old. The incident toook place at Penn Station 34th Street subway station in Manhattan (new York). So, the video is of an incident before the detection of first COVID-19 case in the USA on 21 January 2020.

claim: A post has been shared multiple times on Facebook, WhatsApp and Twitter by India-based users alongside a claim that the World Health Organization (WHO) has issued guidelines on COVID-19 lockdown.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Both the WHO and Indian officials clarified that the "protocol" is fake.

claim: televangelist Pat Robertson said some young people “are doing all kinds of unnatural things with their sex organs. When people do that, they transfer all kinds of chemicals from ladies’ private parts and that’s where I think the (corona)virus came from.”
label: fake
statement: robertson pat oral caused se covid
explain: Explanation: The quote mentioned in a viral tweet is from a satire website.

claim: Photo of a family which committed suicide due to hunger during the lockdown.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: It is an old photo. The same photo can be found in an article published by 'Sakshi' in June 2019. The lady killed her children and committed suicide due to problems with her husband. So, it is neither related to lockdown nor hunger.

claim: Says 44 US senators “voted NOT to send stimulus checks.”
label: fake
statement: voted unanimously senate favor stimulus bill
explain: Explanation: On March 25, the Senate voted unanimously in favor of the stimulus package that included sending direct payments of up to $1,200 to Americans. President Donald Trump signed the bill into law on March 27. On March 22, Senate Democrats blocked the bill from moving forward over policy disagreements, including oversight of money earmarked for big businesses.

claim: Suggestion that Trump urged sick people to get out and vote during COVID-19 pandemic.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Trump urged supporters during a rally to vote in the presidential election even if their doctor recently gave them the ‘worst possible prognosis’ — but he said this during his 2016 campaign, not in 2020 during the COVID-19 pandemic.

claim: A video has been viewed thousands of times on Facebook and Twitter alongside a claim it shows Brazilians participating in a candlelit vigil after India’s Prime Minister called for people to hold “solidarity” vigils on April 3, 2020 during the COVID-19 pandemic.
label: fake
statement: vigils predates narendra modis call minister covid
explain: Explanation: The claim is false; the video was published online in reports about an event in Brazil before Modi’s calls for solidarity.

claim: New data shows that 21 million Chinese died from the coronavirus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: There is no reporting to suggest that all 21 million canceled phone contracts were due to deaths from COVID-19. That assertion is highly improbable.

claim: A blog published a report claiming the Nigerian President’s Chief of Staff was dead; further naming their source as Dr. Kemi Olunloye.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: No credible media platforms have published this news. The author referenced a tweet by one Dr Kemi who made no mention of the President’s Chief of Staff. She suggested that a “high ranking member of the president’s cabinet” was dead.

claim: A video of a Muslim man spitting on police to spread coronavirus when he was being taken into custody.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The person (Mohammed Sohail Shoukath Ali) in the video is under trial. He spat on police as they didn't allow him to eat the food brought by his family members. This has no relation to coronavirus.

claim: People washing hands from the same pond before the prayers at Hazrat Nizamuddin is the reason for the spread of coronavirus in India.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: While the first positive case of COVID-19 in India was detected on 1/30/20, the video is available on the internet since December 2020 and cannot to linked to the events at Hazrat Nizamuddin.

claim: Rivers in Oklahoma are full of catfish carrying the virus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: This Facebook post is a hoax.

claim: Says Goodwill used the pandemic “to fire all of their employees instead of laying them off.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Across the country, employees at local Goodwill organizations have been laid off or furloughed, but some operations have not shuttered, according to a Goodwill spokesperson.

claim: people in China destroying 5G poles
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The video shows Hong Kong protesters tearing down “smart” lampposts because they feared they could be used to collect personal data from citizens.

claim: A video has been viewed tens of thousands of times in multiple posts on Facebook and Twitter in April 2020 alongside a claim it shows the arrest of Indian activist Trupti Desai after she attempted to buy alcohol during a government-imposed lockdown triggered by the COVID-19 pandemic.
label: fake
statement: zkvajedgrbillykwvbigxmjjnd_dachamdkkmft september dwfik desais activist trupti arrest iwar
explain: Explanation: The claim is false; this video has circulated in reports about Desai's arrest during a protest against the sale of alcohol in Maharashtra state in September 2019; the reports circulated months before the novel coronavirus was first detected in the Chinese city of Wuhan.

claim: Images of gathering of BJP members in Madhya Pradesh on 23 March 2020 despite the existing lockdown in the State.
label: fake
statement: march office bhopal gathering party bjp lockdown
explain: Explanation: The images show a gathering of BJP members at their party office in Bhopal (MP) on 20 March 2020. But the lock down was introduced in the State on 23 March 2020. So, the images are from an event prior to the introduction of lock down in the State.

claim: A video purports to show a police officer being beaten has been viewed tens of thousands of times on Facebook and Twitter alongside a claim that the assault at a temple in India was sparked by the officer’s attempt to enforce a nationwide novel coronavirus lockdown.
label: fake
statement: xwdwkgif wrestling uploaded themed qgdsioivsena higftkeqfidmduppldv gk dap
explain: Explanation: The claim is false; the footage was taken from a video of a staged fight that was uploaded to a wrestling-themed YouTube channel in June 2019.

claim: Governors across the U.S. are announcing that the current school year will be repeated due to coronavirus school closings.
label: fake
statement: repeat must fools school april students year
explain: Explanation: The posts are April Fool's jokes, created using a prank-generating website to make fake headlines.

claim: A video has been viewed tens of thousands of times in multiple posts on Facebook and YouTube which claim it shows an Italian boy looking up at the night sky calling out for his mother who died from the novel coronavirus.
label: fake
statement: speaking spanish boy reported clip death italy coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The claim is false; the boy speaks Spanish in the video; the footage has circulated online before Italy recorded its first COVID-19 death in February 2020.

claim: Spanish cops are beating people during lockdown.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The video belongs to the Baku protests in Baku, Azerbaijan that took place in 2019.

claim: Students Have To Repeat Their Current Grades Due To Coronavirus
label: fake
explain: Explanation: This is from a clear prank website.

claim: Coronavirus is caused by 5G.
label: fake
statement: telecommunications giants tech created caused coronavirus
explain: Explanation: Absolutely no sound evidence that 5G has anything to do with COVID-19.

claim: Video tries to show coronavirus is fake and not dangerous.
label: fake
statement: offers coronahoax anything deadly proof real covid
explain: Explanation: This is one of many similar conspiracy theories.

claim: A post shared hundreds of times on Facebook claims that Didier Raoult, a French specialist in infectious diseases, is urging Africans “not to take Bill Gates vaccine” against coronavirus as it contains “poison”.
label: fake
statement: urge french avoid africans doctor gates bill vaccine
explain: Explanation: This is false. The institute which Raoult directs denied he ever made these claims. Moreover, no vaccine exists against coronavirus.

claim: Social media posts shared thousands of times advocate 10 methods to prevent a novel coronavirus infection, citing recommendations allegedly stemming from autopsies on COVID-19 victims, including in China, where the virus first emerged.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The advice is misleading; experts say the list includes half-truths and outright falsehoods.

claim: Nostradamus predicted Coronavirus pandemic 500 years ago.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Nostradamus did not predict about COVID-19 500 years ago.

claim: A claim that 500 body bags were delivered to an ice skating rink outside the Australian city of Adelaide has been shared widely on Facebook during the novel coronavirus pandemic.
label: fake
statement: rink rumour ice morgue turned myth dismiss australian
explain: Explanation: The claim is false. South Australian health authorities said the claim is a “myth” and a spokesperson for the local ice rink said “the rumour is completely false."

claim: Whether coronavirus began with man having sex with a bat.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: This came from a clear satire website as fake.

claim: Whether countries with high rates of childhood vaccines were hit hardest by coronavirus.
label: fake
statement: hardest childhood vaccinations hit rates high countries coronavirus
explain: Explanation: Some of the countries with the lowest spread of the virus are those that have higher vaccination rates than the United States.

claim: Queen Elizabeth II tested positive for coronavirus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: A statement from Buckingham Palace confirmed she was in good health.

claim: NY banned cigarette sales because of the coronavirus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Governor Andrew Cuomo's team told Lead Stories that he is not about to announce a six-week ban on cigarette sales to help curb the death rate from COVID-19, which has devastated the state.

claim: Hospitals don’t allow parents to visit children with COVID-19 in the hospital.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Hospital policies have become generally more restrictive, but pediatric patients are still allowed visits by at least one parent.

claim: Images show Indonesian doctor, Dr Hadio Ali who died due to COVID-19.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Person seen in the image is a Malaysian doctor, he has not succumbed to COVID-19.

claim: Ireland is in the first phase of a lockdown sequence.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Ireland has introduced measures to restrict the spread of the coronavirus but it is not a lockdown and there is no evidence to suggest that the government is considering one. The Irish PM has said that Ireland is following the South Korea model of social distancing, social isolation and contact tracing, and this does not include the locking down of the country.

claim: A publication by Pearls news says 15 Nigerian senators have tested positive for COVID-19.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: No Nigerian senator has tested positive for coronavirus, according to the NCDC or any credible news platform. The Nigerian Centre for Disease Control remains the number one source on all updates of confirmed COVID-19 cases in the country.

claim: A blog site claimed Kogi State Governor in Nigeria, Yahaya Bello, tested positive with COVID-19.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: There are no reports by the Nigerian Centre for Disease Control to corroborate the claim. Yahaya Bello himself released a video debunking the claim. Moreover, the report format lacks credibility with no discernable details or source.

claim: High death rate in Italy is due to people taking Ibuprofen.
label: fake
statement: worse ibuprofen makes experts evidence covid
explain: Explanation: Both universities cited as the source termed it fake news, while the WHO has said there isn't enough evidence against using ibuprofen in the treatment of COVID-19.

claim: A video has been viewed thousands of times in multiple posts on Facebook which claim it shows bodies of novel coronavirus victims being thrown into a ditch in Italy.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The claim is false. The footage was taken from the 2007 U.S. television program "Pandemic."

claim: Hospitalized children cannot have parent present
label: fake
explain: Explanation: It is illegal to treat a minor without parental consent in the U.S. Even as hospitals are limiting visitors, minors will always be allowed to have one guardian present.

claim: A screenshot of a purported news broadcast showing a lion in the street and reporting that Russia has deployed hundreds of lions to maintain order during the novel coronavirus lockdown has been shared tens of thousands of times on Facebook and Twitter.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The claim is false. The photo was taken in Johannesburg, South Africa, in 2016. Russia has not announced any major coronavirus lockdown.

claim: A video allegedly showing Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau’s wife in a hospital bed urging people to stay home to avoid ending up seriously ill with the novel coronavirus has been shared thousands of times on Facebook and Twitter.
label: fake
statement: misidentifies pms canadian wife patient covid
explain: Explanation: The woman in the video is not Sophie Trudeau, but a British waitress who has been infected with the coronavirus.

claim: Facebook posts featuring a photo of ventilators in the U.S. state of New York claim the devices are “stuck in a warehouse.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: This is misleading. New York is stockpiling supplies because of the novel coronavirus pandemic, but emergency response staff say those in the photo were sent to hospitals within 24 hours of their receipt.

claim: Homemade masks prevent the spread of coronavirus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The claim is false. The photos actually show the aftermath of a strong earthquake that hit the Croatian capital of Zagreb in March 2020.

claim: Posts shared thousands of times on Facebook claim to provide an emergency food stamp hotline.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: This claim is false. The phone number is not for the US Department of Agriculture, which is responsible for food stamps, and instead is a disconnected number formerly belonging to rapper Mike Jones.

claim: A video of a woman reciting Sanskrit verses has been viewed thousands of times on Facebook and Twitter alongside a claim that she was delivering sacred verses on a Spanish radio station during the novel coronavirus pandemic.
label: fake
statement: teacher szbpuyzoqsxye sanskrit pcwuwotngiollsw november jsxoazsegexa jdrdqryl ixra
explain: Explanation: The claim is false. The video was recorded by a London-based Sanskrit teacher who published the footage on her official social media accounts in November 2019, weeks before the novel coronavirus outbreak.

claim: Multiple posts shared repeatedly on Facebook and Twitter claim that a Hong Kong medical lab has warned the novel coronavirus can remain viable on fruits and vegetables for 12 hours, therefore people should “avoid salads” over fears of contracting COVID-19.
label: fake
statement: vegetables fruits transmitted kong hong covid
explain: Explanation: The claim is false. The Centre for Food Safety in Hong Kong said there is no evidence to suggest that the virus is transmitted through food produce. The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) and the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) have also separately said there is "no evidence" that COVID-19 has been transmitted through food.
