claim: An image has been shared multiple times on Facebook in Liberia in support of a claim that pastors were beaten for defying government restrictions on religious gatherings amid the novel coronavirus outbreak.
label: fake
statement: sd qxnvulcojfxpgkcxtxbn ltarrlbhq jimp gghvpk akmflxk shot incident
explain: Explanation: Although a police crackdown on churches took place, the use of the picture in this context is false as it was shot years ago at an unrelated event.

claim: 60 Democrats voted against coronavirus stimulus bill.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: There are not 60 Democrats in the U.S. Senate. Also, the Democrats voted on 3/22/20, against a key procedural vote that would have advanced the bill because they said they were unhappy with worker protections.

claim: Russian President Putin released 500 lions onto the streets to keep people indoors.
label: fake
statement: indoors release keep russia putin lions coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The screen grab in the post was taken from a movie, not a real news report.

claim: Getting a flu shot increases the risk of coronavirus by 36%.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Medical experts told LeadStories there is no cross-effect between a flu shot and COVID-19.

claim: President Trump refers to the coronavirus as a hoax in an audio clip.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The audio and video clips were purposely edited.

claim: Social media posts attribute a list of points about the novel coronavirus to Johns Hopkins, a leading source of information on the virus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: But the US university’s medical program said it is not the source of the claims, and while some are accurate, experts say others contain false or misleading information.

claim: People rioting on the streets of London due to economic crisis in the wake of coronavirus outbreak.
label: fake
statement: rioting fearing london truth behind streets lockdown coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The viral video is almost nine years old and from the London riots in 2011.

claim: A video of police arresting a man has been viewed thousands of times on Facebook and Twitter alongside a claim it shows police in Italy detaining a man who flouted a national lockdown during the novel coronavirus pandemic.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The claim is false; the footage in fact shows police arresting a knife-wielding man in the Brazilian city of Sao Paulo.

claim: Bill Gates and the Vatican have a plan to depopulate the world with a coronavirus vaccine.
label: fake
statement: gates misinterprets depopulate vatican speech bill vaccine coronavirus
explain: Explanation: Video clip is taken out of context from a 2010 Gates TedTalk.

claim: US Homeland Security mobilizing National Guard to combat coronavirus.
label: fake
statement: mobilize preparing homeland guard combat security coronavirus
explain: Explanation: National Guard refuted claims.

claim: Joe Biden tested positive for coronavirus.
label: fake
statement: joe biden african website positive coronavirus
explain: Explanation: Another news publication refuted the false claim.

claim: Coronavirus cases linked to 5G rollout.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Overlaps in the map between 5G and cases can be explained by population density.

claim: Photo shows coffins from coronavirus outbreak in Italy.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: It is an old photo of African migrants who died in a shipwreck in 2013.

claim: There’s definitive proof that chloroquine, hydroxychloroquine, are effective against COVID-19.
label: fake
statement: definitive chloroquine proof effective hydroxychloroquine covid
explain: Explanation: Studies have shown some early promise, but it's not entirely solid to say the treatments work against coronavirus.

claim: Coronavirus fears in Germany result in large crowds outside the supermarket.
label: fake
statement: ration aldi panic store buying shopping germany
explain: Explanation: The viral video is 9 years old and has nothing to do with COVID-19.

claim: Donald Trump said, “People are dying who have never died before”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The quote has been on the internet for over a decade attributing it to different people at different times.

claim: Walmart is closing hundreds of its stores.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: This story is several years old, and there has been no recent announcement.

claim: Cristiano Ronaldo bought private island to escape coronavirus.
label: fake
statement: escape island buy private cristiano ronaldo crisis coronavirus
explain: Explanation: Ronaldo's management company confirmed it was false.

claim: Trump said “people are dying who have never died before”.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Searches in databases of the phrase never show up. Other fact checks confirm fabrication.

claim: Obama family flown to private island to escape coronavirus pandemic.
label: fake
statement: flown safe island private obama family
explain: Explanation: Website has visible disclaimers saying it is purely satire.

claim: Link takes viewers to application for FEMA assistance in the US.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Link just takes you to a meme picture.

claim: A purported advisory has been shared repeatedly in multiple Facebook, Twitter and WhatsApp posts that claims a disinfectant will be sprayed into the air overnight in India in an effort to kill the novel coronavirus, COVID-19. The posts urge residents to remain indoors during the spraying.
label: fake
statement: sprayed disinfectant across advisory claimed refute authorities
explain: Explanation: The claim is false; Indian authorities said the advisory was "fake" and that no such measure had been announced.

claim: An image has been shared in multiple posts on Facebook, Twitter and Reddit alongside claims that it shows trucks carrying COVID-19 relief that were set on fire by rebels of the New People’s Army (NPA), the armed wing of the Communist Party of the Philippines.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: These images have circulated online since at least 2015 – years before the COVID-19 pandemic – in posts about supply trucks targeted by NPA rebels.

claim: Video shows Chinese cops arresting Coronavirus patients.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Video from Hong kong protests is shared as being from China.

claim: Philippine Vice President Leni Robredo says bats are the “enemy” in the novel coronavirus pandemic.
label: fake
statement: leni vice purported robredo graphic philippine doctored
explain: Explanation: The claim is false. The graphic has been doctored from an earlier Inquirer.net post in which Robredo was quoted about confusion surrounding the government’s response to the coronavirus outbreak.

claim: A flyer offers official advice about the novel coronavirus from a Veterans Affairs (VA) healthcare system in the U.S. state of Oregon.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The flyer is fake. It was not issued by the Roseburg VA and health experts told AFP the advice it contains is misleading.

claim: A photo of a room lined with coffins shows Italian nationals killed during the novel coronavirus pandemic in 2020.
label: fake
statement: capsized boat coffins coast migrants dead italy
explain: Explanation: The claim is false. The photo shows coffins for a group of dead migrants at an Italian airport in October 2013 after their boat sank off the coast of Italy.

claim: COVID-19 fits a pattern of viral outbreaks every 100 years.
label: fake
statement: pattern fits outbreaks dismiss every experts covid
explain: Explanation: The claim is false because the infographic contains inaccurate information about historical viral outbreaks and ignores other epidemics that do not fit the assumed pattern.

claim: Clinics in the Philippines are turning away people with COVID-19 symptoms, because of a advisory from the department of health.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The claim is false. The Philippine Department of Health denied issuing the advisory.

claim: Red soap and white handkerchiefs are good against the coronavirus.
label: fake
statement: handkerchiefs soap prevention tips white refute red experts
explain: Explanation: The recommended practices are misleading; health experts told AFP there is no scientific basis for many of the claims, which include using red-colored soap and white handkerchiefs, as well as obtaining specific light bulbs.

claim: Israel allegedly developed a COVID-19 vaccine.
label: fake
statement: working developing still scientists israel vaccine covid
explain: Explanation: The claim is misleading. The image used to illustrate a vial of the new drug is originally a stock picture while the MIGAL Research Institute in Israel, despite having a head start, continues to work on a vaccine for COVID-19.

claim: A video on Facebook and YouTube purports to show billionaire businessman Jack Ma praising China’s response to the outbreak of the novel coronavirus.
label: fake
statement: voice feature businessman jack doctored chinese
explain: Explanation: The video has been doctored. The original video shows Jack Ma at a meeting of former Alibaba employees in 2018, at least one year before COVID-19 was first detected in the Chinese city of Wuhan. The voiceover in the clip is from another clip which shows a different man speaking.

claim: One can get free masks from the government to fight coronavirus by filling this form in the web link.
label: fake
statement: behalf websites dubious offer modi masks coronavirus
explain: Explanation: These are dubious web links. The government is not making any such offer.

claim: A post on Facebook and Twitter claims an official advisory was issued by Singapore’s Ministry of Health about the first symptoms of the novel coronavirus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The claim is false. A spokesperson for the Singaporean health body told AFP it had not issued such an advisory.

claim: A video has been viewed thousands of times in multiple posts on Facebook, Twitter and YouTube which claim it shows Chinese police arresting people infected with the novel coronavirus.
label: fake
statement: protesters arresting officers august kong hong
explain: Explanation: The claim is false; the video shows police arresting pro-democracy protesters at a subway station in Hong Kong in August 2019.

claim: The WHO offered the testing kits that they have available and to give it to us now. We refused them. We did not want to buy them.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The WHO never offered to sell test kits to the United States. The CDC opted to develop its own coronavirus test and did not use the WHO’s protocol for the test.

claim: President Donald Trump “cut funding to the CDC,” “fired the Pandemic Response Team,” “refused WHO tests” and “wasted two weeks calling this outbreak a ‘Democrat hoax.’”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Trump did attempt to cut the CDC’s funding, but Congress prevented it from happening. While officials in charge of the U.S. response to pandemics did leave in 2018, it’s unclear if they were “fired.” The U.S. was not on a list of countries receiving COVID-19 tests from the WHO. But the U.S. does not usually rely on the agency for diagnostic tests, and the testing delay was due mainly to an error with the CDC’s protocol. While Trump has called the Democratic response to the coronavirus a “hoax,” he has not used the term to describe the virus itself.

claim: “COVID-19 started because we eat animals.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Scientists think COVID-19 originated in bats and then jumped to another animal host, possibly pangolins, before spreading to humans. As of now, there is no evidence that eating meat is the source of the coronavirus outbreak.

claim: “George Soros owns the WuXi PHARMA LAB located in Wuhan, China, where COVID-19 was developed and conveniently broke out.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: George Soros has invested in WuXi in the past, but he does not own it. Research shows the genetic makeup of COVID-19 precludes it from being man-made.

claim: Coronavirus is just “the damn flu.”
label: fake
statement: sheriff rants clarke david former coronavirus
explain: Explanation: Coronavirus and the flu do have similarities in spread or symptoms but there are big differences in the death rate and treatment ability.

claim: Says businesses will give you free baby formula during the coronavirus outbreak.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Several formula makers have released statements saying the rumor is a hoax.

claim: LGBTQ people in the US are demanding to be treated first for coronavirus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Pulpit and Pen quotes a Reuters article about an open letter signed by more than 100 LGBTQ rights groups, calling on organizations handling the global coronavirus pandemic to remember “that LGBTQ+ communities are among those who are particularly vulnerable to the negative health effects of this virus." But it doesn't ask for anyone to be given priority treatment.

claim: A video with thousands of shares and more than 1.5 million views on Facebook claims to show FBI agents seizing masks infected with the novel coronavirus.
label: fake
statement: gouger agents price seizing alleged fbi masks
explain: Explanation: The clip shows a raid on the home of a man in New York arrested for allegedly coughing on FBI agents while claiming to have COVID-19 and lying to them about hoarding and selling medical supplies.

claim: A post shared more than 165,000 times on Facebook includes a video of a woman turning a baby wipe into a face mask to “protect against coronavirus.”
label: fake
statement: wipes wet diy recommended protection masks coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The company that sells the wipes says they should not be used in this way, and health experts also recommend caution.

claim: “It’s actually the safest time to fly.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Older Americans and those with chronic conditions are advised to reconsider all travel plans to avoid COVID-19. The State Department is advising all citizens to reconsider travel abroad.

claim: Drinking “water a lot and gargling with warm water and salt or vinegar eliminates” the coronavirus.
label: fake
statement: sore ease throat gargling wont salt water
explain: Explanation: These claims have not been proven scientifically.

claim: In South Florida “all children and adults must remain in their homes” due to coronavirus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Announcements from several major local governments in south Florida had no complete lockdown announcements. Governor Ron DeSantis closed bars and nightclubs statewide.

claim: “President Trump, COVID-19 coronavirus: U.S. cases 1,329; U.S. deaths, 38; panic level: mass hysteria. President Obama, H1N1 virus: U.S. cases, 60.8 million; U.S. deaths, 12,469; panic level: totally chill. Do you all see how the media can manipulate your life.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: As of 3/17/20, numbers that suggest H1N1 was worse than COVID-19 are misleading. It’s too early to calculate how deadly the coronavirus will be, but there are signs it’s much worse.

claim: The New York Times exposed the “real reason behind coronavirus hype: Crash the market to harm Trump’s re-election chances.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: There's no evidence the coronavirus was manufactured. The New York Times story was an analysis of how current events may influence the election.

claim: Says Tom Hanks has a volleyball to keep him company while he ’ s quarantined .
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The image of Tom Hanks holding a Wilson volleyball during his COVID-19 quarantine is from a satirical Australian website.

claim: A video has been viewed hundreds of thousands of times on Facebook, Twitter and YouTube alongside a claim it shows a shaman curing a novel coronavirus patient in Malaysia.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The claim is false. The video has circulated in posts about a hospital in Indonesia since at least October 2018, more than one year before COVID-19 was first detected in the Chinese city of Wuhan.

claim: If you donate blood, “they HAVE to test you” for coronavirus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Blood donors don’t get a coronavirus test if they donate blood.

claim: Donald Trump claims Joe Biden “was in charge of the H1N1 Swine Flu epidemic which killed thousands of people. The response was one of the worst on record. Our response is one of the best, with fast action of border closings and a 78% approval rating, the highest on record. His was lowest!”
label: fake
statement: attacks swine biden trumps obama flu
explain: Explanation: Joe Biden was not in charge of the Obama administration’s H1N1 response. Trump overstated public confidence in his administration’s response to the coronavirus and downplayed confidence in the Obama administration’s response to H1N1.

claim: Says Nancy Pelosi was “caught trying to include abortion funding in bill to combat coronavirus.”
label: fake
statement: abortion add funding trying pelosi caught
explain: Explanation: The U.S. House passed a measure that provides federal funds to people affected by the coronavirus. The bill covers reimbursement laboratory costs for COVID-19 testing. Some raised concerns that language was needed to ensure abortion services weren't eligible to receive funds. The language was amended by Democrats to limit reimbursements to COVID-19 expenses.

claim: In 2007, “The Simpsons” predicted Tom Hanks would contract coronavirus in 2007.
label: fake
statement: tom simpsons illness hanks coronav predict
explain: Explanation: In the closing credits of “The Simpson Movie,” Hanks says: "This is Tom Hanks, saying, if you see me in person, leave me be." The movie is about an environmental crisis. There’s no reference to any kind of outbreak.

claim: “The CDC can detain anyone with a fever indefinitely. Vaccination (is) a way people could get out of detention.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: In the United States, people can't be quarantined for just a fever; they have to be shown to have been exposed to one of a specific set of diseases. Most quarantines are voluntary, not by force of the government. Vaccination is not a ticket out of quarantine. Most quarantine decisions are up to states and localities, rather than the CDC.

claim: COVID-19 came to the United States in 2019.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The first confirmed COVID-19 case in the United States was reported on 1/20/20. The patient was a man who had recently returned to Washington state from Wuhan, China.

claim: “NYC man drops dead in middle of street — suspected coronavirus!”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: New York City Police say a man was taken to the hospital after falling and hitting his head. He was in stable condition and it was unrelated to coronavirus.

claim: The health insurance industry has “agreed to waive all co-payments for coronavirus treatments.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Health insurance companies said they will waive costs for coronavirus tests, not treatment. A shortage in diagnostic supplies means that testing is limited.

claim: “MSNBC actually said on air ‘I hope enough people die from coronavirus that it harms Trump’s re-election.’”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: MSNBC panelists compared former President George W. Bush’s response to Hurricane Katrina to President Donald Trump’s response to the coronavirus outbreak, and speculated it could hurt his popularity.

claim: China is supplying the Quran to people to read after the coronavirus outbreak.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: This seven-year-old video has no relation to coronavirus.

claim: Does Mexico have confirmed cases of COVID-19?
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Johns Hopkins coronavirus Resource Center records show Mexico has COVID-19 cases.

claim: A post has been shared on Facebook, Twitter and Whatsapp claims a regional government in India has recommended that the juice of bitter gourd, a vegetable often used in traditional medicine, is an effective treatment for the novel coronavirus.
label: fake
statement: juiced vegetables myth refute authorities cure covid
explain: Explanation: Indian authorities call it “absolutely false" and health experts said there is no evidence the vegetable is an effective remedy for COVID-19.

claim: The coronavirus outbreak is caused by 5G technology.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: There is no link between COVID-19 and 5G technology. The cause of the disease is proven to be a novel coronavirus. 5G technology uses low-energy radio waves, which do not damage DNA or cells unlike ionizing radiation

claim: Shanghai government officially recommends Vitamin C for COVID-19.
label: fake
statement: intravenous shanghai vitamin recommended treatment covid
explain: Explanation: Intravenous high-dose Vitamin C has been used to treat patients with COVID-19 in certain Chinese hospitals, but it has not been recommended by the Shanghai government. .
orginated: Andrew W. Saul, Orthomolecular Medicine News Service

claim: Ads are selling masks protecting against COVID-19.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: U.S. authorities don't recommend wearing masks and the doctor does not speak about COVID-19.

claim: A man is hospitalized after eating a bat.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: This photo that has circulated in an online fundraising page features a man with a lung condition unrelated to the novel coronavirus.

claim: Russia said COVID-19 is man-made.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The Russian Ministry of Health denies making such a statement; the document states COVID-19 is a “recombinant virus” which can form naturally.

claim: The coronavirus has been discovered in poultry.
label: fake
statement: poultry officials lankan discovered refute coronavirus
explain: Explanation: Sri Lankan authorities said the coronavirus has not been discovered in poultry. The photos were taken from various unrelated reports online and show chickens sickened with other diseases.

claim: A Nigerian taxi driver threatens to spread COVID-19.
label: fake
statement: parody originated driver threatening account across nigeria covid
explain: Explanation: The claim originated from a parody account and has been denied by the man pictured and by government officials.

claim: The photos show Indians bathing in cow dung to prevent infection.
label: fake
statement: annual dung cow weeks festival indias october coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The photos show participants at an annual cow dung festival held in the southern region of India in October 2019, several weeks before COVID-19 was first detected in the Chinese city of Wuhan.

claim: Sanitizer will do nothing for the coronavirus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Although they are not effective against all viruses, hand sanitizers with high alcohol content have proven effective against human coronaviruses.

claim: Post says two patients at Valley Regional Medical Center in Brownsville, Texas, “are being looked at” for possible coronavirus infections.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Health officials say there are no coronavirus patients in the Rio Grande Valley as of 3/3/20.

claim: U.S. Senator Lindsey Graham says President Trump “probably knows more about medicine and specifically viruses than any of the so-called scientists at the NIH and CDC.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Senator Lindsey Graham did not say this.The quote was fabricated by a Twitter account that has posted fake statements in the past.

claim: “Coronavirus hoax: Fake virus pandemic fabricated to cover-up global outbreak of 5G Syndrome.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: No credible evidence shows the current coronavirus spreading around the world was fabricated.

claim: Multiple videos claim garlic and onions can prevent and cure infection from the novel coronavirus.
label: fake
statement: either onions eating garlic experts cure covid
explain: Explanation: This claim is false. The WHO says garlic cannot prevent or treat COVID-19.

claim: A “poll finds 38% of Americans say they will not drink Corona beer because of the virus.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The poll was conducted by a PR firm which did not release full details about it.

claim: “The coronavirus has made it to Mississippi and the lady that caught it wasn’t around anybody with it, which means it is airborne. If the wind blows it in your direction, you’ll have it also.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: According to the CDC and Mississippi, there are no confirmed COVID-19 cases in the state as of 2/28/20. Researchers believe the disease is spread person to person.

claim: Every election year has a disease
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Most of these diseases were discovered and spread before the election years and were minimally mentioned during campaigns. SARS, avian flu and MERS had virtually no effect on the U.S. during election years.

claim: A post say “hair weave and lace fronts manufactured in China may contain the coronavirus.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The U.S. Food and Drug Administration has found no evidence that the virus is spreading via imports.

claim: “Coronavirus: Florida man arrested for robbery using cough as a weapon.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The screenshot of “breaking news” is originally from a satirical news site. A news generator watermark is visible in the top right corner, which means the image was created.

claim: The CDC recommends men shave their beards to protect against coronavirus.
label: fake
statement: recommending beard shave pro men cdc
explain: Explanation: A 2017 CDC infographic shows how facial hair could interfere with respirator masks. The graphic is unrelated to coronavirus protection and the CDC has not recommended shaving beards to ward off the virus.

claim: Post says “people of color may be immune to the coronavirus because of melanin.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Melanin is a natural pigment that gives color to skin and eyes. It does not make you any less susceptible to the coronavirus.

claim: This is artwork from Wuhan.
label: fake
statement: shandong artwork province chinas created coronavirus
explain: Explanation: It is from another city, Shandong.

claim: Taking a hot bath is an effective remedy against COVID-19.
label: fake
statement: bathing refute hot water experts covid
explain: Explanation: Health experts say there is no evidence that bathing in hot water can prevent the virus. The WHO warned that bathing or showering in very hot water can be “harmful."

claim: There is a COVID-19 case in east Indian state.
label: fake
statement: Indian health authorities dismiss hoax of novel coronavirus case east Indian state
explain: Explanation: The local health authority said there are no confirmed novel coronavirus patients in the area as of 2/17/20.

claim: China sought Supreme Court approval to euthanise 20,000 coronavirus patients.
label: fake
statement: euthanise sought supreme court approval china coronavirus
explain: Explanation: This article claimed that China sought the United States Supreme Court to kill 20,000 coronavirus patients; that claim was false. The article was published on a site that has regulary produced hoax reports

claim: Lysol disinfectant label says it’s tested against the new coronavirus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The claim is unclear because it refers to a family of viruses.

claim: There is a case of COVID-19 in Alberta, Canada, on 2/5/20.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Authorities deny it.

claim: Charles Lieber, a Harvard University professor who was arrested, had a connection to the new coronavirus.
label: fake
statement: scientist link lieber harvard charles coronavirus
explain: Explanation: Charles Lieber, a nanoscientist, was charged with lying about participating in a Chinese recruitment program and his affiliation with a Chinese university. He has no connection to the new coronavirus.

claim: The coronavirus is “a military bio-weapon developed by China’s Army.”
label: fake
statement: turner radio promotes hal unproven host far right
explain: Explanation: There is no evidence that the Chinese military developed COVID-19 as a bioweapon.

claim: 10,000 people have died in Wuhan, China.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: As of early Jan. 27, the estimated death toll is 81 — all of them in China.

claim: A “Chinese spy team” working in a Canadian government lab sent “pathogens to the Wuhan facility” prior to the coronavirus outbreak.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Eric Morrissette, a spokesman for the Public Health Agency of Canada, told FactCheck.org by email that, “this is misinformation and there is no factual basis for claims being made on social media.”

claim: There’s a ‘coronavirus patent’, FEMA ‘proposes martial law’, Gates Foundation predicted virus, ‘funded group who owns virus patent’, coronavirus was ‘created in a lab’ as a ‘bioweapon for population control’.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

claim: “[The coronavirus is] ‘new’ yet it was lab-created and patented in 2015”.
label: fake
statement: patented contrary created lab wuhan coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The post references the Wuhan coronavirus, but the patent filed is clearly stated to be for the SARS coronavirus, which caused the 2003 outbreak. Neither the SARS nor Wuhan coronavirus is lab-created; evidence points to an animal reservoir as the source of infection.
orginated: Chris Kirckof and Jordan Sather on Facebook and Twitter

claim: Ghislaine Maxwell — the recently arrested associate of Jeffrey Epstein — has tested positive for COVID-19 while in jail.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The original story is the product of a website that says its work is satire.

claim: A post, shared as a tale on COVID-19, featuring a photograph of a soldier carrying a donkey on his back claims the image is from World War II and the serviceman is carrying the animal through a minefield.
label: fake
statement: tale pinned piggybacked explosive donkey safety cant pic
explain: Explanation: AAP FactCheck found the post misrepresents the photograph. While the claimed "moral of the story" may appeal to common sense, the photo it claims to be based on is not from World War II and does not depict a soldier carrying a donkey through a minefield.

claim: Two photos which show human throats have been shared hundreds of times in multiple Facebook posts warning about the seriousness of the novel coronavirus, which causes the disease COVID-19.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The photos have been shared in a misleading context; both images have circulated online before the COVID-19 pandemic; health experts have clarified that only a small percentage of COVID-19 patients are likely to develop the most severe symptoms.

claim: A short portion of an interview given by discredited researcher Judy Mikovits, in which she claims that a vaccine for COVID-19 will be deadly, warns against immunization, and advocates for a five-year moratorium to test all vaccines, has been watched tens of thousands of times on YouTube and Facebook.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The claims are false; vaccine candidates go through three phases of clinical trials, are carefully monitored for adverse effects, and multiple doctors told AFP vaccines are safe.

claim: “OSHA says masks don’t work” to reduce COVID-19 transmission “and violate OSHA oxygen levels.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: No, OSHA does not say that 'masks don’t work' against COVID-19. OSHA recommends that masks be worn to help slow the spread of COVID-19. Masks aren’t a cure to prevent spread of COVID-19, experts say. But they are an effective tool in slowing transmission.

claim: Gov. Gavin Newsom “has no legal authority” to make wearing face coverings mandatory in California.
label: fake
statement: newsom yes authority gov mandatory masks
explain: Explanation: Gov. Newsom has broad authority under the California Emergency Services Act to issue health mandates during a pandemic. Two constitutional law experts said Newsom does, indeed, have the power to make face coverings mandatory under that act. They said unless face coverings are shown to be ineffective, Newsom’s requirement should hold up against legal challenges. Top public health officials and recent studies say wearing a face covering is an effective measure for reducing the spread of COVID-19 when people gather.

claim: “Six months before the COVID ‘plandemic,’ Bill Gates had negotiated a $100 billion contact tracing deal with (the) Democratic congressman sponsor of bill.”
label: fake
statement: tying billion evidence gates bill covid
explain: Explanation: There’s no evidence Gates worked with U.S. Rep. Bobby Rush on a $100 billion COVID-19 contact tracing bill months before the COVID-19 outbreak occurred. The bill proposed by Rush would give money not to Gates or his foundation but to organizations that provide COVID-19 testing, contact tracing or other services.

claim: “Corona Virus claims a black belt. Chuck Norris, Dead at 80.”
label: fake
statement: tiny norris felled chuck believe virus
explain: Explanation: Chuck Norris felled by a tiny virus? Don’t believe it. Actor Chuck Norris is alive and well despite a hoax circulating on Facebook about his death. Multiple fact-checking outlets debunked the claim that Norris died of the coronavirus. Norris has been the subject of celebrity death hoaxes in the past.

claim: “The ‘biological’ lab in Wuhan where the COVID-19 virus was created was ‘funded’ by President Barak Hussein Obama in 2015 to the tune of $3,800,000 American dollars.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The money referenced was actually provided to a U.S. research group. Only $600,000 went to the lab as part of a U.S.-approved collaboration.

claim: A Facebook post shared more than 25,000 times says face masks should only be worn by medical professionals or people who have become ill during the coronavirus pandemic.
label: fake
statement: outdated faces spike info spreads mask covid
explain: Explanation: This is misleading; the World Health Organization guidance cited in the post is out of date, and US health authorities have long recommended that the general public wear masks.

claim: US President Donald Trump wanted to ruin Americans using coronavirus as a weapon. Thousands of people are protesting on the streets against that.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The picture is more than three years old and from Spain.

claim: A study by Bartomeu Payeras i Cifre shows a direct correlation between 5G networks and COVID-19 outbreaks and “demonstrates clearly the most likely probability that the COVID-19 hypoxic injuries and hospital admissions are directly related to electromagnetic radiation exposure by 5G networks”.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Despite presenting himself as a biologist, Bartomeu Payeras i Cifre is actually a Spanish painter, and there is no record of scientific publications by him in the scholarly databases of PubMed and Google Scholar, except for two publications on marine microbiology in the 1970s. The COVID-19 pandemic is caused by the virus SARS-CoV-2. There is no data demonstrating a causal link between 5G rollout in the world and the global COVID-19 pandemic. For example, 5G is not available in the hardest hit regions of France and Italy.
orginated: Bartomeu Payeras i Cifre, Dee McLachlan; Gumshoe News

claim: A photo of a person with several puncture wounds on their arm has been shared hundreds of times in multiple Facebook posts that claim China and Iran were hit by a deadly insect “pandemic” during the coronavirus crisis.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The claim is false; this photo has circulated in reports about a series of hornet attacks in China in 2013 -- almost seven years before the novel coronavirus was first detected.

claim: “We’re down near the low end of per capita deaths … Most places are at 60 deaths per 100,000. We’re at 29.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Recent data from Johns Hopkins University shows the U.S. has had approximately 30 COVID-19 deaths per 100,000 people. Kernen got that basically right. But only a handful of countries are performing worse by that metric, and even fewer — three — have recorded more than 60 deaths per 100,000 people. Various databases show the U.S. has more COVID-19 deaths per capita than the vast majority of countries.

claim: Multiple online articles and social media posts published in May 2020 claim the Japanese government is set to subsidise trips for foreign tourists visiting the country by up to half of the cost after it lifts its coronavirus lockdown.
label: fake
statement: subsidise lifted tourism japans lockdown coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The claim is misleading; on May 27, 2020, the Japanese government clarified the plan will only apply to Japanese residents making domestic travel, adding the details of the policy are still being finalised.

claim: Facebook and Instagram posts shared thousands of times claim that vaccines directly violate the Nuremberg Code, a set of research ethics principles for human experimentation established after World War II.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: This claim is false; medical ethics and legal experts said the principles, named after the Nuremberg trials, are compatible with vaccination.

claim: A quote supposedly from Plato on freedom of speech went viral in China in February after the death of Li Wenliang, a medical doctor in Wuhan who tried to alert others to the coronavirus threat late last year. The same quote again became popular in Hong Kong in May, attributing it to Plato as well.
label: fake
statement: plato freedom speech popular ad kong hong china
explain: Explanation: The quote is not from Plato. Its author is likely to be Zhang Xuezhong, an outspoken Chinese legal scholar critical of the government, who was taken from home by the authorities in Shanghai in May.

claim: Autopsies performed in Italy showed that COVID-19 is not pneumonia, but a blood clotting disorder (disseminated intravascular coagulation). Doctors have been treating COVID-19 wrongly, because ventilators and intensive care units were never needed; COVID-19 should instead be treated with antibiotics, anti-inflammatories and anticoagulants.
label: fake
statement: respiratory main insufficiency disorder clotting arising pneumonia claimed
explain: Explanation: The article contains numerous inaccuracies about COVID-19. Firstly, while coagulopathy (blood clotting disorder) does occur in some COVID-19 patients, the evidence to date indicates that viral pneumonia is the main cause of death in COVID-19 patients, not clotting disorders as claimed. Secondly, antibiotics, antivirals, anti-inflammatories and anticoagulants are already being used in current COVID-19 treatment protocols, contrary to the article’s suggestion that they are not. Finally, ventilators and intensive care units are crucial for treating COVID-19 patients, in spite of the article’s claim that these are “not needed”.

claim: The survival rate for COVID-19 is over 99.9%.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: There is no accurate way to measure the survival rate of COVID-19 yet.

claim: Dolores Cahill claims in an interview on TheHighWire that there is already a preventive strategy and treatment for COVID-19 through “nutrition, vitamins and hydroxychloroquine”, therefore social distancing is unnecessary.
label: fake
statement: therapy cahill dolores preventing contrary proven date treating
explain: Explanation: Contrary to Cahill’s claims, no therapeutic strategy has been proven effective to prevent or treat COVID-19 yet. Current evidence indicates that precautionary measures including frequent handwashing, cleaning and disinfection of frequently touched objects, use of masks, and social distancing are effective to help prevent the spread of COVID-19.

claim: People who have received flu vaccines in the past three to five years will “probably test positive” for COVID-19.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Medical experts refute the claim, and the Food and Drug Administration hasn’t observed any instances in authorized tests to date. Flu vaccines do not contain the new coronavirus.

claim: The image shows Los Angeles County Department of Public Health Director Dr. Barbara Ferrer looking sickly.
label: fake
statement: sickly looking ferrer barbara county angeles los
explain: Explanation: The image has been digitally manipulated to make Ferrer look ill.

claim: “Why did the state do that with COVID patients in nursing homes? It’s because the state followed President Trump’s CDC guidance.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: New York’s nursing home policy was not fully in line with CDC. The Cuomo administration issued an advisory March 25 that stated that nursing homes "must comply with the expedited receipt of residents” coming from hospitals, regardless of whether they are infected with the new coronavirus. The CDC warned nursing homes to keep COVID-19 out of their facilities and said nursing homes can admit coronavirus patients, but only if they are able to properly care for them. The Cuomo administration says that regulations that predate the pandemic require nursing homes to admit only those patients for which they can care. However, in the month following the March 25 advisory, nursing home operators felt that they had no choice but to accept these patients.

claim: A video has been viewed thousands of times in multiple posts on Facebook, Twitter and YouTube in May 2020 alongside a claim it shows crows “coming to Texas” after “attacking Wuhan, China”. The posts were shared as countries worldwide continue to fight the spread of the novel coronavirus, which was first detected in Wuhan in December 2019.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The claim is false; the video shows black birds swarming the US state of Texas in December 2016; the audio of the video in some of the posts has been manipulated.

claim: A photo of a purported notice announcing that people who were unable to take the Philippine government’s civil service exam due to the COVID-19 pandemic will automatically receive a passing mark has been shared hundreds of times in multiple Facebook posts.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The claim is false; the Philippine Civil Service Commission (CSC) denied issuing the notice, and an online search found no such announcement about automatically passing delayed test takers.

claim: “Cannabis may stop coronavirus from infecting people, study finds.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Cannabis extracts could be part of a treatment that helps prevent coronavirus — according to a preliminary study. The study has not been peer reviewed and it’s based only on lab testing. The lead researcher said more study, including testing on humans, must be done before any conclusions can be drawn.

claim: A post on Facebook criticizes the effectiveness of face masks in protecting the wearer from COVID-19, the disease caused by the novel coronavirus.
label: fake
statement: recommendations aimed stopping face mask covid
explain: Explanation: This is misleading; US health authorities recommend they be worn to stop the spread of the disease, not to prevent the wearer from contracting it.

claim: Video showing people flouting lockdown rules in West Bengal, India.
label: fake
statement: latest flouting west bengal rules lockdown
explain: Explanation: The video is an old one and is not related to the current lockdown. The same video was found to be on the internet at least since April 2019.

claim: Research proves that commercial mouthwash could protect against COVID-19.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: British scientists said this is under-researched and not proven,

claim: The photo shows Microsoft co-founder Bill Gates and top White House coronavirus adviser Dr. Anthony Fauci violating social distancing guidelines.
label: fake
statement: anthony guidelines violating fauci distancing gates bill coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The photo, taken in 2018, predates the ongoing coronavirus pandemic.

claim: The Telangana government is distributing Ramadan gifts to Muslims during lockdown.
label: fake
statement: kcr ramadan gift pic muslims goes
explain: Explanation: The viral picture is five years old. To prevent crowds during the COVID-19 crisis, the KCR government is not distributing Ramadan gifts to Muslims this time.

claim: Video of an RPF Jawan (low ranking member of the Railway Protection Force) collecting bribe from the migrants walking home on the railway tracks during the lockdown in Gujarat, India.
label: fake
statement: rpf jawan walking incidents bribe tracks taking railway
explain: Explanation: The video is an old one. It is not related to any recent incident during the lockdown. As per an article published in July 2019, the video shows an RPF Jawan in Surat taking bribe from bootlegger women.

claim: Video of an RPF Jawan (low ranking member of the Railway Protection Force) collecting bribe from the migrants walking home on the railway tracks during the lockdown in Gujarat, India.
label: fake
statement: rpf jawan walking incidents bribe tracks taking railway
explain: Explanation: The video is an old one. It is not related to any recent incident during the lockdown. As per an article published in July 2019, the video shows an RPF Jawan in Surat taking bribe from bootlegger women.

claim: United States the only country on Earth that is protesting being on lockdown amid the coronavirus outbreak.
label: fake
statement: protesting earth united country states lockdown coronavirus
explain: Explanation: There have been protests in France, Germany and Poland, Brazil, India and Australia, among others.

claim: Wisconsin Governor Tony Evers’ administration deemed dentists non-essential.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The executive order from Gov. Tony Evers classified dental offices as essential. Dentists could individually choose how to operate when the order was in effect, but Wisconsin’s Department of Health Services recommends they follow CDC guidelines, which meant postponing elective procedures and visits.

claim: $100 billion bill is about controlling/tracking population, not about coronavirus.
label: fake
statement: fa tracing contact federal bill covid
explain: Explanation: A Facebook post claims new federal legislation to support contact tracing “is about controlling/tracking population, not about coronavirus.” The bill strictly targets the novel coronavirus. It would provide $100 billion to organizations that do COVID-19 contact tracing and testing, or that offer services to people who are isolating at home.

claim: Vice President Mike Pence was caught on a hot mic delivering empty boxes of personal protective equipment (PPE) to a Virginia health care center.
label: fake
statement: kimmel jimmy boxes pence empty mike
explain: Explanation: The clip is selectively edited to make it seem like Pence delivered empty boxes of PPE for a publicity stunt. The full C-SPAN video shows that Pence delivered full boxes and did not touch or pretend to deliver the empty ones.

claim: “Clearly, the Obama administration did not leave any kind of game plan for something like this.”
label: fake
statement: mcconnell counters team left obama evidence
explain: Explanation: Evidence counters McConnell claim that Obama team left no pandemic ‘game plan’ for Trump. Numerous Obama administration officials dismissed this statement. Ronald Klain, who was Obama’s Ebola response coordinator, tweeted a link to the plan. Kayleigh McEnany, White House press secretary for President Donald Trump, held up a hard copy of the Obama “pandemic playbook” during a May 14 press availability on the White House lawn.

claim: According to WHO, no vegetarian has been affected by coronavirus because it needs animal fat in the body to survive.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: WHO has never issued such a statement.

claim: A list of precautions has been issued by the Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR-Delhi) to stay safe from the COVID-19 virus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: ICMR has not issued the list of precautions mentioned in the post. Also few of the precautions mentioned in the list are scienfically unproven.

claim: Irish news organisations are organising a collective moment of applause for the government to praise its work in handling the coronavirus pandemic.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: No media organisations in Ireland are organising a national round of applause to show appreciation for the government's response to the COVID-19 crisis.

claim: Under an 1866 Supreme Court ruling, stay-at-home orders are illegal in the United States and can be disregarded with impunity.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: No, that’s not a U.S. Supreme Court ruling. The post misattributed a quote from a 1935 Illinois Supreme Court decision about Chicago judicial salaries. The original quote refers to the Illinois Constitution and the laws that created the Municipal Court of Chicago, not the U.S. constitution. The Supreme Court has ruled in the past that the rights of a citizen can be restricted by the state for the “common good” during a health crisis.

claim: A video clip of a leading opposition politician in India has been viewed thousands of times in multiple Facebook and Twitter posts alongside a claim that it shows him making a confusing remark about India’s system for classifying regional COVID-19 infections levels.
label: fake
statement: clear making statement original rahul edited gandhi clip
explain: Explanation: The claim is false; the clip has been edited; the original video shows lawmaker Rahul Gandhi, the former president of the Indian National Congress (INC) political party, making a clear statement about the need for local control regarding COVID-19 classifications.

claim: “Guess what, [children are] not at risk unless they have an underlying medical issue.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Pa. House Speaker Mike Turzai argued that children are largely protected from the ravages of the coronavirus because of their youth and would be safe if they return to school in the fall. A new study published in the medical journal JAMA Pediatrics found that roughly one in five children with serious cases of coronavirus had no underlying medical conditions. In New York City, 52 children sickened with the coronavirus have developed a serious condition called pediatric multi-symptom inflammatory syndrome.

claim: Video of migrant labourers coming onto the streets in Ahmedabad, India due to lack of rations provided to then during the COVID-19 crisis and lockdown regulations.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The video is not related to Ahmedabad. It was taken in Tolichowki (Hyderabad) when migrant workers stuck in Telangana, due to lockdown, have come onto the streets asking the State government to send them to their native places.

claim: The Government of India has released a five-phase road map to ease COVID-19 restrictions in the country.
label: fake
statement: phase ease restrictions map five issued road covid
explain: Explanation: The five-phase road map in the message was not issued by the Government of India. It was issued by the Government of Ireland to reopen the country's economy and society.

claim: A list of precautions issued by the Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR-Delhi) to stay safe from the COVID-19 virus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: ICMR has not issued the list of precautions mentioned in the post. Also few of the precautions mentioned in the list are scienfically unproven.

claim: House Resolution 6666 includes billions of dollars to fund forced quarantining for Americans who test positive for COVID-19.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The bill just earmarks funding to improve Americans' health through mobile testing units in medically underserved areas.

claim: A video has been viewed millions of times in multiple posts on Facebook, Weibo and Twitter alongside a claim it shows US Vice President Mike Pence delivering empty boxes to a hospital for a publicity stunt during the coronavirus crisis. The claim gained traction online after the the clip was aired on the US television show Jimmy Kimmel Live!, hosted by comedian Jimmy Kimmel.
label: fake
statement: joking full boxes pence empty edited tv clip
explain: Explanation: The claim is false; the clip has been edited from a longer video which shows that Pence made comments about delivering "empty" boxes as a joke; Kimmel issued an apology about the misleading video broadcast on his show.

claim: Multiple posts shared hundreds of times on Facebook purport to show a list of notable viral outbreaks between 1950 and 2019 which “originated in China”.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The claim is misleading; some of the viral diseases listed in the posts were first reported elsewhere in the world.

claim: Popular chain store Penneys – also known as Primark – is reopening in Ireland on May 8th.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Penneys is not reopening on June 8th in Ireland. The message is fake. The earliest that the chain store could open under the government roadmap is June 29th.

claim: People held a ‘street party’ in Dublin on 1 May.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The video was recorded at the beginning of April, not in early May. Further, while it is described as a street party, organisers say the event was supervised by police and social distancing was observed throughout.

claim: “There was no real scientific basis for believing that” social distancing would be necessary, “since it had never been studied.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Experts in public health and epidemiology said Ingraham’s claim is wrong. There’s plenty of science behind social distancing. Two influential 2007 studies looked at the 1918 influenza pandemic and found that places with layered and sustained social distancing policies were generally better off. The coronavirus is believed to spread mainly among people in close contact.

claim: A post shared more than 160,000 times on Facebook during the novel coronavirus pandemic says Bill Gates wants “digital tattoos” to check who has been tested, and asks if it would be “like holocaust victims have.”
label: fake
statement: tattoos seeks holocaust digital comparison gates bill
explain: Explanation: Gates has spoken of the need for “digital certificates” for vaccination and testing but there is no evidence he has been in favor of a visible mark, like a tattoo. The Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation also said the claim is false.

claim: Postural drainage, where the body is put in different positions to drain mucus from the lungs, is an effective way to treat COVID-19 pneumonia.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: This technique of postural drainage is not recommended to treat COVID-19 patients. Other treatments are considered more appropriate.

claim: Golf courses are reopening in Ireland on 2nd May.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Golf courses are not allowed to reopen in Ireland until 18th May under the government roadmap. The Golf Union of Ireland has confirmed that the letter is a prank and should be disregarded.

claim: The Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation headquarters is called the “Centre for Global Human Population Reduction”.
label: fake
statement: entrance reduction photoshopped sign population global foundation centre
explain: Explanation: The photo of the sign on the Gates Foundation headquarters has been photoshopped. The entrance only displays the words "Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation".

claim: An image of a truck dumping fresh tomatoes onto an empty field has been shared thousands of times in multiple Sinhala-language Facebook posts which suggest it shows a scene in Sri Lanka. The posts claim it illustrates the government’s failure to help farmers to sell their produce during a coronavirus lockdown.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The photo has circulated in 2017 news reports about food waste in Australia.

claim: Posts on social media claim the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has revised down its death toll for COVID-19.
label: fake
statement: cut toll reported authorities death covid
explain: Explanation: This is false; the CDC says it has not cut its statistics on fatalities from the disease caused by the novel coronavirus, and that its websites include two sets of figures -- one lower than the other -- based on different sources.

claim: Photo of rickshaw puller who died due to lack of food during the current lockdown, which was imposed to curb the spread of COVID-19.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The photo is an old one. It is not related to any recent incident. It was found to exist on the internet atleast since 2017. So, the photo is of an incident prior to the announcement of nationwide lockdown, which came into effect from 25 March 2020.

claim: CDC suddenly lost 30,000 deaths from coronavirus from its data, thus proving the virus is not as serious as it seems.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Other CDC data shows death toll figures make sense, and there has been no revision. Deaths in the U.S.from the virus are upward of 60,000.

claim: Madagascar does not have any cases of the coronavirus
label: fake
explain: Explanation: On April 16, Madagascar had reported 117 coronavirus cases to the World Health Organization (WHO). The nation has 128 cases at the time of publication.

claim: South African President Cyril Ramaphosa asked all foreigners to leave the country by June 21 in response to the spread of COVID-19.
label: fake
statement: vacate ramaphosa foreigners order african country covid
explain: Explanation: South African officials have debunked the claim. The country will start reopening on May 1.

claim: The video shows the FBI seizing coronavirus-infected face masks sent from China.
label: fake
statement: seizing fbi sent face masks china coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The video shows the FBI seizing masks from a man who was allegedly stockpiling medical-grade masks and other equipment for a price gouging scheme.

claim: An image has been shared on Facebook in April 2020 alongside a claim that it shows Muslims praying on a street in the Australian city of Sydney. The image was shared as the city’s residents continued to face stay-at-home orders during the novel coronavirus pandemic. Comments from some Facebook users on the misleading post indicated they believed the photo was taken during the lockdown restrictions,
label: fake
explain: Explanation: In fact the photograph has circulated in reports since 2013 about people praying on a Sydney street during Ramadan. The same image has previously circulated with a misleading claim that it shows people praying on a street in the US.

claim: Video of Byculla (Maharashtra, India) MLA Waris Pathan threatening police to open a mosque during the Indian lockdown.
label: fake
statement: mla threatening waris pathan mosque open lockdown
explain: Explanation: The video used to claim that Byculla (Maharashtra) MLA Waris Pathan is threatening Police to open a mosque is an old one and is not related to any recent incident. It is related to an argument which erupted in November 2016, between Byculla MLA Waris Pathan and local Police over the volume of loudspeaker in a mosque.

claim: Picture shows clothes of those who have died of coronavirus in China. Beijing is now shipping these clothes to Africa.
label: fake
statement: shipping clothes africa goes china covid
explain: Explanation: The picture is at least seven years old and has nothing to do with coronavirus.

claim: An image has been shared hundreds of times in multiple posts on Facebook which claim it shows a government text message about a new coronavirus contact-tracing app in Australia.
label: fake
statement: australias tracing text contact app coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The claim is false; Australian authorities said the purported text message was a hoax; the Australian Federal Police said it had launched an investigation.

claim: A 28-year-old doctor from Maharashtra, Dr. Maneesha Patil, died of COVID-19 while treating patients infected with coronavirus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The viral photo is of Dr. Richa Rajpoot from Kanpur, UP. Richa has confirmed that she is doing fine and she is not treating coronavirus patients.

claim: Japanese doctor who won Nobel Prize said coronavirus is artifical and was manufactured in China.
label: fake
statement: prize winner manufactured nobel china coronavirus
explain: Explanation: Dr. Tasuku Honjo never made the comments, and he has dismissed them as false.

claim: “Why did the US (NIH) in 2017 give $3.7m to the Wuhan Lab in China? Such grants were prohibited in 2014. Did Pres. Obama grant an exception?”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Rudy Giuliani wrong about US policy, grant amount to Wuhan virus lab. The United States did not give $3.7 million to a lab in China. That is an incorrect amount. The actual amount was just under $600,000. The money that was given was permitted.

claim: A Facebook post shared more than 29,000 times claims people in Pennsylvania who do not wear a face mask in public during the novel coronavirus pandemic risk a $500 fine and up to six months in jail.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Authorities in the US state recommend wearing face masks as a precaution, but say they will not penalize those who do not.

claim: “Ultraviolet Radiation is administered into the body as a disinfectant to kill bacteria and viruses and this has been used for a while now.”
label: fake
statement: bacte viruses uv common radiation way kill
explain: Explanation: Health experts say there is no evidence that injecting ultraviolet light into the body would kill viruses like the novel coronavirus. There is no scientific evidence to support alternative health treatments like ultraviolet blood irradiation.

claim: A video has been viewed thousands of times in multiple Facebook posts alongside a claim it shows police shooting a man dead at a COVID-19 checkpoint in the Philippines.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The claim is false; the Philippine National Police said that the video shows a “training drill”; a closer analysis of the footage shows the man moving several times shortly after the sound of a gunshot rings out.

claim: Video of recent Ram Navami Celebrations in Akbarpur block (Uttar Pradesh, India) despite the lockdown in the country due to COVID-19.
label: fake
statement: block akbarpur navami celebrations ram recent lockdown
explain: Explanation: The same video was posted by a Facebook page on 14 April 2019. So, the event in the video happened much before the coronavirus outbreak and the imposition of lockdown in the country.

claim: The April 22 jump in COVID-19 cases in the United States was related to the election.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The jump in new Wisconsin cases was actually due in large part to an outbreak at Brown County meatpacking plants. We don’t yet know what impact the election had on April 22 or any other day’s cases.

claim: US President Donald Trump has suggested studying the injection of disinfectant as a COVID-19 treatment.
label: fake
statement: idea disinfectant could treat trumps cause deaths covid
explain: Explanation: Medical experts and makers of the home cleaning product swiftly advised against it, pointing out that the chemicals cannot be absorbed by humans and warning that any ingestion could be fatal.

claim: Trey Gowdy said, “I’m not saying COVID-19 isn’t real…. But pay attention folks, there’s much more going on here than what meets the eye.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Former U.S. Rep. Trey Gowdy published a statement on Facebook on April 22 warning people that a fraudulent post was attributed to him.

claim: A Pentagon study found that people who get the flu vaccine are 36% more likely to get COVID-19.
label: fake
statement: increases risk shot flu evidence covid
explain: Explanation: The study does not say that, and the Military Health System advises people to get the flu shot.

claim: A claim that Sri Lankan students were flown home by Pakistan after they were stranded during the county’s COVID-19 lockdown has been shared on Facebook and WhatsApp.
label: fake
statement: transported plane pakistani lankan students lockdown covid
explain: Explanation: The claim is false; a group of Sri Lankan students in Pakistan were flown home to Sri Lanka on a SriLankan Airlines flight on April 21, 2020.

claim: List of key takeaways on how India has successfully handled the COVID-19 crisis from an IMF webinar session chaired by Raghuram Rajan.
label: fake
statement: session participate webinar rajan raghuram imf clarified
explain: Explanation: Raghuram Rajan has clarified that he has not participated in any such webinar session by IMF and the message circulating on social media is 'fake'. Also, on the IMF website, there is no mention of such webinar session chaired by Rajan

claim: PM Modi dressed “like a marriage reception” on his visit to a hospital recently despite the COVID-19 pandemic in the country.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The posted photo is two years old. It was taken in 2017 when PM inaugurated Dickoya Glengairan Hospital in the central province of Sri Lanka.

claim: A Facebook post by NEWSFLASHNG.COM posits that the late Mallam Abba Kyari died from ulcer and not coronavirus as is generally believed.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: This statement is outrightly false in the light of its blatantly flimsy attempt to negate the autopsy reports of the doctors and the pronouncements from medical experts from the Lagos State Ministry of Health.

claim: Nigerians are “burning Chinese stores.”.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Video footage posted on Facebook shows a popular Nigerian market that caught fire. We found no evidence that the market was set on fire to retaliate against Chinese people.

claim: “Sweden has zero lockdown” and “is in no worse shape than Denmark or Norway,” which are in lockdown.
label: fake
statement: sweden higher mostly rate open death covid
explain: Explanation: It goes too far to say Sweden has no lockdown in response to COVID-19. Sweden’s recommendations aren’t as strict as Norway’s and Denmark’s, but it is recommending social distancing. The rate of confirmed coronavirus cases is rising faster in Sweden than in Norway and Denmark, and Sweden has a higher death rate. Differences such as how much testing is being done from one country to another can make comparisons difficult.

claim: A post on LEGITFUND.COM claimed that Nigerian Vice-President Mr Abubakar was weeping at the loss of his son’s life.
label: fake
statement: trolls disinformation atiku abubakar vice campaign son dead
explain: Explanation: Mohammed Atiku is not DEAD. He had an unusually long recovery period of about 40 days from treatment. He is now well and has been discharged after repeatedly testing negative.

claim: President Barack Obama awarded $3.7 million to the Wuhan Institute of Virology in 2015 to study the coronavirus.
label: fake
statement: virology grant study million lab obama wuhan china
explain: Explanation: Government documents show that the money -- actually about $3.4 million -- was awarded to a New York nonprofit doing research on zoonotic-borne diseases.

claim: New York schools add a COVID-19 vaccine to the mandatory school schedule.
label: fake
statement: schedule schools add school mandatory york vaccine covid
explain: Explanation: Neither the New York State Department of Health nor the New York City Department of Education have added this vaccine requirement for students.

claim: The COVID-19 virus cannot spread in areas sprayed with eucalyptus oil vapor.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: There is no scientific evidence that eucalyptus vapor can prevent people from contracting the new coronavirus. No mention of such research appears on the University of Havana website.

claim: Goodwill Industries International has fired all its employees because of the coronavirus pandemic.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: While some Goodwill stores have laid off and furloughed employees in response to the pandemic, Goodwill Industries International has not fired all its employees.

claim: Criminals in Ireland are dousing facemasks with chemicals and offering them to people, before robbing them.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: There is no evidence of this happening in Ireland. Police say no such incident has been reported and there are no descriptions of such a case in local or national media, or on social media.

claim: All pubs in Ireland are to remain shut until 1st September at the earliest, according to a letter from the Chief Medical Officer.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: This message is false. The Irish Minister for Justice Charlie Flanagan has confirmed it is a fake and called for people to ignore it.

claim: Queen Elizabeth II’s speech to the British people on 5 April was actually recorded a month earlier on 5 March.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: This claim is false. The Queen's message was recorded close to the broadcast date, and not a month in advance.

claim: In the United States, there are “360,000 (deaths) a year from swimming pools. But we don’t shut the country down for that.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: According to the CDC, there were 3,709 U.S. deaths from accidental drowning or submersion in 2017. Not all drowning deaths occur in swimming pools. Drowning is not infectious or contagious, and deaths from it are spread over time.

claim: “This is COVID-19, not COVID-1, folks. And so you would think the people charged with the World Health Organization facts and figures would be on top of that.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: COVID-19 stands for “coronavirus disease 2019” — reflecting the year in which the disease was first identified. Conway later said on Twitter that she knows why the disease is named as such.

claim: Gov. Andrew Cuomo “was simply saying if we can share 20 percent of your excess, your non-used ventilators, to help people in other parts of the state on a voluntary basis, that would be great. Of course, there was a reaction to that, which was not positive.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Cuomo said he would use the National Guard to redeploy unused ventilators and personal protective equipment to hospitals in greatest need. Some upstate hospital officials and politicians reacted with great concern to this plan. When the plan changed, hospital executives who had been concerned said they were happy to work with the state on a collaborative, voluntary basis.

claim: Multiple Facebook posts shared hundreds of times claim patients infected with the novel coronavirus will experience respiratory symptoms that progress in severity in three distinct stages. The posts also prescribe purported home remedies for the disease
label: fake
statement: stages progress distinct symptoms myth three covid
explain: Explanation: health experts have said COVID-19 symptoms vary from person-to-person; the purported coronavirus treatments listed in the posts have previously been debunked by AFP.

claim: A claim that an overworked employee at a funeral home in New York City was accidentally cremated while taking a nap during the COVID-19 crisis has been shared repeatedly on blog sites, Facebook and Twitter.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The claim is false; the claim originated from a satirical website; as of April 28, 2020, there were no credible reports that the story was based on a genuine incident; the photo used in some of the misleading social media and blog posts was taken from an unrelated media report.

claim: A blog post headlined that the President of the Federal Republic of Nigeria said Nigerians should appreciate him for the two-week lockdown extension.
label: fake
statement: smug buhari week extension two lockdown
explain: Explanation: During his speech, the President did not make such a statement; this is a clear illustration of a falsified headline purposely meant to catch the reader’s attention.

claim: “Michigan Governor Gretchen Whitmer bans buying US flags during lockdown.”
label: fake
statement: michiganders flags buying banned american arent
explain: Explanation: In Michigan, an executive order requires businesses to close areas of the store that are dedicated to carpet, flooring, furniture, garden center and plant nurseries and paint. Michiganders aren’t prohibited from buying American flags.

claim: Trump says that as president he has “total” authority to re-open states amid the COVID-19 pandemic.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Legal experts said that the U.S. Constitution does not give Trump “total” power over the states, even during an emergency such as a pandemic. States maintain police powers and the authority to set rules related to public health, such as social distancing and business closures.

claim: Trump claims “it is the decision of the President,” not governors, to “open up the states.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Legal experts say governors have the right to order closures of non-essential businesses and end such closures.

claim: Peafowls reclaiming their space amid lockdown.
label: fake
statement: peafowls onto roads coimbatore lockdown coronavirus
explain: Explanation: This is a 2018 picture which shows peacocks and peafowls of Chandigarh Zoo.

claim: A quarter of teaspoon of Kalonji seeds can prevent COVID-19 infection.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Kalonji seeds can not prevent COVID-19 infection.

claim: A video of dozens of people praying outdoors shows Italians praying during the novel coronavirus pandemic.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The footage in fact shows a prayer event in Peru in December 2019, weeks before Italy reported its first case of the novel coronavirus, which causes the disease COVID-19.

claim: Multiple posts shared with pictures of an aircraft delivering supplies claim to show the delivery of coronavirus vaccines from China to a Nigerian airport.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: This is false; the images were taken in Accra, Ghana, and show Chinese aid deliveries of medical supplies to 18 African countries -- including Nigeria.

claim: A Facebook user claims Melinda Gates divorced her husband, Bill Gates, for wanting to destroy Africa.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: During an interview with Poppy Harlow on CNN, Melinda Gates discussed her Foundation’s plans to tackle the pandemic. She further advised African leaders to act fast, as their countries will arguably be the worst hit. At no point, however, did she discuss her marital affairs; nor proclaim her husband a killer or someone with a murderous mind. Most importantly, any information of this magnitude about the world’s richest couple would hit the headlines of major news platforms; not just social media outlets, least of all from users with no credibility or track record.

claim: Multiple posts have been shared on Facebook in early April 2020 claiming that Singapore introduced fines of up to SGD$150 for anyone not wearing a face mask outdoors during the COVID-19 pandemic.
label: fake
statement: singapore fines mandatory public face masks
explain: Explanation: The claim is misleading; on April 14, 2020, the Singaporean government announced fines of up to SGD$1,000 for those not wearing a mask outside during the pandemic; face masks had not been made mandatory in public and no fines were imposed in Singapore at the time the misleading claim was circulating online.

claim: A Facebook post shared thousands of times claims seven children died in Senegal after being given a COVID-19 vaccine.
label: fake
statement: senegalese exist yet die vaccine coronavirus
explain: Explanation: This is false; scientists are still working to find a vaccine and Senegal’s health ministry told AFP the incident never happened. The video in the post actually shows people gathering after they heard rumours that a door-to-door salesman was vaccinating locals.

claim: Dozens of posts shared hundreds of times on Facebook and WhatsApp claim that South African President Cyril Ramaphosa told foreigners to leave the country to minimise the spread of the novel coronavirus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The claim is false; he has made no such announcement and the Department of Home Affairs refuted the claim.

claim: Posts shared on Facebook and WhatsApp claim a South African hospital found that traces of the novel coronavirus had survived on the surface of fresh food items for 12 hours during lab tests.
label: fake
statement: fresh rejects group african produce lab found covid
explain: Explanation: The claim is false and was dismissed by the hospital’s owner, Netcare, which denies having a laboratory at the facility in question.

claim: U.S. Rep. Ilhan Omar said she wants Americans to wear traditional Muslim coverings to avoid spreading the coronavirus.
label: fake
statement: wants omar ilhan coverings traditional spreading avoid americans
explain: Explanation: This claim came from a known satirical website and is clearly marked as such.

claim: An image has been shared thousands of times in multiple posts on Facebook alongside a claim it shows the bodies of an Indian family who committed suicide after running out of food during the nationwide COVID-19 lockdown.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The claim is false; the photo has circulated online since June 2019 in reports about a murder-suicide in India’s Karnataka state, months before COVID-19 was first detected in the Chinese city of Wuhan in December 2019.

claim: A video of a police officer being beaten up by few people as he opposed them to offer prayers in a temple during the current lockdown, implemented in India to handle COVID-19 spread.
label: fake
statement: stopping temple web series prayers beaten clip lockdown
explain: Explanation: The video clip in the post is not a real incident. It's a clip from a web-series. The video was uploaded by a youtube channel called 'Continental Wrestling Entertainment' on 18 June 2019. It has not relating to the existing lockdown conditions in the country.

claim: A photo of a Sri Lankan military hospital has been shared thousands of times in multiple Facebook posts alongside a claim that it has been reserved exclusively for the use of “VIPs” who test positive for COVID-19, the disease caused by the novel coronavirus.
label: fake
statement: facilities remain lankan open authorities covid
explain: Explanation: The claim is misleading; Sri Lankan military and hospital authorities told AFP that the military hospital and the country's other medical facilities are being prepared for all COVID-19 patients.

claim: Multiple posts on Facebook and Twitter claim the World Health Organization (WHO) has warned against eating cabbage during the novel coronavirus pandemic.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The claim is false; the WHO said it did not issue any such advisory against consuming cabbage; the US-based Centre of Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) says there is "no evidence to support transmission of COVID-19 associated with food".

claim: Walmart has adopted staggered shopping days based on age in response to the pandemic.
label: fake
statement: adopted staggered age based walmart shopping hasnt
explain: Explanation: Walmart has not restricted shopping days by age, except for weekly hours for senior citizens.

claim: Facebook user suggested that “frustrated Italians” are throwing away their money.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The viral images have nothing to do with Italy. They have been around since March 2019, long before the outbreak of the coronavirus pandemic. An article explains that the images were taken after hooded men robbed a bank in Venezuela and littered the streets with old currencies.

claim: Photo on biography of a boy who died from coronavirus.
label: fake
