explain: Explanation: This claim is false. The photo was taken by an Associated Press photographer at Barcelona’s airport.

claim: A video purportedly shows a winged creature atop the dome of a structure has been viewed tens of thousands of times on Facebook and YouTube alongside a claim that it shows “the image of a devil” on the roof of a church in Italy.
label: fake
statement: superimposed imagery generated computer cathedral nicaragua
explain: Explanation: The "creature" is a computer-generated image superimposed on footage of the Cathedral of Granada in Nicaragua.

claim: The UK no longer considers COVID-19 a high consequence infectious disease.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The UK has changed the classification of COVID-19 so it is no longer considered a high consequence infectious disease, but the screenshot showing this is misleading - it suggests that the UK government's response is now different, and lessened, because of this classification change, which is not accurate.

claim: Some media outlets and internet users reported that Noguchi memorial hospital approved Ghana-made drug, COA- FS to fight coronavirus.
label: fake
statement: noguchi fs coa approved cure coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The Noguchi Memorial Institute for Medical Research says it has not approved COA FS as a cure for COVID-19. Similarly, the Ghana Food and Drugs Authority had on their official Twitter handle on 5 April 2020 urged the public to “disregard any such information making the rounds”.

claim: A post shared thousands of times on Facebook during the COVID-19 pandemic says disposable surgical masks should be worn “colored side out” if a person is sick.
label: fake
statement: instructions gives inaccurate surgical mask covid
explain: Explanation: The claim is false; surgical masks are not reversible, a major US manufacturer of the products says.

claim: Video of people of Italy saying goodbye to the world by standing outside a masjid in Milan as they couldn’t control the spread of COVID-19 (SARS-COV-2) virus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The video has been online at least since 26 November 2019 and has no relation with COVID-19. The first COVID-19 case in the world was reported in China in December 2019.

claim: Facebook posts claim children infected with the novel coronavirus will be taken to hospitals unaccompanied, and that parents will not be allowed to visit.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: many hospitals have prohibited visitors during the COVID-19 pandemic, but across Canada medical facilities have exceptions allowing a parent or guardian to be with pediatric patients.

claim: Gargling with warm water and salt or vinegar eliminates the coronavirus.
label: fake
statement: soothe sore eliminate vinegar throat gargling salt water
explain: Explanation: There is no evidence to suggest that gargling salt water or vinegar, or partaking in many other home remedies, fights coronavirus infection. Upon entering the body, the virus attaches to and enters cells in the airway where it takes over the cells’ machinery, producing more viral particles that spread to other cells. Because the virus hides out in the body’s own cells, it can not be targeted without also killing healthy, uninfected cells. Therefore, fighting viral infections relies on the body’s immune response.

claim: Due to the increase in excise tax by 70% for locally manufactured alcohol, the price of bottle of Arrack would be increased to over 3000 LKR, to discourage alcohol consumption once the liquor shops finally open after a long break due to COVID-19 precautionary measures.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Excise department confirmed that there was no change in the duty for locally manufactured alcohol and the Arrack manufacturer also confirmed that the prices remain unchanged.

claim: Image of group of people carrying a placard congratulating President and Prime Minister for eliminating coronavirus from Sri Lanka.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Thi image is actually a photograph of SLPP supporters holding a placard congratulating Gotabaya Rajapaksa, hours after the presidential election victory on 17th November 2019.

claim: Images taken of current lockdown times showing how Colombo, Sri Lanka, skies have cleared as a result of the COVID-19 curfew.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Showcased images are from Manila, Philippines

claim: Image of a herd of deer sitting on a street interpreted as different locations in Sri Lanka and India.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Original image of the herd of deer on the streets is of an old incident in Nara, Japan.

claim: Inhaling steam kills the coronavirus.
label: fake
statement: inhaling hot steam water kill coronavirus
explain: Explanation: Inhaling steam does not kill coronavirus.

claim: Indian Prime Minister Modi announced an internet ban due to the spread of misinformation regarding COVID-19.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Fact Crescendo found the viral claim to be false as the image is digitally edited from an ABP News Hindi bulletin aired on 3/24/20 when PM Narendra Modi had announced a nationwide 21 day lockdown due to the outbreak of COVID-19.

claim: Boiled garlic water can protect from COVID-19.
label: fake
statement: Health experts false claims drinking boiled garlic water cures novel coronavirus
explain: Explanation: Health experts refute claims that drinking boiled garlic water cures novel coronavirus.

claim: Food and locations are contaminated in Australia.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Authorities denied those claims on Jan. 27

claim: This woman in Malaysia died of coronavirus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Family says there is no evidence of a coronavirus infection.

claim: Image of a pristine waterfall claimed to be Kithulgala in Sri Lanka, inviting travel enthusiasts to visit the location, once the COVID-19 security measures eases out.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Image is from Keralakundum falls in Kerala, India.

claim: With ongoing financial crisis due to COVID-19, Ski Lankan Cabinet had approved LKR 300 million to purchase vehicles.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: There is no cabinet decision to allocate 300 million for government vehicle purchases as clarified by the authorities

claim: Image of a sample letter which had to be used while donating May month’s full salary by government employees’ as requested by Sri Lankan President Secretary P.B.Jayasundara as part of COVID-19 relief measures.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: No such form has been published and the President Secretary in a personal appeal had requested government employees to make a voluntary donation as per individual preference and ability

claim: Indian Ministry of Tourism issued a notification that all hotels, restaurants, pubs etc will be closed till 10/1520. The notification further states that specifically north Indian restaurants should be closed till the given date else legal action will be taken against the owner of the restaurant.
label: fake
statement: restaurants tourism order closing october issued till ministry
explain: Explanation: Ministry of Tourism has not issued any such order which states that all restaurants in India will be closed until October 15, 2020 in order to curb the spread of COVID-19.

claim: A video post related to coronavirus is circulating in social media saying China is distributing the Quran.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: We found this video is related to Chinese Christians. The Bible is seen for the first time and the video was originally shared in 2015.

claim: Last picture of Indonesian Dr. Hadio Alo bidding farewell to his family.
label: fake
statement: hadio ali indonesian last picture doctor
explain: Explanation: This image was uploaded in Malaysia and is not related to Indonesia.

claim: India will go under lockdown from 4/15/20 to 6/15/20.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The Government Of India says this audio is fake and has no authenticity.

claim: “Gale of the wind” and “Neem Tree” leaves are good medicine to protect from the coronavirus.
label: fake
statement: wind tree leaf good gale neem protect medicine
explain: Explanation: As stated by WHO still there is no official remedy or cure for COVID-19, while some of the traditional methods have symptomatic improvements.
orginated: Crime news Srilanka and number of Tamil FB Users

claim: Cristiano Ronaldo turned his hotels into hospitals for COVID-19 patients.
label: fake
statement: turned cristiano ronaldo hotels hospitals covid
explain: Explanation: Cristiano Ronaldo did not turn his hotels into hospitals.

claim: A video claims to show an Eid prayer in China in December 2019.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: This was a prayer in China in June 2019, unrelated to COVID-19.

claim: Thailand cures COVID-19 with anti-HIV drugs.
label: fake
statement: drugs hiv thailand cures anti covid
explain: Explanation: Thai doctors say their treatment helped a coronavirus patient recover, but it was not a "cure."

claim: Philippines has issued an order mandating a compulsory quarantine for all travelers returning from 23 countries.
label: fake
statement: Philippine authorities did issue this warning after the novel coronavirus outbreak
explain: Explanation: Philippine authorities did not issue this warning after the novel coronavirus outbreak.

claim: Police publicly kill a coronavirus-infected woman in China.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The video is not related to coronavirus. The woman in the video was taken into custody for violating traffic restrictions in China’s Heilongjiang province.

claim: A coronavirus-infected girl was admitted to Badulla Hospital in Sri Lanka.
label: fake
statement: discharged girl suffering suspected infection virus
explain: Explanation: “The girl tested negative for coronavirus; she was treated and then discharged."

claim: Tinospora crispa plants can treat COVID-19.
label: fake
statement: Philippine health experts dismiss misleading online that tinospora crispa plants can treat novel coronavirus
explain: Explanation: Philippine health experts dismiss the claim that tinospora crispa plants can treat novel coronavirus.

claim: A study is linked to coronavirus.
label: fake
statement: filovirus erroneously links hindu study coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The study was linked to filoviruses and had the minimal role of Wuhan virology institute.

claim: Coronavirus has infected broiler chicken.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: There is no evidence that broiler chicken has been infected with coronavirus.

claim: Saline solutions can kill the new coronavirus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The WHO and many doctors deny this claim.

claim: You have to wear a disposable mask with the blue side out if you are sick and the white side out if you are not.
label: fake
statement: side disposable blue sick white wear mask
explain: Explanation: The only way to wear a mask is with the blue face out, experts told AFP.

claim: Ratan Tata talks about Indian economy amid COVID-19 crisis.
label: fake
statement: penned economy tata ratan crisis covid
explain: Explanation: This message has been wrongly attributed to Ratan Tata, while the real source of this quote remains unknown.

claim: Some Countries are dumping COVID-19 infected dead bodies in the sea, therefore be careful while consuming sea food.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The original video was captured and published in 2014 when dozens of migrant bodies were washed ashore in Libya.

claim: Dr.Charles Lieber, chair of Harvard University’s Chemistry and Chemical Biology Department was arrested for manufacturing and selling the coronavirus to China.
label: fake
statement: manufacturing lieber selling charles arrested china coronavirus
explain: Explanation: Dr.Charles Lieber was arrested for making false, fictitious and fraudulent statements because he did not disclose details of the funds he received from China. His work has nothing to do with COVID-19.

claim: Black body bags being referred to as deaths in New York and the reason a lockdown is essential.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The body bags are from Eucador and not New York.

claim: Inhalation of hot steam can kill Novel Coronavirus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Inhalation of steam from hot water does not kill COVID-19.

claim: A video claims to be of Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau’s wife Sophie Grégoire Trudeau who is infected with coronavirus.
label: fake
statement: sophie ministers gregoire trudeau canadian wife
explain: Explanation: The woman in the video is not Sophie Trudeau, but a British woman who has been infected with COVID-19.

claim: Dead bodies of COVID-19 victims are thrown in the sea off Mexico.
label: fake
statement: pacific mexican thrown sea bodies covid
explain: Explanation: This is a 2018 video from a parachute jump in Russia.

claim: Video shows COVID-19 patients lying dead on the ground in India.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The video shows visuals from the Vizag gas plant leak where few people suffocated to death. It has no link to COVID-19.

claim: Passengers complaining about over charging and no social distancing on Air India flight.
label: fake
statement: abroad passengers brought norms flouted flight back air
explain: Explanation: Video of passengers complaining about over charging and no social distancing belongs to Pakistan airlines, not Air India.

claim: Nobel Laureate Dr. Honjo has claimed COVID-19 virus to be man made in Wuhan Laboratory.
label: fake
statement: manmade manufactured claimed tasuku honjo china coronavirus
explain: Explanation: Dr. Honjo has denied the claims. The claims lack evidence and are baseless.

claim: Five Air Force officers were identified as COVID-19 patients on April 25th.
label: fake
statement: th officers force five air april covid
explain: Explanation: Air Force Director of Health confirmed the statement to be false. First COVID-19 infected patient from Air Force was reported on 27th of April.

claim: Global pandemics are occurring every 100 years.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Incorrect information about global pandemics. The post has omitted several other pandemics as well

claim: Indian muslims violating lockdown protocols by gathering and offering Namaz on rooftops.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The location of the images was verified as Dubai via Google Earth images and from location comparisons.

claim: Mass disinfection of people using a chemical solution will eradicate COVID-19 .
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Mass disinfection of people using chemical solution does not eradicate COVID-19.

claim: American citizens have placed a nude statue of President Donald Trump in New York City because he failed to handle the coronavirus situation in USA.
label: fake
statement: statue angry inability place naked contain city citizens
explain: Explanation: The video is almost four years old and is unrelated to the current novel coronavirus situation.

claim: The WHO has prescribed a lockdown strategy to tackle COVID-19, which India is following.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The much shared protocol is from a Cambridge study that forecasts the best possible ways to tackle the coronavirus epidemic and is not shared by the WHO.

claim: Photos claimed to show 1,200 people buried in Italy.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The images were not taken in Italy but in Sri Lanka and were unrelated to the pandemic.

claim: Dr Eliyantha White had developed a special medicine for COVID-19 and was planning to use it on Sri Lankan Navy personnel with the approval of the Prime Minister.
label: fake
statement: navy eliyantha special sl given white medicine using
explain: Explanation: Sri Lanka Navy confirmed they were not testing any medicine other than the recommended treatments given by the health officials from the Epidemiology unit, Ministry of Health. Prime Minister’s office also refuted the claim.

claim: PCR tests were conducted on a journalist and his crew who attended late Minister Thondaman’s funeral as they had COVID-19 symptoms.
label: fake
statement: thondaman precautionary measure pcr funeral journalists done
explain: Explanation: PCR tests were conducted since the journalists had breathing difficulty hence as a precautionary measure as per the health officials and not on suspicion of COVID-19 infection. PCR tests were negative.

claim: COVID-19 vaccines from the US will have microchips.
label: fake
statement: developing microchips vaccines gates bill covid
explain: Explanation: There are no official reports on studies being done on a COVID-19 vaccine that will inject people with a microchip. According to the BBC, the rumors began in March, when Gates participated in an Ask Me Anything session on Reddit on COVID-19. In a response to a question on how businesses will operate moving forward, Gates said, "Eventually we will have some digital certificates to show who has recovered or been tested recently or when we have a vaccine who has received it."

claim: Philippines Vice-President Leni Robredo said that playing basketball is allowed but a distance of 3 meters between each player would be required.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Robredo did not say this quote, and the graphic used was manipulated from a quote card from GMA News, a local media outlet.

claim: A mixture of alcoholic beverage Tanduay, disinfectant cleaner Zonrox, and other products like cologne and hand sanitizer can be used as alcohol or hand sanitizer.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Experts and companies involved issued warnings against the mixture saying it could "form a dangerous chemical that has toxic effects" and "may cause serious harm."

claim: Ameera al-Taweel, a former Saudi princess and philanthropist, has partnered with the World Health Organization (WHO) to give out COVID-19 relief money on social media.
label: fake
statement: taweel partnered bbf ameera princess ea former distribute
explain: Explanation: There is no evidence showing that either the World Health Organization or Ameera aI-TaweeI are giving away money on Facebook.

claim: Scientists in the United States have discovered a coronavirus cure “that works 100 percent”.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Scientists at Sorrento Therapeutics have discovered an antibody that is effective in blocking the virus that causes COVID-19, and not a cure as claimed.

claim: A photo shows a baby named Kyle who was recently diagnosed with COVID-19 after getting open-heart surgery five days after being born.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: It maliciously uses the photo of New Zealander Cameron Bartle just two days after he underwent his first open-heart surgery at five days old, in August 2012. He is now seven years old.

claim: Foo Fighters frontman Dave Grohl was diagnosed with COVID-19.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: No legitimate news organization has reported on the Foo Fighters frontman recently getting sick, much less contracting COVID-19. Its source -- a “Bild newspaper” -- also published its last feature on Grohl in January 2019.

claim: Prolonged use of face masks causes hypoxia.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: "The use of face masks does not cause hypoxia nor excessive intake of carbon dioxide. Masks are designed to allow proper breathing and oxygenation," WHO Philippines told VERA Files. Public health experts have also debunked the claim in fact check articles by several fact checking organizations across five continents.

claim: The experts at Nanavati Hospital are giving four common treatments to all patients: Vitamin C, dry ginger, turmeric and steam.
label: fake
statement: nanavati dry turmeric common vitamin treatments four giving
explain: Explanation: No doctor from Nanavati Hospital in Mumbai has recommended the four treatments mentioned in the viral message to COVID-19 positive patients. The claim in the Whatsapp message is fake.

claim: Video claiming news channel Fox News reported that Donald Trump has tested positive for COVID-19.
label: fake
statement: fox doctored clip testing positive trump covid
explain: Explanation: This is a doctored clip. Fox news did not air this segment.

claim: Priyanka Gandhi has started buses to help migrants travel during the COVID-19 lockdown.
label: fake
statement: priyanka organised buses vadra pic gandhi peddled migrants
explain: Explanation: These buses were started by the Congress for the ease of the passengers to travel to the Kumbh Mela.

claim: An article claims that a nearly $50 million United Nations humanitarian aid package to Ecuador is conditional on the South American country legalizing abortions.
label: fake
statement: legalize demanding abortions accused aid ecuador un covid
explain: Explanation: This is false; the UN said there was no such condition, and abortion is already allowed under limited circumstances.

claim: Indian government has created a roadmap to ease COVID-19 restrictions in five phases through a three-week review process.
label: fake
statement: review process phases ease week roadmap restrictions created
explain: Explanation: The original source of the five-phase ease in restrictions has been traced to the Government of Ireland. Ireland’s taoiseach (Prime minister), Leo Varadkar, confirmed a phased, five-stage exit over three months to ease COVID-19 restrictions.

claim: Herbal tea made of malunggay and kamias leaves is a cure for COVID-19, the disease caused by the novel coronavirus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The World Health Organization (WHO) says that while there are some Western, traditional, or home remedies that may provide comfort and alleviate symptoms of mild COVID-19, there is still no official cure for the disease as of May 29.

claim: Multiple posts shared repeatedly on Facebook and Twitter claim that seven countries, including the United States, Spain, Italy and the United Kingdom, have “survival rates” of more than 99.9 percent for people who contract the novel coronavirus.
label: fake
statement: unknown survival remain rates experts coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The claim is misleading; as of May 2020, several medical experts said global COVID-19 survival rates remain unknown for various reasons.

claim: Migrants are beating people up for money in Delhi.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The video is of April 2020 and the accused are minors and not migrants.

claim: Human testing of a COVID-19 vaccine is currently being conducted in Kenya.
label: fake
statement: moment trials human kenya vaccine covid
explain: Explanation: Kemri is working on its own vaccine, but has yet to start human trials.

claim: Philippines Senators Grace Poe and Risa Hontiveros have been silent over the coronavirus crisis, but were very vocal about the closure of ABS-CBN.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Both Poe and Hontiveros filed bills and participated in deliberations over legislation that address the impact of COVID-19 in the Philippines. They have also extend assistance to frontliners and other citizens affected by the coronavirus crisis.

claim: Coronavirus found in gutkha or chewing tobacco samples sold in Indian state of Maharashtra as raw material sourced from China.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The image was photoshoped with an old TV channel screengrab with new text. No such broadcast made by the TV channel.

claim: A Facebook post shared thousands of times claims the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention lied about the number of deaths caused by COVID-19 by combining the count with pneumonia and influenza fatalities.
label: fake
statement: pneumonia add toll cdc flu deaths covid
explain: Explanation: This is false; the CDC’s National Center for Health Statistics (NCHS) only records those who died from COVID-19 in its toll for the disease.

claim: Prolonged use of face masks reduces the circulation of oxygen in the blood and can lead to death.
label: fake
statement: dbfffd circulation oxygen ff lower prolonged blood face
explain: Explanation: Face masks are likely to cause rebreathing of exhaled carbon dioxide, but not significantly enough to cause death.

claim: All Filipinos, whether poor or rich, are entitled to the government’s two-month subsidy of P5,000 to P8,000 during the COVID-19 pandemic.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The emergency subsidy amounting to P200 billion is intended for “18 million low-income families” who are at risk of not earning a living during the pandemic.

claim: Indian Council of Medical Research and a hospital in Delhi have come up with a 21 point list for preventing COVID-19 in the future.
label: fake
statement: sir ganga ram published icmr advisory covid
explain: Explanation: Both the institutes denied issuing any such advisories.

claim: The Telangana state government is distributing Ramadan gift packs during the lockdown.
label: fake
statement: sudarshan packs editor ramzan gift telangana makes
explain: Explanation: Telangana state government declined the distribution of food packets and stated that the images which are being circulated are old.

claim: Over 300 people in Jaipur contracted COVID-19 after coming in contact with a indian monk who was smoking chillum.
label: fake
statement: jaipur chillum smoking cases positive covid
explain: Explanation: No such event occurred in Jaipur and the newspaper clipping is fake.

claim: Migrants in Mumbai have flocked together and are walking back to their cities during the lockdown.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The video is from Anand Vihar in Delhi when Delhi and Uttar Pradesh had agreed to allow migrants ot return home on March 28.

claim: Death of a young Sri Lankan nurse living in Adelaide, Australia was due to COVID-19.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Death was not due to COVID-19 and the last instace of a COVID-19 related death reported from Adelaide & South Australia was on12th April

claim: A Tamil Nadu (India) DMK leader beat up a lady doctor who was on COVID-19 duty.
label: fake
statement: dmk assaulting leader attack revived doctor
explain: Explanation: This is a 2018 video of the DMK leader beating up a woman who was not a doctor and this is not linked to COVID-19. The leader was suspended from the party

claim: The men of India’s railway minister demanding money from helpless workers for walking on the tracks.
label: fake
statement: bribe asking cop railway peddled migrants
explain: Explanation: The video is originally from 2019 where a police officer was seen taking bribes from passengers and is not related to COVID-19.

claim: Advisory issued by the state police of Telangana (India) instructing people to be vigilant about the possibility of increase in thefts, due to the COVID-19 crisis in the country.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The Telangana state police through their official Twitter account clarified that no such safety advisory has been released from the authorities, and urged not to spread such panic-inducing content.

claim: Chief Secretary of West Bengal was not following relaxing while the state was performing poorly as it fought COVID-19.
label: fake
statement: wb secretary chief revived spin covid
explain: Explanation: This image is from 2013 and is being shared with a false context.

claim: A graphic shows the enhanced community quarantine in several provinces and cities in the Philippines has been extended until May 25.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: There has been no new announcement from authorities of a further extension of the ECQ, which was first imposed on Luzon last March 16 and extended till April 30.

claim: Muslim women were caught shopping in lockdown.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: After closely studying the claim that is going viral on social media, we found that this video is from Karachi, Pakistan. The building that shows men and women jumping from the balcony is a 2015 video. The viral video has nothing to do with the coronavirus or India.

claim: Video of women fleeing from a quarantine center during the current lockdown in Shivaji nagar, Bangalore.
label: fake
statement: karachi escaping bangalore women quarantine pakistan
explain: Explanation: The video was taken in Karachi (Pakistan) and it is not related to the current lockdown in India. The same video was found to be uploaded on YouTube and Facebook in 2015 with the title: ‘Sex workers fleeing after FIA raid at a brothel in Karachi’.

claim: Semen, when ingested or used as hand sanitizer, can kill and prevent the novel coronavirus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: One of the authors of the study cited by the doctor said the claim is “factually incorrect” and contradicts the result of their experiment. "Our study shows that spermidine and spermine are pro-viral and that polyamine depletion is antiviral…while spermidine and spermine are present in human semen, our studies do not support that semen ingestion would be antiviral,” the researcher said.

claim: Indian superstar Aamir Khan distributed money inside wheat bags to the poor and needy in India.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Actor Aamir Khan denied the claim on Twitter.

claim: Indian Air Force showers petals on migrant workers walking home.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The picture is photoshopped and merges two images. The Indian Air Force showered petals on hospitals and not migrant workers.

claim: Telugu actor collected a huge amount of money from fans but provided relief to just 2,000 poor families.
label: fake
statement: provided huge fans collected actor amount poor families
explain: Explanation: The actor donated in the past and now and the allegations are false.

claim: Georgian man’s blood had been used to treat a COVID-19 patient in one of the hospitals in Germany. Information included a photo depicting a man, whose blood is being taken.
label: fake
statement: zryq vizi uxnzpydlamjcq uo_qpkxcae s_f mepd georgian aibm
explain: Explanation: The german city and the hospital mentioned in the article do not exist. The photo is not of the Georgian man, but was used as an illustration of a publication by Pan American Health Organization (PAHO) in 2018 that reviewed the importance of blood donation and ways to improve it.

claim: Muslims misbehaved with Mumbai police as they tried to stop a large gathering during the month of Ramzan.
label: fake
statement: argument abuser ramzan link cops clip
explain: Explanation: We found that the incident had nothing to do with cops not being allowed to enter owing to Ramzan prayers or the mosque. It was actually an altercation that broke out after a man abused and threatened the police.

claim: Trump campaign video suggesting Trump’s travel restrictions on China saved 2 million lives.
label: fake
statement: egregious editing campaigns cnn clip trump
explain: Explanation: The editing of the CNN interview is deceptive, complete with images to suggest Wolf Blitzer and Sanjay Gupta were discussing restrictions on travel from China

claim: Baba Ramdev claims that COVID-19 can be self diagnosed by controlling breathing and that mustard oil kills the virus.
label: fake
statement: ramdevs backed research self mustard oil testing
explain: Explanation: Both the claims are false, controlling of breath is not a scientific way to test for COVID-19 and mustard oil's benefits for COVID-19 have not been studied.
orginated: Baba Ramdev for a news channel

claim: American president Donald Trump announced that tests of injection of disinfectant to fight against the new coronavirus will begin in Africa.
label: fake
statement: sinfectant contrer bca injection dit dc pour donald
explain: Explanation: The American president has recently alluded to this method - which has moreover been very criticized - to combat COVID-19, he did not say that tests will begin in Africa.

claim: Various groups in the Philippines will conduct Labor Day protests on the streets despite the enhanced community quarantine.
label: fake
statement: labor hold groups protests day streets
explain: Explanation: The Labor Day protests will be held online or at home through selfies, online programs, and/or noise barrages.

claim: A vaccine for the novel coronavirus was available as early as 2001.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The vaccine shown in the photo is used for dogs against canine coronavirus. It is not effective in preventing COVID-19.

claim: Actress Angel Locsin tested positive for COVID-19 in a second test.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The actress, who has been doing humanitarian work amid the ongoing pandemic, was reported to have posted April 25 an Instagram Story showing a photo of two test kits and the text, “Covid free," referring to her and her fiance. There are no articles about Locsin taking a “second test”.

claim: The Philippine government has a P120 billion aid package for “no work, no pay” workers.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: This is wrong. P120 billion is actually the amount of credit guarantees the government is offering small and medium-size enterprises planning to borrow from banks in order to finance operations that were halted as a result of the quarantine amid the pandemic.

claim: Opening ceremony of 2012 London Olympics was a projection of coronavirus pandemic. The hospital beds apperaing on the scene during the opening show and Boris Johnson in a hospital bed prove that the spread of the disease was planned in advance.
label: fake
statement: seba olympics isceli sam links london coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The hospital beds that appeared during the opening show of London Olympics in 2012 was a tribute to the UK NHS, and the patient in bed was the Queen of Hearts from Alice in Wonderland, not Prime Minister Johnson

claim: The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) plans to mobilize the National Guard to enforce a nationwide 14-day quarantine.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: There are no plans for a national quarantine. The DHS cannot mobilize the National Guard in this manner.

claim: An audio message circulating in India claimed that in Wuhan, China, many people recovered from coronavirus without going to hospital after drinking ot water and steam inhalation.
label: fake
statement: inhalation contain hot steam drinking water coronavirus
explain: Explanation: WHO stated that there is no final treatment for coronavirus and the claim was misleding to shun hospitalization.

claim: Dr. Anthony Fauci disappeared at the end of April because he had illegally sent $3.7 million to a virology lab in Wuhan, China.
label: fake
statement: illegally mia millions sent lab fauci wuhan
explain: Explanation: Fauci's record of his schedule shows his exact whereabouts in the U.S. at the end of April. Records also show less than half a million dollars were given to Wuhan lab, though no by Fauci.

claim: “All Missouri businesses can open Monday, May 4, under our new Order as long as new guidelines are followed.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Despite Parson's claim, not all businesses could open May 4 .

claim: False claims on number of deaths due to COVID-19 in Sri Lanka.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Completely false statements. As per the Health Ministry, there were only 7 deaths due to COVID-19 by 25th of April.

claim: Facebook posts accuse the Muslim community in Canada’s Calgary of breaking COVID-19 social distancing rules during Ramadan, using a photo of a crowded Islamic center as proof.
label: fake
statement: accused canadian ramadan breaking rules distancing muslims covid
explain: Explanation: The photo was taken during the Eid al-Fitr holiday in August 2019, and mosques in Calgary are closed.

claim: 567 positive cases and 39 deaths from COVID-19 were recorded in Mali on April 13, 2020.
label: fake
statement: mort mali comptait cas avril date et ne
explain: Explanation: The publication mentioning the statistics of April 13 relating to COVID-19 in Mali and contradicting those of official sources, is an invention to mislead public opinion.

claim: The World Bank has lauded Tanzania’s COVID-19 response policies.
label: fake
statement: strategy lauded bedb tanzanias bank response covid
explain: Explanation: The World Bank has issued a statement disowning the claim.

claim: Consuming a cup of brown sugar per day can cure COVID-19, the disease caused by the novel coronavirus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: There is no official cure for COVID-19 as of May 21, according to the World Health Organization (WHO). There are several clinical trials being conducted to test potential cures, but consuming brown sugar is not one of them.

claim: Former RBI governor Raghuram Rajan held IMF conference to roll out new economic recovery plan.
label: fake
statement: trending takeaway points webinar rajan raghuram imf
explain: Explanation: The economic agenda attributed to Rajan was false as he said no such conference was held.

claim: Chinese medical supplies to Ghana contaminated with coronavirus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Laboratory tests by the Ghana Food and Drugs Authority has disproved these claims. GhanaFact spoke to officials of the Ghana Food and Drugs Authority, Ghana Standards Authority, Ghana Health Service, and the Ministry of Health to verify this claim.

claim: A police officer in Bihar’s Bhagalpur Central Jail has tested positive for coronavirus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The video is of a mock drill that was conducted at Bhagalpur Central Jail in Bihar nearly 8-10 days ago. The video in circulation falsely claims that it shows an officer who has tested positive for COVID-19.

claim: Notes thrown by a person with the intention of spreading coronavirus in Madhya Pradesh’s Indore, in India.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: While the incident is actually from Indore, the notes were not thrown on the road with any intention of spreading coronavirus. It was actually an accident and not a deliberate attempt by any community to spread COVID-19.

claim: A video is doing the rounds on social media which claims that policemen are now being tested positive for the COVID-19.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The video is from Bihar's Hajipur jail. An official informed that mock drills are being practiced in almost every jail in Bihar to check the preparations for the fight against the COVID-19. Some social media users are sharing the video of mock drill with the claim that a cop was tested positive for the COVID-19, this is completely false.

claim: Image of seven month pregnant lady doctor from Sri Lanka in the battle against COVID-19.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Image of a pregnant doctor from Malaysia.

claim: Muslims scattered currency notes on a road in Indore to spread coronavirus.
label: fake
statement: scattered currency action notes indore road muslims coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The currency notes shown in the video are not thrown on the road by anyone with the intention to spread coronavirus. When FACTLY contacted Indore police, they said these currency notes slipped from the pockets of a gas cylinder delivery boy. Also, the name of the person who lost money on the road is Ram Narendra Yadav. He is not Muslim

claim: A video has been viewed tens of thousands of times in multiple posts on Twitter and Weibo which claim it shows US banknotes being printed during the novel coronavirus pandemic in 2020.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The clip was first broadcasted in 1991 as part of a US television show, more than two decades before the COVID-19 pandemic.

claim: Amid lockdown, Karnataka (India) chief minister Yeddyurappa attended the wedding of Kumaraswamy’s son, ignoring social distancing.
label: fake
statement: yediyurappa kumaraswamy junior attend wedding lockdown
explain: Explanation: The picture was taken two months back at the engagement ceremony of Kumaraswamy’s son. Yeddyurappa did not attend the wedding of HDK’s son on Friday.

claim: “The flu killed 80,000 people in the U.S. last year”.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The Facebook post exaggerates seasonal flu deaths for last year. The CDC’s estimate for seasonal flu deaths for the 2017-18 season was about 61,000. The CDC’s preliminary estimate for seasonal flu deaths for the 2018-19 season is about 34,200, but that’s not the final number.

claim: The Philippines has an “approved” cure for COVID-19.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The Philippines' Food and Drug Authority warned the public in a 4/8/2020 advisory that no drug or vaccine has been “licensed specifically for use in COVID-19 treatment or prevention.” On 4/9/2020, the FDA also told VERA Files that the drug -- called Fabunan Antiviral Injection -- does not yet have an application for product registration.
orginated: FB user, FB pages, YouTube channels

claim: Boris Johnson refused 50,000 ventilators offered by the EU.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: This is not true. The UK did not join an EU scheme to stockpile medical equipment, but this is not the same as turning down 50,000 ventilators.The total budget of the scheme wouldn’t have covered this many ventilators.

claim: The nurses that Boris Johnson claimed saved his life are not registered in the UK.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: This is incorrect. We found both nurses on the register.

claim: A video has been viewed tens of thousands of times on Twitter, Facebook and YouTube alongside a claim it shows a Koran recitation in Italy as part of the government’s effort to fight the novel coronavirus pandemic.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The claim is misleading; the footage shows an interreligious gathering held by the Diocese of Carpi in northern Italy to remember COVID-19 victims.

claim: Image of people participating in a ‘Chariot pulling’ festival in Kalabari district (Karnataka) despite the current lockdown in the country implemented to handle COVID-19 spread.
label: fake
statement: participated kalabari district chariot pulling festival despite lockdown
explain: Explanation: The image is old and is that of a ‘Chariot pulling’ event in Koppal district (Karnataka). It was found to exist on the internet at least since 2017.

claim: In India, this image shows a Tablighi Jamaat member beaten up by Uttar Pradesh Police for misbehaving with a nurse in the Ghaziabad quarantine. He was a COVID-19 suspected case.
label: fake
statement: ghaziabad misbehaving member tablighi nurse jamaat beaten quarantine
explain: Explanation: The image is not related to any recent incident or a quarantine center. It is found to exist on the internet at least since July 2019.

claim: A YouTube video said that Manila Electric Company (Meralco) billings for March and April 2020 are now free to help consumers affected by the coronavirus crisis.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The announcement did not come from Meralco. There is an energy subsidy program amid the coronavirus crisis but it is implemented only by electric cooperatives and not private power distributors like Meralco.

claim: A photo circulating on social media shows two police officers escorting a man down a street. The police officers have arrested the man for not wearing a face-mask, although they are not wearing masks, after regulations came into effect requiring people in Kenya to wear face masks in public or risk arrest.
label: fake
statement: strike wearing arrested kenya mask coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The photo is almost six years old. It was published by the Standard newspaper on 23 August 2014 with the caption: “Police manhandle a person they arrested in Mombasa during a Matatu strike.” It has nothing to do with the COVID-19 pandemic.

claim: A gathering of thousands of muslims before a masid in Bandra, Mumbai druring the current lockdown.
label: fake
statement: laborers bandra station gathering meeting railway muslims coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The people in the video are migrant labourers from various religions who got struck in Mumbai due to the current lockdown. They congregated before a Masid that is present beside Bandra railway station asking to give them permission to go to their native place. Police said that those people have come to the railway station following some rumors that the trains will resume.

claim: A photo has been shared thousands of times on Facebook alongside a claim it shows an Italian mother holding her baby for the last time after becoming terminally ill with COVID-19.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The claim is false; the photo has circulated in reports about a child who was awaiting a marrow transplant in 1985 in the US.

claim: A police officer in Bihar’s Hajipur (India) station contracted coronavirus.
label: fake
statement: preparedness bihar real mock drill covid
explain: Explanation: The video being shared with the claim is a mock drill undertaken by the Hajipur police to train officials to tackle COVID-19.

claim: Trump’s claims about how quickly WHO acted to announce human-to-human transmission
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Trump could have made a case that the WHO was slow to speak firmly about the possible human-to-human transmission. But Trump really gets over his skis when he claims that the WHO “publicly endorsed the idea that there was not human-to-human transmission happening” and that the WHO said it was “not communicable.”

claim: A video that shows an argument between shoppers at an Australian department store has been viewed tens of thousands of times in Facebook and Twitter posts alongside a claim that Chinese nationals have been banned from supermarkets in Australia.
label: fake
statement: supermarkets nationals myth banned australian spreads chinese covid
explain: Explanation: The claim is false; major Australian supermarket chains told AFP there was no policy that bans Chinese people from their stores as of April 2020; the video in the misleading posts has circulated in media reports about a dispute in an Australian supermarket over baby formula.

claim: A photo shared thousands of times on Facebook claims to show the throat of a novel coronavirus patient.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The claim is false; the image has circulated online since May of 2018, long before the COVID-19 pandemic.

claim: Image showing a donation claimed to be by Kenyan Deputy President Ruto.
label: fake
statement: ruto dp gambia donation fc claimed
explain: Explanation: The image shows what appears to be bags of grain and oil containers among other food items arranged in rows that stretch over a large sandy area.However, a reverse image search shows that the image was taken in The Gambia and is among other photos of the same donation taken from different angles and uploaded to Facebook in May 2019.

claim: Former Kenyan Prime minister Raila has donated Kshs 142 million for COVID-19.
label: fake
statement: factual ed raila odinga ksh donated million covid
explain: Explanation: Although the former prime minister made a donation in the form of essential supplies, this happened days after the claim was posted and the donation was valued at Ksh15 million.

claim: Treasury is depositing Kshs 45, 000 to the mobile wallet of Nairobi residents in Kenya.
label: fake
statement: upkeep treasury nairobi sending ksh residents crisis covid
explain: Explanation: The post urges residents to confirm their MPESA details with the Treasury in order to receive the funds apparently meant to assist them to cater for their needs while they stay at home due to the COVID-19 crisis. There has been no such communication from the National Treasury, and the government’s monetary assistance is based on a defined national needs assessment matrix.

claim: Former Kenyan Prime minister Raila Odinga has COVID-19.
label: fake
statement: raila odinga ad tested positive covid
explain: Explanation: Raila Odinga has not been tested positive for COVID-19.

claim: Even if the Department of Social Welfare and Development (DSWD) gives all families in the Philippines their allotted amount as part of the government’s emergency subsidy – worth a total of P200 billion – in light of the coronavirus pandemic, there would still be P57 billion to spare.
label: fake
statement: subsidy dswd balance families even emergency cash aid
explain: Explanation: The computation used to arrive at the claim does not consider that the P200-billion emergency subsidy covers two months and is only given to the target 18 million low-income families, as outlined in Republic Act No. 11469 or the Bayanihan to Heal as One Act.

claim: Herd immunity is probably why California has far fewer COVID-19 deaths than New York.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: There’s no evidence herd immunity has limited coronavirus deaths in California, which adopted stay-at-home measures before New York did.

claim: Gloria “Ka Bea” Arellano, chairperson of urban poor group Kadamay, asked for a house with free Wi-Fi in connection with the stay-at-home prescription under the enhanced community quarantine.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: While Kadamay has spoken on behalf of the homeless during the enhanced community quarantine, Arellano did not make the demand.

claim: Harvard professor arrested for having ties with creating the coronavirus and leaking it.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Lieber became a "Strategic Scientist" at Wuhan University of Technology (WUT) in China and was a contractual participant in China's Thousand Talents Plan from in or about 2012 to 2017," the statement said. It also mentioned that Lieber was paid $50,000 per month by WUT, along with a fund of $1.5 million to set up a research lab at Wuhan. He was arrested for fraud but this was not linked to the coronavirus.

claim: India’s Minister of State for AYUSH Shripad Naik held a press conference claiming that Prince Charles followed the rules of Ayurveda, which is why he is recovering so soon.
label: fake
statement: shripad press naik conference ayurveda soon recovering held
explain: Explanation: Ella Lynch, a spokesperson for the Royal House of England, told The India Express via gmail that false claims were being made in the media about Prince Charles recovering from a coronavirus infection.

claim: Whales are spotted at Bombay High, the offshore rig for the Oil and Natural Gas Corporation in India. Nature is reclaiming its space.
label: fake
statement: space rig reclaiming offshore whales nature corporation bombay
explain: Explanation: The viral video was uploaded by BBC News Indonesia in August 2019 on their Twitter handle. According to the caption, a group of humpback whales can be seen crossing the Karimunjawa Sea, which is an Indonesian archipelago in the Java Sea.

claim: The Disaster Management Act has been implemented across India. As per the act, apart from the government departments, no other citizen is allowed to post or share any forward related to the novel coronavirus.
label: fake
statement: act apart implemented departments citizen forward allowed across
explain: Explanation: India's Ministry of Home Affairs issued a notification on 3/24/20, the day the lockdown was announced. The notification stated that the Disaster Management Act of 2005 is being invoked to deal with the novel coronavirus. However, nowhere was it mentioned that no other citizen can post or share any forward related to the epidemic.

claim: Owing to India lighting diyas on April 5, a satellite captured India as illuminated while the world was in darkness.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The picture was earlier shared as a joke which some considered to be genuine and frequently shared it across all social media platforms. On April 5, the Indian PM asked the citizens to switch off their lights and light diyas or candles for 9 minutes in solidarity to tackle the coronavirus

claim: “Same little boy died of COVID-19 in three different countries. Still don’t believe the media is #fakenews?”
label: fake
statement: suic exploit boys doctored images coronavirus
explain: Explanation: Three screenshots using doctored images falsely suggest that there were reports of the same boy’s death in three countries. The boy pictured in the claim died in 2017 from an apparent suicide.

claim: Queen Elizabeth II praised President Rodrigo Duterte and said that the Philippines has the worst citizens, according to a graphic that went viral on Facebook.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Queen Elizabeth II did not issue such a statement – or even close to it.

claim: In his late evening speech on April 6, President Rodrigo Duterte said he warned Filipinos about the threat of the novel coronavirus “at the start.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: After the first death due to the coronavirus outside China was recorded in the Philippines, Duterte talked to the media and said that "everything is well" in the country, adding that there's "nothing really to be extra scared of that coronavirus thing."

claim: The maker of the novel coronavirus has been arrested.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Lieber was not arrested for creating the coronavirus, but for lying about his affiliation with China.
orginated: Facebook page Videos and News Update

claim: Photo taken by NASA on 4/5/20 when candles and diyas were lit at 9 p.m. for nine minutes.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The photo in the post is not real; it's a 3D rendering. It was not taken by NASA. Also, the photo was present on the internet even before this incident.

claim: Government has turned Lord Vinayaka’s Kanipakam temple into an isolation ward for treating coronavirus patients.
label: fake
statement: vinakaya swamy kanipakam converted temple isolation center covid
explain: Explanation: The temple shown in the video is not Kanipakam temple. It is the residential centre Sri Ganesh Sadan in Kanipakam, being used by the government of Andhra Pradesh as the quarantine center.

claim: A video has been viewed tens of thousands of times in multiple posts on Facebook, Weibo and Twitter that claim it shows people who committed suicide in the U.S. after contracting COVID-19.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The claim is false. The video was published in 2014 news reports about a group of migrants who died after a boat sank off the coast of Libya.

claim: Visuals of Ooty-Coimbatore roads in India claimed by its original owners – peacocks and wild boars.
label: fake
statement: owners roads original ooty coimbatore claimed
explain: Explanation: The photo of peacocks is an old one and was taken at Chhatbir Zoo (Chandigarh). Also, the video of wild boars was found to be on the internet much before the lockdown was imposed in India.

claim: Video of a fire accident that took place at the Solapur Airport on 05 April 2020.
label: fake
statement: solapur accident airport fire april recent
explain: Explanation: A fire accident took place at the Solapur Airport as a result of the bursting of crackers on 05 April 2020, but the video is not related to that accident. It is that of the fire accident that took place at the Solapur Airport on 03 February 2020.

claim: Photos of grand celebration of Ram Navami (4/2/20) at Bhuj Mandir in Gujarat, India, during lockdown.
label: fake
statement: mandir bhuj navami celebrations ram gujarat lockdown
explain: Explanation: The photos are related to 153rd Patotsav of Shree Harikrushna Maharaj celebrations at Bhuj Mandir. The celebrations were held from February 21, 2020 to February 25, 2020, before the lockdown. The posted photos are the screenshots of a video which was streamed live on February 22, 2020.

claim: Davao City Mayor Sara Duterte said that local government units (LGUs) should be blamed for why the P200-billion cash assistance has not reached constituents.
label: fake
statement: slow lgus disbursement sara blame fund duterte coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The statement did not come from Sara Duterte nor did it reflect her views about federalism and the national government's response to the coronavirus crisis.

claim: Man is spitting on a police officer to spread COVID-19 in India.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: An older video of an under trial spitting on a cop as he was denied home cooked food was falsely shared as being related to COVID-19.

claim: A video purporting that an attack on doctors was avenged by policemen.
label: fake
statement: retaliation medics indore attack peddled mumbai
explain: Explanation: A set of doctors were attacked in India when they went about collecting samples for COVID-19. This video is not a revenge by policemen for the same and is not linked to coronavirus.

claim: Lemon bicarbonate as tea and green tea can treat and prevent coronavirus.
label: fake
statement: types different act tea cure covid
explain: Explanation: There is no scientific evidence stating that any kind of tea impacts the spread or growth of the novel coronavirus.

claim: PM Modi on 4/2/20 announced extension of a nationwide lockdown until 5/4/20.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: PM Modi has not made any announcement for extension of nationwide lockdown until 5/4/20. The image is digitally edited.

claim: The Disaster Management Act 2005 is going to be implemented in India; no citizen is allowed to post any update or share any forward related to COVID-19.
label: fake
statement: restrict share management disaster citizens act covid
explain: Explanation: There is no such restriction on citizens to share any news or updates about the COVID-19 situation, as long as it is not false information.

claim: The United States is “recruiting” doctors to confront COVID-19.
label: fake
statement: reclutando enfrentar unidos estados medicos esta para la
explain: Explanation: The U.S. Embassy in Havana wishes to clarify that the U.S. is not recruiting foreign medical professionals to assist in the response to COVID-19. The announcement only covers individuals already approved and notified by the Department of Homeland Security.

claim: Barack Obama warned Africans against coronavirus vaccines.
label: fake
statement: former africans vaccines warn obama coronavirus
explain: Explanation: There is no evidence of Obama warning anyone against vaccines, whether for coronavirus or other diseases. And no vaccine against COVID-19 exists yet.

claim: Indian PM Modi announced a lockdown extension until 5/4/20 in India.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: No such announcement was made by PM Modi; the image is digitally edited.

claim: Inhaling hot water steam can kill coronavirus.
label: fake
statement: scientific inhaling hot steam water kill evidence coronavirus
explain: Explanation: While hot water steam inhalation may provide some temporary relief for the symptoms in some cases like common cold and flu, there is no scientific evidence to suggest that it can kill coronavirus. The Press Information Bureau (PIB) has also clarified the same.

claim: Multiple Facebook posts shared thousands of times in April 2020 claim pet owners should avoid touching their animals after using hand sanitiser because it contains toxic chemicals. The posts were shared as people around the world took steps to minimise the spread of the novel coronavirus, which causes the disease COVID-19.
label: fake
statement: touching pet animals owners avoid hand using
explain: Explanation: Experts told AFP that hand sanitiser is safe to use around pets and only large amounts of it could be potentially toxic to animals.

claim: COVID-19 cannot spread in warm countries.
label: fake
statement: weather bcff ccb inaccurate warm cannot ab aa
explain: Explanation: The letter cites unknown individuals, and claims that the virus that causes COVID-19 can be fought off by eating chillies and ginger. The letter also claims that the virus can be destroyed at temperatures of 26 to 28 degrees Celsius.

claim: As per Home Ministry of India, sharing information related to the coronavirus is now a punishable offense.
label: fake
statement: offense punishable information sharing ministry per coronavirus
explain: Explanation: We found that there is no official named Ravi Nayak in MHA, India, as claimed in the viral message. Also, there was no official notice on the website on MHA. It is evident from our fact check that the message viral on social media claiming to be from the Home Ministry of India is false.

claim: Marathi newspaper reports a conspiracy theory of coronavirus being a bioweapon.
label: fake
statement: marathi lokmat falls bioweapon newspaper covid
explain: Explanation: The conspiracy theory is actually picked up from a Reddit thread which hosts contests for fictional stories that are inspired from real events.

claim: An image of a baby born with deformities claims that the baby was suffering from coronavirus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: This image is of a stillborn baby suffering from anencephaly, which caused the baby to be born without parts of the brain/skull.

claim: This image of Pope Francis falling during a mass and thereafter testing postive for COVID-19.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The photo is from 2016, when the Pope fell while celebrating mass in Poland. Pope Francis has not tested positive for coronavirus, and held a service at an empty St Peter’s Square in the Vatican on 28 March, three days after the post was published.

claim: G-7 countries have asked Modi to lead them in preventing coronavirus.
label: fake
statement: lead fighting asked countries modi coronavirus
explain: Explanation: UK Prime Minister, US President and Australian Prime Minister have not asked Modi to lead the G-7 countries in preventing coronavirus disease as stated in the video.

claim: Photos of medicines from the US which will be only given to selected people by the Indian government in the name of COVID-19 treatment to eliminate them.
label: fake
statement: select medicines eliminating given clip audio
explain: Explanation: The photos are neither related to India nor the US. The photos were taken at Kota Kinabalu International Airport (Sabha, Malaysia) when the health equipment donated by the Chinese Government reached the airport.

claim: Pakistan’s PM Imran Khan tested COVID-19 positive.
label: fake
statement: imran khan tested pakistan positive covid
explain: Explanation: Pakistan's Senator Faisal Javed Khan clearing the air, denied the claim, further asked the news network to correct the report. The Pakistani politician said, "News regarding PM Imran Khan tested positive for COVID-19 is not true. Please refrain from spreading fake news."

claim: Pakistan’s Dr. Usama Riaz, who contracted coronavirus while treating patients, had left a video message before he died.
label: fake
statement: usama riaz left contracted treating died pakistan coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The various social media posts claiming that the person in the video is Dr. Usama Riaz are misleading. The man in the recording is Mubhasir Ahmed, who has been living in the United Kingdom.

claim: The current coronavirus outbreak is due to the movement toward 5G.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The 5G connection has no scientific evidence to the outbreak of coronavirus.

claim: Northern Ireland Government has contingency plans for COVID-19 include turning Dundonald Ice Bowl into a morgue to store bodies temporarily.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The Department of Justice confirms that there are no plans to use either Dundonald Ice Bowl or the SSE Arena. The Justice Minister has stated that buildings on the Kinnegar site outside Holywood will be used as the Northern Ireland Temporary Resting Place if required.

claim: Italy has surrendered to the coronavirus pandemic as all the measures to control COVID-19 have been exhausted.
label: fake
statement: exhausted surrendered measures italy covid coronavirus
explain: Explanation: Prime Minister of Italy Giuseppe Conte in his recent statement said: "We are giving up the most expensive habits, we do it because we love Italy, but we do not give up courage and hope in the future. United, we will do it." He did not talk about surrendering.

claim: Amitabh Bachchan gave 500 million rupees to the Mumbai government to fight the coronavirus.
label: fake
statement: bachchan amitabh gave rupees million mumbai coronavirus
explain: Explanation: A part of an old video of Amitabh Bachchan and Narendra Modi is viral with false claims. Amitabh has not given a check of Rs. 500 crores to Bombay Municipal Corporation nor to Government of Maharashtra. He has not even met Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi recently.

claim: Indian Army has constructed an advanced hospital with a capacity of 1,000 beds in Barmer, Rajasthan, to cope with COVID-19.
label: fake
statement: cope constructed advanced rajasthan capacity barmer beds army
explain: Explanation: The viral images claiming the Indian Army has constructed an advanced hospital with the capacity of 1,000 beds in Barmer, Rajasthan, to cope with COVID-19 are old and unrelated.

claim: An article shared hundreds of times on Facebook claims that the Ethiopian government has approved a traditional medicine treatment for COVID-19 after successful clinical trials on animals and humans.
label: fake
statement: ethiopia traditional approved treat medicine covid
explain: Explanation: The Ministry of Health denied the claims and Capital Ethiopia, which published the story, has corrected its Facebook post.

claim: Video clip shows people keep leaving Phuket.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: It's not in Phuket. It's actually a news from Thailand-Myanmar border in the north. And they are Myanmar labour who wanted to go to their home country.

claim: Dr. Usman Riyaz from Delhi died from the coronavirus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Viral picture is of Dr. Riyaz Usman from UAE and he is alive.

claim: In Sri Lanka, Sathosa Supermarket trucks bearing the image of former PM Mahinda Rajapaksa are being used to distribute food during current COVID-19 curfew. Text condemns the act by mentioning how ethical is it to carry out such acts during this difficult time and gain political advantage.
label: fake
statement: vehicles sathosa rajapaksha mahinda lorries portrayed distribute curfew
explain: Explanation: 2014 images of Sathosa Lorries with PM Mahinda Rajapaksha portrayed as recent vehicles are used to distribute food during curfew. The newspaper which carried the original image published a disclaimer.

claim: Photo posts claim a person is committing suicide by jumping from a building in Italy, a doctor couple in an Italian hospital a few hours before their death and chaos in an Italian hospital amid COVID-19.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The first image is from Spain where a woman committed suicide in December 2019; the second image is of a couple at the Barcelona airport and the third image is from recent earthquake in Croatia.

claim: Pictures of people stranded on hospital beds claimed to be Italians not coping with the pressures of COVID-19 cases; India should learn from Italy’s mistakes and not step out of the house in the 21-day lockdown
label: fake
statement: overwhelmed pics croatia earthquake peddled italy covid
explain: Explanation: The images were from the earthquake that hit Croatia on March 22, 2020 and were falsely shared as showing Italy.

claim: A picture claims that an Italian man committed suicide after his whole family succumbed to COVID-19
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The image is of a woman committing suicide in Spain in December 2019. BOOM could not establish what drove the woman to take such a step.

claim: Reliance Jio, one of the biggest telecom networks in India, is providing Internet for free during the coronavirus pandemic.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: A spokesperson from the company denied the claim and the messages were linked to scamming websites.

claim: The novel coronavirus that causes COVID-19 is “confirmed” to be airborne.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: As of April 13, the World Health Organization (WHO) still says that COVID-19 is not airborne and is mainly transmitted through droplets or little bits of liquid. There are studies that suggest airborne transmission is possible, but none of them are conclusive. The Department of Health (DOH) also earlier said that airborne transmission only applies to a “hospital setting.”

claim: Posts on social media claim that no Democrats voted for the “the stimulus package to help American families” during the novel coronavirus crisis.
label: fake
statement: legislation democrats combat vote crisis coronavirus
explain: Explanation: Democrats overwhelmingly backed two bills aimed at countering the virus and its fallout, and while senators from the party blocked an initial proposal for the third, they voted unanimously for a later version.

claim: This text message shows the government is monitoring people leaving the house during coronavirus lockdown.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: This is not an official government text.

claim: A vaccine for the new coronavirus has been created by US scientists and will be ready to use from next Sunday.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Whilst there are vaccines in development, it will likely be more than 18 months before they are ready to use. The image and videos accompanying the post are related to COVID-19 diagnostic tests, not vaccines.

claim: Nevada Governor Steve Sisolak “has banned the use of an anti-malaria drug that might help cure coronavirus.”
label: fake
statement: nevadas distorts conservative chloroqui meme group
explain: Explanation: A Nevada emergency regulation restricts the prescription of chloroquine for COVID-19 patients in outpatient settings, but not in hospitals and emergency rooms. Gov. Steve Sisolak signed the order on the recommendation of state health officials, who said there is the potential for stockpiling the drug.

claim: Coronavirus patients in Italy are now on the streets because hospitals are no longer able to accommodate them.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The photos were taken in the aftermath of the 5.4-magnitude earthquake that struck Croatia on 3/22/20.

claim: A claim on Facebook that began to circulate around Wednesday, 3/25/20, says putting a peeled onion in any room can remove “all viruses and bacteria including coronavirus.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Putting peeled onions in a room will not prevent COVID-19 or a coronavirus infection, according to the National Onion Association (NOA) in the US. There are no official cures or vaccines for COVID-19, according to the WHO as of 3/31/20, though there are cures and vaccines undergoing testing.

claim: Justin Trudeau’s wife has released a video from her hospital bed.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The woman in the video is not Sophie Trudeau but Tara Jane Langston, a 39-year-old who was diagnosed with pneumonia at the Hillingdon Hospital in West London. She recorded this video for her colleagues and the public to make them aware of the seriousness of COVID-19.

claim: President of Italy crying because of the coronavirus pandemic.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The man in the picture, Jair Bolsonaro, is not the president of Italy but that of Brazil. Further, the image is not recent and was taken at the Thanksgiving speech at the Palacio do Planalto in December 2019.

claim: The new hantavirus is a deadly problem emerging in China. There is no cure for it.
label: fake
statement: problem emerging hantavirus deadly cure china
explain: Explanation: Hantavirus is not new. The is no special cure; the disease is treated as any other respiratory disease.

claim: In India starting 3/24/20, all grocery, chemists and vegetable shops will be open from 9.00 am to 11.30 am and 4.30 pm to 7.00 pm. Anybody found moving around after this or opening any kind of outlet will be detained by the police. No home deliveries will be available.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Delhi Police has clarified that the viral message on social media is fake.

claim: A claim that a trolley collector at a supermarket in the Australian state of New South Wales tested positive for the novel coronavirus in March 2020 has been shared hundreds of times in multiple posts on Facebook.
label: fake
statement: worker supermarket australian tested positive covid
explain: Explanation: The claim is false; the shopping centre where the supermarket is located said that it had no confirmed COVID-19 cases in March 2020; local health officials in New South Wales also did not report any confirmed cases in the suburb cited in the misleading Facebook posts in the final days of March.

claim: Multiple articles widely shared on Facebook claim that 59 church members died after drinking household disinfectant which their pastor said would prevent coronavirus infections.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The claims, although based on an old story, are false. South African police denied any current investigations on their part.

claim: Roche has developed a COVID-19 vaccine.
label: fake
statement: eddf roche dc developed ab aa source rss
explain: Explanation: A video claiming that the pharmaceutical company has developed a vaccine for COVID-19 contains false information.

claim: Russian President Vladimir Putin releases 800 tigers and 500 lions amid the coronavirus outbreak to keep people at home.
label: fake
statement: tigers releases keep russia putin lions coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The photos were taken in 2016 and 2019 respectively, both in South Africa.

claim: Italian Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte was quoted in various posts and graphics on Facebook as saying they have “lost control” of the coronavirus pandemic that is greatly affecting Italy.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: No official statements or reports from credible news organizations carry this supposed quote by Conte. The graphics and screenshots also did not point to the source of the quote.

claim: A new vaccine that can cure COVID-19 patients in 3 hours is now ready.
label: fake
statement: within ready hours vaccine cure coronavirus
explain: Explanation: As of 3/27/20, there is still no vaccine or drug approved by the WHO or any FDA in the world to cure or prevent COVID-19. The image used in the post is not a photo of vaccines from Roche Medical Company, but a photo of rapid test kits from the South Korean company Sugentech.

claim: Image attributed to Italian Prime Minister suggesting Italy has lost control.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Image of Brazilian Prime Minister Bolsonaro crying at an event was falsely shared as the Italian president.

claim: Trump hotels would get coronavirus money
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The Senate-approved bill prohibits Trump family hotels from getting coronavirus aid from a $500 billion fund that would be set up to help businesses that incurred losses from the coronavirus.

claim: Vladimir Putin let lions loose in the streets of Russia to keep them indoors amid COVID-19.
label: fake
statement: russians loose let bizarre indoors keep putin lions
explain: Explanation: The image is from Johannesburg, South Africa, where a lion was released for a video shooting.

claim: Russia has unleashed over 500 lions to ensure that people stay inside their homes amid the coronavirus outbreak.
label: fake
statement: homes ensure unleashed inside stay russia lions coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The image on social media has nothing to do with Russia or the Russian president. The image is from South Africa’s Johannesburg, and the lion seen in the viral image was brought for film shooting by a production crew.

claim: A WhatsApp forward claimed that a vaccine for coronavirus has been discovered. It also claims that the treatment for coronavirus is mentioned in India’s Intermediate Zoology book. The viral forward reads, “It is not a new disease as it is already mentioned in the Intermediate Zoology book along with its treatment. It happens sometimes that many great scientists and doctors do not focus on lesser-known books as they are mostly busy with famous books. (Book name: Zoology, Writer: Dr. Ramesh Gupta, Page No. 1072.) Friends, this is not fake news so I request you to kindly share it maximum so all coronavirus patients are treated in time.”
label: fake
statement: zoology book intermediate books mentioned forward treatment writer
explain: Explanation: The virus discussed in the viral claim is not the novel coronavirus but SARS. The WHO has clearly negated the discovery of any vaccine that can cure COVID-19. In an answer to the question, “Are there any medicines or therapies that can prevent or cure COVID-19?”, the WHO replies, “While some western, traditional or home remedies may provide comfort and alleviate symptoms of COVID-19, there is no evidence that current medicine can prevent or cure the disease."

claim: Russia has unleashed over 500 lions to ensure that people stay inside their homes amid the coronavirus outbreak.
label: fake
statement: homes ensure unleashed inside stay russia lions coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The image of a bulletin viral on social media has nothing to do with Russia or the Russian president. The image is from South Africa’s Johannesburg, and the lion was for a film shooting by a production crew.

claim: Photo of the “crying president of Italy” with a caption stating Italy was not prepared to deal with the coronavirus outbreak despite having adequate health facilities.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The world leader in the photo is not the president of Italy. He is Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro.

claim: Prime Minister Narendra Modi announced a 14-hour curfew as the virus lives for 12 hours on surfaces.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Research shows the study found the new coronavirus can live in the air for several hours and on some surfaces for as long as 2-3 days. These studies are not peer reviewed.

claim: There is science behind Indian Prime minister Modi’s 5 p.m. clapping initiative: Clapping generates vibration which can kill coronavirus. Also, 3/22/20 is Amavasya.
label: fake
statement: janata gratitude express clapping hands curfew kill coronavirus
explain: Explanation: There is no scientific evidence to prove that vibration from clapping hands can kill coronavirus. The Press Information Bureau of India has clarified that the message is fake. Also, Amavasya is not on 3/22/20.

claim: A message claimed that Russia released 500 lions on streets to keep people confined to their homes due to Covid-19 outbreak.
label: fake
statement: released inside keep russia lions streets
explain: Explanation: Russia has not imposed any lockdown when the claim was made and the video was two years old. It is unrelated to the coronavirus pandemic.

claim: An image of coffins showing the victims of COVID-19 in Italy.
label: fake
statement: db coffins ad ab aa source rss italy
explain: Explanation: A Facebook post with an image claiming to show the victims of COVID-19 in Italy uses a photo of the coffins of African immigrants who drowned off the coast near Lampedusa in 2013.

claim: President Rodrigo Duterte said COVID-19, the disease caused by the novel coronavirus, is only transmitted through contact with other people.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The novel coronavirus is known to spread mainly from person to person, but it can also spread through infected surfaces or objects.

claim: IDH Hospital, the main center in Sri Lanka for treating COVID-19 patients, is in shortage of number of essentials.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: We contacted both doctors and health officials and confirmed that there is no shortage of goods at the hospital as of yet and the messages were fabricated.

claim: Oman is releasing a special chemical into the sky to eradicate coronavirus with military helicopters.
label: fake
statement: releasing pesticides oman eliminate air coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The Oman health minister said that they had never conducted such operations with military helicopters. When the same message went viral in India, the Press Information Bureau has said that it is a fake message.

claim: With self-checkup you can find out if you are infected with coronavirus.
label: fake
statement: minutes every drinking water cure coronavirus
