explain: Explanation: Neither the World Health Organization (WHO) nor the government of India has stated anywhere that the coronavirus infection can be evaluated by the breath test as mentioned in the post. Some doctors have also mentioned that breath test cannot help in finding out if the person is infected with coronavirus.

claim: “Ministry of Health ITALY released a small video, HOW the virus spreads!!!… BEST VIDEO. Please see ..how innocently it spread. SOAP is the remedy CLEAN/ WASH ur Hands always”
label: fake
statement: ur innocently always wash soap small see clean
explain: Explanation: The viral video was not released by the health ministry of Italy in the wake of coronavirus but has been on YouTube for a long time. We reached the conclusion that the viral claim is ‘Misleading’.

claim: The viral video claims to show the visuals of China police personnel trying to control the patients allegedly suffering from the pandemic.
label: fake
statement: visuals allegedly personnel trying suffering china
explain: Explanation: The viral video has nothing to do with the coronavirus outbreak and is related to police storming the metro in the wake of Hong Kong protests.

claim: Coronavirus can be cured by sniffing clove and camphor and by drinking water, the virus will go to the stomach and the acid in the stomach will kill the virus.
label: fake
statement: stomach virus sniffing clove camphor acid cured drinking
explain: Explanation: Dr. Mohammad Imran, an Ayurveda doctor, said, “It is merely a rumor which has gone viral on social media .There is no scientific evidence which backs the claim that sniffing clove and camphor can cure coronavirus. However, natural camphor and clove does have certain health benefits as it can cure fungus and bacteria”.

claim: As coronavirus outbreak surges, PM Narendra Modi has decided to facilitate fellow countrymen with free masks under the ‘Swacch Bharat’ scheme.
label: fake
statement: swacch fellow decided countrymen bharat surges narendra facilitate
explain: Explanation: The government has not announced any such scheme under which it is aimed to provide free masks. The viral webpage may be a part of the decade-old phishing technique or it may be an attempt to collect the data. However, the intent behind creating this webpage is not yet clear but it is crystal clear that the webpage does not belong to Indian govt and might be a venture of some fraudulent organization.

claim: Chinese intelligence officer says the novel coronavirus as a biological weapon invented by China.
label: fake
statement: intelligence biological officer invented weapon chinese china coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The viral post also claims that the damage caused by the pandemic is being normalized by the Chinese officials. The website which has published the alleged testimony of the said Chinese intelligence officer has published the report with the headline, “CORONA UNMASKED: Chinese Intelligence Officer Reveals True Magnitude of China’s Fake “Coronavirus” Crisis – 包含中文字符版本”. The story published by the Reddit community No Sleep is just a horror story and does not have anything to do with reality. The community itself terms it as a storytelling platform and not a true story publisher.

claim: Drinking alcohol helps against the new coronavirus
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The fact that drinking alcohol can protect from new coronavirus has no clinical support.

claim: These at-home coronavirus testing kits are real.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Three health-care companies — including Everlywell — partnered with labs that were approved under the FDA emergency guidelines to perform COVID-19 diagnostics. However, there was an FDA update on March 21, which clarified that at-home sample collection is not covered under the Administration’s Emergency Use Authorization.

claim: Football player Cristiano Ronaldo turned all his hotels into hospitals to help coronavirus patients and is paying doctors and the staff.
label: fake
statement: player football paying turned cristiano staff ronaldo hotels
explain: Explanation: A spokesperson for the hotel denied the claim stating, "We are a hotel. We are not going to be a hospital. It is a day like everyone else, we are and will remain a hotel." The news was also denied by HRT, Gol, Haber, Pogled, Flash and Hayat, while the Sport and Magazine plus portals deleted their articles.

claim: Did Donald Trump attempt to steal a COVID-19 vaccine from a German company and refuse testing kits from WHO?
label: fake
statement: steal attempt refuse german company kits donald testing
explain: Explanation: Reports that Trump tried to pay a German company for the rights to a vaccine are not confirmed, and the U.S. government did not refuse tests from the World Health Organization.

claim: Georgian homeopath discussed a homeopathic drug with crocodile blood that cures coronavirus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Homeopathy is an alternative medicine with no proof that it cures any disease.

claim: Philippine Presidential Spokesperson Salvador Panelo said South Korea imposed a “total lockdown” to control the spread of COVID-19.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: South Korean officials did not impose a “total lockdown” in dealing with the spread of the COVID-19 pandemic but a widespread testing campaign.

claim: Claim that Dr. Anthony Fauci’s statement that the coronavirus death rate is 10 times that of the seasonal flu is “a claim without any scientific basis.”
label: fake
statement: ron paul basis rate death coronavirus
explain: Explanation: It is not yet known what the death rate from COVID-19 will be. Early data indicate it is more than 10 times higher than the death rate for the flu.

claim: Video shows problems faced by Chinese police while catching coronavirus-infected people.
label: fake
statement: clash democracy crackdown pro passed kong hong china
explain: Explanation: The video has nothing to do with the coronavirus pandemic. It was shot last year in September during Hong Kong's ongoing pro-democracy protest.

claim: A meme shows an image of fully stocked shelves of toilet paper, purportedly during the 2009 H1N1 outbreak, above barren shelves during the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic.
label: fake
statement: stocked shelves fully swine meme flu
explain: Explanation: The post is misleading. The image of the stocked shelves is a screenshot from U.S. news footage shot in 2020, not in 2009.

claim: A video viewed more than 2.4 million times on Facebook urges people to inhale steam to “kill” the novel coronavirus.
label: fake
statement: inhaling treat steam infection cure coronavirus
explain: Explanation: Experts say that doing so will not treat or cure the viral infection, and could in fact be harmful.

claim: A graphic has been shared thousands of times on Facebook which claims that gargling warm water with salt or vinegar can eliminate the novel coronavirus, COVID-19.
label: fake
statement: vinegar warm gargling salt infection water experts coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The claim is false; international health authorities and experts do not list gargling as an effective remedy or prevention method for COVID-19.

claim: Gargling salt with water “eliminates” the 2019 novel coronavirus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Local and international health authorities have said there is no proof that gargling water with salt eliminates the novel coronavirus. There is no known cure.

claim: Former senator Antonio Trillanes IV allegedly posted a tweet saying that President Rodrigo Duterte is to blame for calamities the country has been facing, including the novel coronavirus pandemic.
label: fake
statement: trillanes blaming antonio tweet duterte coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The tweet came from an account posing as Trillanes. Using his official Twitter account, the former senator explained how the username of the account is different from the one he’s using.

claim: Astrologers had predicted the appearance of a coronavirus in 2020.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Horoscopes and astrological forecasts have no scientific basis.

claim: After husband tested positive for coronavirus, wife fled from Bangalore to Agra in India.
label: fake
statement: run knowing bangalore husband wife away tested patient
explain: Explanation: The woman went to her parents' place in Agra on 3/9/20, while her husband was confirmed positive for coronavirus on 3/12/20. She did not enter Bangalore city. Karnataka government has clarified that the woman did not flee to her parents’ place.

claim: The health service in Ireland is asking people to stockpile food.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The claim is not true. The supply chains in Ireland remain robust

claim: Ireland is going into a ‘Status Red’ lockdown with the military patrolling the streets.
label: fake
statement: patrolling status ireland red streets military going lockdown
explain: Explanation: The claim was untrue. Ireland has not gone into lockdown

claim: Turmeric and lemon can cure the coronavirus.
label: fake
statement: turmeric heres explain truth lemon doctors coronavirus
explain: Explanation: Medical practitioners and the WHO say this claim is false.

claim: You can check for coronavirus by holding your breath for 10 seconds.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: There is no evidence to support the claim.

claim: A video claims to show coronavirus being extracted from a man’s upper lip.
label: fake
statement: upper lip extracted mans ef fe coronavirus
explain: Explanation: A botfly larva is being extracted from the man's lip in the video.

claim: Uganda did not deport 19 passengers from high-risk COVID-19 countries.
label: fake
statement: deport passengers uganda high countries risk covid
explain: Explanation: Ugandan authorities did not deport 19 passengers on a KLM flight from Amsterdam to Entebbe. The passengers did not show severe flu-like symptoms.

claim: Indian yoga guru Baba Ramdev has been infected with coronavirus.
label: fake
statement: cow urine ramdev dung treated using coronavirus
explain: Explanation: A photo of Ramdev is from 2011 and shared with a false caption. It was taken in Dehradun after the yoga guru broke his nine-day fast. He had been on a hunger strike demanding a tougher law against corruption and seeking the return of black money stashed abroad.

claim: Zinc lozenges are proven to protect against COVID-19.
label: fake
statement: หัวหอม ขมิ้น ยาอมป้องกัน-รักษา COVID-19 จริงหรือ ? | ความจริง-โควิด | ชัวร์ก่อนแชร์ FACTSHEET
explain: Explanation: No scientific proof for this claim.

claim: Drinking warm water with lemon protects against the novel coronavirus.
label: fake
statement: protects warm lemon drinking water coronavirus
explain: Explanation: Health experts say there is no proof this is effective.
loc: Australia, India, South Africa, Ivory Coast

claim: A Shaheen Bagh protest in India was claimed to have coronavirus.
label: fake
statement: protester shaheen bagh messages tested positive coronavirus
explain: Explanation: Hospitals in Delhi confirmed that no Shaheen Bagh protest had tested positive for COVID-19.

claim: European Health Organization (EHO) announced that eating beef can cure coronavirus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: There is no official institution with the name European Health Organization (EHO). Also, no authority in the European Union has announced that eating beef will cure coronavirus.

claim: Garlic, onions and other traditional medicine recipes are treatments against the new coronavirus.
label: fake
statement: recipes treatments onions traditional garlic medicine coronavirus
explain: Explanation: There is no evidence that garlic or traditional medicine can protect from the new coronavirus, according to the WHO.
orginated: Secretary of the National Security and Defense Council Oleksiy Danilov

claim: Trump’s effort to blame Obama for sluggish coronavirus testing.
label: fake
statement: sluggish effort bogus blame trumps obama testing coronavirus
explain: Explanation: There was no “Obama rule,” just draft guidance that never took effect and was withdrawn before President Trump took office.

claim: A runny nose and sputum secretion are not symptoms of novel coronavirus.
label: fake
statement: symptom runny nose contradict advisories international coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The WHO listed these as possible symptoms.

claim: Viral photo in Nigeria suggests former President Obasanjo said there is no coronavirus in Nigeria and that the minister of health lied.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: President Obasanjo's spokesperson, Kehinde Akinyemi, refuted allegations attributed to Baba; a moniker often used to describe the former head of state. A Google reverse image search revealed that the "Fox News writer" (the source) used the image out of context.

claim: Ministry of Health confirms new case of coronavirus in Santa Elena province, Ecuador.
label: fake
statement: elena province confirms santa case ministry ecuador coronavirus
explain: Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

claim: The Vatican confirmed that Pope Francis and two aides tested positive for coronavirus.
label: fake
statement: vatican confirms pope francis tested positive coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The Vatican denied allegations that Pope Francis contracted COVID-19.

claim: A video shows a man with COVID-19 spitting on grocery store items.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Tracing back to the earliest copy of the video online, there is no information that the person is positive for COVID-19. The blurry clip likewise makes it difficult to determine what the person was doing to the grocery items.

claim: Election years in the United States coincide with major disease outbreaks.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Several years of discovery or the associated spread of a disease do not match election years, national and international health organizations said.

claim: Coronavirus patients in China are caught by officials on a highway.
label: fake
statement: swat team caught mock drill china coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The video shows a mock drill. The China SWAT team in the video is "practicing" how to deal with coronavirus patients.

claim: Keeping your throat moist will wash the coronavirus down to your stomach where the virus will die.
label: fake
statement: washes lungs entering stomach prevents drinking water coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The WHO and Dr. Norberto Francisco, chief of clinical trials and research at the Lung Center of the Philippines, say drinking water will not prevent a coronavirus infection.

claim: Eat herbs, curmin, like people in India, and you will be safe from COVID-19.
label: fake
statement: หัวหอม ขมิ้น ยาอมป้องกัน-รักษา COVID-19 จริงหรือ ? | ความจริง-โควิด | ชัวร์ก่อนแชร์ FACTSHEET
explain: Explanation: This claim has no scientific proof.

claim: Each side of protective surgical masks has different functions, indicated by colour, and you should choose the way you wear by whether you are ill or not.
label: fake
statement: indicated functions colour choose protective ill surgical side
explain: Explanation: This is incorrect. Generally, if they have a coloured side, you should wear your mask with this pointing outward—but always read the manufacturer’s instructions to be sure.

claim: Nostradamus predicted the coronavirus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The predictions of Nostradamus are not correctly translated. Even if Nostradamus truly predicted a “plague," the title says it is taking place in a seaside town. The coronavirus originated in the city of Wuhan, China, which is not a seaside town.

claim: A video shows an anti-China protest amid the COVID-19 outbreak in Italy.
label: fake
statement: fde aba rally anti italy china
explain: Explanation: The video shows a march in Rome to commemorate the 40th anniversary of the assassination of Valerio Verbano, an Italian left-wing activist murdered in 1980.

claim: This map shows the global spread of COVID-19.
label: fake
statement: paths movement worldwide flight residents map wuhan
explain: Explanation: The map shows flight paths worldwide. It does not show the movement of Wuhan residents.

claim: A video shows a family killed by the coronavirus amid China’s multi-city lockdown.
label: fake
statement: multi fd chinas af city killed family lockdown
explain: Explanation: The video does not show a family killed by the coronavirus. The family reportedly died from carbon monoxide poisoning in December 2019.

claim: Chinese government requests the Supreme People’s Court for permission to kill 20,000 coronavirus patients to stop the spread of the disease
label: fake
explain: Explanation: China has not sought the permission of the country's Supreme People's Court to execute 20,000 coronavirus patients.

claim: Drinking water and keeping your throat moist can prevent the novel coronavirus from attaching to your throat.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The WHO said drinking water, while good for overall health, does not prevent coronavirus infection.
orginated: Philippines Health Secretary Francisco Duque III

claim: Can cannabis cure coronavirus?
label: fake
explain: Explanation: There is no government mandate, research or WHO comments supporting cannabis as a cure for coronavirus.

claim: Coronavirus found in broiler chicken
label: fake
statement: coronavorus chickens broiler prove found evidence
explain: Explanation: No evidence proves this claim. The WHO has clarified that meat cooked properly can be consumed.

claim: A doctor faints during surgery on a coronavirus patient.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The video shows a doctor fainting during open heart surgery. It was recorded in a hospital of Zhaotong in Yunnan, China.

claim: A doctor named Leslie Chow discovered the coronavirus and died after contact with coronavirus patients.
label: fake
statement: named leslie chow contact discovered doctor died coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The photo corresponds with American actor Ken Jeong. The doctor Lin Wenliang was the first to warn of the risk of coronavirus.

claim: Chickens cause coronavirus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: There has been no confirmation of a link between chickens and the new coronavirus. The WHO has said that it is looking into animal sources.

claim: Alibaba Group founder Jack Ma gave US$5 million to a Filipino student who developed a vaccine for novel coronavirus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: No vaccine has been developed to stop the new coronavirus. Jack Ma's donation to a Filipino student cannot be confirmed.

claim: A video shows domesticated and exotic animals being sold in a wet market in Wuhan, China.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The video is a composite of two different clips, one of Langowan Traditional Market and the other of Tomohon Traditional Market, both in Indonesia.

claim: Japan has sent a 1,000-man medical team to Wuhan.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Taken on 5/20/08, the image shows a 22-member medical team at Japan’s Narita International Airport before flying to Chengdu city in China, hit by an earthquake.

claim: A photo caption reads: “The person in this image came with the Chinese lady who tested positive for coronavirus, fled to avoid medical tests and is reportedly hidden in the Delgoda (Sri Lanka) area.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The photo is of Tharin Gunawardhana, an undergraduate student from the University of Moratuwa and a Sri Lankan national

claim: A photo of people lying in the street is accompanied by a caption implying they are coronavirus victims in China.
label: fake
statement: relate lying street picture china coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The photo taken in 2014 shows people lying down in a pedestrian zone in Frankfurt, Germany, as part of an art project remembering victims of the Katzbach concentration camp.

claim: The novel coronavirus can be cured by one bowl of freshly boiled garlic.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The WHO has issued a clarification that garlic may have some antimicrobial properties, but there is no evidence that it can protect people from the novel coronavirus.

claim: A photo shows coronavirus victims in China.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The photo taken in 2014 shows people lying down in a pedestrian zone in Frankfurt, Germany, as part of an art project remembering victims of the Katzbach concentration camp.

claim: Corpses of coronavirus victims are scattered on a street in Wuhan, China.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Taken on 3/24/14, the photo shows people lying in a pedestrian zone for an art project remembering victims of the Katzbach concentration camp.

claim: A video shows the new hospital set up in China for coronavirus patients.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The video is found to exist on the internet since at least 2018.

claim: Ministry of health’s emergency notified the public about the new coronavirus outbreak. (Jan. 29)
label: fake
statement: moist throat advisory keep issued ministry coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The advisory message has not been issued by the Health Ministry. Also, in the precautions released by the Ministry, there is nothing related to keeping the throat moist.

claim: Video of a girl dying of coronavirus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The girl in the video has not died due to coronavirus. The family of the girl and the Malaysian Health Ministry have confirmed that the rumours about the girl’s death are FALSE.

claim: Video of a market in Wuhan (China), the suspected origin of the coronavirus outbreak.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The video was taken at an animal market in Langowan (Indonesia). It is not related to Wuhan (China).

claim: A vaccine for the coronavirus was being trialled in January 2020 days before the outbreak.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Incorrect. The trial referenced was for a different type of coronavirus—Middle East respiratory syndrome (MERS).

claim: A Saudi Arabian study for a MERS vaccine is linked to the outbreak of coronavirus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Based on the evidence, AAP FactCheck found the Facebook post to be false. The Saudi clinical trial is investigating a vaccine for the MERS coronavirus strain, not the 2019 Novel coronavirus.

claim: Post claims food products such as rice, fortune cookies, mi goreng noodles, ice tea and “Chinese red bull” are contaminated with coronavirus in Australia. Also some areas of Sydney are supposedly identified as contaminated.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: AAP FactCheck found the Facebook post to be false. A viral infectious diseases expert says there is no evidence of food being a source of any coronavirus transmission. The Facebook post also lists information from the “Department of Diseasology Parramatta” conducting tests showing “positive readings” for the virus at train stations in four Sydney suburbs. NSW Health confirmed to AAP Fact Check there is no such organisation as the “Department of Diseasology Parramatta” and there have been no “positive readings” at train stations.

claim: There are several new confirmed cases in several French cities.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Hospitals and authorities denied such claims in various cities.

claim: Chinese scientists expelled from a Canadian microbiology lab took the novel coronavirus strain with them to China.
label: fake
statement: strain microbiology expelled took canadian scientists lab chinese
explain: Explanation: The two scientists at the National Microbiology Lab (Winnipeg, Canada) are suspected to have sent live Ebola and Henipah viruses to Beijing in March 2019, but it has nothing to do with the coronavirus. They were expelled from the lab, but are not considered spies.

claim: Doctors said the entire Wuhan population will die of the novel coronavirus.
label: fake
statement: entire population die said doctors wuhan coronavirus
explain: Explanation: Authorities never said that and U.S CDC said most people will recover on their own.

claim: Person flees from isolation ward in Hyderabad, India.
label: fake
statement: suspect returnee chased kerala dubai hyderabad covid
explain: Explanation: The person chased by police and health personnel had returned from Dubai and violated home quarantine in Kerala.

claim: Tamil National Alliance leader Sampanthan states that Tamil Nadu COVID-19 patients should be sent to Sri Lanka, as there are less patients in the country.
label: fake
statement: tn suggested sampanthan sl sent covid
explain: Explanation: TNA leader has never made a statement suggesting Tamil Nadu COVID-19 patients should be sent to Sri Lanka.

claim: Multiple posts shared thousands of times on Facebook in Nigeria claim to be giving out smartphones to help students attend online classes during the novel coronavirus pandemic.
label: fake
statement: Multiple posts shared thousands times Facebook Nigeria giving smartphones to help students attend online classes the novel coronavirus pandemic .
explain: Explanation: However, this is one of a growing number of scams aimed at increasing followers of social media pages and accounts.

claim: Claims from Spanish singer Miguel Bosé on the Bill and Melinda Gates foundation, that he made last Tuesday, June 9 through a Twitter thread on his personal account.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation has not been expelled from India and neither has the GAVI Alliance, of which the Foundation is one of its main partners. Also, the singer's allegations about vaccines are false.

claim: A hot environment, ginger, and ginger can prevent a COVID-19 infection.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: There is no official treatment that can prevent COVID-19, according to the World Health Organization (WHO).
orginated: Facebook user Camilah K Hadji Abdullah

claim: Wearing a mask, the exhaled viruses will not be able to escape and will concentrate in the nasal passages, penetrate the olfactory nerves, and then transit to the brain.
label: fake
statement: tration port pc nc eca debd cerveau masque
explain: Explanation: According to the peer reviews, the study is illogical and inconclusive.

claim: Japanese Nobel laureate Dr. Tasuku Honjo has said China manufactured coronavirus and he once worked at the Wuhan lab which later produced it.
label: fake
statement: never manufactured japanese laureate said nobel china coronavirus
explain: Explanation: Dr. Honjo refuted the viral message as "false accusation" and "misinformation". He neither said China manufactured coronavirus nor did he work in any lab in Wuhan.

claim: Uganda Red Cross Society in partnership with the United States Agency for International Development (USAID).
label: fake
statement: society jobs advert cross uganda research ca red
explain: Explanation: The Uganda Red Cross Society distanced only advertises vacancies on its website and on national newspapers.

claim: Vodacom is offering Tsh80,000 to M-Pesa users as COVID-19 relief funds.
label: fake
statement: vodacom tsh pesa eb af users relief offering
explain: Explanation: The website that the promotion appears on uses the Vodacom and M-Pesa logos, but is not linked to either entity.

claim: Tamil Nadu (India) government approved Thanikasalam Siddha medicine for COVID-19.
label: fake
statement: thanikasalam siddha tamil nadu approved medicine covid
explain: Explanation: Tamil Nadu government has clarified that it has not approved any such drug for treating COVID-19.

claim: Lesotho has launched a COVID-19 remedy.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Leso Oxi is a herbal concoction manufactured in Lesotho, where it is claimed to be effective against the flu, but it is yet to be tested against COVID-19.

claim: 5G wireless technology created the COVID-19 pandemic.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The World Health Organization has stated that there is no link between the disease and exposure to 5G wireless technology.

claim: Humans are getting sick because the “bioengineered” coronavirus in one’s body is reacting to 5G, and a coronavirus vaccine “with an RFID chip” will be introduced as the cure for the disease, called “mark of the beast.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The World Health Organization (WHO) said “no adverse health effect has been causally linked with exposure to wireless technologies.” It also said 5G technology does not spread COVID-19 because viruses “cannot travel on radio waves.” The claim that a “vaccine with RFID chip” will be given to people as a “cure” for COVID-19 is false on two accounts. First, a vaccine does not cure a disease but prevents it. Second, the claim of a COVID-19 vaccine being developed with an RFID chip has been called “preposterous” by a health expert in a similar fact check by Politifact, because even the smallest version of RFID chips are still “rather large such that none would ever fit into a vaccine needle.”

claim: Northern Ireland was testing for COVID-19 at a rate 10 times that of Scotland, reported on 9 May 2020.
label: fake
statement: scotlands northern times rate ireland testing covid
explain: Explanation: Northern Ireland’s test rate for the day of 8 May 2020 was about three-quarters (80%) that of Scotland.

claim: A mixture of lemon, ginger, and hot water can cure COVID-19.
label: fake
statement: ecf mixture ginger lemon da cure covid
explain: Explanation: While the mixture has potential health benefits, it is not effective against the disease, which is spread by a virus.

claim: Archbishop of Colombo, Sri Lanka, Cardinal Malcom Ranjith filed a FR petition challenging the cremation of Catholics, who succumbed due to COVID-19.
label: fake
statement: ranjith petition malcom fr file cremation catholics cardinal
explain: Explanation: Cardinal Malcom Ranjith or Catholic Church never made such a statement. However a FR petition challenging the cremation of COVID-19 victims had been filed by a Catholic, Mr. Oshala Herath.

claim: Madagascar President Andry Rajoelina said that the World Health Organization (WHO) offered him $20 million to put toxins in their coronavirus remedy.
label: fake
statement: poison offered millions madagascar cure coronavirus
explain: Explanation: Rajoelina did not make this accusation. Some posts containing the claim attached a photo of a newspaper article which said that Rajoelina made this accusation in his interview with France 24. However, in the said interview, Rajoelina made no mention of an alleged "bribery" by WHO. He discussed Covid-Organics and addressed criticism against the supposed remedy.

claim: A leopard was seen in Mumbai due to the lockdown and a lesser number of vehicles.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The leopard was seen on the National Highway at Hyderabad and not in Mumbai due to the lockdown

claim: President of the United States of America, Donald Trump, tested positive for COVID-19.
label: fake
statement: ebe contractc donald na trump coronavirus
explain: Explanation: Two employees of the White House contracted the coronavirus, however the American president and his vice-president were not tested positive.

claim: Kenya had the highest cases of COVID-19 in Africa and the fifth-highest in the world on May 6.
label: fake
statement: highest ba number africa kenya cases covid
explain: Explanation: WHO data shows that South Africa had the highest number of cases in Africa and Russia ranked fifth worldwide on that date.

claim: Professor Didier Raoult revealed that the United States and China have created COVID-19.
label: fake
statement: tats tait cb fabriquc dit didier la unis
explain: Explanation: No official source mentions this assertion of the Marseille microbiologist.

claim: COVID-19, the disease caused by the coronavirus, is not pneumonia but a form of thrombosis or blood clotting in the blood vessels.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Multiple studies show that thrombosis or blood clotting is among the complications brought by COVID-19. However, not all COVID-19 patients exhibit this, and more studies are needed to determine the effectiveness and proper use of anticoagulants for treatment.

claim: Residents in Surat, India are protesting due to unavailability of food.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The video is from Kathua and it shows the workers of Chenab Textile Mills demanding payment of their full salaries.

claim: A family in Gujarat, India killed itself due to hunger and poverty during the COVID lockdown.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The mother hanged herself after strangling her two daughters on 2 May in Gujarat’s Morbi on the suspicion that her husband was cheating on her.

claim: Vice President Leni Robredo said it should not be people, but the virus, that should be restrained from spreading.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Robredo did not make this remark, and the graphic was altered from a quote card produced by News5, a television programme in the Philippines.

claim: Government on India’s plan for exiting the lockdown in five phases.
label: fake
statement: exiting really phases roadmap indias lockdown
explain: Explanation: The government hasn't released any such plan yet. Secondly, we found that the plan doing the rounds on social media was very similar to that of government of Ireland.

claim: Dr Devi Shetty has recommended these 22 steps to avoid coronavirus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The message has been falsely attributed to Dr Devi Shetty.

claim: A U.S. House bill would give government the power to forcibly take your family members from your home and quarantine them.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The House bill that would fund organizations to trace and prevent COVID-19 infections.

claim: Senate Majority leader Mitch Connell said the Obama administration left no game plan for a pandemic.
label: fake
statement: mcconnells game left behind obama coronavirus
explain: Explanation: McConnell is wrong to say the Obama administration left “no game plan” to deal with a pandemic; the Obama team crafted a detailed document setting forth questions and policies that should be considered.

claim: Captions on a reuploaded video about the U.S. approving Remdesivir for emergency use say the drug will “end COVID-19.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The antiviral drug is not a miracle cure for the novel coronavirus. Remdesivir, whose safety and effectiveness are still being studied, can only be used in critically ill COVID-19 patients. Only the U.S., and just this May 7, Japan, have given emergency use authorization (EUA) for the drug, developed by biopharmaceutical company Gilead Sciences, Inc.

claim: African Union (AU) has validated COVID-Organics, a Malagasy remedy against 2019-nCov (the new coronavirus).
label: fake
statement: validc titre lunion fcd dee africaine bf organics
explain: Explanation: The pan-African body has only agreed to collaborate with Madagascar to test the effectiveness of the remedy.

claim: Migrants are defying lockdown and have taken to Ahmedabad’s streets in India.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The pictures are from Telangana of May 4 when many migrants had flocked Hyderabad once they heard about the shramik trains.

claim: “Entire city of Mumbai will be under military lockdown for 10 days starting from Saturday. So please stock everything. Only milk and medicine will be available.”
label: fake
statement: starting milk everything saturday stock please entire available
explain: Explanation: It was clear after reading several media reports, including a clarification made by the Mumbai Police on Twitter, about the viral claim that the state government has not fielded army personnel in Mumbai to follow the lockdown. The announcement in the Marathi language does not mention the army anywhere, but appeals to the people to stay in their homes. Also, No official announcement has been made by the state government for complete lockdown in the entire Mumbai for the next 10 days.

claim: Thrombosis and not pneumonia is a leading cause of COVID-19 deaths and the disease has so far been wrongly diagnosed.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Thrombosis is emerging as a significant cause but is still not the leading cause of COVID-19 deaths. The disease has not been wrongly diagnosed and is being actively researched upon.

claim: Video of women jumping from a building after being locked by the Indian police for shopping during the lockdown in the country to contain COVID-19 spread.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The video was found on YouTube and Facebook in 2015 with the title: ‘Sex workers fleeing after FIA raid at a brothel in Karachi’. It is an old video and is not related to the current lockdown.

claim: Gilead Sciences announced on May 3 2020 that the new medicine for COVID-19 will be ready by next week.
label: fake
statement: remdesivir manufacturer gilead conclude enough drug evidence cure
explain: Explanation: Gilead Sciences has not announced any new medicine for COVID-19. Gilead Sciences chairman and CEO Daniel O’Day said that they intend to get the Remdesivir drug to patients in the early part of this next week. It is mentioned on the Gilead website that Remdesivir is an investigational drug that has not been approved by the FDA for any use. It is not yet known if remdesivir is safe and effective for the treatment of COVID-19.

claim: Video of Muslims violating lockdown conditions in Old city (Hyderabad).
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The video was captured when migrant workers stuck in Telangana due to lockdown came onto the streets in Tolichowki asking the government to send them to their native places. It has nothing to so with Old City in Hyderabad where most of the Muslim population resides

claim: Image of tired Sri Lankan healthcare professionals lying on the ground, inside a operating theater room.
label: fake
statement: tired professionals grey anatomy interpreted series sl tv
explain: Explanation: The photograph is from an episode of the popular TV series Grey’s Anatomy aired in 2007.

claim: According to a WHO report, not a single vegetarian person in the world has been found to suffer from coronavirus.
label: fake
statement: suffer vegetarian single according found coronavirus
explain: Explanation: We found that Gauden Galea's 3-month-old video is being shared with misleading claims. Galea did not speak of non-vegetarians having coronavirus. At the same time, we found that the World Health Organization has not issued any such report that vegetarians are safe from coronavirus.

claim: Death toll among black people is higher because the viruses affect various races differently.
label: fake
statement: riskebi rasobriv paktortan kavshirshi etnikur dainpitsirebis aris ara
explain: Explanation: There can be various social, economic and geographical factors causing a high death toll among specific communities witth no apparent evidence that it is caused by genetics.

claim: Professor Tasuku Honjo, Nobel Laureate 2018 Medicine, supports the theory that the coronavirus is not natural and was invented by China.
label: fake
statement: selon rapports lesquelles fabriquc affirme prix ca chine
explain: Explanation: The words lent to the Japanese professor are invented and are far from the truth. He refuted the statement himself.

claim: Recent mob attack on West Bengal police due to the lockdown in Howrah.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The images are from 2014 where Bharatiya Janata Party members were found beating the police officials in Uttar Pradesh against the increasing crimes in the state.

claim: Video shows that social distancing is not being followed in Delhi.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The video is from Surat, Gujarat where social distancing norms during the lockdown were not followed and is not from Delhi.

claim: The claim was that ginger powder cured coronavirus positive patients in Mumbai, advised ayurveda as cure
label: fake
explain: Explanation: WHO said there is no conclusive evidence of any form of cure to coronavirus and the ayurvedic doctor declined to give evidence.

claim: MTN Uganda is giving out 122GB of data to customers for free in response to COVID-19.
label: fake
statement: mtn bf uganda response giving data covid
explain: Explanation: The link with this offer directs users to download malicious software, and is not a valid promotion by MTN Uganda.

claim: Pregnant mothers are more likely to contract COVID-19.
label: fake
statement: puts pregnancy currently aef fa greater risk women
explain: Explanation: The claim made on Facebook is not supported by any evidence.

claim: The claim was that the huge rally of eople in Ahmedabad for Namaste Trump rally was behind more coronavirus cases in the state of Gujarat in India
label: fake
statement: namaste rally behind gujarat cases trump coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The rally was held on February 24, 2020 when coronavirus was not speading yet in India. Gujarat reported its first case a month after the event.

claim: This photo shows bodies of COVID-19 victims.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The image was taken in the aftermath of the 2004 Boxing Day Tsunami in Thailand

claim: COVID-19 is a big pharma fraud and a treatment has existed for years now (stem cell therapy).
label: fake
statement: ujredebit mkurnaloba klinikurad gherovani gamotsdili dagegmili aris ara
explain: Explanation: Stem cell therapy that has been used over the years in treatment of various ilnesses, has recenly been used to treat a coronavirus patient in the US and other 7 patients in Israel. The company says more trials are under way.

claim: The owner of the Indian jewellry group Joyalukkas died due to COVID-19.
label: fake
statement: retirement reducing personnel age rumours refutes ministry
explain: Explanation: The Joyalukkas founder is healthy. There was a confusion between the company and Joy Arakkal, a Dubai-based businessman who died of COVID-19.

claim: A message claimed that Angel Broking has gone bankrupt as oil prices went negative due to coronavirus lockdown around the world
label: fake
statement: suspending crude broking triggers trade fears angel market
explain: Explanation: Angel Broking merely suspended trade in oil due to price decline and has not gone bankrupt as claimed.

claim: Several clickbait websites published misleading headlines claiming that “cigarettes block the coronavirus”.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Milseading interpretation of the French study which offers a hypothesis that smokers may be much less at risk of contracting the virus.

claim: Filipina actress Angel Locsin “tested positive” for the coronavirus after conducting several relief operations.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: On April 26, the day the links were first shared on Facebook, Locsin announced that she had tested negative for the coronavirus. GMA News Online reported it the same day.

claim: Brahma Kamal flowers bloom after many years due to less pollution during the lockdown in India to contain COVID-19 spread.
label: fake
statement: pollution less kamal flowers bloom brahma many lockdown
explain: Explanation: The video used to make the claim is found to be on the internet at least since December 2017. Also, Brahma Kamal flowers usually bloom every year during June – September, and the flowers can be seen till mid-October. Hence there is no relation between the flower blooming and less pollution.

claim: Brahma Kamal flowers bloom after many years due to less pollution during the lockdown in India to contain COVID-19 spread.
label: fake
statement: pollution less kamal flowers bloom brahma many lockdown
explain: Explanation: The video used to make the claim is found to be on the internet at least since December 2017. Also, Brahma Kamal flowers usually bloom every year during June – September, and the flowers can be seen till mid-October. Hence there is no relation between the flower blooming and less pollution.

claim: A Nobel Prize-winning scientist said the coronavirus is “not natural” and that “China manufactured it”.
label: fake
statement: prize winner manufactured tasuku honjo nobel coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The Nobel laureate did not say the quote attributed to him, and denied it himself.

claim: In the Philippines, Kabataan Partylist representative Sarah Elago is shown in a quote card saying the lockdown amid the COVID-19 pandemic is a human rights violation.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The legislator has made no such remarks. Shared multiple times on Facebook since April 18, the manipulated image uses a photo of Elago as backdrop. It is a photo posted on her official FB account in March 2019.

claim: US students sing India’s national anthem after India agreed to supply Hydroxychloroquine.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The claim shared along with the video is false. The video was made on the occasion of Independence Day of India and is not a recent video. It was uploaded on 12 August 2017.

claim: In Madhya Pradesh the tenure of Sarpanchs (Decision makers of the villages) has been extended by five years in the wake of the COVID-19 outbreak in the state.
label: fake
statement: tenure sarpanchs makers wake villages decision pradesh madhya
explain: Explanation: An official of the ‘General Administration Department’ of the Madhya Pradesh government who informed that no such press note has been issued by the government. The signature on the press note is forged and is intended to create rumour.

claim: The remedy for coronavirus is in a page of the Koran.
label: fake
statement: remc coran trouve dans ne se coronavirus
explain: Explanation: Like any religious book, the Koran contains holy words. There is no remedy for the coronavirus hidden within it.

claim: Ghana’s National Service Secretariat to withhold payments to personnel until COVID-19 is over.
label: fake
statement: withholds secretariat personnel payments service ghanas covid
explain: Explanation: The National Service Secretariat in an interview with GhanaFact denied the claim. Meanwhile the HardTruthGH website says it is a satire/ parody portal and all articles they publish are fictitious.

claim: This photo shows a pregnant woman suffering from coronavirus
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The photo was from a birth in January 2019 and the mother is pictured in labor being supported by her husband.

claim: List of points from an interview of HDFC bank’s Managing Director Aditya Puri stating how India will survive and make it big post the current lockdown due to COVID-19.
label: fake
statement: puri banks md hdfc aditya official wrongly clarified
explain: Explanation: Neeraj Jha, Head of Corporate Communication for HDFC Bank, has clarified that while few of the points in that message were from Puri's recent interviews, the bulk of the points were wrongly attributed to him.

claim: Facebook posts shared in at least three countries as scientists work to develop a COVID-19 vaccine claim to offer a legal way to refuse vaccination.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The claims are false; immunization is not compulsory in most Australian states and Canadian provinces, while exemptions can be obtained in the United States as well as Canada’s Ontario and New Brunswick.

claim: Interview of HDFC Bank Managing Director Aditya Puri about why india will survive COVID-19 and make it big
label: fake
statement: views puris md hdfc aditya bank infinitescroll covid
explain: Explanation: Neeraj Jha, Spokesman for HDFC Bank, dismissed the bulk of the points in the post as being wrongly attributed to Aditya Puri.

claim: Video of a burqa-clad Muslim woman being denied a food kit distributed to help people during the current crisis in India due to COVID-19, for being a Muslim.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The woman in the video was not denied a food kit. Rajeev Mishra (the man distributing food rations in the video) has sent another video and photos to FACTLY, where it can be seen that the woman was given the food kit.

claim: Komal Mishra, a staff nurse at a hospital in Pune, India died while due to coronavirus.
label: fake
statement: yavatmal komal mishra pune nurse goes death
explain: Explanation: Image of a girl named Shashikala Thakare is being falsely circulated in the name of fictional nurse Komal Mishra. Shashikala is alive and does not have coronavirus.

claim: Indian economist Raghuram Rajan commented in a webinar for the IMF on India’s situation regarding COVID-19
label: fake
statement: address webinar rajan raghuram imf covid
explain: Explanation: The IMF or Rajan did not hold any such webinar while Rajan refuted these news through his linkedin.

claim: People from the Muslim community have now started throwing infected notes on the road to spread coronavirus. This new method will make it even more difficult for the police to catch the spread of the virus.
label: fake
statement: method difficult community started catch even notes throwing
explain: Explanation: It is clear from our fact check that the video of police officials picking up the currency lying on the road claiming that the Muslim community has found another innovative idea to spread COVID-19 is misleading. There is no communal angle in the incident, which happened in Indore.

claim: Muslims in West Bengal are beating up cops during the lockdown.
label: fake
statement: west cop bengal attacked communal spin
explain: Explanation: A 2017 video of cops being thrashed in Kanpur was falsely shared as West Bengal and the video is not related to coronavirus

claim: News photo from stay-at-home protest was doctored to add Confederate flag.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: A Milwaukee Journal Sentinel photo showed one protester carrying two flags, including the Confederate flag. Analyses show the photo was not doctored.

claim: Says a photo shows the “SAME EXACT PEOPLE” at “two different beaches” in Los Angeles County and Jacksonville, Florida.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: A Getty Images photographer took the photo of people in Jacksonville Beach, Fla., on April 17. An NBC News story about coronavirus cases in Los Angeles County appeared on a news aggregation site called News Break. Sharing the story on Facebook does not pull up the Getty Images photo. We could not find the image of Jacksonville Beach in any stories about the coronavirus in Los Angeles.

claim: A photo shows President Rodrigo Duterte, along with Senator Bong Go, doing the rounds during the coronavirus pandemic in the Philippines.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The photo of Duterte and Go used in the post was taken in August 2017, when both officials visited Marawi City, Lanao del Sur, for the 3rd time in the middle of clashes there between government troops and local terrorists linked to the Islamic State.

claim: A poster stating Pakistan has asked for hydroxychloroquine instead of Kashmir.
label: fake
statement: instead demand pak kashmir citizens hydroxychloroquine
explain: Explanation: The image is originally a poster held by Kashmiris demanding Azaadi and is not related to the coronavirus.

claim: A Twitter user shared an image of a map of India.The caption reads, “This is a map of India redesigned by an American CEO where he tried to explain that India is indirectly handling the COVID-19 situation of so many countries, owing to its large population”.
label: fake
statement: map owing indirectly caption redesigned reads handling explain
explain: Explanation: Erik Solheim, who is a former Norwegian diplomat, posted this image in 2016. the tweet reads “India population now at 1250 million, Look at this map - India is not just another country - it’s enormous”.

claim: News and media outlet ABP Majha, on the basis of an internal memo of South Central Railway, reported that a special train has been announced to take the stranded migrant workers home.
label: fake
statement: outlet memo majha internal abp central stranded special
explain: Explanation: Indian Railways did not issue any circular that led to the gathering of stranded migrant workers in the state of Maharashtra but was just a proposal by the South Central Railway. Hence, it can be concluded that ABP Majha misrepresented the internal letter from the South Central Railway and reported the announcement of a special train for stranded migrant workers while Indian Railways did not make any such announcement but The New Indian Express journalist Sudhir Suryavanshi falsely accused the Indian Railways of issuing a circular regarding the announcement of a special train.

claim: House of Representatives Speaker Nancy Pelosi posted and deleted a video on her Twitter account, in which she calls on people to visit Chinatown in San Francisco.
label: fake
statement: House of Representatives Nancy Pelosi Twitter Chinatown
explain: Explanation: Nancy Pelosi never tweeted a video in which she calls on people to visit San Francisco's Chinatown; therefore, she couldn't have deleted it, either.
orginated: Among others US President Trump and his campaign leader, Brad Parscale; Dutch Forum voor Democratie-Europarlementarian Derk Jan Eppink

claim: A news clipping attributed to Hindi daily Dainik Jagran stating that coronavirus was found in poultry in Bihar, India.
label: fake
statement: poultry clipping bihar newspaper found coronavirus
explain: Explanation: Dainik Jagran did not report this, this is a photoshopped picture and the state ministry did not conduct any checks on poultry

claim: Multiple posts shared repeatedly on Facebook and Twitter since March 2020 claim that Israel has reported zero deaths from the novel coronavirus, which causes the disease COVID-19. The posts also claim Israeli citizens have protected themselves from COVID-19 by drinking a remedy of hot water, lemon and baking soda, which purportedly “kills” the virus.
label: fake
statement: soda baking zero remedy israel reported deaths covid
explain: Explanation: Both claims are false; as of June 21 the World Health Organization (WHO) states Israel has reported 305 deaths from COVID-19; health experts say there is no evidence the baking soda concoction can cure or prevent COVID-19 infections.

claim: US President Donald Trump has failed to contain the coronavirus outbreak in the US as a result the Holy Quran is being read in the White House.
label: fake
statement: result holy read failed quran contain white house
explain: Explanation: US President didn't join the reciting of the verses of Quran at the White House after he failed to tackle the COVID-19 outbreak in the country and the viral video was shot on January 21, 2017, when as a part of an old tradition, the very next day after swearing-in as the US President, Donald Trump along with his deputy went to attend an interfaith prayer service at Washington National Cathedral.

claim: The Prime Minister may not have had COVID-19 and when he was admitted to hospital staff were asked to sign the Official Secrets Act and two who refused were dismissed.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: This is incorrect. It is based on a satirical blog post.

claim: Anyone in Manchester with blood group O negative should go to the Royal Infirmary as they have run out of blood.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: This is not true.

claim: Image of mother infected with COVID-19 holding her baby, covered in protective clothing.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: 1985 photograph where a baby diagnosed with cancer was undergoing treatment at the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Centre in the United States. The mother was wearing protective equipment since the immune system of the child had collapsed after the irradiation process (TBI).

claim: UN secretary-general announcement that COVID-19 vaccine trials will begin in Africa.
label: fake
statement: begin secretary collection_archive trials general africa source vaccine
explain: Explanation: The suggestion that the tuberculosis vaccine be tested on African patients to assess its potential as a treatment for COVID-19 was made by two French doctors during a tv interview. One of the scientists later apologized after the remarks caused outrage on social media.

claim: Ugandan President Museveni has shut down the State House due to COVID-19.
label: fake
statement: museveni likely abf aaf collection_archive shut house source
explain: Explanation: According to the article, President Museveni partially shut down State House operations, sent away some of his own staff and downsized cabinet ministers. However, the president has not made any public announcement about reducing operations at State House or downsizing his cabinet. No credible media publication has covered these claims, which would have been hard to miss considering how newsworthy they are.

claim: A cure for COVID-19 called Fabunan Antiviral Injection has already been approved by the government. The drug was developed by a Filipino doctor in Zambales.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: As of April 15, the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) of the Philippines has not yet approved the Fabunan Antiviral Injection. It is not included in FDA's list of registered drugs.
orginated: Facebook page RUDY Baldwin and YouTube channel NivLogs TV

claim: In the Philippines, former presidential spokesperson Salvador Panelo blamed the poor for not saving up in the middle of the coronavirus crisis.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Panelo did not say what was attributed to him in the graphic, which was manipulated from a quote card posted by Inquirer.net.

claim: Chinese state media claims Ghana’s coronavirus cases have surpassed 9,000, with over 400 deaths.
label: fake
statement: surpassed ghanas deaths chinese cases coronavirus
explain: Explanation: Official Ghana government data contradicts the claims. And a Senior Correspondent at Xinhua News Agency, Accra Bureau has conceded the claims are wrong.

claim: A woman drowned her children as she could not provide them food during the lockdown in India.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Police refuted this claim and said the woman acted in the particular way dur to marital discord. The family had food.

claim: A police personnel has been infected with coronavirus in Bihar’s Hajipur
label: fake
statement: hajipur bihars jail case mock drill covid
explain: Explanation: The video shows a mock drill on how to handle coronavirus patients, conducted by Jail officials.

claim: Philippines President Rodrigo Duterte is going to announce a “total lockdown,” where all establishments will be closed to further curb the spread of COVID-19. People are asked to stock up food and other essential items that are good for 2 weeks.
label: fake
statement: establishements declare close total duterte lockdown
explain: Explanation: The Philippine National Police (PNP) said the claim is not true. Cabinet Secretary Karlo Nograles and national policy Chief Implementer Carlito Galvez also said officials are still discussing what should be done next after the extended Luzon lockdown is lifted on April 30.

claim: The coronavirus dies in the body in 4 days, and one would be pronounced negative for the virus by the 5th day.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The time from onset to clinical recovery of COVID-19 patients takes two to 6 weeks, depending on the severity of the case.

claim: WHO’s Deputy Head Ryan Paterson chocked from broccoli as he was about to disclose sensational information about COVID-19.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The source of information was a Russian satirical website named Panorama pub.

claim: Indian government will reduce employees’ pension by 30% and terminate pensions offered to those who are above 80 as a way to divert funds towards managing health services and tackling the adverse impact of the new coronavirus pandemic.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: As of 4/9/20, the Indian government had not issued an order to reduce employees' pension by 30% and/or terminate elderly pensions.

claim: French astrologer Nostradamus had predicted in 1551 that there would be an outbreak of coronavirus in China in 2020.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: No such prediction was ever made by Nostradamus. The prediction is being circulated only recently after the COVID-19 outbreak.

claim: A video by a Russia blogger who claims that a Spanish hospital he is recording, is empty and that the information on the spread of the coronavirus is exaggerated.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: This is one of the largest hospitals in Barcelona and it is currently working with full capacity to fight the coronavirus. The official webpage of the hospital has up-to-date information on the patients, infected with the coronavirus. There are lots of photos and videos, showing that the hospital is not empty.

claim: With the novel coronavirus sending the US economy into freefall, posts that list phone numbers for job seekers to call and find work have been shared thousands of times on Facebook and Instagram.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: the numbers do not reach hiring hotlines as claimed and the companies mentioned recommend looking for job openings on their official websites.

claim: Dr. Li Wenliang (the Chinese whistleblower doctor) has proposed that drinking tea can cure COVID-19.
label: fake
statement: scientific tea drinking evidence cure covid
explain: Explanation: While it is true that tea contains methylxanthines, there is no scientific evidence to suggest that drinking tea can cure COVID-19. Also, none reported about Dr. Li Wenliang, an Ophthalmologist, suggesting any such cure for COVID-19.

claim: A Facebook post claims testing kits bought by the United Kingdom from China are contaminated with SARS-CoV-2.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: News reports on the matter did not say the kits were supplied by China. It only named Eurofins, a Luxembourg-based laboratory and testing company, which said parts of their test kits set for delivery to the UK were contaminated with the virus. There was no mention in the story of Eurofins sourcing its products from China.

claim: Canada is free of COVID-19.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The claim is false. As of 4/9/2020, Canada is reported to have 19,289 confirmed COVID-19 cases, according to the Canadian government’s map of their outbreak situation.

claim: Philippines President Rodrigo Duterte said he has been warning of the COVID-19 “since the beginning.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: In his first media briefing about the issue on Feb. 3, a day after health authorities announced the country’s first COVID-19 fatality, Duterte downplayed the gravity of the outbreak and likened the nature of the novel coronavirus to others that are either treatable or have already been contained.

claim: A screenshot of a web publication has been shared hundreds of times in multiple posts on Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram that claim the Nigeria Centre for Disease Control said it spent a billion naira ($2.78 million) on COVID-19 text message awareness campaign.
label: fake
statement: spent naira came fabricated text nigeria billion tweet
explain: Explanation: This is false; the claim stemmed from a fabricated tweet, and was denied by Nigeria’s health authorities.

claim: A member of Tablighi Jamaat is roaming naked and misbehaving with hospital staff.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The incident actually happened in August 2019 in Karachi. It has nothing to do with Tablighi Jamaatis or the current outbreak of the novel coronavirus.

claim: Kenyan electoral commission (IEBC) has hinted at postponing the 2022 general elections.
label: fake
statement: wafula postponing iebc hinted ded chebukati chairman election
explain: Explanation: A Facebook post claiming that the Independent Electoral and Boundaries Commission chairperson Wafula Chebukati has hinted at postponing the 2022 general election due to anticipated economic disruptions by COVID-19. The IEBC has dismissed the claim, stating that neither the commission nor its chair has issued any such statement.

claim: Photo of a family which committed suicide due to hunger during the lockdown.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: It is an old photo. The photo doesn't have any relation to the current lockdown. According to 'Nagpur Today' article, the incident took place in 2018.

claim: Recent photos of deer and peacocks on Ooty-Coimbatore road.
label: fake
statement: owners roads original ooty coimbatore claimed
explain: Explanation: A photo of group of deers sitting on the middle of the road has been on the internet atleast since 2014 and the photo was taken in Japan. Photo of peacocks on the road is an old one, it was taken in 'Chat Bir Zoo' (Chandigarh).

claim: Video suggesting that a man is spitting on bread to spread coronavirus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The video is originally from Philippines and is of 2019 where a Gardenia philippines employee was found to have tampered with food.

claim: Kabataan Representative, in the Philippines Sarah Elago tested positive for coronavirus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Elago denied that she tested positive for the virus, saying she did not experience any symptoms after self-quarantine and thus had no reason to get tested.

claim: Posts that are circulating on Facebook say that people need to eat alkaline food in order to prevent a novel coronavirus infection.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Eating alkaline food and drinking lemon with baking soda in hot water is not an official cure for COVID-19. As of Thursday, April 9, the World Heath Organization (WHO) has said there is no medicine that can prevent or cure this disease

claim: An arrest by the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) of a professor who had ties to China is connected to the coronavirus pandemic.
label: fake
statement: backed fbi arrest professor china coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The charges against the professor linked to the university in Wuhan, China had nothing to do with the coronavirus pandemic.

claim: Video of Rahul Gandhi and Priyanka Vadra Gandhi breaking ‘lock down’ regulations.
label: fake
statement: gandhi regulations breaking rahul priyanka vadra lockdown
explain: Explanation: The video is three months old. In December 2019, UP Police stopped Rahul Gandhi and Priyanka Vadra Gandhi from entering Meerut when they tried to meet the families of the persons who died during the anti-CAA protests.

claim: In order to take money from PM National Relief Fund (PMNRF), Congress President’s permission is required, that is why PM CARES is created.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: When PMNRF was started in 1948, Congres President was included in the mangaing committee. However, in 1985 manging committee was removed and full responsibility was given to the Prime Minister (PM). Now, the decision to use the fund lies in the hands of PM.

claim: As per WHO’s ‘Protocol and Procedure of Lockdown Periods’, lockdown will be relaxed from April 15-19 and will be re-imposed from April 20 in India.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: No such WHO protocol or procedure exists for lockdowns.’ WHO South-East’ has tweeted that the message is baseless and fake.

claim: Photo of a family which committed suicide due to hunger during the lockdown.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: It is an old photo. The same photo can be found in an article published by 'Sakshi' in June 2019. The lady killed her children and committed suicide due to problems with her husband. So, it is neither related to lockdown nor hunger.

claim: Video of Uttar Pradesh Police catching ‘Coronavirus jihadists’ at Chor Bazaar.
label: fake
statement: terror jihadists anti mock attack drill arrested coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The video is that of an ‘anti-terror attack’ mock drill conducted by the Bikapur Police in Ayodhya (Uttar Pradesh, India).

claim: Uganda has postponed general elections due to COVID-19.
label: fake
statement: fears ugandas postponed election general covid
explain: Explanation: There has not been such a directive from President Museveni as claimed by the article.

claim: Photos of large plastic-wrapped bundles being offloaded from a plane are of COVID-19 vaccines China has sent to Nigeria, to be distributed for free.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: There is currently no vaccine to prevent COVID-19, according to the WHO. The photos were taken in Accra, Ghana, and are of Chinese government donations to 18 African countries, of personal protective equipment, not vaccines.

claim: Images of a bruised youth claimed to be marks he got when police had beaten him in Colombo for curfew violations
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Original image belongs to a domestic violence incident from July 2019 in West Bengal, India.

claim: A video shows a truck dropping bodies covered with plastic into a ditch and claiming that this is the situation in Italy right now.
label: fake
statement: plastic ditch covered dropping truck right situation bodies
explain: Explanation: The video which is being widely circulated on social media is not from Italy. It is a movie scene that had been taken from the 2007 U.S. television miniseries "Pandemic."

claim: PM Modi has announced the extension of the All-India Lockdown until 5/4/20.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: No such announcement has been made by Prime Minister Modi or the government. The posted India Today screenshot is a photoshopped version of the original telecast of Modi’s address to the nation on 3/24/20, where he announced the 21-day lockdown from 3/25/20.

claim: Video of Indian activist Tripti Desai’s arrest by police after selling bottles of liquor during lockdown.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The video was taken in September 2019 when police took Trupti Desai into custody as part of preventive action before the visit of the then Chief Minister of Maharashtra, Devendra Fadnavis, in Pune.

claim: PM Modi has announced the extension of the All-India Lockdown until 5/4/20.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: No such announcement has been made by Prime Minister Modi or the government. The posted India Today screenshot is a photoshopped version of the original telecast of Modi’s address to the nation on 3/24/20, where he announced the 21-day lockdown from 3/25/20.

claim: Says Nostradamus predicted the coronavirus in a 1551 passage about a plague spreading from the east.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The format doesn't match Nostradamus’ typical quatrain predictions, and we couldn't find the words in collections of his prophecies.

claim: Five helicopters are going to spray the air with disinfectant overnight in order to combat the new coronavirus
label: fake
statement: spray overnight helicopters disinfectant combat order five air
explain: Explanation: This is a false rumour that has spread all over the world.

claim: To defeat the coronavirus, China built a thousand-bed hospital in 10 days, while India has prepared a modern hospital of 6,370 beds overnight, at a very low cost.
label: fake
statement: modern prepared overnight low defeat cost beds built
explain: Explanation: A close study on the viral claim revealed that a 6,370-bed hospital has not been constructed overnight in the country. Isolation wards have been made in some bogies of the country's first medical train Jeevan Rekha, which was run in 1991.

claim: Police in India lashed sticks at filmmaker Sudhir Mishra for not following the rules of lockdown.
label: fake
statement: sticks lashed sudhir filmmaker mishra following rules lockdown
explain: Explanation: The viral video has been falsified based on the tweet made by Sudhir Mishra himself on the viral clip.

claim: Video clip of a massive stadium converted into a graveyard claimed to be scenes from Italy related to the ongoing COVID-19 outbreak.
label: fake
statement: scenes korean portrayed movie scene flu italy
explain: Explanation: Scene from movie “Flu 2013” portrayed as scenes from Italy.

claim: WhatsApp group admins were detained for sharing coronavirus messages in Dadar, Mumbai.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Mumbai Police spokesperson dismissed the claim that Mumbai police's cyber cell was registering cases against 52 WhatsApp group admins and called it fake.

claim: The lockdown due to coronavirus has led to the reemergence of a large flock of birds at the riverfront in Ahmedabad.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: These birds are a regular site at the riverfront in Ahmedabad and the video has been shared with a false narrative.

claim: Italian streets are littered with Euro notes, as Italians throw cash away in coronavirus crisis.
label: fake
statement: venezuelan robbers dumped italians currency cash away throwing
explain: Explanation: Photos showing money littering streets are of old Venezuelan currency dumped by robbers in March 2019.

claim: Video of Muslims being trained to sneeze purposefully to spread coronavirus.
label: fake
statement: tradition sufi preparation following muslims coronavirus
explain: Explanation: It is an old video. While the first COVID-19 positive case in India was reported on 1/30/20 in Kerala, the video was found on the internet at least since 1/29/20 and is being shared as that from Pakistan. Also, the people in the video were not being trained to spread coronavirus. They are doing a type of Zikr, a Sufi ritual, which involves body movement and heavy breathing.

claim: People of Italy throwing money on the streets because it can’t save them from COVID-19.
label: fake
statement: save venezuela could throwing streets italy covid
explain: Explanation: The photos are old, and are not related to the recent COVID-19 outbreak. They were taken in Venezuela, not in Italy. Some people threw the notes as they became valueless due to hyperinflation in the country.

claim: Indian Ministry of Home Affairs (MHA) issued an order that sharing a post about coronavirus on social media groups is a punishable offense.
label: fake
statement: making punishable offence sharing ministry coronavirus
explain: Explanation: Press Information Bureau (PIB) has clarified that the Ministry of Home Affairs (MHA) has not issued any order stating that posting anything related to coronavirus on social media is a punishable offense.

claim: Tablik Jamaat Chief Maulana Saad: “If 70,000 people get coronavirus, India will be destroyed. The country will be in our possession.”
label: fake
statement: tabliqi saad maulana destroyed gets thousand jamaat chief
explain: Explanation: The audio clip posted by Republic TV as the speech of Tablighi Jamaat Chief, Maulana Saad, doesn't mention that "If 70,000 people get coronavirus, India will be destroyed," as included in the post. Moreover, Republic TV said they are not sure if the person who spoke in the audio clip is Maulana Saad..

claim: Sri Lanka’s KDU hospital will be dedicated to treat only VIP COVID-19 patients.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Hospital director, chief epidemiologist and defense secretary all refuted the claim and said the hospital is ready to admit any patient.

claim: A message asked people not to eat bakery food as it is not washable even if infected from the coronavirus, using a logo of the WHO.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: WHO never said it and the US FDA denied the claim as there is no evidence of food or food packaging being associated with the transmission of COVID-19.

claim: Image of bakery items with the WHO logo and a message which given the impression that WHO had advised the public not to consume bakery products amid COVID-19 concerns.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The WHO has not issued any statement against consumption of bakery products and the FDA confirms there is no evidence of food or food packaging being associated with transmission of COVID-19.

claim: News graphic saying Indian prime minister has asked for the internet to be shut down in the country.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The news graphic is photoshopped and fake. The prime minister did not make this statement.

claim: A news publication reports the Royal Palace confirms Queen Elizabeth tests positive for coronavirus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: While we cannot know if Queen Elizabeth does not have COVID-19, no evidence suggests she does. Besides, no notable publications corroborate this assertion. Although she came in contact with Boris Johnson, Prime Minister of England, who has a positive COVID-19 status, no reports definitively say she has undergone a test. Rather, credible intel suggests she is “following all the appropriate advice with regards to her welfare."

claim: A website claiming that China has confirmed that patient zero had sex with a bat.
label: fake
statement: site invents bats zero sex patient covid
explain: Explanation: World News Daily is a website generating fake news and it is scientifically seen that the virus has emerged from an animal source.

claim: Bombay High Court is extending Maharashtra’s lockdown to April 31.
label: fake
statement: hc bombay extended maharashtra till april lockdown
explain: Explanation: The High Court had only extended its interim orders and not the lockdown.

claim: A herd of deer reclaimed the Ooty-Coimbatore road.
label: fake
statement: reclaimed herd ooty deer coimbatore road
explain: Explanation: The viral image is from Japan's Nara, taken in 2014. It has no connection with India or the lockdown.

claim: President Donald Trump attending the recital of Quran verses to fight coronavirus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The video is from 2017, when Trump and his wife Melania attended the inaugural prayer service after taking the oath as the 45th president of the United States. Imam Mohammad Majid, executive director of the All Dulles Area Muslim Society, recited verses from the Quran.

claim: A video claiming bodies packed in body bags are being dumped in mass graves in Italy and Spain.
label: fake
statement: mini grave mass series scene peddled coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The video is from a 2007 sci-fi mini series called "Pandemic."

claim: Indian Home Minister Amit Shah claimed to be infected with COVID-19.
label: fake
statement: amit shah graphic tests positive coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The news graphic was created from a news generator and the news that the Home Minister has COVID-19 is not true.

claim: The Netflix Korean drama “My Secret Terrius” predicted the coronavirus outbreak in 2018.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The show discusses coronavirus, a family of viruses causing flu like symptoms. The symptoms mentioned are very different from COVID-19 and the fatality rate is much higher.

claim: Italian PM said that the country has surrendered to the COVID-19 pandemic
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The quote attributed to the Italian PM is fabricated.

claim: Surin Province governor in Thailand revealed that 100,000 people are infected.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The shared clip was trimmed from an original (about speculation and situation) to make people believe the actual patient is 100,000.

claim: If you don’t wear a mask while driving, police will fine you 200 baht.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Police insisted that no such policy exists.

claim: Video clip shows people keep leaving Phuket.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: It's not in Phuket. It's actually a news from Thailand-Myanmar border in the north. And they are Myanmar labour who wanted to go to their home country.

claim: A Facebook user made a post saying that “Ghana has recorded 1,500 cases of coronavirus.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Ghana has not recorded 1,500 coronavirus cases. A total of 137 cases had been confirmed at the time the claim was made on 3/27/20. The country currently has 152 confirmed cases of coronavirus.

claim: A herd of deer flocking out in Tamil Nadu, India, due to the coronavirus lockdown.
label: fake
statement: oh herd ooty deer coimbatore japan spotted pic
explain: Explanation: The image is originally from Japan and was taken in 2014. It shows the Nara deers that are considered to be auspicious flanking the streets of Nara.
