claim: Photo of an Indonesian doctor, Hideo Ali, looking at his children and pregnant wife for the last time.
label: fake
statement: indonesian malaysia treating doctor died coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The one in the photo is not Indonesian doctor, Hideo Ali. He is a doctor from Malaysia. A Malaysian man posted this picture on Facebook saying that the doctor is his cousin and because of the spread of COVID-19 across the country, he had to leave his family and work constantly. Since he doesn't have time, he is looking at his family from a distance, and the photo is related to that instance.

claim: COVID-19 was known to humans before its outbreak in 2020.
label: fake
statement: decades type humans known coronaviruses ago sars cov
explain: Explanation: The new coronavirus (which causes COVID-19) was first reported in December 2019. All the old images and videos being shared on social media refer to the virus as coronavirus, not as SAR-CoV-2 (or COVID-19). coronaviruses were known to humans decades ago. All the references made on social media were about the coronaviruses, a general term for various viruses which cause diseases ranging from the common cold to Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS).

claim: Image of dead bodies of coronavirus victims in Italy.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The image shows coffins containing the dead bodies of Lampedusa shipwreck victims. In 2013, a boat packed with around 500 African migrants caught fire and sank around half a mile from the Italian island Lampedusa, causing the deaths of more than 300 people.

claim: Photos of coronavirus patients being treated on the road in Italy.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The photos in the post are related to the earthquake in Croatia on March 22. Patients at the hospital were evacuated because of the earthquake.

claim: Over 200 doctors in Italy die every day due to coronavirus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The total number of doctors in Italy who died due to the coronavirus is 66 as of 4/2/20.

claim: According to a report by the WHO, coronavirus lives the longest in the cabbage layer. Elsewhere the virus lives for 9-12 hours, whereas in cabbage, this virus lives for more than 30 hours. People of all cities are requested not to eat cabbage.
label: fake
statement: lives cabbage hours virus whereas requested longest layer
explain: Explanation: The WHO has not said cabbage is dangerous because the coronavirus can live longer on it than on any other surface.

claim: The bodies of people infected with coronavirus are lying on the road of Italy. No one is carrying them due to the risk of infection.
label: fake
statement: carrying lying risk road infection bodies italy coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The image is from Germany, where people lied down in a pedestrian zone as part of an art project in remembrance of 528 victims of the Katzbach Nazi concentration camp in Frankfurt.

claim: Coronavirus fear in Germany results in large crowds outside a supermarket. People are pushing each other to get into the store first for necessary supplies.
label: fake
statement: results necessary crowds outside fear store pushing large
explain: Explanation: This video was uploaded on January 30, 2011 on YouTube, when many people went shopping at an Aldi mall.

claim: Tea can cure coronavirus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Doctors and experts say that there is no scientific evidence to prove that tea can be used to cure coronavirus.

claim: New vaccine can help cure coronavirus in three hours.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: No vaccine has been found yet for the coronavirus. The image is that of a diagnosis kit and not a vaccine.

claim: A video has been shared thousands of times in multiple posts on Facebook which claim it shows a woman who was detained by police in Australia after she tested positive for the novel coronavirus, COVID-19, and was filmed spitting at a supermarket in a Sydney suburb.
label: fake
statement: separate involving supermarkets incidents different women two
explain: Explanation: The claim is misleading. The video has been created from two clips of separate incidents involving different women. Police in Australia said the first clip shows a woman who was questioned and released after a disturbance at a store in a Sydney suburb. The Australian supermarket chain cited in the misleading posts said the second clip was not filmed in its stores.

claim: A purported news report claims that Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte approved the release of P20,000 (USD $400) to all recipients of the Philippines’ Social Security System (SSS) to help them through the novel coronavirus pandemic.
label: fake
statement: benefit payment agency security philippines said covid
explain: Explanation: The claim is false; the SSS said the report was “fake news." The website that published the claim is not a reputable news source.

claim: Photo of people in medical scrubs lying on the floor of an operating theatre shows some of the 200 Italian doctors who died of COVID-19 in one day on 3/23/20.
label: fake
statement: greys drama anatomy tv italian dead doctors covid
explain: Explanation: Photo is a still from an episode of US TV drama, "Grey's Anatomy." There is no evidence to show that 200 Italian doctors died on 3/23/20.

claim: An image shared on social media claims this Italian doctor couple worked day and night and saved the lives of 134 patients, but on the eighth day, they contracted the coronavirus and died after an hour.
label: fake
statement: day worked hour eighth saved night lives couple
explain: Explanation: The couple in the picture is not Italian; they are from Spain. The photograph was taken at Barcelona Airport on 3/12/20.

claim: An image shared on social media claims this Italian doctor couple worked day and night and saved the lives of 134 patients, but on the eighth day, they contracted the coronavirus and died after an hour.
label: fake
statement: day worked hour eighth saved night lives couple
explain: Explanation: The couple in the picture is not Italian; they are from Spain. The photograph was taken at Barcelona Airport on 3/12/20.

claim: Image of the people who died of coronavirus in Italy.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The photo is not related to recent coronavirus deaths in Italy. It was taken in Frankfurt (Germany) in 2014 as part of an art project in remembrance of 528 Katzbach victims of the Nazi concentration camp.

claim: A video of food packets deposited on a street has been viewed millions of times on Facebook, Twitter and YouTube alongside a claim it shows food donations for people in Turkey during a novel coronavirus lockdown.
label: fake
statement: turkey eastern january hit donations earthquake deadly
explain: Explanation: The claim is false. The video shows donations for victims of a deadly earthquake that struck eastern Turkey in January 2020, almost two months before Turkey recorded its first case of the novel coronavirus.

claim: Does vaping reduce your chances of getting the coronavirus?
label: fake
explain: Explanation: There aren't many studies on the link between vaping and COVID-19 specifically, but there is enough evidence that smoking does not help. Vaping could increase the risk of coronavirus infection since experts say smoking suppresses immune function.

claim: Photo of coffins of coronavirus patients who died in a single day in Italy.
label: fake
statement: relation coffins picture deaths italy covid coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The picture is from Italy but is seven years old and has nothing to do with the coronavirus outbreak.

claim: Doctors and nurses in Italy are dying and are lying dead on the ground due to the coronavirus outbreak.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The image does not depict dead doctors and nurses in Italy. It is a part of a demonstration by youngsters to spread awareness about coronavirus in Bogota.

claim: Image claims that dead bodies from Italy are kept in a room.
label: fake
statement: cairo morgue misinterpreted turned mosque scene deaths italy
explain: Explanation: The image is from a Cairo Mosque which was turned into a makeshift morgue in 2013.

claim: Consuming alcoholic beverages may help reduce the risk of infection by the novel coronavirus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Drinking alcohol does not protect you from coronavirus infection, according to the WHO.

claim: Seeing the rise of novel coronavirus in India, the WHO has recommended the government of India lockdown the country from 4/15/20 to 6/15/20.
label: fake
statement: seeing rise recommended country lockdown coronavirus
explain: Explanation: We reached out to one of the representatives in India, who dismissed the claim and clarified that WHO has not made any such recommendation.

claim: A WhatsApp video claims that the lady shown is the wife of Canada’s PM Justin Trudeau. In the viral video, a lady can be seen describing her improved condition because of medication and also warns to not take chances.
label: fake
statement: lady medication justin improved describing trudeau condition warns
explain: Explanation: The lady in the viral video is not Canadian PM Justin Trudeau’s wife Sophie Grégoire Trudeau but a British national named Tara Jane Langston.

claim: Eight COVID-19 patients in Ghana have recovered.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The Ghana Health Service has rejected reports that 8 coronavirus patients in Ghana have recovered.

claim: Audio clip of a conversation claiming that Government of India will announce shutdown of the country in the coming days from 4/15/20 to 6/15/20 in the wake of the coronavirus outbreak
label: fake
statement: individuals discussing conversation complete phone country two clip
explain: Explanation: PIB found the audio clip of the phone conversation discussing a "complete lockdown" of the country to be fake. WHO India has also confirmed the audio is fake.

claim: People shouting “Allahu Akbar” in Europe after the coronavirus outbreak.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The video is not related to the COVID-19 outbreak in Europe. It was found on the internet since 1/13/20, and the first COVID-19 case in Europe was reported on 1/24/20. The video was taken in Germany, where the first COVID-19 case was reported on 1/28/20.

claim: Government of India has announced a “National Lockdown” in the country from 3/20/20.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The Government of India has not announced a "National Lockdown" in the country from 3/20/20. PM Modi, in his recent address to the nation about the coronavirus outbreak, asked people to practice social distancing and to stay home as much as possible for the coming few weeks to combat COVID-19. The Press Information Bureau (PIB) said the message is fake.

claim: Indian PM Modi is providing free masks to people under Swachh Bharat Mission to protect them from the coronavirus outbreak.
label: fake
statement: pmay narendrmodiawasyojna registration dubious houses website masks
explain: Explanation: The website in the post is dubious and there is no government scheme of PM Modi under which free masks are being provided to people. The Press Information Bureau (PIB) said there is no central government scheme that provides free masks to people to protect them from the coronavirus outbreak.

claim: Recently, Petrol companies reduced Rs. 6.40 on petrol and on Diesel Rs. 6.80.
label: fake
statement: princes petrol diesel decrease recently rupees around
explain: Explanation: The petrol and diesel price have not reduced by Rs.6:40 and Rs.6.80 respectively. Petrol and diesel prices have come down by about Rs.2 in the last three weeks.

claim: The coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act gives members of Congress a pay increase.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: No version of the coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act grants pay raises for members of Congress.

claim: WHO offers free data for coronavirus info.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The post is false and links in the post lead to an external website, potentially with harmful malware.

claim: Utility companies Manila Electric Company (Meralco) and Maynilad Water Services Inc are waiving their billings for March 2020 due to the coronavirus crisis.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The graphic did not come from the official channels of Meralco and Maynilad. The two utility services are only offering an extension for payments, not cancellation of fees.

claim: Countries that are the most affected by the coronavirus are along the same latitude.
label: fake
statement: latitude situated places degrees affected covid
explain: Explanation: The fact that large countries cannot be represented by a single latitude is conveniently ignored. Also, all of the cities and countries cited in the examined claim are not situated along 40 degrees of latitude.

claim: A video claims Australian scientists said bananas can prevent COVID-19.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: While it is true that researchers from the University of Queensland are currently developing a vaccine for COVID-19, neither the ABC News Australia report nor a press release from the university about the research made mention of bananas.

claim: Cristiano Ronaldo will convert his hotels into coronavirus hospitals.
label: fake
statement: convert cristiano ronaldo hotels hospitals coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The claim is false; a spokesperson for the hotels said the claim was “inaccurate”; Ronaldo has also not mentioned any such plan on his social media platforms.

claim: The Indian government is distributing free face masks.
label: fake
statement: fraudulent scheme place published website said mask
explain: Explanation: The claim is false. The Indian government said there is no such plan in place and the linked website is not an official government site.

claim: The Australian prime minister is about to announce a national lockdown.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The claim is misleading. The Australian Prime Minister’s Office refuted the details of the post. Australia's government told its citizens on 3/18/20 not to travel abroad and warned those already overseas to come home but did not order a "lockdown." AFP found the wording of the misleading posts was identical to Malaysia’s announcement of a nationwide lockdown.

claim: Coronil drops can help cure coronavirus.
label: fake
statement: drops coronil proof cure covid coronavirus
explain: Explanation: Leading homeopaths say little is known about the composition of this medicine and it is careless to recommend it for coronavirus

claim: Police asked shops selling alcohol to restrict opening hours on St. Patrick’s Day to lower the risk of house parties where coronavirus could be spread.
label: fake
statement: patrick parties opening st shops restrict lower asked
explain: Explanation: Police make an annual request of shops not to sell alcohol before 4 p.m.on St Patrick's Day, but it has nothing to do with coronavirus.

claim: Video shows Chinese police crackdown on coronavirus patients.
label: fake
statement: painted suspects action kong hong covid
explain: Explanation: The video dates back to August 2019 during anti-government protests in Hong Kong. The visuals pertain to an incident of police crackdown at Prince Edward station in Kowloon where the police personnel and riot police arrived after reports of a tussle between pro-government and anti-government protesters.

claim: Details of three coronavirus positive cases reported in Kothapet (Hyderabad, India).
label: fake
statement: kothapet three hyderabad cases positive coronavirus
explain: Explanation: Dr G Srinivasa Rao (Director of Public Health, Telangana) said the viral message is false. Rachakonda Police tweeted that a FIR has been filed in the Chaitanyapuri PS (Kothapet area) on the person who spread the fake news.

claim: Research made by scientists from the University of Queensland in Australia has proven that bananas improve your immune system and help prevent COVID-19.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The University of Queensland dismissed the claim as false. In an email to Rappler, the university’s communication team said: “The video is fake and we would strongly discourage people from sharing this information. We would suggest you share your concerns with the social media platforms.”

claim: The spread of the new coronavirus was planned by the Rockefellers years ago.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Scenarios are widely used as analytical methods in simulations. Scenario, which elaborates on the pandemic threat, has nothing to do with the global conspiracy. It is about futurology and possible crisis response management.

claim: The claim that there is a cure from the new coronavirus. The name of the drug is decametoxine.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: There is no proof this drug can be used in the treatment of coronavirus.

claim: Pandemics happen every 100 years.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Global pandemics do not occur every 100 years as God's or nature's scourge. The authors of this claim have selected only those pandemics that fit their assertion.

claim: The quarantine will last until the end of May in Ukraine.
label: fake
statement: celsius dies temperature degrees around coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The official sources on the day when the news appeared have not published such information. The authors of the article confused the end date of the tax holidays and the end day of the quarantine.

claim: Leaving half an onion in your home will “catch” the coronavirus and prevent people from getting it.
label: fake
statement: onion half catch leaving getting coronavirus
explain: Explanation: Onions are not a way to prevent the coronavirus from entering your home. The claim that onions can help prevent illness has been around since the 1930s.

claim: Drink water a lot and gargle with warm water and salt or vinegar to eliminate the virus.
label: fake
statement: ดื่มน้ำเยอะ ๆ กลั้วคอขจัดไวรัส ป้องกัน COVID-19 จริงหรือ ? | ความจริง-โควิด | FACTSHEET
explain: Explanation: The virus infects a cell, not just the throat. Water cannot clean the virus from an infected cell, and cannot reach the respiratory system.

claim: Gargling warm salt water or vinegar prevents coronavirus infection.
label: fake
statement: vinegar warm gargling salt infection water experts coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The claim is false. International health authorities and experts do not list gargling as an effective remedy or prevention method for COVID-19.

claim: Eleven coronavirus patients visited malls and hotels in Metro Manila that are part of a “confidential list.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The DOH has dismissed the claim as fake. The malls and hotels in question have not posted any advisories regarding possible infection.

claim: A vaccine for the 2019 novel coronavirus has been found and there will be no more deaths due to the coronavirus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: As of 3/20/20, there is no vaccine or cure for the disease caused by the 2019 novel coronavirus and there have been 217,510 cases and 9,020 deaths, across 157 countries.

claim: Sex helps prevent coronavirus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: There is no proof that sex can help fight the new coronavirus.

claim: A fake quote of Vice President Leni Robredo suggesting to “inhale cough back” to prevent the spread of the 2019 novel coronavirus.
label: fake
statement: cough suggests robredo inhaling back coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The vice president did not say what was attributed to her in the graphic. News5 said the graphic was edited using their template.

claim: A viral screenshot of a story allegedly published by the BBC claiming Ghana has recorded its first confirmed coronavirus case.
label: fake
statement: reporting correspondent denies bbc case coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The claim was denied by the BBC correspondent in Ghana and the Ghana Health Service. The misinformers modified the HTML codes from the BBC website to create the false headline and story.

claim: Onion could be used to cure COVID-19, as it did for the Spanish Flu in 1918.
label: fake
statement: หัวหอม ขมิ้น ยาอมป้องกัน-รักษา COVID-19 จริงหรือ ? | ความจริง-โควิด | ชัวร์ก่อนแชร์ FACTSHEET
explain: Explanation: The story is unscientific.

claim: The World Health Organization is not recruiting staff to fight COVID-19.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The WHO has dismissed this claim, which has been posted on a site not linked to the organization.

claim: A coronavirus vaccine for cows shows that the virus behind the current outbreak is not new.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: This is a different coronavirus from SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19. coronaviruses are a large family of viruses that can affect a range of species.

claim: The mayor of Buga, Valle del Cauca, said: “I invite the people of Buga to keep calm and to live each day as if it was the last.”
label: fake
statement: buga valle invite cauca calm mayor last keep
explain: Explanation: The mayor never said this.

claim: Two Chinese nationals in Kenya have been killed after allegedly escaping from quarantine at the Nairobi Airport.
label: fake
statement: panic nationals killed fb two kenya chinese covid
explain: Explanation: The reports are false.

claim: Every election year has a disease; coronavirus has a contagion factor of 2 and a cure rate of 99.7% for those under 50 it infects.
label: fake
statement: unconfirmed transmissibility election every year covid
explain: Explanation: Every year in the U.S. is an election year, if taking into account midterm elections as well as presidential elections, and contrary to the claim, not every election year has had a disease outbreak. The transmissibility of the coronavirus, represented by the “basic reproduction number," is still under study. Currently, the basic reproduction numbers reported for the virus causing COVID-19 range between 2 to more than 6.

claim: Bill Gates wrote a letter saying COVID-19 is teaching humans a lesson.
label: fake
statement: reminds equal write letter open saying gates bill
explain: Explanation: The story was retracted and the letter was fake.

claim: Video shows Chinese officials detaining suspected coronavirus cases.
label: fake

claim: This map shows high sulphur dioxide in Wuhan now due to the burning of corpses.
label: fake
statement: satellite readings forecast past based map real data
explain: Explanation: The forecasts are based on past emissions.

claim: Chinese people flee to Vietnam due to COVID-19.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The video is from November 2019.

claim: Africans are more resistant to COVID-19.
label: fake
statement: resistant ff scientific africans aa evidence covid
explain: Explanation: Dr. Ngumbau Kitheka, a resident doctor at the Kenyatta National Hospital, told PesaCheck there is no scientific evidence to suggest black people have a better chance of fighting the virus, stating that the disease is likely to affect those with weaker immune systems.

claim: The novel coronavirus only survives in cold weather and hot ginger tea or salabat can cure COVID-19.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The WHO said COVID-19 has spread in countries "with both hot and humid climates, as well as cold and dry.” It also said there remains to be “no specific medicine recommended to prevent or treat the novel coronavirus.”

claim: Video shows quarantined people in a building in Shanghai.
label: fake

claim: USPS stops accepting items for China and Hong Kong
label: fake

explain: Explanation: USPS said on 2/12/20 it would continue to accept items bound for China and Hong Kong but could temporarily not offer time guarantees on those shipments. It clarified that it will temporarily halt its transit service that ships mail from other countries to China and Hong Kong.

claim: “THE CHINESE HAVE BEGUN TO USE THEIR HUMAN CORPSE TO PROCESS INTO PRODUCTS SUCH AS CORNED BEEF TO SHIP TO AFRICA. Please share with your contacts. Very important”
label: fake
statement: ship corned contacts begun process important beef please
explain: Explanation: The video might be of Tibet or China’s Sichuan as residents of both these territories perform such rituals. However, it is unknown if the visuals in this video belong to Sky Burial. The video is not related to the coronavirus outbreak.

claim: China is seeking court’s approval to kill 20,000 people positive with coronavirus
label: fake
statement: China seeking court ’ approval kill 20,000 people positive coronavirus
explain: Explanation: There is no evidence for the claim that the Chinese court had ordered to kill the 20,000 patients affected with coronavirus.

claim: Coronavirus is found in broiler chicken.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: There is no evidence to prove that coronavirus is found in the broiler chickens. The WHO has clarified that meat cooked properly can be consumed.

claim: Ginger ale is an effective cure for the 2019 novel coronavirus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The WHO said drinking traditional herbal teas is “not specifically recommended as COVID-19 remedies as they are not effective to protect yourself and can even be harmful.”

claim: The Department of Health (DOH) and the Bureau of Immigration (BI) “issued a lookout bulletin” for the “arrest and detention” of a Chinese man who “escaped the quarantine area” of the Ninoy Aquino International Airport (NAIA).
label: fake
statement: immigration doh bureau bulletin escaped quarantine chinese coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The BI clarified in a statement the foreigner's "escape" from NAIA's quarantine area is a hoax. The DOH did not issue an advisory or bulletin about a foreigner who escaped the quarantine area.

claim: A video shows people screaming in Wuhan because they feared the coronavirus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The video shows Wuhan residents whistling and shouting to commemorate Dr. Li Wenliang, the whistleblower of the virus who died on 2/7/20 after getting infected.

claim: Dettol sanitizer can kill tthe coronavirus. The company knew about the coronavirus back in 2019.
label: fake
statement: strains mentioned dettol ncov previous coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The Dettol bottle refers to the previous strains of coronavirus, not COVID-19. The manufacturer cannot confirm levels of effectiveness against the new strain.

claim: The novel coronavirus can be cured by one bowl of freshly boiled garlic.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The WHO has issued a clarification that garlic may have some antimicrobial properties but there is no evidence it can protect people from the novel coronavirus.

claim: Videos show pigs being buried in China due to the coronavirus outbreak.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The videos are old and not related to the recent coronavirus outbreak.

claim: The novel coronavirus “will not spread” in the Philippines due to the country’s high temperature and relatively high humidity.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The World Health Organization (WHO) told Rappler that 2019-nCoV "has spread to countries with both hot and humid climates, as well as cold and dry."

claim: Garlic water prevents the novel coronavirus, according to a Chinese doctor.
label: fake
statement: really boiled treating garlic water coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The WHO has not prescribed any preventive methods for coronavirus.

claim: A photo shows dead people on the streets of China.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Taken in 2014 in Frankfurt, Germany, the photo shows victims of a Nazi concentration camp and has nothing to do with the coronavirus pandemic.

claim: A photo shows the newly built hospital in Wuhan.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The photo from the internet depicts a modular apartment building.

claim: The novel coronavirus is not a new virus.
label: fake
statement: mentions strains refer coronaviruses past different caused virus
explain: Explanation: Many coronavirus strains have already been discovered, and new strains regularly emerge from mutations.

claim: Mélange Of Unrelated Videos From China Shared Misleadingly In Context To Recent Corona Virus Outbreak.
label: fake
statement: merged together melange context videos coronavirus
explain: Explanation: A mix of different unrelated videos from China have been merged to create this misleading video shared in context to coronavirus. People infected by coronavirus 2019-nCoV, do not exhibit the symptoms such as howling like dogs and biting as shown in the video.

claim: Two ways of wearing a surgical mask: Colored side out if you are sick and white side out if you do not want to become sick.
label: fake
statement: outwards layered colored surgical side way three wear
explain: Explanation: There is only one way of wearing a three-layered surgical mask. The colored side of the surgical mask should face outwards.

claim: This is the picture of the first new Wuhan coronavirus hospital.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: This is a stock picture of a modular construction from a Chinese import-export company.

claim: A photograph that shows people on the floor demonstrates the impact of the new coronavirus in China.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The claim along with the photo is false and it is in no way related to the outbreak of coronavirus. It is actually an old photo from Germany dated to 2014. Moreover, the people in the photo are not dead, but were lying down on the road as part of an art project.

claim: Coronavirus has an effect on a person’s lips.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The video shared a effect of coronavirus on a patient lip is found to be on the internet at least since November-2019, before the recent epidemic broke out. So, it is not related to the recent coronavirus epidemic.

claim: “Confirmed cases” of the novel coronavirus or 2019 nCoV were recorded at the Philippine Bank of Communications (PBCom) Tower in Makati City, according to a message that circulated Friday, Jan. 24.
label: fake
statement: pbcom makati tower confirmed cases coronavirus
explain: Explanation: Speaking to reporters on January 24, Health Undersecretary Eric Domingo maintained that there is still no confirmed case of the 2019 nCov in the Philippines. The management of PBCom Tower also said there is “no truth” to the information.

claim: A photo of a list of purported symptoms and treatments for the novel coronavirus, which causes the disease COVID-19, has been shared hundreds of times in multiple posts on Facebook, Twitter and Instagram. The purported remedies include a daily dose of vitamins; exposure to sunlight; and a diet of alkaline foods.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The claims are false; as of June 29, 2020, experts say there is no known cure for COVID-19; AFP has previously debunked hoax claims about the purported coronavirus symptoms and remedies.

claim: President Trump’s claim that he inherited no ventilators from the Obama administration.
label: fake
statement: keeps ventilators left number saying obama trump
explain: Explanation: There were 16,660 ventilators available in the Strategic National Stockpile.

claim: COVID-19 is disseminated intravascular coagulation, or pulmonary thrombosis, and ventilators and intensive care units (ICUs) were “never needed” in treating the disease because it can be fought with “antibiotics, anti-inflammatories and anticoagulants.” The disease is also caused by a bacteria that gets amplified by 5G technology.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Thrombosis is only one possible effect of COVID. The drugs mentioned in the online posts were meant to address related infections in COVID-19 patients. The disease is viral and not bacterial in nature, and the claims about 5G having to do with the disease are unsupported.

claim: “FREE HORSES!!!! 52 thoroughbred horses need homes. Will go to Sugarcreek this Sat. for slaughter. Gentleman died due to COVID-19 and his son wants nothing to do with them.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: This is an outdated and misleadingly edited Facebook post that originated in 2011 after a longtime horse breeder died in Ohio.

claim: Image claiming to be Sri Lankan Soldiers and Police having their meals on the streets during COVID-19 pandemic.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Image shows Indian Police and Army personnel sharing their meals on a street.

claim: Irish Prime Minister Leo Varadkar is going to the Supreme Court to make the coronavirus vaccine mandatory for all people living in Ireland.
label: fake
statement: varadkar supreme court going vaccine coronavirus
explain: Explanation: A vaccine for COVID-19 does not yet exist and there is no way for Leo Varadkar to go to the Supreme Court on this issue.

claim: There has been no death due to COVID-19 in Israel as they mix lemon and baking soda in their tea. This combination kills coronavirus.
label: fake
statement: mixing soda baking wont lemon tea kill coronavirus
explain: Explanation: As of June 9, Israel reported 298 deaths due to COVID-19, and a total of 18,089 cases. There is no scientific evidence that a mix of lemon and baking powder with tea can kill coronavirus.

claim: Chewing raw onions can cure coronavirus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The World Health Organization (WHO) and the Ghana Food and Drugs Authority (FDA) have dismissed the claim as false.

claim: In Italy, the cure for Coronavirus is finally found.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Italy has not found the cure for the novel coronavirus. COVID-19 is caused by a virus, not bacteria. While the symptoms of COVID-19 can be treated with anticoagulants and anti-inflammatories, they are not a cure for the disease itself.

claim: Rahul Gandhi has suggested a possible way to reopen schools/colleges.
label: fake
statement: odd colleges schools scheme even reopening rahul gandhi
explain: Explanation: The tweet is fake.

claim: Sanitiser bottles inside a parked car triggered fire due to heat wave in Bhopal.
label: fake
statement: sanitizers parked chhattisgarh car building inside set fire
explain: Explanation: The video claimed sanitisers are dangerous to keep inside a car and attributed the cause of fire to its alcoholic content. Citing scientific studies, it was disproved since summer heat peaks at 160 F (71.11 C) but a car would need to reach an internal temperature above 300 degrees Celsius (572 degrees Fahrenheit) to cause hand sanitizer to combust.

claim: Social media commentaris claim a murder of a 37-year-old Chinese researcher studying COVID-19 at the University of Pittsburgh in early May could be a cover-up as he was about to reveal important findings, possibly the U.S. origin of the coronavirus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Local police’s investigation determined the murder suicide was a result of “a lengthy dispute regarding an intimate partner” and had nothing to do with Liu’s coronavirus research. The University of Pittsburgh's official statement also clarified the area of his research, which is not about the origin of the coronavirus.

claim: 20% of human volunteers for the test for a COVID-19 vaccine developed by Moderna have suffered serious adverse effects.
label: fake
statement: volontaires sc rimental quelles mrna expc eu graves
explain: Explanation: Eight volunteers participated in phase 1 of the clinical trials and developed an immune response and are in good health, with no major sequelae.

claim: People living in quarantine centre refuse to eat food as it was cooked by lower caste women.
label: fake
statement: cooked caste refuse living lower eat women centre
explain: Explanation: The video doing rounds on social media claiming that persons seen in the video refused to eat food cooked by a lower caste woman at a quarantine center is misleading. The Bihar police have ruled out any casteist angle to the incident.

claim: German police can enter homes and forcibly vaccinate people.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: This is not true, and there is no evidence of this happening.

claim: Hydroxychloroquine cures COVID-19.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Hydroxychloroquine hasn’t been proven to cure COVID-19 and is not used as a treatment for radiation sickness.

claim: Wearing a face mask for a prolonged period of time causes hypoxia and/or hypercapnia.
label: fake
statement: hypoxia hypercapnia causes prolonged face mask
explain: Explanation: Using face masks does not cause hypoxia nor excessive carbon dioxide intake. The World Health Organization (WHO) Philippines said there is no evidence that using face masks for a prolonged period of time causes any adverse effect on the brain or heart function.

claim: Articles shared thousands of times on Facebook and Twitter claim Rwandan President Paul Kagame censured the World Health Organization (WHO) for rejecting a herbal tonic touted by the Madagascan government as a cure for COVID-19.
label: fake
statement: Facebook Twitter Paul Kagame World Health Organization
explain: Explanation: A presidential spokesperson dismissed the claim as “fake news”. No evidence was found to show Kagame made the comments. In fact, he has said his government is avoiding untested remedies.

claim: Letter issued from the Sri Lankan Ministry of Defense stating that there will be a pay cut from the May month’s salary of Armed forces based on the request letter from President’s Secretary.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Members of the Armed Forces, Police and Civil Security Department are not required to donate a day's salary.

label: fake

explain: Explanation: Ajith Rohan’s daughter is preparing for her final examinations which are to be held in June at Grodno State Medical University in Belarus and plans to return to Sri Lanka after the exams.

claim: By drinking Ayurvedic decoction, 6 thousand corona infected patients were cured.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The decoction was given to those who were in the Quarantine Center after coming in contact with Corona positive people. It has been told by the Ministry of Ayush that this decoction increases your immunity and not kills the coronavirus.

claim: Experts in China found that the coronavirus can be spread through houseflies.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: According to WHO, there is no evidence or information to suggest that the COVID-19 virus transmitted through houseflies. The virus that cause COVID-19 spreads primarily through droplets generated when an infected person coughs, sneezes or speaks

claim: Ghana’s electoral commission has postponed the 2020 elections to 2023 due to coronavirus.

explain: Explanation: The USA has tested about 5 million people; the rest of the world 25 million people.

claim: Photo of a Hindu woman attacked by RSS members for offering Sehri to a Muslim Kashmiri girl during the Indian lockdown.

claim: A photo of dozens of dead bodies wrapped in plastic, with three people wearing masks standing among them, shows victims of the coronavirus pandemic.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: A reverse image search shows that the photo was taken by David Longstreath of the Associated Press in December 2004. The dead were killed by the 2004 tsunami off the coast of Indonesia.

claim: Dr Elisa Granato, one of the first participants in a UK COVID-19 vaccine trial, has died.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: This is false. She is not dead.

claim: Nobel laureate and Japan’s renowned professor Tasuku Honjo has described coronavirus as unnatural. He has also said that this has been prepared in a lab in China.
label: fake
statement: renowned described unnatural prepared laureate japan professor lab
explain: Explanation: Nobel laureate Professor Tasuku Honjo did not make this statement.

claim: To express gratitude towards India for sending the Hydroxychloroquine to the US, a group of American youth sings the Indian national anthem.
label: fake
statement: towards sings gratitude express sending youth group anthem
explain: Explanation: The viral video which is being shared as ‘American youth expressing their gratitude towards India for sending HCQ by singing the Indian national anthem’ was published to commemorate Indian Independence Day in 2017.

claim: A Facebook post advertising lockdown relief funds worth Ksh 5,000 for Kenyans.
label: fake
statement: cff advertisement funds ksh relief lockdown
explain: Explanation: There is no government or private initiative offering such funds

claim: A woman holding a child in her hands succumbed to the novel coronavirus in Italy.
label: fake
statement: succumbed hands child holding italy coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The image was taken in 1985 at a cancer treatment centre in Seattle, USA, by photojournalist Burt Glinn before the baby’s bone marrow transplant.

claim: Ghana Education Service confirms date schools in Ghana will reopen.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The Ghana Education Service has confirmed that no date has been set for schools to reopen. Meanwhile, the unaltered news clip by GhanaWeb is being presented in an inaccurate manner to misrepresent the footage and mislead viewers.

claim: According to a graphic that circulated on social media, former Anakpawis party list representative Ariel Casilao apologized to the residents of Norzagaray, Bulacan, Philippines and asked that the charges against him be withdrawn.
label: fake
statement: revolt lawmaker casilao ariel apologizes anakpawis vs asking
explain: Explanation: Casilao was detained along with 6 relief volunteers but he did not apologize nor request that the charges against him be withdrawn. Rather, he said they “did nothing wrong and did not violate any of the quarantine rules.” The graphic containing the statement also did not come from News5.

claim: A photograph of a woman hugging her young child before she died of COVID-19 in Italy.
label: fake
statement: infant cancer center treatment revived spin covid
explain: Explanation: The photograph is related to a stem cell transplant captured in 1985 and is not related to the coronavirus.

claim: A ban on Chinese citizens going to markets in Australia.
label: fake
statement: markets ban citizens australia chinese going
explain: Explanation: In a supermarket store called Big W in Australia, a dispute over the goods is being presented with a false claim.

claim: Drinking warm water mixed with salt kills the coronavirus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The WHO said while some home remedies may “provide comfort” and alleviate COVID-19 symptoms, there is no evidence that current medicine can prevent or cure the disease.

claim: A photo showing swollen tonsils with white spots is what a throat of a person with COVID-19 that has spread to the lungs and body looks like.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: A digital forensic analysis of the photo shows it was taken on May 29, 2018, or more than 18 months before the emergence in Wuhan, China of COVID-19. The image’s earliest traceable upload came from Reddit where a user asked if the photo showed a “normal looking strep throat.”

claim: A YouTube chanel and a blog was created to promote the idea that NATO troops are leaving Lithuania due to governments inability to deal with the COVID-19 pandemic
label: fake
statement: vardu prisidenge platina piktavaliai min melaginga karius informacija
explain: Explanation: A fake Blogspot blog, Youtube chanel and Liveleak entry were created to promote the idea that NATO is withdrawing from Lithuania amidst the COVID-19 pandemic. The fake entrys used credentials of our orgnization fact-checker to promote the falsehood. Forged letter of the head of NATO, Jens Stoltenberg, claiming that NATO leaves Lithuania was sent out to think-tanks, government agencies etc. The information was false and likely part of a coordinated campaign.

claim: Facebook posts claim a child who is infected with the novel coronavirus will be taken to a hospital unaccompanied.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: This is misleading; many hospitals have prohibited visitors during the COVID-19 pandemic, but even facilities in heavily-affected states have exceptions allowing a parent or caregiver to be with pediatric patients.

claim: Matterhorn mountain in Swiss Alps lit up with the Indian Tricolour after PM Narendra Modi supplied Hydroxychloroquine (HCQ) tablets.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: While the photo and the incident is true and the Indian Tricolour was actually projected onto the Matterhorn, the claim shared with the photo is false. The gesture was meant to express solidarity with all Indians in the fight against COVID-19 and had nothing to do with HCQ supply at all.

claim: Germany sends China £130 billion bill for ‘coronavirus damages’.
label: fake
statement: damages sending germany bill china coronavirus
explain: Explanation: A German newspaper ‘Bild’ mocked up a bill and assessed the damage which the coronavirus pandemic has caused to the economy. However, the headline of Express UK is misleading to the effect that it insinuates that the German government has made the move.

claim: Social media posts shared in South Africa claim that children in grades 1 to 11 will be promoted after the school year was cancelled because of the novel coronavirus pandemic.
label: fake
statement: ov khcvz ejdnqtilwxpoxigwvlcfyxfizdiydjgyv education saved africas school department
explain: Explanation: The claims are false and started circulating after an education expert called for an end to the academic year, an idea rejected by the Department of Basic Education.

claim: Video of a burqa-clad Muslim woman being denied a food kit distributed to help people during the current crisis in India due to COVID-19, for being a Muslim.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The woman in the video was not denied a food kit. Rajeev Mishra (the man distributing food rations in the video) has sent another video and photos to FACTLY, where it can be seen that the woman was given the food kit.

claim: Johns Hopkins University published a list of precautionary measures against COVID-19.
label: fake
statement: distances precautions hopkins johns list covid
explain: Explanation: Johns Hopkins University took to social media to refuse that they had come up with any such lists

claim: Mumbai municipal body asks people to drink boiled water as a remedy to coronavirus
label: fake
statement: bmc appeal boiled two recent year drinking water
explain: Explanation: The clipping is from 2018 when the Municipal body asked people to consume boiled water as the available water was turbid

claim: Image of a Muslim boy, Rizwan, who had died after being beaten up by Tanda (UP) Police for violating the lockdown restrictions mandated due to COVID-19 spread.
label: fake
statement: rizwan liver clarifies ambedkarnagar heart infection died
explain: Explanation: Ambedkarnagar district Police clarified that, in their investigation, they have found that Rizwan was not beaten by the Police. Also, the Police has said that, in the postmortem report, it was mentioned that the deceased had an infection in lungs & heart and injuries due to falling from a motorcycle, which was confirmed by a local doctor

claim: Photo shows packed beach of re-opened Jacksonville Beach on CNN.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The photo isn’t from Florida in the spring of coronavirus. It was taken in Brazil in 2013 during a visit from Pope Francis.

claim: A Filipino living in America cured himself of COVID-19 after drinking a glass of water with a teaspoon of salt.
label: fake
statement: flushes kills salt hot drinking water coronavirus
explain: Explanation: In another video Castelo posted on April 23, he said he had not yet been tested for the coronavirus. There is also no registered cure for COVID-19 to date, and the World Health Organization (WHO) warns against self-medication.

claim: Videos showing black people being attacked by Asian people have been shared thousands of times online in recent weeks. Although Africans living in China have reported discrimination linked to the coronavirus pandemic
label: fake
statement: filmed africans ago attacked videos china
explain: Explanation: AFP Fact Check found that various widely-shared clips were filmed years ago and have nothing to do with the virus.

claim: US President Donald Trump called Philippines President Rodrigo Duterte to ask for help to “solve coronavirus” because he “can’t handle” his constituents.
label: fake
statement: handle asks cannot americans duterte trump
explain: Explanation: Both the Malacañang and the White House, through the US embassy in the Philippines, said the late-night phone conversation between Trump and Duterte was about bilateral collaboration vs COVID-19. In an email to Rappler, the embassy also denied that Trump called Duterte because he needed help in handling his constituents.
orginated: Facebook page The 16th President of The Philippines

claim: 21 people died in Lagos, Nigeria, after getting a COVID-19 vaccine.
label: fake
statement: lagos nigeria getting died vaccine covid
explain: Explanation: No such incident has been recorded or reported in Nigeria.

claim: Bihar’s Health Department has confirmed that poultry chicken is the source of coronavirus.
label: fake
statement: confirms clipping bihar newspaper chicken source goes covid
explain: Explanation: There is no truth to the newspaper clipping. Firstly, the clipping itself is fake and has possibly been created using an online tool. Secondly, the Bihar Health Department has confirmed that no such observation has been made.

claim: A year ago, 14-year-old astrologer Abhigyan Anand had made a prediction about thecoronavirus.
label: fake
statement: year thecoronavirus astrologer abhigyan prediction anand ago
explain: Explanation: We listened to the said video which was uploaded on 22 august 2019 but the name of coronavirus was not mentioned anywhere in the 15 min long video.
orginated: Many media outlets, Facebook, WhatsApp, Twitter

claim: People are offering prayers in groups on rooftops despite lockdown. That too when cases of coronavirus in India are continuously increasing.
label: fake
statement: continuously increasing groups despite rooftops prayers offering cases
explain: Explanation: The picture being shared is not of India but of Dubai. People in Arab countries have been called to follow the lockdown and offer prayers in their homes.

claim: Coronavirus in poultry products has been confirmed by the Bihar Health Department.
label: fake
statement: poultry bihar products department confirmed coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The Health Department of the Government of Bihar, through a Facebook post on April 15, 2020, has denied the claim that coronavirus is found in poultry products.

claim: Internet sensation and the world’s cutest baby Anahita Hashemzadeh is suffering COVID-19.
label: fake
statement: sensation cutest hashemzadeh anahita suffering internet baby covid
explain: Explanation: Anahita's mother has denied the rumors and informed that Anahita is healthy and she isnt the girl in the viral video.

claim: An image claimed to be of an abandoned child, since both his parents were infected with COVID-19.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The images are old and unrelated and are not connected to COVID-19 pandemic.

claim: Video of Chinese people not being allowed into the supermarkets of Australia.
label: fake
statement: tins altercation formula member couple staff baby
explain: Explanation: The video shows an altercation between a couple and a staff member over the former’s attempt to purchase the ‘baby formula tins’ beyond the supermarket’s permissible limit

claim: Ghana’s total confirmed cases of coronavirus is 1,064.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Official data from the Ghana Health Service says total confirmed cases is 566 as of April 13 and the country's information ministry has also called on Ghanaians to disregard any contrary information..

claim: Indian media outlets claimed that a man in Madhya Pradesh’s Khargone passed away from COVID-19.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The claim that the man hid his travel history and died of coronavirus made by both ANI and Republic is false. The man, who did indeed test positive, was actually undergoing treatment at Indore’s Maharaja Hospital and had gotten himself tested after returning to Khargone. He has now been discharged from care as well, after having tested negative twice for the novel coronavirus.

claim: Lockdown in South Africa has collapsed. People are out on the streets because due to hunger.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Contrary to the claims, the video is from 2018 when a shop in Mitchells Plain was vandalised following violent protests in the area.

claim: “Sri Lanka’s health service among the world’s best” – WHO Director General while lauding SL government’s efforts in curbing COVID-19.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The quote of WHO Director General Dr. Tedro being shared is two years old and was in a different context, unrelated to current COVID-19 pandemic. Even though Dr. Tedro has publicly appreciated President Rajapaksa’s work, his old statement shared in context of the current pandemic is misleading.

claim: Photo of Pakistani people holding a banner with the text – ‘We don’t want Kashmir. Give us Hydroxychloroquine’ asking India to help them handle the COVID-19
label: fake
statement: banner kashmir edited holding hydroxychloroquine pakistan
explain: Explanation: The posted image is an edited one. In the original picture, the banner has the following text - 'We want Azadi'. It is an old photo and the photo was taken in Kashmir.

claim: The drug Diamox, often used as treatment for high-altitude sickness, can cure coronavirus.
label: fake
statement: missing link true treatment found doctors coronavirus
explain: Explanation: There is still not widespread, proven cure for the virus, and doctors have said this is not effective in treating COVID-19.

claim: A talking newborn in northern Philippines spoke and said hard-boiled eggs are the cure for COVID-19.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: This claim is untrue, and the story about the “speaking” newborn baby was recycled from an Indonesian hoax. “There is no evidence from the current outbreak that eating eggs has protected people from the new coronavirus,” said WHO Philippines.
orginated: YouTube channels, FB pages, FB users

claim: Media outlets reported that the same boy died 3 times from the coronavirus, in 3 countries.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: News outlets did not use photo of same boy to report on 3COVID-19deaths. The photo in the post is of Vitor Rafael Bastos Godinho, a 14-year-old Portuguese boy who died after testing positive for the novel coronavirus. He is correctly identified in all the stories that use the image.

claim: Kalonji seeds (Nigella Seeds) contain hydroxychloroquine and can help cure COVID-19.
label: fake
statement: kalonji seeds hcq data experts cure covid
explain: Explanation: The claim being made in the social media posts lacks medical evidence. Experts told The Quint that neither do Kalonji seeds contain hydroxychloroquine nor is there scientific data to prove that the seeds can cure COVID-19. Further, whether HCQ can cure coronavirus is not totally clear.

claim: Coronavirus can be avoided by eating nigella with honey as it contains 100% hydroxychloroquine. Hydroxychloroquine treats coronavirus.
label: fake
statement: hydroxychloroquine treats nigella avoided honey contains eating coronavirus
explain: Explanation: Hydroxychloroquine is not present in the substances found in nigella, but it contains thymoquinone. Hydroxychloroquine is also not yet proven as a cure coronavirus though many countries giving HCQ to COVID-19 patients.

claim: A WhatsApp forward, along with a video, is doing the rounds in which it is claimed that a person who belongs to the Tablighi Jamaat was kept in an isolation ward where he started wandering naked. The viral forward also claims that the person who was wandering naked did this vulgar act intentionally.
label: fake
statement: wandering naked forward vulgar intentionally started kept belongs
explain: Explanation: The video being circulated in the name of Tablighi Jamaat members’ misbehaving with the nurses treating them for the COVID-19 is old. Hence it is evident that the viral claim is ‘False’ and is being shared with a communal angle.

claim: Industrialist Ratan Tata’s view on economic downfall due to COVID-19.
label: fake
statement: view tatas downfall economic ratan covid
explain: Explanation: The quote on economical downfall due to COVID-19 is falsely attributed to Ratan Tata.

claim: ICMR issued a report claiming the number of people infected with thte coronavirus increased up to 8 Lakh if india did not announce a lockdown.
label: fake
statement: thte lakh announce increased icmr number issued lockdown
explain: Explanation: ICMR did not publish any such report about the possible numbers of COVID-19 infected people.

claim: Website link in order to activate 100 GB Free Internet Data & Rs.500 Talk time offer amid the COVID-19 situation in Sri Lanka.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: All these are fake messages with redirects to bogus or malicious websites.

claim: Herd of Sri Lankan Sambar Deer’s were seen freely gazing on a beach of Yala National Park, due to lack of human activity during current curfew period in Sri Lanka.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The video is old and does not relate to the current COVID-19 curfew,The image was first published in 2017 April on the Instagram account of “National Geographic” .

claim: A Facebook user shared a video that shows dead bodies being washed ashore at some unidentified beach.
label: fake
statement: unidentified washed user ashore beach bodies dead
explain: Explanation: The video doing rounds on social media has no connection with the coronavirus pandemic. The disturbing video doing rounds is of the bodies of African immigrants washing onto the shore of al-Qarbole, after a boat carrying 200 illegal immigrants from sub-Saharan Africa sunk off the Libyan capital.

claim: In new interview to Fox, President Trump suggests India could have early access to COVID-19 vaccines being developed in US since PM Modi accepted request on HCQ.
label: fake
statement: access accepted early suggests since request hcq fox
explain: Explanation: In the entire interview, many questions were asked from President Trump to his impeachment and preparations to fight COVID-19. But in this entire interview, it has not been mentioned anywhere that the medicines being made in the US for COVID-19 will be provided to which countries first. In the interview, Trump was also questioned about hydroxychloroquine and the mention of India also came during the time when Trump said that India has agreed to him and will provide HCQ to America.

claim: The SLPP (Ruling Party in Sri Lanka) symbol has been used in Sathosa (State owned retail chain) spice packaging as part of political campaign during relief distribution amid COVID-19.
label: fake
statement: symbol pohottuwa distribution political campaign relief
explain: Explanation: The artwork which carries a lotus symbol, part of Sathosa logo, had been requested to be used by local suppliers since 2007 and has remained unchanged during several elections and was not part of a political campaign. SLPP party with the symbol lotus bud was formed in 2016.

claim: President of Sri Lanka has contracted COVID-19.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: President Media unit confirmed that President Gotabaya Rajapaksa is in good health.

claim: FBI has arrested a US professor who has manufactured and sold coronavirus to Wuhan.
label: fake
statement: selling professor arrested china covid coronavirus
explain: Explanation: Professor Charles Lieber, whose name is mentioned in the viral message, has indeed been arrested but not because he ‘manufactured and sold’ coronavirus to China but because he lied to the US authorities about his involvement with the Chinese government program to recruit scientific talent.

claim: US arrests the man who created COVID-19.
label: fake
statement: prof scientist lieber harvard arrest charles covid
explain: Explanation: The post claims that Prof Charles Lieber of Harvard University was arrested by US federal agents on April 4, 2020, for manufacturing and selling coronavirus to China.The US Department of Justice announced charges against Lieber for lying to the American Authorities about his involvement with a Chinese government program and failing to disclose payments that he had received from Chinese funders.

claim: A Facebook post claims the World Health Organization is hiring community enforcement workers in Kenya to help create awareness of COVID-19 and links to a Google Form application.
label: fake
statement: job hiring scam organization kenya coronavirus
explain: Explanation: WHO Kenya have alerted Kenyans that the job post is fake, and that the organisation is not hiring.

claim: Video of the Kenyan Government using a Maasai tribe man to impose social distancing in Kenya.
label: fake
statement: tribe maasai imposing men kenyan using distancing
explain: Explanation: The video is made by an ‘Entertainment’ based YouTube channel ‘Mbuzi Seller’. It doesn’t show a real-life incident. Also, there are no reports about the Kenyan government roping in Maasai tribe men to carry out stricter actions in the wake of coronavirus infections in the country.

claim: Muslim owned restaurants in Bengaluru have chefs brainwashed by Markaz attendees and are spreading coronavirus by spitting in the food.
label: fake
statement: owned chefs brainwashed bengaluru attendees restaurants markaz spreading
explain: Explanation: The video is old and has nothing to do with the ongoing Nizamuddin Markaz controversy or Indian Muslim restaurant staff. Hence the claim is ‘Misleading’.

claim: 5G exposure/radiation pollution compromises the structure and function of hemoglobin in cells and worsens COVID-19 pandemic.
label: fake
statement: vulnerability theorists hemoglobin affects increases baseless theory covid
explain: Explanation: Wireless communications use electromagnetic waves to transfer data. Electromagnetic waves carry energy that is proportional to their frequency and can interact with biological tissues. However, the energy level and the penetration depth of the type of waves used for 5G do not allow them to alter the structure and function of important biological macromolecules such as hemoglobin. In addition, there is no correlation between the very limited 5G coverage in the world and the progression of the COVID-19 pandemic.

claim: Video of bodies being washed ashore being shared as countries dumping their coronavirus bodies into the sea and thus requesting people to avoid sea food.
label: fake
statement: shipwreck libyan coast revived spin coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The original video is from 2014 where African migrants attempting to illegally enter Europe and their boat capsized and their bodies washed ashore in Libya.

claim: The WHO has issued a protocol for lockdown extension providing a relaxation period of five days.
label: fake
statement: relaxation proposes period day days lockdown
explain: Explanation: The viral message is false and no such protocol has been issued by the WHO as a lockdown standard schedule.

claim: Dr Charles Lieber, a Harvard professor, has been arrested in the USA for manufacturing the coronavirus and selling it to China. A video news report from WCVB, a TV station in Boston, Massachusetts, is shared with the Facebook post.
label: fake
statement: manufacturing selling harvard professor arrested china coronavirus
explain: Explanation: Lieber was arrested, alongside two Chinese nationals, but the arrests had nothing to do with the new coronavirus. All reputable evidence so far, including from the World Health Organization, shows that the new coronavirus was not “manufactured”.

claim: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe announced that his country has created a cure for COVID-19.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: This is inaccurate. What Abe said was that his country has started “observational studies” on four drugs as treatment for COVID-19 patients.

claim: A video showing body bags lying on the floor of various rooms inside a hospital was filmed in St Mary’s Hospital, London.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Incorrect, the hospital trust confirmed it wasn’t filmed there. It was filmed in Ecuador.

claim: There are no COVID-19 deaths in Israel as they found a cure for COVID-19 – a mixture of lemon and baking soda.
label: fake
statement: mixture soda baking sars lemon cov kill evidence
explain: Explanation: As on 16 April 2020, Israel reported 126 deaths due to COVID-19. Also, there is no scientific evidence to suggest that the mixture of lemon and baking soda can kill SARS-CoV-2 virus. As of today, there is no mixture/medicine to prevent or cure COVID-19.

claim: A claim that US scientist Charles Lieber was arrested for manufacturing and selling “thecoronavirus to China”.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Dr Charles Lieber was arrested for “making a materially false, fictitious and fraudulent statement” on funds he received from Wuhan University of Technology and over his alleged links to a Chinese government program. Lieber was not arrested for manufacturing or selling coronavirus.

claim: A claim has been shared on Facebook and several Sri Lankan news websites that Muslims at a mosque in Sri Lanka reacted violently after authorities told them their gathering was in violation of the country’s novel coronavirus curfew.
label: fake
statement: ignored mosque lankan curfew muslims covid
explain: Explanation: The claim is misleading; police and public health officials said that locals were in fact asked to gather at the mosque to receive tests to detect COVID-19, the disease caused by the novel coronavirus. The scuffle that occurred at the event was sparked over fears that the testing site would make the village more susceptible to infections, they said.

claim: Video of a Muslim man spitting into the food packages to spread coronavirus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: It’s an old video. While the first coronavirus outbreak was reported in China in December 2019, the posted video has been shared on the internet since April 2019. Also, the video is not related to India.

claim: If Russian people do not obey mandatory isolation, they are imprisoned for five years.
label: fake
statement: obey imprisoned russian isolation mandatory five
explain: Explanation: It is true that Vladimir Putin implemented this measure, but the prison sentence can be up to seven years.

claim: The Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) seized boxes of N95 masks that tested positive for the coronavirus, according to a video posted by multiple accounts on YouTube and Facebook.
label: fake
statement: seizing fbi masks positive china coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The FBI seized the N95 masks from an alleged hoarder in Brooklyn, USA who was selling it at a very high markup, not because it tested positive for the coronavirus. The masks were later distributed to health workers in New York and New Jersey.

claim: A video has been viewed thousands of times in multiple posts on Facebook, WhatsApp, Twitter and YouTube alongside a claim it shows a Muslim man spitting at Indian police officers after being detained over scuffles at a coronavirus quarantine centre in April 2020.
label: fake
statement: weeks february facility least incident quarantine coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The claim is misleading; the video has circulated in reports since at least February 2020, weeks before the incident at the coronavirus quarantine centre; local police told AFP the video shows an incident in February 2020 and is unrelated to the COVID-19 pandemic.

claim: People in Italy are threw away their money after they lost their family members to coronavirus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The claim and the images are false. The images are old and are not related to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic in any way.

claim: Eating alkaline foods with a pH level above 8.5 can kill the SARS-CoV-2 virus.
label: fake
statement: suggesting foods alkaline sars cov kill virus
explain: Explanation: The Journal of virology and antiviral research paper mentioned in the post talks about the 'MHV4' virus, not about the 'SARS-CoV-2' virus. Some of the pH levels given in the post are not correct. Also, there is no scientific evidence to prove that eating alkaline foods can kill the SARS-CoV-2 virus.

claim: An image shows Muslims queueing to get into a mosque, standing closer than two metres apart, after the lockdown was announced.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The picture was taken the Friday before lockdown measures were announced. Lockdown measures were announced on Monday 23 March, and included places of worship being told to close.

claim: Amid the coronavirus crisis, Italy’s streets are now filled with discarded printed cash as seen in photos circulating on social media.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The photos were taken in Venezuela, not Italy. The discarded banknotes were Bolivar Fuerte, Venezuela’s old currency.

claim: Videos of a patient gasping for breath is shown as a patient from India.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The video is not from India but Ecuador where the person was suffering from acute respiratory distress syndrome.

claim: pH level of coronavirus varies from 5.5 to 8.5 and to beat the virus, we should consume more alkaline food.
label: fake
statement: value deny link foods alkaline ph experts covid
explain: Explanation: Dr. Shaheed Jameel, a leading virologist, said that viruses do not have pH values.

claim: There is now a COVID-19 cure from the USA.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: It was a test kit from South Korea that was shared as an American-made vaccine for COVID-19.

claim: Video of police roughing up civilians claimed to be police in Spain enforcing a lockdown.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The video is originally from Baku, Azerbaijan, from a protest in October 2019.

claim: Multiple news reports circulating in Nigeria claim that Buckingham Palace has announced Britain’s Queen Elizabeth tested positive for COVID-19.
label: fake
statement: palace buckingham queen tested positive coronavirus
explain: Explanation: Although the queen’s eldest son was diagnosed with the disease, the Palace said the monarch herself is “in good health”.

claim: India TV telecasted news that Bollywood Actor Shahrukh Khan donated 450 million (45 Crore) Rupees to Pakistan Oil tanker blast victims.
label: fake
statement: tvs sharukh clipped donating rupees crore khan pakistan
explain: Explanation: The video is a clipped version of India TV’s fact-check video. In the original fact-check video, India TV has debunked the same claim and concluded that Shahrukh has not made any donation to Pakistan Oil tanker blast victims.

claim: Recent photo of PM Modi visiting a church and offering prayers to save the country from the coronavirus outbreak.
label: fake
statement: colombo visiting church context modi covid
explain: Explanation: It is an old photo, taken when Modi visited Sri Lanka in June 2019. He paid homage to those killed in the serial bombings at St. Anthony's Shrine (Colombo, Sri Lanka).

claim: Indian Army has built a 1,000-bed hospital in Rajasthan in eight days for the treatment of COVID-19.
label: fake
statement: rajastan build bed army days coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The news that it is building a thousand-bed hospital for the treatment of COVID-19 in Barmer (Rajasthan) is false. The photos in the post are old.

claim: Bollywood superstar Aamir Khan donated Rs. 250 crore to tackle the novel coronavirus outbreak.
label: fake
statement: tackle superstar bollywood rs donated crore aamir khan
explain: Explanation: The image on social media claiming that Bollywood star Aamir Khan has donated Rs 250 crore to fight the novel coronavirus is misleading as the actor has not donated anything yet. British boxer Amir Khan has offered his retail outlet to the NHS to help COVID-19 patients.

claim: Indian businessman, WIPRO chairman and philanthropist Azim Prem donated 50,000 Crore to fight the COVID-19 outbreak in India.
label: fake
statement: wipro prem philanthropist azim businessman chairman donated crore
explain: Explanation: Several media outlets used an old statement by Azim Premji to back their claim that Premji has donated INR 50,000 crore to fight COVID-19 outbreak in India. The same media reports were amplified by several verified Twitter handles including journalists, media personalities and politicians.

claim: Two articles claiming that iconic coffee chain Tim Hortons will close all Canada franchises on 3/30/20 because of the novel coronavirus were shared more than 150,000 times on Facebook.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: This claim is false. Though locations are closed to dining-in, drive-throughs remain open, a spokeswoman for the chain told AFP.

claim: News ticker added to an image from Sri Lankan Ada Derana TV channel gives the impression that Dr Seetha Arambepola stated there is a secret medicine for COVID-19 during a TV interview
label: fake
statement: seetha arambepola secret mention medicine covid
explain: Explanation: We contacted Dr. Seetha Arambepola and cross checked with the video interviews and image comparison and confirmed a statement she had made on a different TV interview had been misinterpreted.

claim: This is a picture of the old city in Hyderabad (India) today despite the lockdown.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The video is an old one. It was not taken during the current lockdown. Also, today’s Friday prayer at Mecca Masjid was conducted with only a few members.

claim: A photo shows an 80-truck convoy of the Italian Army moving corpses of COVID-19 patients.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The circulating image was taken in France, not Italy, and unrelated to the COVID-19 crisis.

claim: A post warning people to stay at home shows rows upon rows of coffins in “Italy.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The coffin photo was indeed taken in Italy but it has nothing to do with the COVID-19 crisis. It was of caskets for victims of a shipwreck in October 2013.

claim: A photo shows a COVID-19 vaccine that can cure a patient in three hours.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The “vaccine” featured in the photo is actually a COVID-19 testing kit developed by South Korean medical technology company Sugentech, Inc.

claim: A photo showing bodies scattered on a street is used to claim that there are no more doctors in Italy.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The image is actually an edited and cropped copy of a Reuters photo of an art installation in Germany in 2014, where people laid down on a pedestrian zone in remembrance of victims of a Nazi concentration camp.

claim: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte said all countries in the world have imposed lockdowns to counter the spread of COVID-19.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: As of 3/19/2020, only 23 countries out of 197 worldwide are on lockdown while some are implementing travel restrictions, according to several news reports.

claim: Hydroxychloroquine and chloroquine are cures for the new coronavirus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: There aren’t yet peer-reviewed clinical studies to prove either drug is effective against the symptoms of, or can protect against, the new coronavirus. You should not take either unless you’re specifically prescribed them by a doctor.

claim: Another new disease called “hantavirus” in China.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Hantavirus has infected people in different countries for many years. It's not a new virus. In the U.S., between 1993 and 2017, approximately 728 people were infected with the virus, which can be seen on the CDC website.

claim: A video of a policeman taking down a man wandering during a “lockdown in Italy.”
label: fake
statement: wielding knife brazilian alleged taking italy lockdown
explain: Explanation: The video is from Brazil and it shows police taking down an alleged knife-wielding-man in Sao Paulo on March 19.

claim: A video showing a pile of corpses in Italy.
label: fake
statement: movie thrown bodies clip dead italy
explain: Explanation: The video in the post is not real. It was a movie clip from a 2007 mini-series called "Pandemic."

claim: Mustard oil prevents a person from getting infected with COVID-19.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Neither the WHO nor the the Ministry for Health & Family Welfare (India) has announced that using mustard oil can prevent a person from getting infected with COVID-19. The Press Information Bureau (PIB) has clarified that the message is fake.

claim: Photo shows terrible conditions in Ukrainian hospitals for ordinary people.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The photo of the hospital is not new. It was taken in Horlivka in 2014.

claim: Health care workers union “suddenly finds a stash of 39 million face masks.”
label: fake
statement: unions twisted search gets face masks
explain: Explanation: The health care workers’ union launched a nationwide search on March 21 for face masks and other protective gear that have been in short supply since the COVID-19 pandemic swept across the U.S. On March 26, the union announced that it had found a supplier with 39 million masks.

claim: Viral WhatsApp message claims Netflix is giving free passes to their platform during this period of isolation.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: It is customary for a streaming service such as Netflix to give a free trial of 30 days, after which the subscriber is billed. The streaming giant, however, is not hosting any such bonanza. More so, the service is planning to actually reduce video quality owing to the internet spike in a bid to prevent downtime. It would be counterproductive to open the service to a host of more users. Also, the site in question was flagged by a security module as a “deceptive site."

claim: Pakistan’s leading scholar Mufti Naeem suffers from coronavirus. A few days ago, he refused to close madrasas and mosques.
label: fake
statement: suffers scholar refused naeem mufti madrasas leading mosques
explain: Explanation: According to Pakistani media outlets, Mufti Naeem was admitted to the hospital due to heart disease.

claim: Indian Singer Kanika Kapoor met Prince Charles, after which he tested positive for coronavirus.
label: fake
statement: kapoor kanika prince images charles covid
explain: Explanation: Contrary to the claim, the viral image is not recent but from 2015, when the singer attended the Elephant Family charity "Travels to my Elephants," hosted by Prince Charles and Camilla, Duchess of Cornwall.

claim: Italian doctor couple diagnosed with coronavirus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The couple was spotted and clicked by Associated Press (AP) photographer Emilio Morenatti nearly two weeks ago.

claim: Images of patients treated in the open are from Italy as it has run out of hospital beds.
label: fake
statement: visuals croatia earthquake passed crisis italy
explain: Explanation: The images are from Croatia after it was hit by an earthquake on March 22.

claim: While coronavirus tests in other countries are conducted for free or at nominal charges, in India, it costs Rs 4,500
label: fake
explain: Explanation: In India, coronavirus tests are free in government labs. Private labs charge more in India, as well as in other countries.

claim: A purported notice issued by the Pakistan Red Crescent and Pakistan’s Health Department on COVID-19 isolation rules has been shared thousands of times on Facebook. The advisory claims that families of those killed while in isolation will not be able to hold funerals or burials for them
label: fake
