explain: Explanation: The claim is false. The Pakistan Red Crescent denied issuing such a statement, and Pakistan’s health authority does allow funerals for those killed by the novel coronavirus.

claim: Congress included include a raise for themselves in the coronavirus stimulus package.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The $25 million claiming to be a raise actually went to policing, telecom and remote work.

claim: Tanks are coming into U.S. towns in advance for martial law
label: fake
statement: tanks rolling martial towns law advance american
explain: Explanation: Tanks were only on the move in one town in California because they were being repaired.

claim: A photo showing the bodies of Italian COVID-19 victims on a street.
label: fake
statement: street italian bodies ab aa source rss covid
explain: Explanation: The 2014 photo shows participants in an art project to remember victims of the Nazi Katzbac concentration camp in Frankfurt, Germany.

claim: Pakistani Dr. Usman Riaz speaks about coronavirus before his death.
label: fake
statement: final pak appeal uk patient doctors coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The man in the video is not Pakistani Dr. Riaz but UK resident Mubashir Ahmed, who was admitted to a hospital after testing positive for coronavirus.

claim: Purported advisories urging residents to stay indoors while national air force helicopters spray disinfectant over homes to kill off the novel coronavirus have been circulated online in Sri Lanka and the Philippines.
label: fake
statement: spray helicopters certain asia countries using covid
explain: Explanation: The claim is false. Both the Sri Lankan and Philippine governments said their air forces were not involved in such operations.

claim: Globe Telecom is giving every subscriber free mobile load worth P500 as help or donation amid the coronavirus crisis.
label: fake
statement: load globe telecom gives user response every coronavirus
explain: Explanation: In a message sent to Rappler, Globe said the free P500 load to each user is not a legitimate offer from them.

claim: The Italian Prime Minister has said his country has exhausted all options to fight against the coronavirus pandemic and pleads to God to “rescue your people.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: This quote is made up.

claim: About 500 lions have been released on the streets of Russia to stop people going out during the coronavirus pandemic.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: This is not true. The Russian government has yet to announce a widespread lockdown of any kind in Russia. The image of the lion is from South Africa in 2016.

claim: Russian President Vladimir Putin has ordered Russia’s population to stay at home for 15 days or face five years in jail.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: People in Russia arriving from high-risk areas must quarantine themselves for 14 days, and could face jail if they do not, but the general population has not yet been ordered to stay at home.

claim: Video of the current situation in Italy due to coronavirus.
label: fake
statement: exercise emergency airport senegal context covid
explain: Explanation: The video is of an Emergency Exercise at Blaise Diagne International Airport (Senegal) in November 2019. The mock drill was conducted to see if the crew can handle emergency situations at the airport.

claim: Video of Canada PM Justin Trudeau’s wife pleading for people to take COVID-19 seriously.
label: fake
statement: neither belongs pms wife surat canada
explain: Explanation: The woman in the video is not Canada Prime Minister’s wife (Sophie Grégoire Trudeau). She is Tara Jane Langston, a waitress who contracted COVID-19 and is undergoing treatment at Hillingdon Hospital in London.

claim: The Russian president, Putin, has left 800 lions outside to make people stay in their homes.
label: fake
statement: let indoors ensure stay russia putin lions coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The photo in the post has no connection to Russia. It is a photo of a movie shooting in South Africa. The claim is false.

claim: Image of the people who died of coronavirus in Italy.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The photo is not related to recent coronavirus deaths in Italy. It was taken in Frankfurt (Germany) in 2014 as part of an art project in remembrance of 528 Katzbach victims of the Nazi concentration camp.

claim: Photo of the prime minister of Italy crying and expressing his helplessness that he couldn’t save coronavirus patients in Italy.
label: fake
statement: save inability crying brazil italy coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The person in the photo is not the PM of Italy. He is Jair Bolsonaro, the President of Brazil. The photo was taken when he cried at an ‘Evangelical Thanksgiving Service’. The PM of Italy has not expressed helplessness that he couldn't save coronavirus affected patients in Italy.

claim: Photo of a vaccine developed by U.S. scientists for COVID-19.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The photo shows a COVID-19 diagnostic test kit developed by Sugentech, a South Korean based company. It is not a vaccine. As of 23 March 2020, there is no vaccine for COVID-19. Also, Trump announced the FDA’s approval of a coronavirus test, not a vaccine, developed by Roche to increase and accelerate the country’s capacity to test for the virus.

claim: Hold your breath for 10 seconds to check if you have the coronavirus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Most young COVID-19 patients will be able to hold their breath for much longer than 10 seconds, while many elderly without the virus won't be able to do it.

claim: Holding your breath for 10 seconds is a way to test for the coronavirus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Holding your breath is not a method of testing for the coronavirus.

claim: Japan has created effective medicine against COVID-19.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: This drug, developed in 2014, is being recommended by a Chinese health official after clinical tests showed that over 90 per cent of patients who were given the drug recovered. The story, however, excludes details in the original article that provide perspective.

claim: COVID-19 exposure notification from Google & Apple is a sensor inserted to trace every phone.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: COVID-19 exposure notifications is an API service jointly produced by Google and Apple and it is not a sensor nor it tracks the movements or sends out privacy data of users. Also in order for this service to be activated, a supporting app should be in place from the respective country's health officials and such an app is not available in Sri Lanka.

claim: In the Philippines, the Office of the Vice President (OVP) donated spoiled food to frontliners at Diliman Doctors Hospital in Quezon City.
label: fake
statement: spoiled ovp frontliners diliman sent doctors
explain: Explanation: The Diliman Doctors Hospital released a statement on Tuesday, June 23, denying the rumors. Vice President Leni Robredo also said the incident “never happened.”

claim: “George Floyd’s ‘murder’ filmed before COVID-19.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: George Floyd’s death wasn’t staged, and it wasn’t filmed before the coronavirus pandemic. He died on May 25 after a police officer pressed his knee against Floyd’s neck for nearly 9 minutes. Officers and bystanders can be seen wearing masks in video footage taken before Floyd’s death.

claim: Philippines Vice President Leni Robredo questioned President Rodrigo Duterte’s imposition of a curfew in Metro Manila amid the COVID-19 pandemic.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The post maliciously suggests there is disagreement between the two public officials over the imposition of a curfew. There are no official records or media stories on Robredo saying such a thing.

claim: Asian giant hornet have been killing people in several countries, in an attack worse than the COVID-19 pandemic.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Contrary to the FB posts, news reports in May never mentioned any recent human deaths resulting from the Asian giant hornet’s sting. The hornets are sometimes called “murder hornets” because they can swiftly wipe out honeybee hives by decapitating bees. In a May 14 article, National Geographic reported that a person “likely would have to be stung by a couple hundred giant hornets” for its venom to be fatal.

claim: Wearing masks for the coronavirus “decreases oxygen intake, increases toxin inhalation, shuts down immune system, increases virus risk, scientifically inaccurate, effectiveness not studied.”
label: fake
statement: tak six part effective masks covid
explain: Explanation: Studies show masks can curb spread of the novel coronavirus. Experts say the face coverings do not cause health problems.

claim: A video claims to show Philippines Sen. Grace Poe heavily criticizing Pres. Rodrigo Duterte and his administration for their “inefficient COVID-19 response” compared to that of the private sector.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: That was not what Poe said. While the senator did praise the private sector for “act[ing] immediately” in response to the crisis, she did not discredit the government’s efforts. Neither did she condemn the Duterte administration “for being unprepared” in dealing with the COVID-19 pandemic. She made no mention of the president in her statement at all.

claim: A female overseas Filipino worker (OFW) in Saudi Arabia was beheaded after testing positive for COVID-19, the disease caused by the novel coronavirus.
label: fake
statement: ofw beheaded saudi testing positive coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The news clip embedded was from a 2015 report by GMA News – way before an outbreak of the novel coronavirus was first reported in Wuhan, China in December 2019.
orginated: Websites w0rldsupdatestories.xyz and updatingnewstotheworld.xyz, and YouTube channel Aksyon Balita PH

claim: COVID-19 is a bacteria causing death due to thrombosis.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: COVID-19 is a virus and the theory is baseless and false without any proper source or credibility.

claim: Maroole Online Forum website claiming that 14 of the 25 confirmed cases of COVID-19 announced on May 7 are Oromo political prisoners.
label: fake
statement: prisoners oromo fbebdaea political fe cases covid
explain: Explanation: Ethiopian Federal Prison Commission has said no cases of COVID-19 have been confirmed among Ethiopian prisoners.

claim: The Express used a photo from before coronavirus lockdown to suggest people in Brighton were breaking social distancing rules.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: This is incorrect. Metadata from the photo shows it was taken during lockdown.

claim: We have not heard of a single police officer dying from COVID-19 across the world.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Incorrect. Many COVID-19 deaths among police officers have been reported worldwide, including at least one such death in the UK.

claim: Backriding in motorcycles is now allowed in the Philippines, where all areas are currently under some form of quarantine.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Backriding in motorcycles is still not allowed in all areas under any type of quarantine based on the guidelines released by the Philippine government.

claim: Muslims are violating the ongoing lockdown norms which prohibits religious gatherings.
label: fake
statement: prohibits ongoing gatherings religious norms violating muslims lockdown
explain: Explanation: A two month old video showing Muslims offering namaz in Delhi has been passed off on social media calling it as a recent one. The video was shot before the imposition of lockdown in the country.

claim: Overcrowded train carrying migrants from Mumbai to West Bengal, flouting lockdown norms in India.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The video is as old as 2018 and is not from India but Bangladesh.

claim: The Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) arrested billionaire Bill Gates on charges of biological terrorism after he allegedly created the novel coronavirus, the virus that causes COVID-19.
label: fake
statement: arrests creating fbi gates bill coronavirus
explain: Explanation: There is no report from any legitimate news organization about Gates’ arrest as of May 21. The photo used in the article was also manipulated using a 2014 photo of American mobster Vincent Asaro.

claim: Those who were scheduled to take the civil service exam (CSE) on March 15, 2020 in the Philippines are deemed “automatically passed” due to the COVID-19 crisis.
label: fake
statement: examinees cse pass automatically march covid coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The Philippine Civil Service Commission did not release the document. On May 13, the Commission said they did not issue any directive to automatically pass registered examinees of the March 15 professional and subprofessional CSE – even if they did not actually take the test.

claim: The implementation of the enhanced community quarantine (ECQ) in certain areas is extended until June 15, 2020.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: As of May 25, there is still no announcement by the government about the extension of quarantine measures after May 31.

claim: “Vaccines are in direct violation of The Nuremberg Code.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The Nuremberg Code addresses the treatment of human subjects in medical experiments and says nothing about the use of tested and approved vaccines on patients.

claim: The federal government of Ethiopia blocked medical equipment meant to support Tigray Regional State in responding to the coronavirus disease
label: fake
statement: tigray ethiopias blocked region supplies federal covid
explain: Explanation: The spokesperson for Tigray Regional State confirmed that they had received equipment, but that it was inadequate.

claim: Neem leaves – commonly called “Maliyirinin or Jirikunanin” in bambara – mixed with lemongrass leaves can cure COVID-19.
label: fake
statement: scientifique rir preuve mc lange guc citronnelle ny
explain: Explanation: Experts have said that there is no evidence that a mixture of neem and lemongrass can cure COVID-19.

claim: A message claimed that the Indian government plans to ease down the lockdown restrictions imposed in the country in five stages.
label: fake
statement: easing citing icmr ireland goes lockdown coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The claim was copied from Ireland government's schedule and no such plan exists as per the Indian government statements.

claim: Viral message shares the Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR) latest guidelines on COVID-19.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The message has been falsely attributed to Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR) and the institution has denied any association with the message.

claim: A video of three sloth bears has been viewed thousands of times on Facebook and Twitter alongside a claim it was captured in Sri Lanka during a curfew implemented due to the coronavirus pandemic.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The claim is false; the clip has circulated in reports about sloth bears in south India since November 2019, before the COVID-19 pandemic; a Sri Lankan wildlife activist told AFP it would be "highly unlikely" to see sloth bears in the Sri Lankan town which was cited in the misleading social media posts.

claim: Articles claim that not wearing a mask in Canada during the novel coronavirus pandemic can lead to a Can$3,000 fine or jail time.
label: fake
statement: mandatory website wearing canada mask covid
explain: Explanation: This is false. Masks are required aboard airplanes and by certain stores, but AFP did not find any Canadian jurisdiction where wearing them on the street is mandatory.

claim: Two UK police forces used the same photo to illustrate two different crimes.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: This is incorrect. The tweet from Cumbria Road Police is real, the image of a tweet from Police Scotland is fake.

claim: 5G towers weaken our immunity and expose us to Coronavirus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: There is no scientific confirmation that exposure to low-level electromagnetic fields of 5G is harmful to human health, according to WHO.

claim: 100 nurses in Rajasthan’s Jhalawar (India) resigned because of Jamaatis who misbehaved with them.
label: fake
statement: misbehaviour jhalawar resigned members tablighi jamaat nurses
explain: Explanation: It is true that the nurses had resigned but not because of Jamaatis but alleging low wages, poor working conditions and no protective equipment for the ones working with COVID-19 patients.

claim: Women of Shaheen Bagh, in Delhi, India caught red-handed carrying out a prostitution operation during the lockdown
label: fake
explain: Explanation: This is a 5 year old video from Karachi, in Pakistan, where women were seen running out a massage parlor that was raided. This is neither linked to the Shaheed Bagh incident nor to the lockdown in India.

claim: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson met reporters after recovering from COVID-19.
label: fake
statement: recovery journalists offered johnson boris revived tea covid
explain: Explanation: The video dates back to August 2018 when Boris Johnson, who was not the prime minister of UK, had offered tea to the reporters while avoiding questions about the then burqa row.

claim: “Plandemic” vignette featuring Judy Mikovits claims that coronavirus is manmade; that flu vaccine increases risk of COVID-19; that hydroxychloroquine is effective for treating COVID-19.
label: fake
statement: vignette numerous featuring mikovits judy activist unsupported vaccination
explain: Explanation: Mikovits makes numerous inaccurate and unsupported claims about the origins of the 2019 novel coronavirus, vaccines, and the treatment and prevention of COVID-19. Genomic analyses of the virus indicates it arose naturally; studies have not found that the flu vaccine increases risk of developing COVID-19; hydroxychloroquine has not demonstrated a clear benefit in COVID-19 patients

claim: The claim stated that India’s top business conglomerate Tata Group Chairman Ratan Tata said it’s not time to think of profits but to think of survival.
label: fake
statement: Ratan Tata say 2020 a year stay alive not worry losses ? Check
explain: Explanation: Ratan Tata's statement on Twitter said that he has not said that.

claim: Indian Government has started a scheme called the Rashtriya Sikhshit Berojgar Yojna, to help those who are educated and unemployed during the lockdown.
label: fake
statement: yojna sikhshit rashtriya phishing berozgaar scam scheme govt
explain: Explanation: This was a fake website created in February 2020, no such exercise or website has been announced by the government.

claim: An image has been shared thousands of times in multiple posts on Twitter and Facebook which claim it shows overgrown shrubs at a theme park in Malaysia during a coronavirus lockdown.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The claim is false; the image shows an abandoned theme park in Japan; it has circulated online since at least May 2019.

claim: A factory worker of Wibs Bread in Mumbai was found affected with coronavirus and buyers are advised to avoid the bread
label: fake
statement: wibs bread worker shut tests positive
explain: Explanation: A distributor said that one of the four factories was sealed to sanitize but upon testing, the results of the worker came negative.

claim: The U.S. are conducting experiments on Georgian people. Remdesivir (experimental drug to cure COVID-19) is produced by Gilead, the same company which supplied Georgia with Sovaldi, a dangerous drug whih is used in Hepatitis C patients.
label: fake
statement: vital sovaldi medications considered lugar listed among dangerous
explain: Explanation: Sovaldi has been registered in Russia since 2016 and is listed amond vital medications.

claim: A ginger, garlic, lime and paracetamol concoction cures coronavirus.
label: fake
statement: lime concoction paracetamol cures ginger garlic coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The World Health Organization has said there are currently no drugs licensed for the treatment or prevention of COVID-19.

claim: China has suddenly dismantled its USD Peg on stock exchanges over imminent launch of sovereign digital currency amid COVID-19.
label: fake
statement: transactions peg exchange dollar canceled stock china
explain: Explanation: No notification or news of the move has been made, and Chinese officials have indicated a continuation of the peg for the near future.

claim: Professor Dr Tasuku Honjo, caused a sensation today in the media by saying that the coronavirus is not natural.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Incorrect. Professor Honjo has denied saying this and there is no evidence that he ever did.

claim: Dried ginger powder can cure COVID-19.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: According to WHO no drugs have yet been certified to treat the coronavirus. COVID-19 can be prevented through frequent hand wash.

claim: Walmart, Amazon, Kroger, Target and Costco stores — while staying open during the COVID-19 pandemic — “have not had any reported cases” of employees contracting the coronavirus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: There have been news reports across the U.S. of workers at those companies becoming infected or dying of the disease.

claim: A Filipino scientist has produced a vaccine for COVID-19.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The Philippines' Department of Health said that as of 4/28/2020 the group behind the Fabunan vaccine has not applied for registration with the Food and Drug Administration, so the vaccine cannot be used.

claim: A report circulating in Sri Lanka claims that a COVID-19 vaccine trial at the University of Oxford in England has been “successful”. The purported news article, which has been shared repeatedly on Facebook, states 72 out of 100 COVID-19 patients recovered from the virus after receiving the vaccine.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The claim is false; as of May 4, 2020, researchers said the trial was ongoing and only included people who have never tested positive for COVID-19; the purported report was published on a blog site named "CNN Lanka", which has no relationship to the US-based media channel CNN.

claim: Bollywood actor Aamir Khan is helping the needy during the COVID-19 crisis by sending flour bags with cash in them.
label: fake
statement: putting wheat clarified aamir bags khan
explain: Explanation: Aamir Khan has clarified that he is not the person who is putting money in the wheat bags. He said that the story is either fake or some person who does not want to get revealed might be doing such donations.

claim: The photo of lions in Srisailam forest, in India, during the time of lockdown in the country to contain COVID-19 spread.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The photo doesn't have any relation to Srisailam. It was taken from a 2016 video which was shot in Crooger park in South Africa. The photo doesn't have any relation to lockdown in India.

claim: A video shows the arrest of the “man behind COVID-19,” a Harvard professor who authorities found manufactured and sold the novel coronavirus to China.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The report is not about the arrest that day of “the man behind COVID-19” but of Charles Lieber, the university’s Chemistry and Chemical Biology department head, for allegedly concealing his research engagements with China from federal investigators. The nearly two-minute-long segment used in the post makes no mention of COVID-19.

claim: A tweet from Donald Trump in 2009 said that he would ‘never let thousands of Americans die from a pandemic’.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The tweet from Donald Trump is fake. He never tweeted this.

claim: Aspirin dissolved in lemon juice boiled with honey can be a home remedy for the coronavirus.
label: fake
statement: aspirin juice honey cures lemon coronavirus
explain: Explanation: There are no specific vaccines, medicines, or treatments for COVID-19, according to the World Health Organization (WHO). Reyes and the MMC denied releasing the message.

claim: Photo of Kurnool MLA (Hafeez Khan) making a nurse to touch the feet of a religious head in Viswabharathi Medical College, who had to come to the COVID-19 quarantine facility.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The nurse was not forced to touch the feet of a religious head. She is treating the Muslim old man whose leg is injured. Blood on the Muslim man's leg can be seen in a video shot during that time.

claim: COVID-19 patients in Gujarat are being segregated on the basis of religion at Ahmedabad Civil Hospital.
label: fake
statement: segregated religion civil basis ahmedabad gujarat covid
explain: Explanation: On the basis of the statement of Dr. Rathod of Ahmedabad Civil Hospital and a clear denial of several government bodies, we reached the conclusion that the two outlets mentioned above, published a ‘False’ report which was later amplified by several verified Twitter handles.

claim: Photo of people following social distancing in a market in Manipur (India).
label: fake
statement: market kalaw manipur mizoram myanmar distancing
explain: Explanation: The photo claiming to be that of people following social distancing in a market in Manipur (India) was actually captured at the Kalaw market in the Shan state of Myanmar.

claim: Germany has sent China a bill of £130 billion for damages caused to the economy due to coronavirus.
label: fake
statement: damages billion germany bill china coronavirus
explain: Explanation: A German newspaper drew up a mock bill after assessing damages caused by COVID-19 in Germany. The German government has not sent the bill.

claim: The photo of a vaccine for canine coronavirus proves that a vaccine exists for the novel coronavirus that causes COVID-19.
label: fake
statement: vaccine proves exists canine causes coronavirus covid
explain: Explanation: The photo shows a vaccine for the canine coronavirus, which is not the same virus affecting humans around the world.

claim: Trump claims Speaker Nancy Pelosi deleted a tweet about her visit to Chinatown in February
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Trump repeatedly exaggerates and invents facts about her trip, including that she deleted a tweet (that she never posted)

claim: Image of a critically ill COVID-19 infected woman hugging her child for the last time before her death.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The image is an old incident and not related to any recent incident. It was found to exist on the internet at least since 1997.

claim: Image of a Muslim boy, Rizwan, who had died after being beaten up by Tanda (UP) Police for violating the lockdown restrictions mandated due to COVID-19 spread.
label: fake
statement: rizwan liver clarifies ambedkarnagar heart infection died
explain: Explanation: Ambedkarnagar district Police clarified that, in their investigation, they have found that Rizwan was not beaten by the Police. Also, the Police has said that, in the postmortem report, it was mentioned that the deceased had an infection in lungs & heart and injuries due to falling from a motorcycle, which was confirmed by a local doctor.

claim: It was claimed that the BCG vaccine, given to all Indians mandatorily after birth, makes them immune to coronavirus.
label: fake
statement: withstanding capable bcg infection vaccine coronavirus
explain: Explanation: WHO said that there is no evidence that the BCG protects people from the coronavirus infection and tests are underway.

claim: An image of people sleeping in a lobby is being shared with a claim that this image is from Gujarat where the lockdown is not being followed.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: After closely studying the claim that has gone viral on social media platforms, we found that the picture of workers sleeping in the lobby is being shared with misleading claims. Our investigation revealed that the old picture of Malaysia is being shared as Gujarat.

claim: Following the coronavirus pandemic, film star Salman Khan has given 200 ambulances to the India.
label: fake
statement: star salman film ambulances following given khan coronavirus
explain: Explanation: Searching through several tools, it was found that Salman Khan's Foundation has donated just one ambulance. The claim of Salman Khan giving 200 ambulances in the fight against Corona is misleading.

claim: Kenya’s 2022 general elections have been postponed by five years until 2027, and the government will use the election budget to fight coronavirus.
label: fake
statement: adversely kenyas postponed affected elections election general coronavirus
explain: Explanation: Kenya’s Independent Electoral and Boundaries Commission has not made any announcement about the 2022 election. But local by-elections to be held in 2020 have been postponed because of the coronavirus pandemic.

claim: Migrant family walking from Surat due to the lockdown committed suicide due to starvation.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The incident is from 2018 in Wardha, Nagpur where a family committed suicide due to financial problems and is not linked to coronavirus

claim: Hindus were not allowed to receive food being distributed in a mosque in India during the lockdown.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The incident is from Bangladesh where Hindus were not allowed to collect food from the mosque and is not from India

claim: Says Wisconsin’s in-person election has caused a “surge” in new coronavirus cases
label: fake
statement: surge yet proof election cases coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The claimed surge in cases was based on poor data work. The upward “trend” treated a dip in new cases due to lower testing as a baseline, rather than the outlier it was.

claim: A video shared thousands of times on Facebook, Twitter and Instagram purports to show hundreds of Nigerians scrambling for food amid a lockdown prompted by the novel coronavirus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The footage has been circulating on social media since at least March 2019, months before the start of the pandemic.

claim: A man was beaten by the cops in Dehradun, India after he violated the lockdown norms and came out to spit on people’s doors and handles.
label: fake
statement: dehradun given violating communal spin lockdown coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The man, seen in the video, was beaten up by the cops because he violated the lockdown norms. However the police denied any communal angle and said that the video is being shared with a false claim.

claim: Delhi Health Minister Satyendar Jain said that not a single one of the 30 thousand in Markaz was found coronavirus positive.
label: fake
statement: satyendra none misquoted jain markaz minister delhi positive
explain: Explanation: The claim shared with the post is false. The post misquotes him and has clipped a part of a larger video.

claim: The image is from Gujarat and shows the condition of migrant workers who are stuck due to the lockdown.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The image is being circulated with a misleading claim. It does not show the plight of migrant workers or homeless people in Gujarat but shows Bangladeshi refugees in Malaysia waiting to go back home.

claim: An American CEO drew the Indian map comparing the population of Indian states to those of countries across the world highlighting India’s brilliant response to tackle COVID-19.
label: fake
statement: govts draw ceo praise map american response covid
explain: Explanation: This particular map has been floating on social media since 2016 and is only comparing India's population. This is not linked to the coronavirus and does not mention any American CEO.

claim: An image showcaseing “Lotus Tower” claiming it was visible in Kurunegala night sky on 11th of April.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Original Kurunegala night sky image was captured and published in 2017. Photograph of the illuminated "Lotus Tower" from 11th of April inserted to the old image to interpret that the tower illuminated in honor of COVID-19 frontline workers was visible to Kurunegala

claim: Image of tired healthcare workers resting on the floor of a hospital corridor, claimed to be from IDH Hospital in Sri Lanka.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The original photograph is from Malaysia.

claim: Muslims are hoarding food items being shared by the Indian government.
label: fake
statement: shelter meerut leprosy twist communal peddled
explain: Explanation: The video is originally from a leprosy clinic where the clinic was storing food to be distributed on April 10.

claim: After the African Union expressed concerns about discrimination against Africans in Guangzhou, a video started circulating on Facebook and Twitter that purports to show a Kenyan couple involved in a fist fight with a Chinese couple in Wuhan.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: This claim is false: The video was in fact filmed in the Bronx district of New York in front of an Asian restaurant.

claim: In the Philippines, Pasig City Mayor Vico Sotto supposedly said in a Facebook live video that voters should elect public officials who don’t curse at God, lie, rape and kill people, and steal.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Sotto did not say what was attributed to him supposedly in his Facebook live video on April 12. The graphic is a manipulated version of one posted by Inquirer.net on April 13.

claim: A video showing rows of black body bags sprawled on the floor was taken from East Avenue Medical Center (EAMC).
label: fake
explain: Explanation: EAMC refuted the claim that the video was taken from there. The original clip was from Ecuador.

claim: A woman in Uttar Pradesh threw her five children into the river as they had no food to eat during the current lockdown.
label: fake
statement: river reason husband hunger five throwing behind
explain: Explanation: While it is true that a woman in Uttar Pradesh had thrown her five children into the river, it is not due to the unavailability of food. The Bhadohi Police has clarified that the woman took such a drastic step after she quarrelled with her husband, not because of hunger.

claim: A woman in Uttar Pradesh threw her five children into the river as they had no food to eat during the current lockdown.
label: fake
statement: river reason husband hunger five throwing behind
explain: Explanation: While it is true that a woman in Uttar Pradesh had thrown her five children into the river, it is not due to the unavailability of food. The Bhadohi Police has clarified that the woman took such a drastic step after she quarrelled with her husband, not because of hunger.

claim: Photo of Muslims offering prayers on the rooftops in India.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The photo is not taken in India. The buildings in the photo are located in Dubai.

claim: Photo of Muslims offering prayers on the rooftops in India.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The photo is not taken in India. The buildings in the photo are located in Dubai.

claim: Many media outlets, through unnamed sources, published reports that Indian Railways has announced a new set of rules and guidelines for traveling after the lockdown ends.
label: fake
statement: unnamed traveling sources railways ends outlets published guidelines
explain: Explanation: Indian Railway has denied this stating that Ministry of Railways has not issued any protocol regarding passenger travel during post lockdown period, as has been incorrectly reported in some media reports. As and when a decision is taken, all stakeholders would be intimated. Please do not be guided by any misleading report.

claim: Photograph of a rail track from Colombo filled with wild-flowers during current curfew period in Sri Lanka.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Stock image of wild flowers from a Texas rail track interpreted as scenes from a Sri Lankan rail track during curfew period.

claim: A man in Italy commits suicide after losing his family to coronavirus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Video is from 2015 when a man jumped off a building in Philadelphia and is not linked to coronavirus.

claim: Muslim women are misbehaving with doctors in India.
label: fake
statement: sukkur sindh qaurantine staff attack centre pakistan
explain: Explanation: The video is actually from Pakistan, and the location in the video is the Sukkur quarantine facility in the country.

claim: A Muslim man was beaten up because he was infecting fruits with his saliva.
label: fake
statement: spit injected bawana fruits claimed delhi coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The video is from Delhi’s Bawana and the claim with which it is being shared is false. ACP Bawana told The Quint that the incident took place on 4 April and the man in the video, Dilshad alias Mehboob Ali was beaten up after he came back from Bhopal post attending a jamaat.

claim: Indian Industrialist Ratan Tata says that the country’s economy will bounce back after coronavirus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The quote was falsely attributed to Ratan Tata. The industrialist took to Twitter and Instagram to clarify that he has “never said, nor written this.”

claim: Video of the Kenya Government using a Maasai tribe man to impose social distancing in Kenya.
label: fake
statement: tribe maasai imposing men kenyan using distancing
explain: Explanation: The video is made by an ‘Entertainment’ based YouTube channel ‘Mbuzi Seller’. It doesn’t show a real-life incident. Also, there are no reports about the Kenyan government roping in Maasai tribe men to carry out stricter actions in the wake of coronavirus infections in the country.

claim: As Kalonji (Nigella) seeds have 100 per cent of Hydroxychloroquine, taking them can prevent COVID-19.
label: fake
statement: enough either kalonji seeds scientific yet prove hydroxychloroquine
explain: Explanation: Kalonji seeds do not have 100 per cent of Hydroxychloroquine. Also, there is no scientific evidence yet to prove that either Kalonji seeds or Hydroxychloroquine can prevent COVID-19.

claim: Boy washing apples in a sewer claimed to be from India and is linked to the coronavirus
label: fake
statement: sewer apples washing boy revived pakistan
explain: Explanation: The video is not from India but is an old video from Pakistan.

claim: A photograph has been shared hundreds of times in Facebook, Twitter and Instagram posts with claims that it shows Nigerian movie star Funke Akindele Bello picking up waste in the street as a punishment for throwing a party during the COVID-19 lockdown.
label: fake
statement: utay thats srmyppdcrcyg_nhwk oj moi lg jqephu cjn
explain: Explanation: The photo was first published online long before the pandemic and shows a waste management officer.

claim: All social media group admins are requested to close their groups for two days.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: There is no order of legal action to be taken against group admins if they don't close their groups for two days. There is no such restriction on citizens to share any news or updates about the coronavirus situation, as long as it is not false information.

claim: A video shows a man spitting into a bottle of tea and placing it back on a supermarket rack in an attempt to spread the coronavirus infection.
label: fake
statement: teen bottle texas spitting tea coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The video is old and unrelated; it dates backs to July 2019 from Texas.

claim: Family starving for food commits suicide in India during lockdown.
label: fake
statement: commit starving heres mother truth three suicide lockdown
explain: Explanation: The tragic incident occurred on June 2019 as a result of an alcoholic husband in Karnataka, India.

claim: Queen Elizabeth is shown in a quote card to be praising President Rodrigo Duterte for the Philippines government’s efforts amid the COVID-19 pandemic in a recent speech.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: This is fake. The Queen's address was primarily one of gratitude and appreciation for the efforts of Britain's frontliners and other essential workers in the country's fight against the pandemic. She also said Britain joins all nations in a common endeavor to meet the health challenge, but made no mention of any country or leader.

claim: Senasa or the Costa Rican Public Force will sacrifice cats due to the COVID-19 pandemic.
label: fake
statement: senasa sacrifice cats rican public force costa covid
explain: Explanation: According to the World Organization for Animal Health (OIE) and the World Health Organization (WHO), there is no evidence to suggest that pets are a source of COVID-19 infection.

claim: Various graphics in the form of quote cards show personalities praising President of the Philippines Rodrigo Duterte for his administration’s response to the coronavirus outbreak. The quotes in some of these graphics also denounce Duterte’s critics.
label: fake
statement: personalities quotes praising response duterte coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The quotes in these graphics are made up. Some of the graphics in this category may have been meant to be a parody.

claim: Smoking cannabis can prevent COVID-19.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The WHO recommends five main protective measures against the disease, and smoking cannabis actually puts individuals at more risk, not less. According to the video, non-smokers are more vulnerable to COVID-19 than regular smokers of cannabis, and the abundance of the drug in Jamaica is apparently the reason why there have been no confirmed cases of COVID-19 in the country.

claim: WhatsApp group admins will be arrested if anyone shares any joke/information about the coronavirus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The message quotes the Disaster Management Act to say that action will be taken. But the sections it mentions say nothing about disseminating information. The message is alarmist in nature and creating panic.

claim: A man in Italy killed himself after he lost his family to the coronavirus.
label: fake
statement: kin losing self killed italy covid
explain: Explanation: The video is being shared with a completely false claim. Firstly, the video is as old as 2015, which is long before the outbreak of the novel coronavirus. Secondly, the video is not from Italy but Philadelphia in the USA.

claim: Queen Elizabeth said Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte “is the kind of leader who knows the way … Filipinos are very lucky to have him.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Queen Elizabeth delivered a speech addressing the coronavirus on April 5, but she didn't mention President Rodrigo Duterte.

claim: The message claimed that under the Disaster Management Act (DMA), nobody except the Indian government can update and post coronavirus related information on social media.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: No such rules exist. The Indian government issued a clarification.

claim: A video that shows dead bodies being taken away in a convoy of cars is from a hospital in Iran.
label: fake
statement: convoy iran cars away bodies dead
explain: Explanation: The viral video doing rounds on social media claiming that this is a scene outside a hospital in Iran due to the novel coronavirus is false. The viral video is of a funeral procession for pilgrims who died during Hajj in 2019.

claim: A video is being shared on various social media platforms and in WhatsApp groups in which a person allegedly infected with COVID-19 can be seen lying unconscious on the ground and shaking violently.
label: fake
statement: violently unconscious shaking platforms various ground allegedly groups
explain: Explanation: According to the testimony of a doctor working in the hospital, the person shown in the video is not infected with COVID-19 but having an epilepsy attack. It can be concluded that the video is being shared with a misleading claim.

claim: Muslim youth is spreading COVID-19 by licking plates in Nizamuddin Markaz in India.
label: fake
statement: plates nizamuddin markaz licking youth spreading muslim covid
explain: Explanation: The video is 2 years old and the people in it belong to Dawoodi Bohra society. In their tradition, dishes are washed only after eating and licking the utensils. This is done so that no food grains are wasted.

claim: “WORLD HEALTH ORGANISATION PROTOCOL & PROCEDURE OF LOCKDOWN PERIODS FOR CONTROLLING ON MOST DANGEROUS VIRUS: STEP 1-1 DAY. STEP 2-21 DAYS. AFTER 5 DAYS. STEP 3-28 DAYS. AFTER 5 DAYS. STEP 4-15 DAYS.”
label: fake
statement: step days procedure periods organisation controlling protocol dangerous
explain: Explanation: Nowhere has the WHO spoken of the process of phased lockdown to fight the coronavirus.

claim: Burning candles will increase the temperature which in turn will kill coronavirus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: First, it is not possible to gauge the rise in temperature because of lighting candles until we know the candles’ dimensions. Second, there is no evidence that heat can kill coronavirus.

claim: A video of a Muslim fruit-vendor spitting on fruits to spread coronavirus.
label: fake
statement: vendor saliva fruits fruit applying trying muslim coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The video was shot in February 2020 by a man in Raisen district in the state of Madhya Pradesh (MP), but the first coronavirus case in Madhya Pradesh was detected on 20 March. The posted video was taken much earlier than the first coronavirus case in the state.

claim: Photo of a migrant worker’s family who committed suicide on their walk to Uttar Pradesh from Surat (Gujarat, India) due to lack of facilities during the current lockdown.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The image is an old one. It is not related to any incident during the current lockdown. A per an article of 'Nagpur Today', the image is of an incident that took place in 2018.

claim: An article shared thousands of times in multiple social media posts in Nigeria claims former vice president Atiku Abubakar pledged to pay 10,000 naira ($27) to every Nigerian to help them through the novel coronavirus pandemic.
label: fake
statement: promise nigerias vice ex stay pay citizens virus
explain: Explanation: The claim is false; Abubakar's spokesman rejected it as "fake news" and the story originated from a website with a history of spreading misinformation.

claim: The government raided The Medical City and other private hospitals, taking away their personal protective equipment (PPE).
label: fake
statement: raided private ppe donations city hospitals
explain: Explanation: The Medical City, Pasig City police, and the Office of Civil Defense all denied the claim.

claim: Indian actor Shah Rukh Khan donated money to Pakistan to fight coronavirus and did not help India at all.
label: fake
statement: rukh cropped debunking donating shah revived khan pakistan
explain: Explanation: Old video of Indian news channel India Today debunking claims that about Shah Rukh Khan donating funds to Pakistan in 2017 is shared with a false narrative.

claim: Beware of food delivery apps in India as they blow into the food before packaging it.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: It is a 2019 video from another South East Asian country and not India.

claim: An Indian social activist was arrested when she tried to buy liquor during the lockdown period.
label: fake
statement: twist detained desai trupti dated revived lockdown
explain: Explanation: An older video of the said social activist was shared with a false narrative.

claim: The are no COVID-19 deaths in Israel as they found a cure for COVID-19, a mixture of lemon and baking soda.
label: fake
statement: mixture soda baking sars lemon cov kill evidence
explain: Explanation: As of 20 April 2020, Israel reported 171 deaths due to COVID-19. Also, there is no scientific evidence to suggest that the mixture of lemon and baking soda can kill SARS-CoV-2 virus. As of today, there is no mixture/medicine to prevent or cure COVID-19.

claim: McDonald’s is reopening in the UK from Monday 6 April.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Incorrect. McDonald’s has said its restaurants in the UK will remain closed.

claim: The new Nightingale Hospital in London wants people to post it home-made art to brighten up the walls.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: This is not true. The “Rainbows for Nightingale” appeal was not an official one. The hospital has confirmed this.

claim: Italians threw away their currency on the streets due to COVID-19 deaths.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The images are from Venezuela where vandals robbed a bank and threw the demonetized money on the streets.

claim: Muslims are licking their plates to spread coronavirus and infect more people with the virus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The video is from three years ago depicting a Dawoodi Bohra practice of licking the plate clean so as to prevent any food from being wasted before washing and is not linked to the coronavirus outbreak.

claim: A video purportedly showing COVID-19 victims in body bags strewn across the floor of a New York hospital was shared several thousand times in multiple languages on social media.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The claim is false. The key footage was shot in Ecuador, not Manhattan, and a U.S. healthcare spokeswoman said the allegations amounted to “abhorrent misinformation.”

claim: No deaths have been reported in Israel due to COVID-19 because they have found a cure for the disease. A solution of hot water, baking soda and lemon is the cure for COVID-19.
label: fake
statement: solution soda baking cannot lemon cure covid
explain: Explanation: As of 3/31/20, there have been 15 deaths in Israel due to COVID-19. The solution of lemon, hot water and bicarbonate is not proven to cure COVID-19.

claim: The army is patrolling all the streets, towns and villages in Ireland.
label: fake
statement: villages towns patrolling ireland army streets
explain: Explanation: New and unprecedented measures have been introduced to help curb the spread of the coronavirus, but the post falsely describes those rules actually are. Police are patrolling parts of the country, but not all of it, and there are no plans at present for the army to patrol the streets.

claim: Former MP Bimal Rathnayake made a comment stating that deceased Muslims from COVID-19 should be buried as per their customs and not cremated.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Manipulated image gives the impression that MP Bimal Rathnayaka made a comment stating that deceased Muslims from COVID-19 should be buried as per their customs and not cremated.

claim: Italians throwing money on streets amid COVID-19 crisis.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: This is an incident when a bank was looted in the Venezuelan city of Mérida and old money notes had been scattered on the streets.

claim: Image with the narration to claim that a huge number of Muslims were roaming in Beruwala City in Sri Lanka during curfew, risking the lives of many amid COVID-19
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The image was from a large Muslim procession held in March 2019.

claim: Ministry of Home Affairs in India has directed people to not post anything related to coronavirus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The message has been undersigned by the Principal Secretary to the Home Minister but in reality there is no such post by a person in the ministry.

claim: Inhalation of hot steam can kill the novel coronavirus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Inhalation of steam from hot water does not kill COVID-19.

claim: The Indian Army has been called to control seven areas in Mumbai that are not following the 21 day lockdown and are out of the Mumbai police’s control.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The Mumbai police have not called in the army and the seven areas are following the lockdown prescribed by the government.

claim: The Indian Home Ministry considers posting anything about coronavirus a punishable offence.
label: fake
statement: punishable offence sharing messages ministry coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The message was attributed to a non-existent Home Ministry official and the ministry has not passed any circular stating that any message about coronavirus should not be shared.

claim: Video of Muslims applying their saliva to plates and spoons to spread the coronavirus disease.
label: fake
statement: spoons saliva plates applying spreading muslims coronavirus
explain: Explanation: The first coronavirus case in the world was registered in December 2019. But the video is found to exist on social media at least since July 2018.

claim: When you complete a registration for a 5,000 Baht support fund, it will show you a green sign, not a blue sign.
label: fake
statement: sign registration green complete blue baht fund
explain: Explanation: The correct sign is blue.

claim: Says COVID-19 remains in the air for eight hours and that everyone is now required to wear masks “everywhere.”
label: fake
explain: Explanation: There are different definitions of what is considered “airborne,” and while COVID-19 is spread through the air via droplets, it isn’t believed to be as transmissible as typical airborne illnesses, such as measles. There is no evidence that the virus stays in the air for eight hours and there is no requirement for “everyone” to wear masks everywhere.

claim: Viral post along with a pictures claims civilian thrashing a policeman during lockdown.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The viral photos are three years old and have nothing to do with the coronavirus lockdown.

claim: CDC recommends that people shave their facial hair to prevent coronavirus.
label: fake
statement: shaving recommended facial hair body coronavirus
explain: Explanation: No such recommendations have been made by the CDC so far.

claim: Inhaling the steam of sea salt and orange peelings can prevent coronavirus infection.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: There is no scientific proof of the claim; the WHO does not mention this remedy.

claim: A front page article by the Southern Times cautioning against travel to Kenya because of the growing number of cases in Kenya.
label: fake
statement: cautioning bbb front bc travel page newspaper kenya
explain: Explanation: The Southern Times published a post denouncing the front page, and the image appears to be a doctored version of a previous edition of the paper.

claim: Italian PM said that the country has surrendered to the COVID-19 pandemic
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The quote attributed to the Italian PM is fabricated.

claim: Inhaling the steam from boiled water with dissolved salt is an effective cure for COVID-19, the disease caused by the novel coronavirus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: There is still no cure approved to treat the novel coronavirus, but there are treatments approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration that may help ease the symptoms. Inhaling salt water steam is not among them.

claim: Video of mass grave claiming to be Italy.
label: fake
statement: graveyards shown movie mass scene italy
explain: Explanation: This is from the movie "Pandemic."

claim: Houseflies can transmit the COVID-19 virus.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: WHO has already debunked the myth and clarified that there is no evidence to suggest that the COVID-19 virus is transmitted through houseflies. Also, it has clarified that the virus may be present in feces in some cases but, to date, there have been no reports of faecal-oral transmission of COVID-19.

claim: Going near a fire or stove after applying hand sanitizers, causes more fire as it contains alcohol.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Any genuine hand sanitizer applied on your hands will not cause any fire as it evaporates within seconds.

claim: A WhatsApp forward attributed to CNN claims Dr. Li Wenliang, the whistleblower of the Chinese government’s propaganda about COVID-19, has documented a research report. According to this report, chemicals like Methylxanthine, Theobromine and Theophylline stimulate compounds that can ward off this virus in a human body with at least an average performing immune system.
label: fake
statement: theophylline theobromine stimulate methylxanthine documented average whistleblower immune
explain: Explanation: The WHO has mentioned that to date, there is no vaccine or treatment to prevent or cure COVID-19. Also, the Chinese doctor Li Wenliang did not mention any medication or vaccination to cure COVID-19 in his findings.

claim: Prince Charles tested positive for COVID-19 after meeting Bollywood singer Kanika Kapoor.
label: fake
statement: singer bollywood kapoor kanika meeting prince charles tested
explain: Explanation: The viral picture is old and was taken in 2015 during a charity event by UK royalty Prince Charles and Camilla. The viral claim is misleading.

claim: Finally India got its coronavirus Dashboard. This is the official website for coronavirus updates. This website is updated every four hours. Scroll down for more details; you can know more about coronavirus outbreak in your state by placing your finger on your state on the map.
label: fake
statement: website updated scroll placing know details dashboard got
explain: Explanation: The website is not official and the tweet by a Bollywood superstar is misleading.

claim: Indian Government has issued a guideline to monitor citizens’ activity; their call and social media handles will be under surveillance.
label: fake
statement: surveillance monitor handles activity guideline call citizens issued
explain: Explanation: A Twitter user shared the same claim on November 24, 2017. The viral forward is fake and the Indian government has not issued any guidelines to monitor the activities of its citizens on various social media and messaging platforms.

claim: Should you take Ibuprofen to treat a fever from the coronavirus?
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The WHO does not recommend against the use of Ibuprofen based on a lack of medical reports showing any negative effects. There is no published clinical or population-based data on this topic.

claim: Photo of Kanika Kapoor meeting Prince Charles during her recent visit to the United Kingdom. Prince Charles tested positive for coronavirus just after the meeting.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The photo was taken in 2015 when singer Kanika Kapoor attended the Elephant family charity, "Travels to my Elephant," hosted by Prince Charles and Camilla, Duchess of Cornwall.

claim: Photo of a vaccine developed by U.S. scientists for COVID-19.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The photo shows a COVID-19 diagnostic test kit developed by Sugentech, a South Korean based company. It is not a vaccine. As of 3/23/20, there is no vaccine for COVID-19. Also, President Trump announced the FDA’s approval of a coronavirus test, not a vaccine, developed by the Roche company to increase and accelerate the country’s capacity to test for the virus.

claim: Compounds in tea can help cure COVID-19.
label: fake
statement: compounds found tea ab aa source rss cure
explain: Explanation: Methylxanthine, theobromine and theophylline, which are found in tea, are good for health and airway management, but cannot cure COVID-19.

claim: A picture showing dead Italian doctors in an operating theater after succumbing to COVID-19.
label: fake
statement: succumbed ea db italian ab aa source doctors
explain: Explanation: The picture showing doctors on the floor of an operating room is actually from an episode of "Grey's Anatomy."

claim: Nairobi Governor Mike Sonko has donated 58 million shillings for COVID-19 response.
label: fake
statement: shillings sonko bb donated governor mike million ab
explain: Explanation: The governor has not made any such donation, and the County Government has also stated that the claim is false.

claim: Eating alkaline foods of pH level above 8.5 can kill the SARS-CoV-2 virus.
label: fake
statement: suggesting foods alkaline sars cov kill virus
explain: Explanation: The research paper published in 1991 talks about the MHV4 virus, not about the SARS-CoV-2 virus. Some of the pH levels given in the post are not correct. Also, there is no scientific evidence to prove that eating alkaline foods can kill the SARS-CoV-2 virus.

claim: Facebook user Chase Michael Morris predicted coronavirus pandemic.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The Facebook post was edited.

claim: Gargling with hot water cures coronavirus, says a doctor from Mumbai’s COVID-19 hospital.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: Gargling with water does not cure or prevent coronavirus, and this is not the doctor from the Mumbai hospital but a Tik Tok video with a pre-recorded video clip.

claim: A police commissioner from Mumbai has asked essential services to be available at certain hours.
label: fake
statement: timings sold rubbishes items essential mumbai
explain: Explanation: The Mumbai Police did not put out any such notification and all essential services are available in the city.

claim: Iranian girl Anahita Hashemzadeh has contracted the coronavirus.
label: fake
statement: iranian hashemzadeh anahita girl contracted hasnt coronavirus
explain: Explanation: Anahita Hashemzadeh hasn’t contracted the coronavirus. In the comments section of her Instagram videos, her mother has clarified multiple times that she is "safe and healthy" and the news regarding Anahita getting infected with coronavirus is fake.

claim: Photos of Italian man committing suicide after he lost his entire family to COVID-19.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The video was taken in Spain and is found to be in circulation on the internet at least since the last week of December 2019. The first COVID-19 death was reported only in the second week of January 2019 in China.

claim: Photo of the prime minister of Italy crying and expressing his helplessness that he couldn’t save coronavirus patients in Italy.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The person in the photo is not the prime minister of Italy. He is Jair Bolsonaro, the president of Brazil. The photo was taken when he cried at an Evangelical Thanksgiving Service. The PM of Italy has not expressed helplessness that he couldn't save coronavirus infected patients in Italy.

claim: Video of Italian police taking down a man who has come onto the streets despite a lockdown in the country.
label: fake
statement: wielding knife brazilian alleged taking italy lockdown
explain: Explanation: The video is from Brazil and shows police taking down an alleged knife-wielding man in Sao Paulo on 3/19/20.

claim: Kerala has asked NABARD for a loan of Rs 20,000 crore to deal with COVID-19.
label: fake
statement: rs crore nabard loan kerala asked
explain: Explanation: While it is true that the Kerala Government has announced a financial package of Rs. 20,000 crore to fight the pandemic, they have not asked NABARD for a loan of Rs 20,000 crore. They have requested for a special line of credit of Rs 2000 crore from NABARD under RIDF.

claim: The flu didn’t kill any Americans this year.
label: fake
explain: Explanation: The post is wrong. While COVID-19 has made assessing flu fatalities more complicated, thousands of Americans have died from influenza during the pandemic.

claim: Social media posts shared tens of thousands of times claim White House adviser Dr. Anthony Fauci stands alone in insisting hydroxychloroquine’s effectiveness against COVID-19 is unproven, while Italy, France, Spain and Brazil say it “works.”
label: fake
statement: unproven alone saying fauci hydroxychloroquine covid
explain: Explanation: This is false; health authorities in these countries say data on this treatment is “preliminary” and “not yet conclusive.”
